abstract: Maskings and mummings have been the order of the day, or, rather, of the night until the day, for some weeks past, in the social circles of our City, and the Germans have, as usual, in the carnival time, had their goodly share of the fun. The splendid masques of the "Liederkranz" and the "Arion" are still fresh in the memory of the fair and gay, and the past week has been marked by the Artillery and Hussar Balls given by the Vaterland soldiers in our midst. Many of these entertainments have been elegant and agreeable, but for real genuine, old-fashioned German gemuethlichkeit, or good-humored jollity, none of them compared with the masked ball given by the "Germania" Sing Verein, at the Metropolitan Rooms in Hester-street, on Tuesday evening last.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, the bill authorizing attorneys residing in other States to practice in the Courts of this State was passed. Notice was given of a bill to regulate the Fire Department of this City. The bill to afford aid to the Albany and Susquehannah Railroad was passed; as were also the Kings County Court-house bill, and the bill to amend the act concerning the rights and liabilities of husbands and wives.

abstract: Observations from Kansas; Excerpts from Min. Lord Lyons official dispatches on war from attack on Fort Sumter to date
snippet: Observations from Kansas; Excerpts from Min. Lord Lyons official dispatches on war from attack on Fort Sumter to date
lead_paragraph: We have already given copious selections from the series of papers relating to the American question just laid before the British Parliament. To-day we recur to them with a view of presenting a run- ning history of the great rebellion as seen by the British Minister at Washington and as contained in the diplomatic dispatches of Lord LYONS to his Government. The extraordinary importance of the transaction in which he has been directly engaged with the Cabinet at Washington, as well as the extreme interest which attaches to this inside view of our affairs as recorded day by day in these official communications to the British Government, make this body of dispatches a historical document of permanent value. We confine our selections to Parliamentary paper No. 1, entitled "Correspondence relating to the Civil War in the United States of North America," and which is composed of 156 dispatches, the majority of them addressed by Lord LYONS to Lord JOHN RUSSELL, Her British Majesty's Foreign Secretary.

abstract: This institution, under the immediate charge of Drs. E. & E. BLACKWELL, is looked upon with interest, not only in our own City, but by a large circle of friends in Philadelphia and Boston. The Fair, which was opened on Wednesday night at Dodworth's Lower Saloon, on Broadway, to aid in its support, is marked by unusual featness, --, as, for instance, the circulation of a beautifully illustrated paper filled with contributions from eminent American authors, together with their photographs. The name of this paper is Only Once. Other fine specimens of photographic art are to be found in beautiful fancy studies upon cards, the reverse of each describing the sentiment of the pieces A collection of copies from master-pieces of DURAND' MIGNOT and others adorn several of the tables, and exquisite specimens of fine art in all its branches are innumerable. The objects of utility were in nowise overlooked, as was manifest to the eye of every true housewife and mother. Baby wrappings of exquisite finish were collected upon one table, and among them was shown conspicuously a box of little shirts complete with yoke, &c., and richly finished with soft lace of a minute pattern. They were sold before the first visitors had fairly made the tour of the room. The young people seemed to incline naturally toward a certain table presided over by a spirit of cheerfulness in the form of a lady, who, it was observed, used the "plain language," -- for upon its surface were arrayed in tempting disorder, toys and trifles which are far from being "little things to little minds." Some tea roses and leaves in wax are the most finished specimens of the kind that have been exposed upon the many stands that have been enriched with these cold yet delicate imitations of nature, in the successive fairs of this Winter. The sprigs that elicited the admiration of which we speak were the handiwork of Miss ADELAIDE BAYLISS.

abstract: Yesterday morning, soon after daylight, four armored gunboats, one wooden one, five transports partially filled with troops, and two mortarboats, left here in the direction of Columbus. Expectation--to use a not entirely original metaphor--stood on tiptoe. Everybody, including one or two reporters who had succeeded in getting an invitation to accompany the expedition, was nearly insane with relation to what the next twenty-four hours would bring forth.

abstract: We have had rumors from the Southwest for a week past that the rebels were evacuating Columbus, on the Mississippi and there have been many signs that the evacuation was really going on. We learn now from the Memphis papers that Rev. Gen. POLK issued orders for the abandonment of the position ten days ago. At the same time, he ordered that the fortifications should be demolished, and also that the track of the Memphis and Ohio Railroad be torn up -- doubtless so as to prevent Gen. GRANT from suddenly throwing a column forward to the Mississippi and cutting off his retreat. The rebels will take refuge upon Island No. 10, which, it seems, can be rendered "impregnable." This is one of the innumerable small islands in the Mississippi, the numbering of which begins a short distance below Cairo. It is just over the Kentucky line, nearly opposite the village of Obionville, at which heavy works were thrown up by negro laborers last Autumn. The rebels expect, by holding the island, to block up the passageway of our iron-clad gunboats down the river; while they will doubtless send the bulk of the Columbus forces to Memphis, to defend that city against a land assault.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a bill to carry out the stipulations of the treaty with Hanover, for the abolition of the Stadt dues, was reported from the Committee on Foreign Relations. Mr. STARKE, of Oregon, offered a resolution to refer the papers relating to his case to the Judicial Committee, and took occasion to defend himself briefly against the charge of disloyalty. A debate ensued, which occupied the time until the expiration of the morning hour, when the resolution was laid aside. The House bill, providing for an additional clerk in the office of the Assistant Treasurer in this City, was passed. The Legislative Appropriation bill was then considered in Committee of the Whole.

abstract: ANNUAL EXAMINATION OF WARD SCHOOL NO 10. The examinations of our Public Schools have commenced, and are in daily progress, under the conduct of S.S.RANDALL, Esq., and his assistants, Messrs. KIDDLE and JONES. The last two days have been devoted to Grammar School No. 10, in Wooster-street, which establishment is held to be the highest type of our Public School system. The Principal, Prof. JOHN...
lead_paragraph: ANNUAL EXAMINATION OF WARD SCHOOL NO 10. -- The examinations of our Public Schools have commenced, and are in daily progress, under the conduct of S.S.RANDALL, Esq., and his assistants, Messrs. KIDDLE and JONES. The last two days have been devoted to Grammar School No. 10, in Wooster-street, which establishment is held to be the highest type of our Public School system. The Principal, Prof. JOHN F. STODDARD, well known in all educational circles by his series of mathematical works, has paid special attention to the cultivation of its principles in the departments under his supervision, the results of which tutorage were very perceptible in the classes which were examined in mental arithmetic, that most difficult subject for immature intellects to compass. The Primary Departments, both male and female, exhibited fair proficiency in the ordinary routine branches' as history, geography, elocution, &c. The highest class in the Female Department sustained themselves with great credit, and reflected honor upon their preceptress, MISS EMMA L. THOMPSON, late matron of the Military Hospital in Alexandria. This young lady procured leave of absence from the school officers at the commencement of the nursing movement, but has since returned to her former sphere of duty. The "Robinson Zouaves" form the most novel feature of this school, and they look upon their daily drill as a pleasant episode in their course of studies. The erect bearing and soldierly precision of movement upon the part of the young cadets, was an additional attraction to the exercises of the class. The Superintendent complimented the school at the close for its marked advancement, and the perfect order with which the pupils had conducted themselves.

abstract: Editorial estimates number of Confederate soldiers in Virginia
snippet: Editorial estimates number of Confederate soldiers in Virginia
lead_paragraph: If, within six days, or six months, the army of the Potomac should march against Manassas, or outflank it, or take it in the rear, or attack or circumvent it in any other way, or from any possible angle, what would be the probable number of rebels attacked, or outflanked, or left isolated and helpless in that formidable stronghold? We know that, nine months ago, the rebel Congress authorized DAVIS to raise four hundred thousand soldiers for his defence; we know that all the rebel newspapers have proclaimed, over and over again, that the whole fighting population of the South had rushed to arms, or were about to do so, and had gone, or were at once going, to the points menaced by invasion; we know that the secession organ of this City has twice published pretended lists of the rebel regiments, of immense length, and that in one of its estimates it gave the number of regiments at four hundred and fifty, while in another it stated the rebel force in the field at 496,000 men. JEFF. DAVIS, also, in his Inaugural, the other day, said that a million men in arms now confronted each other, and we know certainly that not over half of that number are in our army. We know, on the other hand, that the rebel imagination delights in tropes and hyperboles; we know that the Herald has an end, if not a master to serve, by its preposterous estimates; and we know that the rebel figures of number, as well as their figures of speeeh, have been remarkably belied in our late encounters in the Southwest. The rebel army at Bowling Green had been ordinarily estimated as high as sixty to seventy-five thousand; that at Columbus from forty to sixty thousand; while from Nashville, Memphis, and other points, we have had secession estimates that would run the entire rebel force in the Southwest up to at least half of DAVIS' half million. But we know pretty well that after Bowling Green had reinforced Fort Donelson with 10,000 men, there was not much more than that number left to retreat to Murfreesboro'; and if the force now evacuating Columbus counts anything like forty or sixty thousand, it will be a remarkable movement for such a body -- even if it be a rebel body. It is possible enough that for various reasons, the rebels may have exaggerated, in an equal degree, the strength of their force on the Potomac. When they have talked wildly about two or three hundred thousand fierce and furious soldiers stationed there, it may be that they over calculated by the matter of (say) one or two hundred thousand. We know that at Bull Run, where all the available forces were concentrated, BEAUREGARD states the number of men engaged and on the field at an exceedingly low figure; we know that if their soldiers were counted by a very large number of hundreds of thousands, they would be likely to send much heavier forces to defend the important strategic points BURNSIDE is now seizing in North Carolina; and there are many other reasons to doubt that they have any such huge masses of troops as they claim. We would not under-estimate the numbers or the courage of the rebel soldiers on the Potomac. We doubt not that both are great. But one hundred thousand we believe to be a large estimate for the whole body. A letter just arrived in this City from a discreet and reliable person in Richmond, states the number at sixty thousand; but this is, perhaps, somewhat below the mark. But still, there is no doubt that it is much nearer the truth than the prodigious figures with which the rebels have so long frightened us.

abstract: Editorial on efforts in Congress to evict Sen. Starke (Oregon) for treason
snippet: Editorial on efforts in Congress to evict Sen. Starke (Oregon) for treason
lead_paragraph: The case of BENJAMIN STARKE engages the attention of the United States Senate. Mr. STARKE comes properly accredited as the Senator from Oregon. His papers are unexceptionably regular. His seat is not contested. But certain gentlemen have made and sent to Washington a score of affidavits, to the effect that at the outset of the civil war, STARKE was loud in his denunciations of the North, and tearful in his sympathy with rebels and traitors; and although his outward conversion from these reprobate practices is not denied, STARKE, they say, should not be permitted to occupy a place in that august and indisputably loyal body, the Senate. And in Mr. SUMNER, and others of similar turn of mind, the remonstrants find approval and support.
headline: {'main': 'The Senate at Play.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Senate at Play.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: reports from Columbus indicate evacuation by Confederates
snippet: reports from Columbus indicate evacuation by Confederates
lead_paragraph: JEFF. DAVIS' first regular Message to the "permanent" rebel Government is published this morning. It is a very curious and significant document. He says that his Government had attempted more than it could achieve, and in its effort to protect the whole of its territory, it had encountered disasters. He has not yet received the official reports of the discomfitures at Roanoke or Donelson; the Roanoke affair, however, was deeply humiliating; and he is unwilling to believe that a large army surrendered at Fort Donelson without a desperate effort to cut its way through the enemy. But strenuous efforts have been made to send reinforcements to the threatened positions; and the disappointments will nerve the people to still greater exertions. He opposes the policy of enlistments for short terms, and urges the soldiers to reinlist for the war. He cannot tell the present strength of his army, but estimates it at 400 regiments of infantry, with cavalry and artillery. He thinks the whole body of new levies and reenlisted men will be ready within thirty days. His army was at present so disorganized as to impair its ability for successful defence. His navy is in a satisfactory condition. His finances are prosperous, he has no floating debt, and the expenditures have only been $170,000,000! His postage system is steadily improving. In closing he assures his Congress of his hearty cooperation in all its efforts. Our military authorities will doubtless not be blind to some of the important facts mentioned by the President of the so-styled Confederate States.

abstract: The Message of the rebel President of the rebel Confederacy to the rebel Congress is reported for the readers of the TIMES this morning. It follows close upon the heels of the Inaugural Address. That document was marked by much of the presumption and confidence which have all along characterized the words and deeds of the insurgent leaders; the transmutation of reverses into victories; amplification of the popular resources; assurance of triumphant success; depreciation and defiance of the enemy. It was difficult to discover in the language of the incoming Chief Magistrate, that the course of treason had not run smoothly, redeeming all the engagements of those who set it in motion, and offering the most gratifying results for the future.

abstract: If diplomacy now-a-days is a very different affair from the system of espoinage which the Venetian Republic organized for itself at every Court of Europe, the contrast is not less striking in the fate that befalls modern diplomatic correspondence.
lead_paragraph: If diplomacy now-a-days is a very different affair from the system of espoinage which the Venetian Republic organized for itself at every Court of Europe, the contrast is not less striking in the fate that befalls modern diplomatic correspondence. Instead of being sepultured in secret archives like the collection of SIMANCAS, whose mine of gossip, slander and intrigue European historians are only now beginning to work, our democratic publicity demands that Ambassadors annually make a clean breast of it; and all the mysteries of diplomatic note-paper are yearly unveiled and laid before Congress or Parliament in the vulgar form of a Blue-Book. The current session of the British Legislature has brought with it its customary batch of such official papers, and among these are no less than six voluminous Collections of documents relating to the United States, of which we have received copies. We have already drawn largely on this body of diplomacy, and to-day we make new and copious selections from that collection of the papers which contains Lord LYONS' dispatches to his Government.

abstract: NORTH CAROLINIANS! Our country needs your aid for its protection and defence against an invading foe. The President of the Confederate States has made a requisition upon our State to complete her quota of troops in the field. Our own borders are invaded by the enemy in force, now threatening an advance, to deprive us of liberty, property, and all that we held dear as a self-governing and free people.
lead_paragraph: NORTH CAROLINIANS! Our country needs your aid for its protection and defence against an invading foe. The President of the Confederate States has made a requisition upon our State to complete her quota of troops in the field. Our own borders are invaded by the enemy in force, now threatening an advance, to deprive us of liberty, property, and all that we held dear as a self-governing and free people. We must resist him at all hazards, and by every means in our power. He wages a war for our subjugation, a war forced upon us in wrong and prosecuted without right, and in a spirit of vengeful wickedness without a parallel in the history of warfare among civilized nations.

abstract: A correspondent from Yorktown informs the Richmond Dispatch that the Louisiana Zouave Battalion has reenlisted for the war. "The spirit of reenlistment," that paper says, "has exceeded the most sanguine expectations. If the recruiting is at all comparable to the noble spirit in the army, we only fear we shall not have arms enough for the men. But let them enlist -- let them come forward like men to sustain their country's cause, and arms will no doubt be found for them. There is one way they can be had, if no other, and that is to take them from the enemy. This can be done if our men will it. But there is the deadly pike yet to be brought into us. Many regiments may be armed and drilled with that, to do sure and efficient work on the battle-field."

abstract: The steamship Arabia, from Liverpool, on the 15th, and Queenstown on the 16th ult., arrived at Halifax, yesterday, having put in short of coal. Her advices are two days later, but are not specially important. The Archduke MAXIMILLAN is said positively to have signified his acceptance of the throne of Mexico. The French papers are under the impression that the Mexican question will lead to the overthrow of the Palmerston Cabinet.
lead_paragraph: The steamship Arabia, from Liverpool, on the 15th, and Queenstown on the 16th ult., arrived at Halifax, yesterday, having put in short of coal. Her advices are two days later, but are not specially important. The Archduke MAXIMILLAN is said positively to have signified his acceptance of the throne of Mexico. The French papers are under the impression that the Mexican question will lead to the overthrow of the Palmerston Cabinet. The gunboat Tuscarora is reported to have proceeded to Gibraltar, where the Sumter still remained without coals. The Mason and Slidell affair cost the British Government 364,000. The Liverpool Cotton Market was firmer, but prices were unchanged. Breadstuffs were steady, and Provisions quiet. Consols, 92 1/8@93.

abstract: Serious irregularities in the trains on the New-Jersey Railroad have occurred during the last forty-eight hours. On Friday night several of the trains were stuck in the heavy snowdrifts, one of them being out all night; and yesterday the train from Philadelphia, due here at about 1 P.M., met with an accident between Newark and Jersey City. The engine ran over a piece of wood lodged in such a manner as to throw it off the track and into a train of coal-cars standing on a siding; some of the latter were pretty well broken up and piled upon the engine, which also sustained serious injury. The baggage-car, which was next the engine, was detached and thrown on the opposite side, landing the baggage crates in the greatest confusion against the bank. The cars containing passengers did not leave the track, and the passengers, as well as all the men employed on the train, fortunately escaped uninjured. During the rest of the afternoon all the trains were more or less delayed in getting by the obstruction, and it was not until about 7 o'clock that both tracks were cleared and the trains enabled to run on time.
lead_paragraph: Serious irregularities in the trains on the New-Jersey Railroad have occurred during the last forty-eight hours. abstract: The Fayetteville Arkansian, of the 25th ult., says that Gen. PRICE sent an express to Col. HERBERT, commanding at Fayetteville, informing the latter officer that the Federals were advancing upon Springfield with a heavy force, and asking for aid. About a week since, the Northern papers had a telegram from St. Louis, saying that an expedition had started from Rolla.
lead_paragraph: The Fayetteville Arkansian, of the 25th ult., says that Gen. PRICE sent an express to Col. HERBERT, commanding at Fayetteville, informing the latter officer that the Federals were advancing upon Springfield with a heavy force, and asking for aid. About a week since, the Northern papers had a telegram from St. Louis, saying that an expedition had started from Rolla. The natural supposition is that this force was meant to attack PRICE. The distance between Springfield and Rolla is about 113 miles; and the Federals had ample time to [???] Springfield. The Arkansian estimates PRICE's force at 18,000 men, but, as far as we can ascertain, this is double the number he really has. We hope he may be reinforced and enabled to give the enemy battle. The Arkansian says it is understood that Gen. MCINTOSH will go to PRICE's assistance at once. It was said that when Gen. MCCULLOCH left here for the West, it was under orders to take his command to the headquarters of Gen. VAN DORN. We have no doubt but that VAN DORN will take some immediate steps to relieve PRICE by sending him aid or menacing the enemy so as to create a diversion in PRICE's favor.

abstract: WASHINGTON's Farewell Address was read in Chicago as well as elsewhere, on Saturday last. At the conclusion of the reading, the audience called loudly for Gen. CASS, and with an emphasis that would take no denial. The General, in answer to repeated calls, came forward and said that he was not prepared to make a speech on that occasion; that he should consider it ill-timed to make one after listening to the address just read. It would be presumptuous to attempt to give force to its admonitions. It was a prophetic voice from the tomb, one not to be lightly regarded, and it was the duty of every citizen to take serious thought of prevent events, and ponder well the teachings given by WASHINGTON. It was good for all to meet on this natal day, and it was especially good now, when our country is rent with strite -- a country which has possessed greater freedom than has ever fallen to the lot of any Government. But lately we have heard the cry from a portion of it, "To your [???], O, Israel!" Their hosts are endeavoring to destroy this temple of liberty which WASHINGTON has bequeathed to us; they are striving to pull down its pillars, and crush us in its fall, but, said the speaker, with earnest emphasis, "they can't do it." The applause which followed the remark was absolutely deafening, and again and again the cheer was taken up until the hall rang anew. The General repeated the remark with even stronger emphasis, and the applause was renewed. Our glorious fabric, continued the speaker, shall survive, protected by our brave army and navy, and, defying the storm, it shall still stand and spread its shadow far and wide, like the shadow of a great rock in a weary land. There have been many causeless insurrections; rebellions have often appeared on the page of history, but never before was there such a rebellion as this. Previous to it no man could rise up and say that he had ever received any injury from the Government; from Maine to Texas every man sat under the shadow of his own vine and fig-tree, and there was none to molest or make him afraid. Such a spectacle as this rebellion was reserved for the present generation to witness. It is a time, however, to congratulate ourselves on the patriotism, the wisdom and firmness, which the loyal American people have exhibited. From every town and hamlet they are pouring their strong men into the field, and, thanks to God, we are being victorious. He spoke of the honors paid to WASHINGTON on the occasion of his Eastern tour, and of the enthusiasm that everywhere abounded. In the address to the Senate announcing his death, he was characterized as "first in peace, first in war, first in the hearts of his countrymen." Many years have passed, and this judgment has been confirmed. Of all the heroes of ancient or modern times, whose deeds have not perished with them, whose names are inscribed upon the scroll of fame, the brightest, the purest, is the name of WASHINGTON. The conclusion of the remarks, as indeed every sentence had been, was greeted with tumultuous applause.

abstract: Ts Brig.-Gen. Reno:  On Friday, the 7th, at 5 P.M., my regiment disembarked. I formed the line rapidly, and in good order. Then Gen. abstract: RECEPTION OF COL. A.M. WOOD. -- The citizens and Common Council Committees have nearly completed the arrangements for the reception of Col. WOOD, of the Fourteenth Regiment, upon his arrival in this city. The Committees expect to meet Col. WOOD in Philadelphia Friday evening, and reach this city on their return at about noon on Monday next. The firemen, military and a large number of civic societies will take part in the proceedings. The Grand Marshal, Hon. F.B. SPINOLA, has been busily engaged all the week in perfecting his arrangements. A meeting was held Friday at the City Armory of the present members of Fourteenth Regiment, now on furlough in this city to make arrangements to join in the reception of their Colonel. Thirty-six members were present -- seventeen of whom are wounded or released prisoners. They will join in the procession, the wounded in carriages and the balance will act as a guard of honor. The exempt members of the regiment will also turn out under Capt. WH. M. BURNET.

abstract: Our gallant tars are reaping a rich harvest not only of glory but of cash. Scarcely a day passes but some of our vessels nab a prize, and of course our boys come in for their share of prize-money. Yesterday we recorded the taking of the British iron steamship Labuan, attempting to run the blockade of a Gulf port. She was a rich prize, indeed, valued at something like a quarter million of dollars. A few days ago, we had to report the capture of the schooner Lizzie Weston, off Apalachicola, loaded with 800 bales of cotton; of the schooner Gipsey, inside of Horn Island Pass, also laden with a cargo of cotton, and of the British schooner Mars, off Fernandina, laden with salt. These are but samples of what is constantly occurring. Of course this keeps our gallant tars in the very best of humor, and at the same time keeps them very wide awake to see that no prizes slip through their fingers, out or in to a rebel port.

abstract: The Memphis Appeal learns from a lady friend that a project is on foot among the gentler sex of Memphis to organize a "broomstick battalion," for the especial protection of such young gentlemen as are indisposed to enlist for the protection of their country. Nice young men, that attend "small teaparties," wear kid gloves, and have their hair dressed five or six times a week by the barber, will receive their particular attention.

abstract: The San Francisco Bulletin of Feb. 1 says "H.A. Perry, the well-known actor, died this forenoon about 11 o'clock, at his residence on Jackson-street, between Powell and Stockton streets, of consumption. About a twelvemonth ago, when playing in the interior, he caught cold, which soon settled on his lungs, and proved fatal in the end. For the last few months he has been closely confined to his house, and for six weeks or more has not left his bed-chamber. Mr. Perry was born in Philadelphia, on Christmas Day, 1826, and was therefore, when he died, entering the thirty-seventh year of his age. When quite a boy, he used to work in a stable, and ride horse races. Tiring of this business, he ran off and learned the tailoring trade; but having a hankering, for the atricals, before long went on the boards. He made his first appearance on the stage, when about 19 years old, at the Walnut-street Theatre, in Philadelphia, in the character of Malcolm, in 'Macbeth.' In 1851 he was leading man at the Broadway Theatre, New-York. Afterwards he traveled in company with Julia Dean for two years; and, leaving her, 'starred' it for two years more in the Western cities. He next played in New-York, in Burton's company, and soon after 'starred' it through the Canadas and the States. He played in Wood & McVicar's company, in St. Louis, Cincinnati and Chicago; again at the Walnut, in 1859, and later, at Niblo's Garden, New-York. Two years ago, he arrived here, and made debut, if we recollect aright, at the old Lyceum Theatre, in the character of Othello. Since then he has been almost constantly on the boards in this city, except during his last illness, and when he made an occasional professional visit to the interior towns. Frequenters of the Opera House will recollect him as the leading actor, if not the most valuable one, in the excellent stock company which the management of that theatre had collected during the last year or two."

abstract: In this Court yesterday a motion of considerable importance was argued, in the case of JOSEPH POWELL, convicted of grand larceny. A new trial for the accused was moved by Mr. SPENCER, on the ground of newly discovered evidence, which was objected to by Mr. HALL, who considered the Court had no right to grant new trials. The Court reserved its decision.

abstract: -- The Richmond Dispatch surrenders all hope of French and English intervention by avowing that the South would sooner sympathize with Russia than with the English Government, which is charged with urging on the "Abolition crusade that is culminating in this war, and then coldly left the South to meet it as it could!" The offence of the English is of a compound nature. They should, in the estimation of the rebels, break the blockade, and should not have insulted, indecently, Messrs. MASON and SLIDELL, through their leading Press.

abstract: One of the most beautiful economies of nature is that when scolds get tired of venting their spleen at others they turn their batteries against each other; and it quite reconciles one to Billingsgate when two fishwives get well by the ears.
lead_paragraph: One of the most beautiful economies of nature is that when scolds get tired of venting their spleen at others they turn their batteries against each other; and it quite reconciles one to Billingsgate when two fishwives get well by the ears. The Saturday Review, in its latest issue, affords a very good exemplification of this general moral truth in an article headed "The Times [London] on Federal Government," in which it soundly berates the "Thunderer" for its ignorance, unfairness malice, malignity, impertinence, and what not as to American affairs. With the cue to the situation, which most of our readers possess -- knowing that that weekly, which has been well christened the Saturday Reviler, has done little else for the past twelve months than pour out floods of vitriol on everything American -- it is as good as a play to hear the lecture it reads its daily cotemporary of Printing House-square.

abstract: -- It is worth while reading the proceedings of the rebel Congress, if for no other object, to see the mad schemes which despair is suggesting to men who already descry the stern front of advancing justice. The latest and wildest is the resolution introduced into their "Senate" last Wednesday, to "encourage" planters and owners of cotton and tobacco to destroy their crops in order to prevent them from falling into our possession -- the encouragement consisting in a promise of indemnification by the rebel Government. There is a simplicity about the proposal that is delicious. For it will be remembered that when MEMMINGER, the rebel Secretary of the Treasury, issued his confederate bonds, his strong point in proof of their value was, that the loan was based upon cotton and tobacco. It is now proposed that the planters shall burn the basis itself and receive "indemnification" in the form of bonds that have not the smallest value, except what they derive from the security which they are encouraged to destroy! If this is not cutting off their nose to spite their face, what is?
lead_paragraph: -- It is worth while reading the proceedings of the rebel Congress, if for no other object, to see the mad schemes which despair is suggesting to men who already descry the stern front of advancing justice. The latest and wildest is the resolution introduced into their "Senate" last Wednesday, to "encourage" planters and owners of cotton and tobacco to destroy their crops in order to prevent them from falling into our possession -- the encouragement consisting in a promise of indemnification by the rebel Government. There is a simplicity about the proposal that is delicious. For it will be remembered that when MEMMINGER, the rebel Secretary of the Treasury, issued his confederate bonds, his strong point in proof of their value was, that the loan was based upon cotton and tobacco. It is now proposed that the planters shall burn the basis itself and receive "indemnification" in the form of bonds that have not the smallest value, except what they derive from the security which they are encouraged to destroy! If this is not cutting off their nose to spite their face, what is?

abstract: Editorial praises loyalty to Union in eastern Tennessee
snippet: Editorial praises loyalty to Union in eastern Tennessee
lead_paragraph: We have had many proofs of the extraordinary loyalty and devotion to the Union of the patriots of East Tennessee. But an article which we publish this morning, from the Knoxville Register, (a rebel sheet) of a late date, exhibits a state of affairs more remarkable than anything of which we have heretofore heard. It appears that some months ago, the Unionists in that part of the State were organized for a general uprising against the rebel despotism, and armed themselves, and assembled in bodies in quite a number of counties; but the [Secessionist authorities, both State and Confederate, dispatched large columns of rebel troops there, who succeeded, by means of the sword, the halter and the dungeon, in suppressing these Union outbreaks. Part of the evidence which appeared on the trial of some of these Union men is given; and one thrilling scene is brought to light which, as showing the spirit of these men, is worth reiterating here. It was in the wild mountain regions of Greene County, in the extreme eastern part of the State. A party of thirty or forty Unionists were gathered together late at night, discussing their plans of operation against the rebels. While thus engaged, Col. FRY, since famous as the killer of ZOLLICOFFER, alighted from his horse, and bounded into the yard, exclaiming, "Friends! I am Col. FRY, and I am come to share with you." He addressed his fellow-loyalists, who were unanimous in their expressions of approbation, and with one accord determined that he should be their leader, and that they would follow him, if necessary, to death. Then says the rebel report:
headline: {'main': 'An Extraordinary Scene in East Tennessee.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'An Extraordinary Scene in East Tennessee.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The total number of American vessels lost during the month of February was 35. The list includes 4 steamers, 5 ships, 7 barks, 4 brigs, 14 schooners, and 1 sloop. Of these, 21 were wrecked, 6 abandoned, 1 burnt, 2 foundered, and 5 are missing. Several other vessels, not comprised in the above list, were stranded during the late gale and seriously damaged, but are not yet considered as lost.

lead_paragraph: The friends of this class of people will be interested in reading the following letter by Capt. SAXTON, Assistant Quartermaster at Hilton Head. He is an intelligent gentleman, and his statements are reliable, having had much experience in their care. We are glad to learn that instructors are to be sent to them, and that a general effort through the country is now making to collect clothing for the destitute. A collection has been requested of all our City churches to-day. All goods should be sent to the depot, No. 320 Broadway, Monday morning, in time for the expedition: Four WELLES, PORT ROYAL, S.C., Friday, Feb. 10, 1862.

abstract: Government has received advices from Nashville to Friday last. It was reported that the enemy was retreating toward the Tennessee River; but as that stream is rather crooked, this information is rather indefinite. The subsequent announcement that they are concentrating at Chattanooga, however, renders it a little more clear. A great change is found to have occurred already in the political feeling in Tennessee, and the War Department feels itself warranted in taking measures immediately to raise and arm volunteer troops in that State. The evacuation of Columbus by the rebels is confirmed.

abstract: Permits are now granted for shipments, for family use, down the Louisville and Nashville Railroad, as well as the Ohio, and, I believe, for like shipments up the Cumberland and Tennessee. The Cincinnati and Louisville Press suggest the immediate relaxing of the embargo, and the early abolishing of the permit system, with reference to every district where the sway of the nation is reestablished, and the necessity for that system is thus done away.

lead_paragraph: -- The extraordinary tenor of DAVIS' Message to the rebel Congress, telegraphed to our paper yesterday morning, caused the genuineness of the document to be questioned by some parties on the Stock Exchange, yesterday, and perhaps in other quarters. Of course, there was other reason for doubt than the frank admissions of the weakness, not to say desperation of the rebel cause. The paper reached our Baltimore Agent in due course, and was promptly telegraphed, word for word. By the mail of yesterday, we have an inkling of the temper in which it was received by the rebel Congress. On a question of privilege, a member from Louisiana, and another from South Carolina, spoke as follows:

abstract: gives series of lectures at Brooklyn Academy of Music
snippet: gives series of lectures at Brooklyn Academy of Music
lead_paragraph: The sixth and last lecture of the Graham series was delivered on Sunday evening, Feb. 23. So eager have the community been to hear these lectures, that, in order to get a seat in the Academy of Music, it was necessary to be there an hour before the lecture commenced. Prof. AGASSIZ proposed to complete, in the last lecture, so far as the limits would allow, the demonstration of a plan in the order of succession of animals, which implies thought, deliberation and the direct intervention of an intelligent Creator. Nowhere is the evidence of plan more plain than in the radiated animals. As the basis of their structure we may take the Sphere. For though the plan of radiation, as exhibited in these animals, is not a mathematical sphere, it is, nevertheless, an organic sphere; it is a sphere in which there is as much variation as can well be introduced upon the idea of radiation. And the first difference we notice is this: that instead of the outer structure bearing a relation to a central point, it bears a relation to an axis which extends from pole to pole. The living sphere, as shown in the radiated animals, comes nearer to a revolving sphere, which is the axis of revolution, having two poles and an equator. This axis is surrounded by parts which are identical in their nature, and which bear the same relation to one another and to a central axis. But the two poles are essentially different. Now, if we present the problem of radiation in a mathematical point of view, it would be this: How to execute with the elements given -- with a vertical axis, around which are arranged parts of equal value -- all the possible variations involved in that plan. This question I have actually submitted to one of our great mathematicians. I requested him to solve the problem, how to devise structures variously executed, the elements being given, without introducing any new elements. His answer was readily given, and it was this: To represent the whole sphere as a series of wedges placed side by side. To make this demonstration clear I will take for illustration the melon with its ribbed surface, or the orange whose internal part is composed of a number of spherical wedges which are all equal. Now in executing any structure upon the idea of radiation, the simplest way would be to gather around the axis a number of these spherical wedges until the whole space is occupied. There would be a larger or smaller number according to the angle of the two sides of the wedge, so that by varying the thickness of the wedges we could introduce at once a variety of structure.

abstract: In review of the numerous public institutions monumental of our citizens' far-reaching benevolence, stands one which, save in circles immediately interested, is rarely talked of, yet which, from the peculiarity of its associations, is singularly interesting. If one had never visited it a Southerner, for instance, who had never dreamed of such an establishment and were shown the curious and remarkably impressive stereoscopic views which are here...
lead_paragraph: In review of the numerous public institutions monumental of our citizens' far-reaching benevolence, stands one which, save in circles immediately interested, is rarely talked of, yet which, from the peculiarity of its associations, is singularly interesting. If one had never visited it -- a Southerner, for instance, who had never dreamed of such an establishment -- and were shown the curious and remarkably impressive stereoscopic views which are here shown of the interior departments as they appear -- daily routine, the natural sentiment would be incredulity. The idea of 237 young curly-headed "contrabands," or, as an Arkansas trader would say, in telling out the mush to a drove of such, "little niggers," being gathered together in order and cleanliness, to receive discipline and instruction, with a view to their usefulness as citizens and their soul's salvation, would scarcely be realized. Not they alone are benefited; as a work originated and upheld by the enlightened and refined as well as the opulent and powerful of our closely observed and influential land, it obtains a significance far outweighing any missions to Owhyhee, Birmah, or Tongataboo.

abstract: This body has issued its report for the month of January, 1862, under date of St. Louis, Feb. 10. It has distributed 15,589 different articles, consisting, among other things, of 696 bed comforts, 1,507 towels, 2,328 pairs of socks, etc. The total number of articles distributed to Feb. 1 was 34,604, and since its establishment the Commission has received 525 boxes and barrels of goods from different States and cities, and the sum of $2,276 45 has been received in money, two-thirds of which has been expended. The Commission calls for additional contributions, and asks that all boxes of goods may be directed to JAMES E. YEATMAN, President Western Sanitary Commission, St. Louis, Mo., as heretofore, and the names of the parties sending, and of the place sent from, should be plainly marked on the boxes, that their receipt may be more readily acknowledged.

abstract: The perusal of the extraordinary document sent to the rebel Congress by JEFF. DAVIS and printed in the TIMES yesterday, very naturally excites the profoundest astonishment. Doubts as to the authenticity of the paper probably suggested themselves to the minds of a majority of readers, who only became satisfied of its genuineness, when, toward the close, the old and familiar tone of assumption and confidence peculiar to this class of Southern literature became audible, and JEFF. DAVIS was manifestly himself again. Never was a cause so palpably abandoned. The force of the preliminary admissions is not in the least impaired by the subsequent promises of better things. It is confessed that "the Government had attempted more than it had power successfully to achieve." We are told in what this impossible task consisted. It was "the effort to protect by our arms the whole territory of the Confederate States, seaboard and inland." How true is this statement, we of the North very well know, who see Missouri and Kentucky cleared of the rebels, and note how along the whole coast are posted powerful expeditions, not only closing in the rebel States from all exterior communication and aid, but prepared to penetrate to the very heart of the insurgent territory. But it has been no part of the rebel policy to admit the most indisputable facts, if they militated against their interest. The war temper of the Southern people was created and has been kept alive by delusions. There has been no day since South Carolina became a fugitive from national justice, when it was safe to let in a gleam of truth to the popular mind of the South; for that single ray might have sufficed to destroy the entire fabric of the Confederate leaders, and bring the ruins upon their mischievous heads. It has been a reign at once of error and terror. The ignorant masses, moved originally by the impulse of falsehood, have been urged on to destruction by perseverance in the same diabolical system, the first departure from which is now made by DAVIS himself.

abstract: A REMARKABLE CASE OF MALICIOUS MISCHIEF. -- EDWARD ST. JOHN, of No. 137 Ninth-street, was arrested on Friday by Detective MCDOUGAL, upon the complaint of D. WICKHAM, of No. 9 Maiden-lane. Mr. WICKHAM complains that for four or five weeks past, ST. JOHN has been in the habit of answering by letter all kinds of advertisements published in the morning papers, and in them requesting the advertisers to call at the house of the complainant in Eleventh-street. Four or five hundred calls have been made upon the family of Mr. WICKHAM in answer to these missives, and the complainant and his family have consequently been very much annoyed. No explanations made by the family could convince the callers they had been deceived, and morning, noon and night, the hall bell was kept ringing. The affair every day grew worse, until finally Mr. WICKHAM applied for relief at the office of the Detective Police, and Officer MCDOUGAL succeeded in arresting the defender on Friday afternoon. Both of the parties are said to be men of wealth and position in society, and no satisfactory reason is given at present for the unusual proceedings on the part of Mr. ST. JOHN. When taken to the Detective Office the prisoner left with authorities valuables to the amount of about $3,000. He is held to await a further examination.

abstract: A Cairo paper says: "We have the most reliable information in this vicinity that the rebel gunboat fleet, of the construction of which the Southern papers frequently spoke previous to the establishment of the blockade, is now completely fitted out and equipped, and is ready for the upward march. A United States officer spoke of this matter yesterday to one of the Captains of Col. HANSON's Kentucky Regiment. The latter said he was in the City of New-Orleans a couple of weeks since, and that eight rebel gunboats were then lying at the wharf awaiting orders to proceed up the Mississippi. The fleet, he said, is under the command of Commodore HOLLINS. The boats are all iron-clad; much more heavily plated than ours, and less vulnerable. Their machinery is all below the gun decks. In this respect they are equal to the Benton, the best boat of the United States fleet. The rebel officer further stated that it is the intention of Commodore HOLLINS to make an attack on Cairo, and that speedily. 'Mark my prediction, you will find these boats before Fort Holt in less than ten days,' was one of the remarks which I heard him make. The rumor of a contemplated attack on Cairo has spread no little consternation among the people here, and if the rebels really have the kind of fleet I have just described, their apprehensions are not altogether groundless. At present, such an attack could easily be repulsed. We have seven or eight boats here, and though some of them are not in good repair, they could all be brought into requisition in case of emergency. In a week or so, however, five or six of these will start for the Cumberland River, leaving the place certainly pregnable to a fleet of eight well armed vessels."

abstract: Diagram and description of Union-occupied Confederate areas on Mississippi River in Missouri and Kentucky
snippet: Diagram and description of Union-occupied Confederate areas on Mississippi River in Missouri and Kentucky
lead_paragraph: The rebel papers inform us that the army which is evacuating Columbus has been ordered by Rev. Gen. POLK to retire to Island No. 10, and there prepare for action against our advancing column. We give herewith a diagram of the river from Columbus down to that position, by which the character and bearings of the Island will be seen. No. 10, as we have already stated, is one of the innumerable small islands in the Mississippi River, the numbering of which begins just below Cairo. It is very near the line separating the State of Kentucky from Tennessee. It is probably about a mile long and a half a mile wide. It is nearly opposite the village of Obionville, at which heavy works were thrown up by negro laborers last Autumn. The island is one hundred and sixty miles above Memphis, and nine hundred miles above New-Orleans. The rebels hope from this point to stop the descent of our gunboats down the river to assault Memphis. They boast that they can at once render the position impregnable. We think it likely, however, if they occupy it at all, that they will leave but a small force there to obstruct the river, and send the bulk of the Columbus army to more important points. The geographical location and the size of Island No. 10 will be clearly seen from the diagram.

abstract: During the week just ending the business of some departments of the Custom House has been largely in excess of that usually transacted. Most of the business during that period has been transacted by the clerks of the Warehouse Department, the receipts from the duties on bonded goods approaching $200,000 some days of the week.
lead_paragraph: During the week just ending the business of some departments of the Custom House has been largely in excess of that usually transacted. Most of the business during that period has been transacted by the clerks of the Warehouse Department, the receipts from the duties on bonded goods approaching $200,000 some days of the week. This sum is much greater than that usually received from this source of revenue; indeed there have been but few days in many years when the sum paid equaled that named. The explanation of this sudden increase of duties received is probably as follows: During the past month or two large quantities of goods of certain descriptions have been placed in bond. The largest invoices thus warehoused have been of sugar, coffee and tea, the last two of which are articles which under the former tariff laws were scarcely ever bonded, inasmuch as they were allowed entry free of duty. The high rates of duty now levied on the three articles mentioned force the importers of them to take advantage of the warehousing privilege, and the result of their so doing has been the deposit of millions of pounds of them in public store since the beginning of the year. The passage of the Treasury Note Bill with the important amendment requiring duties to be paid in the demand notes of the first issue, or in coin, together with the probability of the passage of a new tariff act, which the importers, in their timidity, fear may take effect on the goods already imported and in bond, has caused the owners of such merchandise to withdraw it as quickly as possible. In thus doing, they have found it necessary to demand Treasury notes at the banks with which to pay their duties at the custom-house; here they met with a difficulty which they had not foreseen -- the banks having been so particular, of late, about receiving demand-notes in large sums, were destitute of the required quantity. A large proportion of the duties received have been from the articles already mentioned.

abstract: Rev. FRANCIS VINTON, D.D., pastor of Trinity Church, lectured, on Wednesday evening, before the General Society of Mechanics and Tradesmen, on "The Cause and Cure of the Rebellion." A very large audience was present, and the platform was occupied by the President and Lecture Committee of the Society, Major ANDERSON and Comptroller HAWS. The hero of Fort Sumter was honored with three hearty cheers.
lead_paragraph: Rev. FRANCIS VINTON, D.D., pastor of Trinity Church, lectured, on Wednesday evening, before the General Society of Mechanics and Tradesmen, on "The Cause and Cure of the Rebellion." A very large audience was present, and the platform was occupied by the President and Lecture Committee of the Society, Major ANDERSON and Comptroller HAWS. The hero of Fort Sumter was honored with three hearty cheers.

abstract: The Richmond Examiner, of Wednesday last, says: "A rumor prevails that the enemy, in very strong force, are marching upon Winchester, and that Gen. KIRBY SMITH, with his command, has gone from Manassas to Winchester to meet them, in conjunction with the forces under the command of Gen. THOMAS J. JACKSON."

abstract: GENERAL ORDERS, No. 8. -- The Brigadier-General commanding the Division congratulates the troops under his command on the recent brilliant successes of our arms at this place, which led to the unconditional surrender of the enemy on the 16th inst., and to which they contributed in no small degree. He hopes everything for the future from their conduct on this occasion. He begs to request that the brigade and regimental commanders, every officer, non-commissioned officer and soldier, to accept his warmest thanks for their gallantry and good conduct under fire, and their patient endurance without a murmur of the inclement weather to which they were exposed for several days and nights in succession, without shelter or fire, and with limited food.
lead_paragraph: GENERAL ORDERS, No. 8. -- The Brigadier-General commanding the Division congratulates the troops under his command on the recent brilliant successes of our arms at this place, which led to the unconditional surrender of the enemy on the 16th inst., and to which they contributed in no small degree. abstract: -- The story, by telegraph that BUELL's force southeast of Nashville had surrounded the rebels at Murfreesboro, is not officially confirmed from Washington. To get in the rear of the town of Murfreesboro, it would be necessary for BUELL to have one of his columns cross the Cumberland above Nashville, say near Gallatin, from which point there is a good turnpike to Lebanon, Wilson County; and from Lebanon, if we mistake not, there is also a good turnpike to Murfreesboro. We have no account of any such movement, although one of the columns of BUELL, marching from Bowling Green in the direction of Nashville, may have made this diversion. The town of Murfreesboro is not a defensible point. It is on the railroad from Nashville to Chattanooga, and if the rebels had command of the railroad equipment, and they were disposed to decline a battle, the way was open to retreat upon Chattanooga and Atlanta, unless really surrounded in the way we have here referred to.
lead_paragraph: -- The story, by telegraph that BUELL's force southeast of Nashville had surrounded the rebels at Murfreesboro, is not officially confirmed from Washington. To get in the rear of the town of Murfreesboro, it would be necessary for BUELL to have one of his columns cross the Cumberland above Nashville, say near Gallatin, from which point there is a good turnpike to Lebanon, Wilson County; and from Lebanon, if we mistake not, there is also a good turnpike to Murfreesboro. We have no account of any such movement, although one of the columns of BUELL, marching from Bowling Green in the direction of Nashville, may have made this diversion. The town of Murfreesboro is not a defensible point. It is on the railroad from Nashville to Chattanooga, and if the rebels had command of the railroad equipment, and they were disposed to decline a battle, the way was open to retreat upon Chattanooga and Atlanta, unless really surrounded in the way we have here referred to.

abstract: -- Notwithstanding the stringent order of the Secretary of War for the suppression of military news, the Herald yesterday laid before the public a dispatch from the Upper Potomac, describing the movement of Gen. BANKS to the south side of the river. Similar intelligence was in the possession of the TIMES, but more observant of duty, we properly withheld it. It now remains to be seen whether the orders of the War Department are worthless, because unattended by a penalty; or whether the order now referred to was designed to foster and encourage a disloyal Press, defiant of all authority, by giving it advantages over journals to whom the mere suggestion of the Government, in a crisis like the present, has all the force of law. The Herald was not merely extravagant, but even fulsome in its laudation of the step taken by Mr. STANTON. It has been the first to treat it with contempt. We ask, is it to do so with impunity?
lead_paragraph: -- Notwithstanding the stringent order of the Secretary of War for the suppression of military news, the Herald yesterday laid before the public a dispatch from the Upper Potomac, describing the movement of Gen. The Herald was not merely extravagant, but even fulsome in its laudation of the step taken by Mr. STANTON. It has been the first to treat it with contempt. We ask, is it to do so with impunity?

abstract: nouncement that the Tax bill will be presented to the House of Representatives to-day will be received with profound satisfaction. The labor of framing a perfect system of direct taxation, adapted to a people who have never lent their support in this way to the Federal Government, was a task of inconceivable magnitude. A thousand conflicting interests had to be consulted, local and sectional jealousies conciliated, the burdens distributed as equitably as possible between loyal and disloyal communities, and districts which depended upon agriculture and those which depended upon commerce, and the more or less wealthy classes of society. Indeed, merely to enumerate the shallows and quicksands which had to be kept in view, would overtask him who catalogues the stars. We can only trust, from the intimations which have thus far reached us, that the Committee has done its work wisely, and that the House will be able to respond to the urgent popular demand by promptly giving its labors legislative force. There will cease to be talk of National bankruptcy the moment an adequate taxbill appears on the statute book.

We can only trust, from the intimations which have thus far reached us, that the Committee has done its work wisely, and that the House will be able to respond to the urgent popular demand by promptly giving its labors legislative force. There will cease to be talk of National bankruptcy the moment an adequate taxbill appears on the statute book.

abstract: Maryland has timely nailed another lie of JEFF. DAVIS to the counter. In the inaugura address at Richmond the other day, the insurgent chief repeated the old story that Maryland was one in interest and sympathy with the rebellious States, and only needed to be relieved from the grip of National authority to unite its fortunes with theirs. After the election of the actual State Government and Legislature by an overwhelming Union vote, it was to be expected that this particular falsity would be permitted to sleep. But such is not the practice of the rebels. The story, no truer before than since the election, is still capable of hard service in that regiment of lies, which have done such unremitting duty in the cause of rebellion, and hence the propriety of the Maryland House of Delegates burking it as effectually as they have just done. A few days ago, Hon. REVERDY JOHNSON introduced into that body a resolution declaring the assertion to be "an unfounded and gross calumny upon the people of the State," and showing that the almost universal sentiment of the population of Maryland was one of pity for the delusions of the Southern people, and indignation at the bad men who, for wicked ends, had plunged them in woes unspeakable. This resolution the House adopted by a vote of 58 to 5. The vote is all that was necessary to purge the record of the brave little State which the rebel leader has so obstinately insisted upon befouling.

abstract: James Ridgway vs. L.H. McIntosh and John W.C. Loud. -- This action was on a promissary note for $150, made by defendant McIntosh, and indorsed by defendant Loud. The making and delivering of the note were admitted on the part of the defendants, but the defendant Loud set up an agreement by which he was to have six months after the maturity of the note before he should be liable to pay, in the event of the failure of the maker to meet the obligation.
lead_paragraph: James Ridgway vs. L.H. McIntosh and John W.C. Loud. -- This action was on a promissary note for $150, made by defendant McIntosh, and indorsed by defendant Loud. The making and delivering of the note were admitted on the part of the defendants, but the defendant Loud set up an agreement by which he was to have six months after the maturity of the note before he should be liable to pay, in the event of the failure of the maker to meet the obligation.

abstract: I see the San Francisco papers are disposed to set down and perhaps to put down the new gold discoveries as humbugs. abstract: The death of Gen. LANDER at this moment is a National calamity. A daring and skillful leader, he possessed that magnetism which always inspires courage and confidence in soldiers, who cheerfully follow such leaders into the very jaws of death. For months past, ever since, indeed, he was partially disabled by the wound received at Ball's Bluff, Gen. LANDER has been waiting with unconcealed impatience for the order to advance. Commanding on the extreme right of the line, his part in the general movement would have been a brilliant one. To the opportunities it would afford him of effective service and distinction, he looked forward eagerly; and now, when the movement has actually begun, the disappointed hero drops on the very threshold of victory. We may indeed shed a tear for him; but the great loser is the country, which thus parts with one of its most trusted, experienced and gallant servants.
lead_paragraph: The death of Gen. LANDER at this moment is a National calamity. abstract: RICHMOND. -- Capt. SHELLHORN, of the schooner [???], arrived here yesterday from Baltimore, having been sent by the authorities of that city, by the Ericsson line. He reports that, at 12 o'clock on Monday last, while off the Patapsco River, a violent storm came on, and at 7 in the evening his vessel sink, covering her decks; himself, his nephew, JOSEPH S, SHROPSHIRE, aged about twenty-six, his two sons, aged fourteen and sixteen, being all the hands on board. They hoisted their small boat up into the rigging and the four hands got into it, and attempted to cover themselves from the storm with the mainsall, but it was blown into shreds. They continued in this position from 7 o'clock until 11 at night, when the two sons expired in horrible agony. Capt. SHELLHORN states they were in this situation (he having one of his dead sons frozen in his arms and Mr. SHROPSHIRE the other) until 11 o'clock on Tuesday, when they were rescued by the steamer Ajax. Mr. SHELLHORN's clothing was cut off him, and a dry suit furnished him. In his frozen clothes there were sixteen dollars, all the money he had in the world, which was stolen from him, Capt. SHELLHORN's hands and feet were badly frozen, as also were Mr. SHROPSHIRE's, and it is probable both will lose the use of their hands and feet. Their residence is on Columbia-avenue, third door west of Frankford Road, Nineteenth Ward. They are in destitute circumstances. -- Philadelphia Ledger, Feb. 28.

abstract: The following is a brief extract from a letter written by a lady in Missouri. It bears date soon after the battle of Wilson's Creek, near Springfield, and gives a touching description of the condition of the wounded and dying soldiers removed from that field of triumph and carnage.
lead_paragraph: The following is a brief extract from a letter written by a lady in Missouri. It bears date soon after the battle of Wilson's Creek, near Springfield, and gives a touching description of the condition of the wounded and dying soldiers removed from that field of triumph and carnage. The writer was devoting her time, energies and means, with other loyal ladies, to alleviate their sufferings, and to administer Christian consolation.

abstract: March has certainly come in like a lion; whether it will go out like a lamb can only be decided by the record of the future. Yesterday afternoon and last evening wore among the most severe of the season, not so much on account of the intense cold, though it was cold enough, but because the air was filled with flying snow squalls, and the wind searched into every nook and corner without any mercy.

abstract: The steamship Arabia, from Liverpool, on the 15th, and Queenstown on the 16th ult., arrived at Halifax, on Saturday, having put in short of coal. Her advices are two days later, but are not specially important. The Archduke MAXIMILIAN is said positively to have signified his acceptance of the throne of Mexico. The French papers are under the impression that the Mexican question will lead to the overthrow of the Palmerston Cabinet. Austria having protested against the views of Prussia with reference to German affairs, Prussia, in a note to Austria and the other German States, says that there appears to be no well-founded motive for such a protest. In the House of Lords, Earl RUSSELL, in reply to Lord STANHOPE, stated that Government had protested against the permanent destruction of any harbors by the stone blockade, and the American Government denied any such intention. It is understood that the address from the French Chambers is to contain a mild rebuke to the Pope for not listening to the conciliatory propositions of France for the settlement of the Roman question. The Austrian concordat is to be revised, with the consent of the Pope. The gunboat Tuscarora is reported to have proceeded to Gibraltar, where the Sumter still remained without coals. The Mason and Slidell affair cost the British Government Â£364,000. The Liverpool Cotton Market was firmer, but prices were unchanged. Breadstuffs were steady, and Provisions quiet. Consols, 92 7/8@93.

abstract: THE SIGEL DELEGATION The delegates appointed at the German mass meeting, recently held in this City, to represent it in Washington and there express the sentiments of the Germany of New-York in relation to the vexations alleged to have been undergone in Missouri by Gen. FRANZ SIGEL, met on Saturday evening at Pythagoras Hall.
lead_paragraph: THE SIGEL DELEGATION. -- The delegates appointed at the German mass meeting, recently held in this City, to represent it in Washington and there express the sentiments of the Germany of New-York in relation to the vexations alleged to have been undergone in Missouri by Gen. FRANZ SIGEL, met on Saturday evening at Pythagoras Hall. Mr. FRIEDRICH KAPP was called to the Chair and Mr. JULIUS BRILL, appointed Secretary. Mr. BALLING presented the financial report of the delegation, which was approved and arranged, whereupon, after determining to pay no attention to the public call lately made upon them by a Committee emanating from the Social Reform Verein and charged with the investigation, to some extent, of their proceedings in Washington, the delegation adjourned sine die.

abstract: Editorial favors building canal from Mississippi River to Lake Michigan; Editorial favors building canal from Mississippi River to Lake Michigan
snippet: Editorial favors building canal from Mississippi River to Lake Michigan; Editorial favors building canal from Mississippi River to Lake Michigan
lead_paragraph: We are glad to see that war, the work of destruction, does not engross the entire thoughts or labors of Congress, but that the first pause success brings is devoted to plans to render more perfect and complete the vast system of public works which is the true glory and pride of our people, and which has enabled them. though young in years, to carry a giant's burden, and crush a rebellion which all but ourselves have, to within a week or two, regarded as as un fail accompli. The mileage of the public works, the canals and railroads of the United States, exceeds, those of all other nations. They enable us to fill the warehouses of Liverpool, Havre and Bremen with wheat and corn grown 2,500 miles inland, and 6,000 miles from the consumers In their construction, we have only taken advantage of the provisions that nature kindly made in our favor. To adapt it to our wants, the Continent had to be reconstructed, by diverting its great rivers from their natural outlets, which were in inhospitable climes, far distant from the convenient seats of population, industry and commerce of the continent. The first grand achievement, the Eric Canal, turned the waters, and with them the commerce of the great lakes, into our harbor. The work has been improved till its capacity has been increased five fold. It now floats what a few years ago would have been a ship of very respectable tonnage for ocean service. Through this work there were delivered at tide-water the past year nearly 2,000,000 tons of breadstuff's, the shipment of which to foreign countries kept the balance of trade in our favor, and saved us from National bankruptcy But for this work, so noiseless, yet so efficent in its action, the rebellion would have proved, as it has been esteemed, a success. This is as palpable as the noonday sun of whose presence we are hardly conscious so long as it is in the horizon. Both foreigners and rebels persisted in declaring our impotence, simply because they never took any pains to inform themselves of ou strength and the method upon which it rests.

abstract: The casual reference, on Saturday, to the Ninth Volunteers has evoked a letter from Mr. JAMES B. WHITING in vindication of that regiment. It will be found elsewhere. We are quite disposed to accept the opinions of Judge WHITING as conclusive as to the gallantry of the corps, especially as we are not aware that that attribute has ever been called in question. We only object to undue prominence being given to any one regiment over another, where all are meritorious, and where excessive laudation of one tends to breed discontentent and disgust among the rest.

abstract: It would, perhaps, be premature to attempt a, reliable estimate of the popular sentiment in Tennessee, taking the State altogether, on the question of the rebellion. The extreme leaders in the violent and desperate act of separation last June, and a large portion of the Press, have not yet abated their madness if we are to judge by the last received news.
lead_paragraph: It would, perhaps, be premature to attempt a, reliable estimate of the popular sentiment in Tennessee, taking the State altogether, on the question of the rebellion. The extreme leaders in the violent and desperate act of separation last June, and a large portion of the Press, have not yet abated their madness if we are to judge by the last received newspaper extracts from Nashville and Memphis and some of the rumors by telegraph and through the Virginia papers. In reference to the Nashville extracts, we remark that most of them bear date before the rebel disaster a Fort Donelson. That result probably modified the temper of the editors toward the old Union. The change would not be as violent at heart as it would appear in contrast will their recent belligerent attitude. The leading journal of the city, the Republican Banner, went into the Confederate cause with the utmost reluctance, and has since manifested nothing more than a con strained support, under the plea of maintaining the independence of the State agains what is called Federal coercion. One or more of the others were Union journals to the latest moment before HARRIS and his Legislature precipitated the people into revolution. The large and wealthy County of Davidson, in which the City of Nashville and the Capitol buildings of the State are located, was largely Union in sentiment to the same unfortunate period. The interests of its people were with the Union, their most intimate social relations with Kentucky and Missouri, and their best trade with Cincinnati and the North. The property-holders, both town and country, had their dearest stake and security in the Government of the United States. For more than thirty years, first under the leadership of JACKSON and then of JOHN BELL, they had contemned the nullification and secession doctrines of South Carolina, and at one time, in the Summer of 1850, came near driving out of the city a Southern State Rights Convention, for plotting in their midst the separation of the Union. To say that these people are not ready to return to their allegiance, on the well-assured fact that our beneficent Government and its present Administration mean them no harm, to the rights of person or property, and have no other object than to put down this unnatural rebellion, and restore peace and security to their firesides, and freedom to their trade and intercourse with their old neighbors and friends, would be to utterly ignore all their political antecedents.

abstract: Editorial on NY Herald refusal to obey ban on printing military intelligence
snippet: Editorial on NY Herald refusal to obey ban on printing military intelligence
lead_paragraph: On Saturday morning the Herald published intelligence of the advance of Gen. BANKS' Division into Virginia. The TIMES, and we presume other papers, had the same news, but suppressed it, in obedience to the order issued from the War Department. We respectfully demand of the Secretary of War either the revocation of his order, or else its enforcement against the Herald. If that paper is permitted thus to disregard it with impunity, nothing but the most flagrant favoritism can insist upon its being obeyed by other journals.

abstract: Gen. BUELL telegraphed to Gen. McCLELLAN last night that the rebels have abandoned Murfreesboro, and are in full retreat towards the Tennessee River. Crossing this river will place them in Alabama, and free Middle Tennessee of every armed rebel force. Inasmuch as the enemy retreat along a railroad line, tearing up the rails as they pass, it will be difficult for Gen. BUELL to catch them.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sunday, March 2.

abstract: NARROW ESCAPE OF A RAILROAD PASSENGER TRAIN. -- The locomotive and baggage car of the Philadelphia train, due at Jersey City at 1 P.M. on Saturday, when within about three miles of the city was thrown from the track. The engine ran against a coal train standing on a turn out, doing considerable damage. The baggage car ran off on the opposite side and the orates were thrown into a ditch. The passenger cars remained upon the track and no person was injured. Some delay was caused to other trains until 7 P.M., when the obstructions were removed.

abstract: Last evening quite a crowd of people collected at the New-York Central Depot, hoping to get a sight  at the rebel Generals, BUCKNER and THOHMAN, who were expected from the West. The hopes of the crowd were dissipated, however, on learning that the propriotor of Congress Hall had received a telegram from the conductor of the sleeping-car, ordering supper for the two rebels and their escort, which they would take without alighting.
