abstract: Editorial observations on Beauregard activities
snippet: Editorial observations on Beauregard activities
lead_paragraph: rebel fortunes began to wane in the Southwest, after the fall of the stronghold at Mill Spring, BEAUREGARD was dispatched there to examine the various fortified positions held by the rebels, and to render them even more impregnable than they were -- if there be degrees of impregnability. The Southwestern rebels became jubilant as the hero of Sumter and Manassas approached. His presence was considered equivalent to a reinforcement of ten thousand ordinary rebels. If, heretofore, Bowling Green and Columbus, and the Forts on the Cumberland and Tennessee Rivers, had kept at bay the mighty armies under BUELL and HALLECK, then, after BEAUREGARD took control of them, they could defy the whole Yankee nation in arms. The great fortifier arrived at Nashville. He scanned the defences of the city with his engineering eye, and speedily passed up to Bowling Green. There he remained some time, and thence returned to Nashville. He had hardly got away from Bowling Green, however, before the rebels there began to fly from their impregnable works. They fled from Bowling Green, from Nashville, from Murfreesboro, and are still fleeing. BEAUREGARD next rushed westward to strengthen by his presence and his genius Columbus, the Sebastopol of the West, a place at whose defences the engineer of Camargo himself had labored for half a year, and which was blessed with the prayers and strengthened by the science of the reverend POLK. Add to these things BEAUREGARD, and of what avail would be the power of our armies, or the shot and shell of our river fleet? But no sooner had BEAUREGARD arrived at Columbus, than the other rebels began to run away; and now, this impregnable position, too, is in turn evacuated. Wherever BEAUREGARD goes now, he seems to be but the herald of evacuation. The rebels have heretofore declared that Memphis was impregnable, and that "Island No. 10" could easily be rendered so. But BEAUREGARD had not then visited those points. When he does reach them, and particularly if our Western army be not far off, there is little doubt, judging from the past, that he and the other rebels will suddenly evacuate. This rebel charlatan built up a sort of reputation on the strength of his bombardment of Fort Sumter, his fortifications at Manassas, and the fiasco at Bull Run. But his invincibility, even in rebel eyes, must now be gone. Henceforth, instead of being known as the great fortifier, he will figure only as the great evacuator.

abstract: Recruiting for the regular army is looking up. During the past week about 25 men and boys were enlisted for the general service, 17 of whom were sent to Governor's Island, and te remainder to Carlisled Barracks, Penn,the headquarters of the mounted service. The Fifth Artillery and the Eighth and Twelfth Infantry enlisted ten men.
lead_paragraph: Recruiting for the regular army is looking up. During the past week about 25 men and boys were enlisted for the general service, 17 of whom were sent to Governor's Island, and te remainder to Carlisled Barracks, Penn,the headquarters of the mounted service. The Fifth Artillery and the Eighth and Twelfth Infantry enlisted ten men.

abstract: There are some novels that write themselves. The author simply introduces you to the characters, sees that you are on terms of intimale acquaintance with the hero and heroine, and then steps behind the curtain. Tho work then goes on in a natural way.
lead_paragraph: There are some novels that write themselves. The author simply introduces you to the characters, sees that you are on terms of intimale acquaintance with the hero and heroine, and then steps behind the curtain. Tho work then goes on in a natural way. The men and women with whom you have been made acquainted, talk and act precisely as men and women of similar dispositions would in real life. And thus you come to regard the world to which you have been introduced as a real one. You know the hero so well, and believe in him so faithfully, that you feel like telling him which horn of a dilemma to choose when he is forked between two. You sympathize with him in his sorrows and join him in his gladness; like him you come to entertain a hearty prejudice against tailors, boot-makers, and other people of that useful but persistent stamp. And in like manner you find yourself quite at home with the heroine, advising her against bestowing her affections unworthily; confiding to her the fact that one of her admirers drinks, while the other one is addicted to transcendentalism, and that she can be happy with neither. You take an interest, for her sake, in the fashions; you would advise her in the matter of bonnets, and reprove her mildly, but firmly, if she eat fish with a knife, or violated any other moral obligation.

abstract: GOTTSCHALK'S second matinee on Saturday attracted an excellent audience to the Academy of Music, where it was given, and furnished a new confirmation of the now well-known fact that the ladies of the Metropolis require a special entertainment of their own, where they may gratify a reasonable curiosity without the formality of male escort.
lead_paragraph: GOTTSCHALK's second matinee on Saturday attracted an excellent audience to the Academy of Music, where it was given, and furnished a new confirmation of the now well-known fact that the ladies of the Metropolis require a special entertainment of their own, where they may gratify a reasonable curiosity without the formality of male escort. The experiment was so successful indeed that it will be repeated during the present week. DONIZETTI's little opera of "Betly," was performed with spirit and effect by Miss HINKLEY, Signor BRIGNOLI, Signor SUSINI, and a small chorus -- Mr. MAX MARETZEK presiding in the orchestra. The music is pretty and familiar, although the work itself is a comparative stranger to our boards. The composer has not hesitated to borrow freely from his former works. Who has so much right to do so?

abstract: Our readers will remember this splendid regiment, which passed through this City in the middle of December, in charge of its Ccioncl, LEMUEL B. PLATT, of Coichester, by whom it had been organized and equipped. The regiment went to Washington, where it remained some weeks and then, proceeded to Annapolis, where it is now stationed. Since leaving Vermont, although at the outset it was exposed to very severe hardships, Col. PLATT has not lost a man from death or desertion.

abstract: -- The reception provided by the Corporation of Brooklyn for Col. WOOD, the captive Commander of the Fourteenth Militia, will do as much honor to the city as to the object of the demonstration In the fiasco of Bull Run, Col. WOOD exhibited the best qualities of a soldier -- courage, coolness and steadiness. Wounded seriously, he was made prisoner by the enemy, who carried him to Richmond. His captivity has been lengthened not only by the injury sustained in the fight, but by chafing impatience at the detention from his command, at a time when action was needed, and was apparently impending. Time has, however, dealt kindly by the Colonel. He leaves his prison at the moment when his brave fellows once more need his presence to lead them into action. Let him, therefore, have his abounding welcome, and then, with a God speed, let him go back to Richmond a victor, not a prisoner.

abstract: FATAL BURNING ACCIDENT. -- Mrs. BARTON, wife of E.A. BARTON, residing at No. 387 Carlton-avenue, was so severely burned yesterday by her clothes taking fire, that she died within a few hours. A little son of deceased, 17 months old, who clung to his mother during the excitement, was so badly burned that his recovery is doubtful. Mrs. BARTON's clothes took fire from a small stove in the bath-room, and at the time there was no one in the house except herself, child, and a servant girl. The latter ran into the street and gave the alarm of fire, when several residents in the vicinity at once rendered assistance, but it was of no avail.

abstract: Editorial on progress of Union cause in Tennessee
snippet: Editorial on progress of Union cause in Tennessee
lead_paragraph: Government is in receipt of highly important advices from Tennessee and Kentucky. Gen. BUELL telegraphed, on Saturday night, to Gen. McCLELLAN, that Murfreesboro had been abandoned by the rebels, who were retreating along the Nashville and Chattanooga Railroad, tearing up the rails as they proceeded, thus rendering pursuit difficult. It was announced in our dispatches, yesterday, that the rebels were concentrating at Chattanooga, and this dispatch from Gen. BUELL renders this probable. Chattanooga, although in Tennessee, is very near the Georgia line, and the railroad passes through the northeast corner of Alabama, and touches the Georgia line before reaching it. A great change is found to have occurred already in the political feeling in Tennessee, and the War Department feels itself warranted in taking measures immediately to raise and arm volunteer troops in that State. The important announcement is also made by authority, in our dispatches this morning, that the Tennessee and Cumberland Rivers will be opened this week to free and unrestricted commerce, under the order of the Secretary of the Treasury. This will prove a just measure of relief to the loyal people of Tennessee, who have been subjected to the greatest deprivations during the rebel occupation of the State.

abstract: The arrangements for the reception of ALFRED M. WOOD, Colonel of the Fourteenth Regiment N.Y.S.M., were completed yesterday. Col. WOOD, it will be remembered, was severely wounded at the battle of Bull Run, was taken prisoner, and was one of the field officers selected by the rebel Government whose fate was to be determined by the fate of the rebel privateers captured by the Union forces. When the three-months' men were called for, the Fourteenth Regiment volunteered, but before the corps could be thoroughly equipped, the quota of three months' men was filled, whereupon the Fourteenth promptly volunteered for three years, or the continuance of the war.

abstract: -- The Government is evidently disposed to make a magnanimous use of its victories. It will be seen in our Washington correspondence that, while the various bills of pains and penalties, providing for confiscations and other retributive measures against rebellion, have been thrown over in the House of Representatives, there is a determination on the part of the Executive to reopen the Cumberland and Tennessee rivers to commerce. This is well. So long as we reserve a little step-fatherly treatment for those who have beguiled an unhappy people into rebellion, we can well afford to indulge the people with the most kindly and paternal consideration, seeing that so we must effectually refute the falsehoods upon which the fabric of treason rests. Let the Southern people receive some installment of the good things which the restored Union will bring them, and let them lose all fear of vindictive measures, and we shall have achieved the most important of all successes -- the conquest of their prejudices.

abstract: Editorial on imprisoned Confederate Gen. Buckner
snippet: Editorial on imprisoned Confederate Gen. Buckner
lead_paragraph: After a somewhat checkered pilgrimage, Gen. BUCKNER has, we learn, been safely lodged in Fort Warren, Boston harbor, where he will be held as a prisoner of war, till the end of the rebellion. We mention this with a sense of satisfaction which arises not merely from the fact of having so notorious a traitor in our hands, but also because there was some appearance, a little while ago, that another fate, and one that could not have failed to have caused embarrassment to the Union cause, was about to be visited upon him. It may be remembered that immediately on the capture of BUCKNER, and his transfer as a prisoner to Cairo, Judge CATRON issued a warrant for his arrest, and ten days ago, the telegraph announced that the robe General had been delivered to the Unite States Marshal, and was about to be taken to Kentucky to stand his trial before the highest tribunal of his country on the charge of treason. While fully appreciating the motive that led the noble old patriot-judge -- himself an exile from his native State of Tennessee, on account of his unflinching devotion to the Union -- to seek to bring the traitor chief to swift justice, we did not hesitate to express the opinion that the time had not yet come for a proper adjudication of the case. We are left to infer that the Administration took the same view, and that Executive interference was exercised to arrest the legal proceedings and restore the rebel General to the status of a prisoner of war.

abstract: Dies in Union camp, Virginia
snippet: Dies in Union camp, Virginia
lead_paragraph: The telegraph brings the melancholy intelligence, this morning, ihat Brig.-Gen. FREDERICK W. LANDER, the fearless soldier, the bravest of the brave, died yesterday in camp at Pau Pau,Western Virginia, from the effect of his wound received in the affair at Edwards' Ferry. There is no officer in the army whose loss could cause a more profound and universal sorrow than that of Gen. LANDER. He was beloved and trusted in the highest degree by his own command; while his character and career, as well as his actions since the war began, led the whole country to look upon him as the very beau ideal of an American soldier, and as a man from whom great and heroic things were to be expected as the war progressed.

abstract: One of the largest meetings of the members of Tammany Society was held last evening at Tammany Hall.
lead_paragraph: One of the largest meetings of the members of Tammany Society was held last evening at Tammany Hall. At the commencement of the meeting Colonel DELAVAN presided. After some business of a routine nature. NELSON J. WATERBURY was elected Grand Sachem. Upon election, he addressed the Society in a brief and patriotic manner, and alluded to the valuable services of two late members of the Society -- JAMES CONNER, and WILLIAM D. KENNEDY, who lost his life in the active service of his country.

abstract: 1. Be it crdained, &c. That it shall be the duty of the Governor, from time to time, to issue his proclamation calling for volunteers to meet the requisitions of the Confederate Government, now made, or hereafter to be made: Provided, however, That, volunteers, heretofore in service re-enlisting, shall have credit for the time they have served: Provided further: That said volunteers shall not be a longer time than three years, and to be sooner discharged in case the present war terminates before the expiration of that time: And provided further, That the Government shall not be required to keep in the Confederate service more than the regular quota of North Carolina.

abstract: A correspondent of the Dispatch, writing from Augusta, Georgia, gives the following account from an "eye-witness:"
lead_paragraph: Saturday was the Rubicon of Fort Donelson. The enemy had received strong reinforcements during the week, and now they numbered, according to their own estimates, fifty thousand men. Snow lay on the ground to the depth of three inches, and a cold, blinding steet poured incessantly in the faces of our soldiers. Still, with all these odds, they fattered not. Early in the day, the order came from head-quarters to make a vigorous attack on the right flank of the Federal army, which, [???] thousand strong, was posted of the opposite hills, under command of Gen. GRANT. Not more than ten thousand of our were engaged in this movement, but such was the impetuosity of their advance, that the enemy [???] in confusion from their entrenchments.

abstract: -- It will be seen from an announcement in another column, that a meeting is to be held this evening at the Cooper Institute, with a view to the establishment in this City of a reformatory for the rescue of such victims of the social evil as are anxious to escape from infamy, and regain their lost position as useful and reputable members of society. Excepting Paris and Vienna, there is perhaps no modern city where the number of fallen women is so large in proportion to the population. And yet, notwithstanding our boasted civilization, few efforts have been systematically made among us for the benefit of these friendless outcasts. In London, various benevolent societies have established some half-dozen Magdalen asylums, and by their labors thousands of women have been enabled to retrieve their position, and to enter on a new life of honesty and good repute. Scarcely a large town in England is without an institution of this philanthropic character. In New-York, we trust that the plans which have been found so successful in Great Britain, will be efficiently and wisely set in operation, and we are quite sure that if prudence, zeal, and sagacity preside over the labors of the new institution, the requisite funds will not be wanting.

abstract: We have already published the most important part of the extended correspondence that passed between our Minister at London and Earl RUSSELL with regard to the Nashville. The first vigorous protest of Mr. ADAMS has, however, not hitherto been published, and we give it in another column, as an interesting historical document. It will be observed that our Minister puts the conduct of the Nashville in its true light -- indignantly declaring that the willful burning of a private merchant ship "approximates too closely within the definition of piracy to receive the smallest countenance from any Christian people." He then proceeds to state his conviction that Her Majesty's Government will visit with its utmost indignation any attempt to seek shelter under its jurisdiction from the consequences of indulging in unauthorized acts of violence on the ocean. And he further protests that the Nashville shall not be allowed to carry out the purpose for which she crossed the ocean, to wit: "The making more effective preparations in the ports of Great Britain for carrying on a war against the people of a friendly (to Great Britain) nation."

lead_paragraph: Last evening a meeting of Tammany Society was held, in order to elect a Grand Sachem, which resulted in the return of Mr. NELSON J. WATERBURY. After which several gentlemen were installed as members of the society, among them were JAMES T. BRADY, Judge HEARNE, ANDREW V. STOUT, Capt. JOSEPH DOWLING, and others. Col. COGSWELL, of the Tammany Regiment, who has just returned from Richmond, having been taken a prisoner at Ball's Bluff, had a reception given him by the Society. Speeches were made, and the whole affair was one of a; most pleasing nature.

abstract: Editorial on rapid succession of Union victories in Southwest
snippet: Editorial on rapid succession of Union victories in Southwest
lead_paragraph: -- The complaints heretofore so frequently and justly made of the failure of our military leaders to follow up the successes achieved at different points, do not, certainly, apply to the Generals commanding in the Southwest. On the 6th of last month Fort Henry was assailed and taken; on the 12th our army was before Fort Donelson, and on the 16th, after three days' fighting, the fort fell; on the 17th our army was in Clarksville; on the 22d it was in Nashville, over a hundred miles above Fort Donelson; and now it is again in pursuit of the flying enemy. By these operations we compelledthe rebels to evacuate Bowling Green, Russelville and Gallatin, which were at once occupied by detachments of our troops; we also compelled them to evacuate Columbus and Hickman, which are likewise, doubtless, now in our possession. Neither have our Western columns paused yet anywhere to rest, or to fortify, or to battle with the enemy's pickets. A second gunboat reconnoissance has been made up into Alabama; and the officer in command has, in an official dispatch, asked for a detachment of troops to go to a point in that State; from three other directions in Tennessee, also, operations are going on. looking to the possession of points only second in importance to Nashville, and which, if they prove successful, will speedily entirely rid the State of rebel soldiers. If, when Fort Henry was captured, Gen. GRANT had sat down and commenced strengthening his position -- if he had begun operations against unhappy newspaper reporters, or made an attempt to solve the Slavery question, the probability is that the rebels would by this time have had Clarksville so strongly fortified, and the Cumberland and Tennessee rivers so thickly lined with batteries, as to preclude any movement of our army or navy for mouths; while the rebel Legislature at Nashville would have gone on binding Tennessee still more firmly to the Government of JEFF. DAVIS, and the cruel persecution of Union men would still have been carried on all over the State.
headline: {'main': 'FOLLOWING UP SUCCESSES--RAPID AND BRILLIANT MOVEMENTS IN THE SOUTHWEST.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'FOLLOWING UP SUCCESSES--RAPID AND BRILLIANT MOVEMENTS IN THE SOUTHWEST.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Chauncey Rose, Executor, vs. Henry Rose et al,  ALLEN, J. The interesting and important questions involved in this action, and elaborately argued by counsel, call for a deliberate and careful examination and consideration by the Court. To my regret,
lead_paragraph: Chauncey Rose, Executor, vs. Henry Rose et al. -- ALLEN, J. -- The interesting and important questions involved in this action, and elaborately argued by counsel, call for a deliberate and careful examination and consideration by the Court. To my regret, however, I have been unable, since the trial, to devote any time to the case, and some weeks must elapse before I can give the case that attention which it deserves. A further delay in the decision would be unjust to the parties, especially as the result of any consideration I might give the case, and any decision I might make, would not be final, or materially aid the parties. The amount in controversy, and the nature and difficulty of the questions involved in the action under it, render it certain that the judgment of this Court, at Special or General Term, will be but steps in the progress of the suit -- the judgment of the Court of last resort only will terminate the litigation, and it is fit that it should be so in a case of this character and importance.

abstract: THE CAB BILL --DISTRIBUTIONS TO THE FAMILIES OF VOLUNTEERS. -- The Board of Councilmen met yesterday evening at the usual hour -- Councilman PINCKNEY in the Chair. The attendance was full, and a considerable amount of general business was brought up; communications and reports in number were referred to appropriate Committees. Councilman LENT of offered a resolution to the effect that permission be given to the North, eastern Dispensary of the City of New-York to occupy the building on the southeast corner of Lexington-avenue, which was amended so as to read at the close, "for three mouths," and then it was carried. General order No. 9, was a resolution in reference to memorializing the Legislature against the passage of the "Cab bill." It was called up and laid over. A communication from the Comptroller, transmitting a statement of the disbursements male, during the month of February last, to the families of volunteers from this City, was received. The number of families obtaining obtaining relief was 13,054, to wit: adults, 12,003; children, 17,504 -- total number of individuals, 30,407, and sum total expended, $131,700. The Board, adjourned until 5 P.M., Monday next.

abstract: Editorial on Confederate problem of what crops to plant now that they have over supply of cotton; Editorial notes Confederate States over-supply of cotton; Editorial on Confederate States problem of what crops to plant
snippet: Editorial on Confederate problem of what crops to plant now that they have over supply of cotton; Editorial notes Confederate States over-supply of cotton; Editorial on Confederate States problem of what crops to plant
lead_paragraph: It is the misfortune of the rebellion that its day of adversity has come at the very moment when all its interests are calling most loudly for delay. Had the National victories been postponed a little longer, who, except Mr. YANCEY, is prophet enough to say what would have been the result of the rebel machinations and misrepresentations on the Parliament just convened in England? Had those victories come a few weeks later, Mr. DAVIS, perhaps, would have been able to have made some arrangements about supplying the places or obtaining the satisfactory reenlistment of the soldiers whose term of service is now so nearly out; at least the season of planting would have passed, and the character of the crop would have been fixed for the year.
headline: {'main': 'What Shall the Southerners Plant?', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'What Shall the Southerners Plant?', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: From Tennessee and the Southwest, we do not learn of any new army movements, There seems to be no doubt that the rebels have not only evacuated their fortifications at Columbus, but have also burnt down the town.
lead_paragraph: From Tennessee and the Southwest, we do not learn of any new army movements, There seems to be no doubt that the rebels have not only evacuated their fortifications at Columbus, but have also burnt down the town. Two gunboats had again ascended the Tennessee River, and had [???] an engagement with a party of rebels -- the result of which was the repulse of the latter with slaughter. The Memphis papers confirm the news we have previously had of our army movements in Central Tennessee; but the Appeal says that a deep gloom pervades the citizens of Nashville, and that they avoid intercourse with the invaders. The journals strongly urge the rebel Government to pursue an aggressive policy. The State Legislature met at Memphis on the 27th, but adjourned for want of a quorum. An election for local officers had been held in Hardin County, Tenn., and the Union ticket was chosen by a light vote but a heavy majority. Railroad communication between Louisville and Nashville will be at once resumed. The mails, so far as soldiers' letters are concerned, now run regularly to Nashville. At a municipal election at the latter city, the retiring Mayor promised the citizens Federal protection, if they remained quiet. The rebel army has evacuated Murfreesboro, and seems to be still pursuing a southward course. With the establishment of a loyal and legitimate Government, the rebellion, as a military fact, will very speedily be extinguished in Tennessee.

abstract: Editorial on arrival of Confederate privateer Nashville at Wilmington, Del
snippet: Editorial on arrival of Confederate privateer Nashville at Wilmington, Del
lead_paragraph: We are not at all surprised to hear that the Nashville has made her appearance on this side of the Atlantic. The recent proclamation of the British Government, prohibiting armed vessels of either the United States or the rebels from entering any British port, (a measure which, by the way, they were moved to adopt in consequence of the nervous flutter caused by the arrival at Southampton of the U.S. gunboat Tuscarora, to lie in wait for this very Nashville,) was in reality a death-blow to the rebel privateers; and the valiant PEGRAM, seeing his chivalrous occupation of burning defenceless merchantmen gone, doubtless thought it prudent to turn his pirate prow homeward, and run the chance of dodging into some rebel rat-hole. Accordingly, on the 3d of February, the Nashville left Southampton -- the sinister twenty-four hours' law, adopted by the British authorities, giving her two hundred miles start, (a British man-of-war, with ports open, stood guard over the Tuscarora while the rebel vessel steamed down the Solent,) and rendering pursuit useless. The game having escaped, the Tuscarora is reported to have proceeded to the Mediterranean to watch the remaining pirate ship, the Sumter; and the Nashville was left free to make her way back to the American shores of the Atlantic, where she turns up at Wilmington, N.C., after running the blockade.
headline: {'main': 'The Nashville at Wilmington.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Nashville at Wilmington.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: James Calanan, Jr., et al. vs. Jasper T. Van Vleck, et al. This was an action to recover the balance of an account which had been transferred from the books of one firm to the books of another, as successors. The facts are that prior to June 1, 1857, one
lead_paragraph: James Calanan, Jr., et al. vs. Jasper T. Van Vleck, et al. -- This was an action to recover the balance of an account which had been transferred from the books of one firm to the books of another, as successors. The facts are that prior to June 1, 1857, one A.J. Stevens was engaged in the business of banking at Fort Des Moines, Iowa, under the name of A.J. Stevens & Co., and opened a bank account in such name with defendants' house in New-York. Stevens at that time had no partners, but of this defendants, as alleged, were ignorant. In April, 1857, defendants received a letter from A.J. Stevens & Co., directing them to pay John Thompson for such packages of the Agricultural Bunk of Tennessee, as he might hand the in and forward the same to A.J. Stevens & Co., and charge the same to them. These instructions, as claimed, were never countermanded. The defendants acted under thorn until August, 1857. In June, 1857, the plaintiffs, Calanan and Ingham, were admitted as partners in the firm of A.J. Stevens & Co. This fact was made known to the defendants by letter, which contained the signatures of Stevens and Ingham, and requested defendants to render a statement of "our account" to that date. Defendants continued to purchase and remit bills of said bank to A.J. Stevens & Co.

abstract: BARNUM'S MUSEUM. A new spectacle piece, called "Sadak and Kalasrade," was produced here last evening, with the quiet success which usually characterizes the ventures of Mr. BARNUM'S management, and which can be accounted for by the fact  that the majority of the audience is invariably composed of the sotter sex.
lead_paragraph: BARNUM's MUSEUM. -- A new spectacle piece, called "Sadak and Kalasrade," was produced here last evening, with the quiet success which usually characterizes the ventures of Mr. BARNUM'S management, and which can be accounted for by the fact that the majority of the audience is invariably composed of the sotter sex. It is, as its name indicates, of oriental origin, and rejoices in much splendor of scenery and costume. The head of the royal house of Persia is involved in a serious flirtation with the wife of Sadak, leader of the forces and Gen. MCCLELLAN of the period. He goes so far as to carry the lady off, and imprison her in a room furnished with a huge Aloe -- a gold bird like the one on the top of the flag-staff of the St. Nicholas Hotel, and a sofa. The virtue of the General's wife, the wrongs of the valorous Sadak, and the perfidy of the Sultan, are the chosen themes of the dramatist, who, we may add, has improved them in a popular way, and with "a single eye" to effect. Incident crowds upon incident; fight; upon fight; moral triumph upon moral triumph; until at length the wicked Sultan is dethroned, and the plucky and pure Sadak elected in his place.

abstract: The House Committee of Ways and Means yesterday, reported their bill for raising a revenue from internal taxes or Excise duties, for the support of the Government and the payment of interest on the Public debt. This subject, comparatively new to the revenue legislation of the General Government, was placed in charge of a Sub-Committee some weeks ago; since when their labors have been almost incessant, and of the most trying and difficult nature.
lead_paragraph: The House Committee of Ways and Means yesterday, reported their bill for raising a revenue from internal taxes or Excise duties, for the support of the Government and the payment of interest on the Public debt. This subject, comparatively new to the revenue legislation of the General Government, was placed in charge of a Sub-Committee some weeks ago; since when their labors have been almost incessant, and of the most trying and difficult nature. The first results were brought before the whole Committee in the shape of a general bill, and this, in turn, was worked upon until a unanimous conclusion and report was arrived at. The bill, therefore, comes before the House and the country with the highest sanction of deliberation and unanimity in the committee, and if not the perfection of wisdom, the measure is at least entitled to the prompt and liberal support of the House, and the generous indulgence of the tax-payers. Of course, the same unanimity among the latter, as with the framers of the bill, is hardly to be expected. Nearly every class will probably find something to complain of -- ofundue burthens in one direction -- of in. equalities in another; and, it may be, of (suppressed) opposition in the third. But in the main, we have a right to assume, that the provisions of the bill have been as justly balanced as the nature of this mode of taxation would permit, and that the weighty burthens are made to fall upon the articles and occupations which are best able to support them. But whether this be strictly so or not, it would be utterly impossible to frame a system of excise and income taxes to please all parties, and the very best compromise to be aimed at, in the present condition of the country, the exigences of the Government and the paramount duty of maintaining the public credit, is that which shall secure the most certain as well as the amplest revenue at the lightest expense and annoyance of collection.
headline: {'main': 'The Internal Tax Bill.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Internal Tax Bill.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Editorial on Government suppression of war news
snippet: Editorial on Government suppression of war news
lead_paragraph: The first law of political economy is that mischief always results from intermeddling with the laws of trade. Interference with the currents of public intelligence and opinion is no less hazardous. Yesterday the City was agitated with the most painful rumors in regard to the military events of last week. It was freely asserted on the voucher of private authority, that Gen. BANKS, after passing the Potomac, had met with a serious disaster; that Gen. LANDER had been killed in battle; that the reverse would cause a postponement of operations for a fortnight at least. It was equally current that the conduct of Gen. McCLELLAN had incurred the severest censure of the administration, insomuch that a substitute would have to be found for him before a general advance should be made in earnest. Wild and improbable as these rumors were, they were in the mouths of everybody. They carried dismay to thousands of hearts; they depressed the stock market. In the ordinary course of things, nothing of the sort could have happened. So long as the public had reason to confide in the Press having full and authentic details of all that was occurring, it had only to inspect the bulletin board, or await the evening edition, to correct flying rumors. But the order of the War Department has changed this. The lies contrived by the malicious and mischievous, or by the speculator anxious to affect the movements of Wall-street, have now Government warrant for their currency; while the truth is placed in the index. No obstruction stands in the way of the freest circulation of falsehood; the War Office censorship applies only to facts.
headline: {'main': 'The Suppression of War News.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Suppression of War News.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Yesterday morning at 7 o'clock, JOHN DORSEY and JOHN MORRISON procceded to a place two miles south of Factoryville, Staten island, and engaged in a personal conflict, which lasted one hour and thirty-seven minutes. Forty-two rounds were fought. MORRISON was severely punished, and was taken from the field by his friends in a nearly blinded condition. DORSEY received some heavy blows. About forty persons were present. The whole affair was man aged without any interference on the part of the authorities.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, the credentials of Hon. JOSEPH A. WRIGHT, appointed from Indiana in place of BRIGHT, were presented, and he took his seat. A petition was presented from citizens of New-York, asking Congress to reduce to a territory South Carolina, Georgia and Florida. Peti
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday, the credentials of Hon. JOSEPH A. WRIGHT, appointed from Indiana in place of BRIGHT, were presented, and he took his seat. A petition was presented from citizens of New-York, asking Congress to reduce to a territory South Carolina, Georgia and Florida. Petitions asking that the full rank of Major-General be conferred upon Gen. WOOL, were also presented. The bill requiring the oath of allegiance to be administered to captains of American vessels was passed. The bill to encourage enlistments in the regular army, and the bill for the better organization of the cavalry, were briefly debated in turn, and laid aside. The bill for the organization of the Staff of Division was passed. A joint resolution, authorizing the President to appoint as many Assistant Adjutant-Generals, and other officers of the Staff, as in his judgment the service requires, was passed. The confiscation bill was then considered, and Mr. MCDOUGALL, of California, made a speech against its passage, occupying the time until the Senate went into Executive Session.

abstract: This evening, in the Cooper Institute, a meeting will be held, under the auspices of the Mayor and other gentlemen, to discuss the plans proposed by Miss EMMA HARDINGE to rescue from a life of shame and vice such young females as are weary of infamy, and anxious for reformation.
lead_paragraph: This evening, in the Cooper Institute, a meeting will be held, under the auspices of the Mayor and other gentlemen, to discuss the plans proposed by Miss EMMA HARDINGE to rescue from a life of shame and vice such young females as are weary of infamy, and anxious for reformation. It is stated that in New-York there are at present more than six thousand public prostitutes, the majority of whom are from fifteen to twenty-five years of age. Three-eighths of the number are natives of this country; many of them, born abroad, came here poor, but virtuous, and hoped to improve their condition and gain a respectable place in society by emigrating to a free country. The average duration of life among these degraded victims of licentiousness is only four years. But, though their numbers are thus thinned by the ravages of disease and death, the fallen sisterhood is continually augmenting. Destitution, intemperance, seduction, and other causes, recruit their ranks. A capital of neatly four millions of dollars is invested in this horrid traffic in infamy; and an annual expenditure of more than seven millions of dollars shows the vast proportions which the social evil has assumed in this City. Under these circumstances, it is surprising that so little has heretofore, been done to protect or reclaim those young women who, though fallen, long for an opportunity to rise again, to abandon evil courses, and to take some humble and useful place in society. In Europe great success has attended the operations of Magdalen Asylums, and it has, therefore, been determined by some, of our influential philanthropic citizens to adopt a similar plan in this City. We hope that the meeting which is to be held this evening in furtherance of these views will be largely attended. The following correspondence has been forwarded to us en the subject:

abstract: Editorials on plan to create new US Judicial District in NYS
snippet: Editorials on plan to create new US Judicial District in NYS
lead_paragraph: One of the greatest difficulties which lawmakers have to contend with is ignorance of the facts concerning which they are called to legislate. How can it be otherwise? Consider the innumerable subjects which come before Congress from all parts of the country, in respect to each one of which Congress is required to adopt the best measure practicable. It is not possible but that in many things it should fail merely from ignorance. It is impossible that all of its members should thoroughly investigate every subject for themselves, and they do not do it. In many, if not most cases, the great mass rely upon the statements of some one who they think ought to know the facts of the case, while, if they were to inquire into it, they would perhaps find that he was acting upon entirely erroneous information, received, perhaps, from a biased or an interested source. It is the easiest thing in the world to be mistaken as to facts, and in consequence to adopt erroneous views or urge mistaken measures. Take, for instance, the proposed bill creating a Solicitor of Customs, which was urged mainly upon two grounds, both of which, on investigation, proved to be entirely erroneous. If the bill is ever brought up before Congress, we shall not beat all surprised to see them both brought up again, and the bill urged forward on the ground of those mythical six hundred suite against the Government, and that mythical $20,000 a year paid by the Government to extra counsel in revenue cases.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, favorable reports were made on the bills to amend the General Railroad law, to repeal the act authorizing the formation of town and insurance companies, and to authorize the Brooklyn Common Council to fix the names and numbers of streets in that city. The bill to provide for the distribution of soldiers' allotments was also reported favorably, and referred to the first Committee of the Whole. The bill to incorporate the Metropolitan Cab Company was reported unfavorably, but the report was laid on the table. Among the bills introduced was one to provide for the assessment of real estate for labor on the highways, and one to provide for the selection of jurors in Courts of Justices of the Peace. The bill to enforce the responsibility of stockholders in banking associations was debated in Committee of the Whole. A bill to authorize the Commissioners of the New-York Sinking Fund to sell certain lands was introduced.

abstract: It is reported that insurances are daily effected on ships and their cargoes to run the blockade of the Southern ports. The highest premium paid is fifteen guineas, and the ships are entitled to select any port. In some instances the risk to ports easy of access are as low se ten guineas. Nearly all the vessels insured are steamers of 1,500 tons.

abstract: editorial on occupation
snippet: editorial on occupation
lead_paragraph: There can be no longer any doubt touching the intention of the Allies to make an effort to impose a king on Mexico. Earl RUSSELL'S declaration, in a letter quoted in these columns the other day sets the matter at rest. "If the Mexican people," says his lordship, "by a spontaneous movement place the Austrian Archduke on the throne, there is nothing in the Convention to prevent it." Of course not. It if Mexican people, of their own free will, think proper to abjure republicanism, and to give themselves a master, in the person of the Archduke MAXIMILIAN, they have an unquestionable right to do so. But if a throne be not erected in Mexico, and MAXIMILIAN do not wear a crown, until this happens, it is not very probable that either event will ever occur; and if they should occur through the instrumentality of the ballot-box, and foreign mercenaries, and domestic traitors, that will be no more a "spontaneous movement," on the part of the Mexican people, than the surrender of his purse to the bandit is a spontaneous movement on the part of the helpless wayfarer. Whatever be the result, however, the combined Powers, we presume, are determined to make the experiment in Mexico; but, should they succeed there, it must not be concluded that they will then rest from their labors. Ambition grows by what it feeds on, and success in Mexico will not improbably encourage them to repeat the operation in the other Spanish-American Republics. Those Republics have been all offenders, in the same way, if not to the same extent, as their more Northern sister; like her, they are debtors to European capitalists; like her, they are turbulent and anarchical. Hence there will be just as valid ground for intervention in their case, as in Mexico. But is not the idea too absurd to have been conceived by that coalition? Not at all. The Church of Rome has her Society for the Propagation of the Faith; why should there not also exist an Association of States for the propagation of king, craft?

abstract: -A feeling of theutmost surprise pervaded the City last evening, upon the announcement that Mr. W.B. TAYLOR had been removed the New-York Post-office, to make way for Mr. [???] WAKEMAN, to Mr. TAYLOR Has filled the position to the entire satisfaction of our people. His appointment was unanimously approved his removal has not, we believe, been sought by any portion of the community. It is, therefore, in manifest disregard of the wishes and sentiments of our people, that this old and meritorious public servant has been displaced. It will be a matter of curious inquiry hereafter to ascertain what influences have been brought to bear upon the Postmaster-General to procure the change.

abstract: Mr. IVERSON, of Georgia, formerly Senator (along with TOOMBS) for that State, announces in a Southern journal, that he has "retired from public life." What may be the character of the honors he has enjoyed under the "Confederacy," and whose fardel he thus solemnly puts off, we know not; for IVERSON, though entering heart and soul into the secession movement, has been rather under a cloud during the Confederate regime. Probably, however, he simply means to indicate his unwillingness in the future to become a candidate for any official position. IVERSON is evidently a prudent man, and has a keen scent of what is coming. His example will soon have a great many imitators in gentlemen desirous of "retiring from public life." Probably, those who have behaved no worse than the Ex-Senator from Georgia may be allowed quietly to withdraw to the political death they court; but there are others who will be very anxious to "retire from public life," whose desire the hangman will be called on to gratify in a way they hardly yet dream of.

abstract: Tuesday, the gunboat Conestoga was ordered to proceed from Cairo to this place, for the purpose of conveying orders to such of the gunboat fleet as might be up the Cumberland River. The substance of the order was, I suppose, that all the boats which could be spared, should, together with the mortarboats, report immediately at Cairo, with a view to operations down the Mississippi River.

abstract: -Sincethe opening of Parliament and the declaration of the pacific policy of the English Government, the London Times, with its usual inconstancy, has hastened to revise some of its opinions on American affairs. In an amusing article replete with splenetic virulence and affected candor, our cotemporary recently acknowledged the efficiency of the Southern blockade, though he has persistently labored to prove the contrary for several months past. The price of cotton, he says, and the inability of the secession emigres to return to their homes without imminent danger of a dungeon in Fort Lafayette or Fort Warren, prove that the investing squadron are keeping up a blockade of a tolerably efficient character. As a the Times has thus discovered and confessed one of his numerous mistakes relative to our affairs, we may expect that he will soon revise his opinions on certain other points regarding which he has been equally positive and equally in the wrong,

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a memorial from merchants on the Pacific Coast was presented, asking Government to provide immediately for the transportation of the mails between New-York, Panama and Aspinwall, as at present there is no such arrangement. Mr. DIXON, of Connecticut, offered a joint resolution appointing HENRY BARNARD to fill the vacancy in the Board of Regents of the Smithsonian Institute, made vacant by the death of Prof. FELTON. It was referred to the Library Committee. The bill for the safe-keeping and maintenance of prisoners of war was passed. The bill authorizing the President to appoint a Commissioner to confer with British and French Commissioners relative to the preservation of the Atlantic fisheries, was passed. A bill was passed directing that the presents from the King of Siam be deposited among the curiosities of the Department of the Interior. After some further business of minor importance, the Confiscation bill was taken up, and Mr. MCDOUGALL, of California, concluded his speech against its passage, commenced on Monday. Mr. COWAN, of Pennsylvania, also made a speech opposing its passage.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, a memorial from merchants on the Pacific Coast was presented, asking Government to provide immediately for the transportation of the mails between New-York, Panama and Aspinwall, as at present there is no such arrangement. Mr. DIXON, of Connecticut, offered a joint resolution appointing HENRY BARNARD to fill the vacancy in the Board of Regents of the Smithsonian Institute, made vacant by the death of Prof. FELTON. It was referred to the Library Committee. The bill for the safe-keeping and maintenance of prisoners of war was passed. The bill authorizing the President to appoint a Commissioner to confer with British and French Commissioners relative to the preservation of the Atlantic fisheries, was passed. A bill was passed directing that the presents from the King of Siam be deposited among the curiosities of the Department of the Interior. After some further business of minor importance, the Confiscation bill was taken up, and Mr. MCDOUGALL, of California, concluded his speech against its passage, commenced on Monday. Mr. COWAN, of Pennsylvania, also made a speech opposing its passage.

abstract: A National gunboat went down from Cairo to Columbus on Monday, and it was discovered that the rebels had really fled, having removed their guns and laid the town in ashes. It is now said that they have retreated to Fort Randolph, 160 miles below Columbus. Commodore FOOTE's dispatch to the Navy Department states that his armed reconnoissance on Sunday last caused the rebels then remaining there to beat a hasty retreat, leaving behind them a number of guns, carriages, ammunition and stores, shot and shell, anchors, the remnants of a chain lately stretched across the river, and a large number of torpedoes. Most of the huts, tents and quarters were destroyed. The works are described as of great strength. After the rebel evacuation, the town was first occupied by the Second Illinois Cavalry.
lead_paragraph: A National gunboat went down from Cairo to Columbus on Monday, and it was discovered that the rebels had really fled, having removed their guns and laid the town in ashes. Most of the huts, tents and quarters were destroyed. The works are described as of great strength. After the rebel evacuation, the town was first occupied by the Second Illinois Cavalry.

abstract: In the House of Lords, on the 14th ult., the Earl of STANNOPE rose to put a question to the Foreign Secretary in reference to a report which had just reached this country that a second squadron of ships, laden with stone, had been dispatched by the Government of the United States, to be sunk in Maffitt's Channel, in front of Charleston harbor, and also that a third squadron, laden in a similar manner, was in progress of equipment for a similar object. He wished to know from the noble Earl whether he had received any dispatches from Washington in confirmation of that report, and, if so, what course he intended to take in the matter. The former dispatches of the noble Earl had laid before the American Government in so comprehensive a form, and with such unanswerable arguments, the considerations which ought to guide them in regard to such enterprises, that he had hoped that it had settled the question. [Hear, hear.] That dispatch seemed to be a most worthy sequel to the policy with respect to American affairs, which all parties were agreed in thinking had done so much credit to the noble Earl, and had so fully vindicated the honor of the country, and to the approbation which had already been bestowed on that policy he begged to add his humble meed of praise. It was difficult to see how the sinking of large ships laden with stone on banks of mud at the entrance of a harbor could end in anything else but the permanent destruction of that harbor; and it was on that ground, as far as he could understand, that the measure was originally put forward and afterwards justified. The permanent destruction of a harbor was not justified by the laws of war. [Hear, hear.] War undoubtedly sanctioned many grievous acts, but it did not sanction any act of this kind. [Hear.] The permanent destruction of a harbor was not an act of war of man against man, or of nation against nation, but it was an act of war against the bounty of Providence, which had vouchsafed harbors for the advantage of commerce and for the civilizing influences of intercourse between one people and another. [Hear, hear.] On this ground we were well entitled and were bound to enter a protest against such acts. [Hear, hear.] He wished to hear from the noble Earl whether these reports were well founded, and, if so, whether he had taken or designed to take any steps in the matter. He should also wish to know whether the noble Earl had received any communication from the Government of France on the subject, and whether the Government of France, to his official knowledge, had made any similar representations to the Government of the United States with respect to the destruction of the Port of Charleston.

abstract: After a political existence of more than seventy years, we have for the first time been driven into a system of internal taxation is a permanent policy or measure -- a system which will connect nearly every act or enjoyment with a contribution into the National Treasury. We have left behind, and perhaps forever, the golden era in our history which, but for the experience we have furnished, would in after ages have been regarded as one of those fictions that set off the excellencies and immunities of that primitive epoch which every nation pictures to itself as realizing its highest conception of the social condition. Our Government was inexpensive, so long as no one attempted its overthrow. But the spirit of discord that has been let loose has instantly brought our expenses up to those of a first-class Power. We are called upon, in a day, to provide a revenue which, with other nations, has been the work of generations, if not of centuries.

abstract: William S. McNamara vs. Charles G. Anthony -- This was an action against the defendant as guarantee for the performance of a certain contract. The plaintiff alleged that in consideration of the assignment of a contract, and for building certain houses, one John B. Mill agreed to pay him certain sums of money. That the defendant in this action, in consideration of one dollar, guaranteed the performance of the contract by said Mee. That Mee had failed to perform the contract, and notice thereof had been given to the defendant. The defence set up was that plaintiff did not finish the houses according to the specifications, and according to pattern houses referred to in said agreement; nor in the time specified. The plaintiff showed that he followed the specifications. The Court charged the jury that as matter of law, the plaintiff was bound to follow the specifications, and not the pattern houses. Verdict for plaintiff, $3,754 50. An allowance of $100 was ordered thereon.
lead_paragraph: William S. McNamara vs. Charles G. Anthony -- This was an action against the defendant as guarantee for the performance of a certain contract. The plaintiff showed that he followed the specifications. The Court charged the jury that as matter of law, the plaintiff was bound to follow the specifications, and not the pattern houses. abstract: The kindly things the President said yesterday to Mr. BARREDA, the Peruvian Minister, were not only wise but timely. At the very hour the telegraph was flashing the statement that Spain is considering the propriety of furnishing the Incas with a successor in the person of some, princeling of the Bourbon line; and that the deeds of PIZARRO will, probably be emulated as soon as those of CORTEZ have been reenacted; at such a moment the bonds between the republics of the New World cannot be too closely drawn. The time may not be distant when a Holy Alliance between all the peoples of this hemisphere may be required to establish a balance of power, by expelling from it all European intruders.

abstract: Judge BETTS announced to the bar, this morning, that after hearing prize and seizure cases, he would take up the Admiralty Calendar. The Assistant District-Attorney said he should not be able to occupy the Court with that class of cases for more than this week of the present month, and the Court thereupon announced that on Monday of next week the Admiralty Calendar would be called on, and that there would be no jury causes heard this term.
lead_paragraph: Judge BETTS announced to the bar, this morning, that after hearing prize and seizure cases, he would take up the Admiralty Calendar. The Assistant District-Attorney said he should not be able to occupy the Court with that class of cases for more than this week of the present month, and the Court thereupon announced that on Monday of next week the Admiralty Calendar would be called on, and that there would be no jury causes heard this term.

abstract: -- We copy from the Tribune, in other columns, a highly important letter addressed by Maj.-Gen. FREMONT to the Senate Committee on the conduct of the war. Under a variety of charges affecting his military competency and discretion -- charges some of which found official indorsement in the report of the House Committee on Army Contracts and others in the extraordinary report of Adj.-Gen. THOMAS -- Gen. FREMONT has remained quiet for some months. Why this tardiness of response, we are unable to say; but silence is now broken, and an issue is fairly raised between the accused and his prosecutors. The whole country will read Gen. FREMONT's defence with the profoundest interest.

abstract: The Report of the Commissioners of Charities and Correction for last year has been presented to the Legislature. It is a document of interest and importance to every tax-payer, philanthropist and citizen. The public institutions in charge of the Commissioners are intended to furnish relief to almost every kind and form of suffering and want that exists in this great City; and the taxes levied for their support are intended to supersede, in ordinary cases, the necessity for private charity. It is well, on behalf of the poor, that a Board composed of such men as this is, is in continual session, and ever ready to relieve their wants; and it is well on behalf of the community which sustains these charities, that such men can be retained for their honest and economical management. The work of the Commissioners extends over a large ground, and in every Department there are evidences of the most judicious management. It gives but little idea of the variety and complexity of the duties devolving upon them to maintain the Departments with which their labor is divided, and the institutions under their charge -- the relief of the "out-door poor," the care of the great hospitals, Bellevue, Small-pox, Ward's Island and Blackwell's Island, the management of the Alms-house, the Work-house, the Lunatic Asylum, the Colored Home, and Colored Orphan Asylum, the City Prison, Penitentiary, etc. To those who do not personally inspect the practical working of these social charities and corrective institutions, no conception can be had of the amount of suffering relieved, of the burdens which are taken from the shoulders of the individual citizen, or of the labor devolving upon their managers. The condition of the buildings is in every case admirable; the provision for the inmates is as near complete as is possible with an economical expenditure; the medical attention to the sick is as perfect as the science of medicine can suggest; lunatics, vagrants and criminals are put under moral discipline that has been attended with the happiest results; and the children of the street have, as far as they are within the purview of the Commissioners, been trained to order, industry, intelligence and virtue. All this has been done with a careful economy with which not the most thrifty can complain. Though the amount of relief afforded was far greater than under the mixed Commission, which existed up to 1859, yet the expenditures of last year were less than those of 1859 by nearly a hundred thousand dollars. In fact, looking from any direction at the year's work of theCommission of Public Charities and Correction, and even the most rigid critic can award little but praise. The citizens of New-York owe much to the gentlemen composing it; and it is pleasant, after examining both the report and the work represented by it, to express the conviction that, in no city in the world are the public charities better managed than in this Metropolis.

abstract: In the House of Lords, Feb. 18, Lord CARNARVON called attention to the arrest of SHAVER, a British subject, by the American Government, and his imprisonment in Fort Warren. As Mr. SHAVER had suffered much in health, and been in imminent peril of his life, Lord CARNARVON considered that it was especially a case for compensation, accompanied with expressions of regret on the part of the American Government. He wished, therefore, to know whether any claim for compensation had been made by Her Majesty's Government, and whether there would be any objection to lay the correspondence respecting it on the table of the House.

abstract: The latest cartoon of Punch represents that dignitary in the cap, gown, and spectacles of a pedagogue, smiling approval at little Earl RUSSELL, who, sustained by little Lord PALMERSTON, struggles forward with a monstrous blue book labeled "Papers on American Affairs." American affairs are in reality the multiform topic of John Bull. He writes and reads of them in his newspapers, talks of them over his wine, speaks of them on the hustings, preaches about them from his pulpit. They enter into his workshops, empty his ships, disturb his balances at bank, threaten starvation to his laborers. There is no place where the discussion ends; there is no interest so unaffected as to turn from it with indifference. For the moment, American questions are the special and inevitable order of the day. In Parliament, the subject has the charm of novelty. Last session everybody was eager to speak, and everybody had to be silent. For this silence members are now disposed to indemnify themselves. A day scarcely passes without some of the many points disputable coming up for the consideration of both houses. In the Lords, the rights of British subjects, as affected by the war, have to be investigated, or the blockade challenged; and to every inquiry the Foreign Secretary has to be prepared with a response. The discussions of the Commons take a wider scope. On another page of this paper is reproduced a highly interesting passage at arms between Mr. JOHN BRIGHT and the Premier; the former, making the Canadian estimates his text, denouncing the war policy of the Cabinet, and eulogizing the conduct of the American Government and people. Mr. BRIGHT sees no failure in American institutions. He ridicules with capital effect the talk of a mob overawing the Executive, or of a Secretary of State precipitating the country into a war, and those other multitudinous errors and misconceptions into which Englishmen are incessantly betrayed in their allusions to transatlantic matters. He does full justice to the cause of the North, and brands with scorn the cowardice which selected the very crisis in the American case to make ferocious and insulting gesticulations at the American people. Lord PALMERSTON, with facile and plausible rhetoric replied, and, of course, contented with his rejoinder a House unaccustomed to sympathize with the reformer of Rochdale, and taught by national self-conceit to regard all things American as wrong when they depart from English models. The glory of the Trent settlement was too recent and too gratifying to be surrendered at the word of a radical, and the Premier prevailed.

Mr. BRIGHT sees no failure in American institutions. He ridicules with capital effect the talk of a mob overawing the Executive, or of a Secretary of State precipitating the country into a war, and those other multitudinous errors and misconceptions into which Englishmen are incessantly betrayed in their allusions to transatlantic matters. He does full justice to the cause of the North, and brands with scorn the cowardice which selected the very crisis in the American case to make ferocious and insulting gesticulations at the American people. Lord PALMERSTON, with facile and plausible rhetoric replied, and, of course, contented with his rejoinder a House unaccustomed to sympathize with the reformer of Rochdale, and taught by national self-conceit to regard all things American as wrong when they depart from English models. lead_paragraph: By the arrival of the Norwegian at Portland, and the Arabia and Bremen at this port, we have advices from Europe five days later. The Norwe- gian left Liverpool on the 20th, and Londonderry on the 21st ult. The supplementary estimates for the naval and military expenditures in the Trent affair, amounting to 973,000, were moved in the House of Commons on the 17th, and unani- mously agreed to. In the debate on the subject, Mr. BRIGHT strongly denounced the policy of the Government. He said the money had been worse than thrown away. He refuted the idea that the American Government was influenced by a mob, and argued that the interests of England were so bound up with America, that it was in every respect inadvisable to inflict a sting that it would take centuries to remove. Lord PALMERSTON defended the Ministers, and said that Mr. BRIGHT's opinions were confined to himself; he contended that there was every reason to justify England in backing up her demand in the manner she did, as the course of the American Government clearly showed that they did not, at the earlier stage of the affair, regard the act as one they ought to disavow. He thought the course taken deserved commendation, and believed it was calculated to insure the continuance of peace. In the House of Lords, on the 18th, the Earl of Carnarvon called attention to the imprisonment of Mr. SHAVER, a British subject, in Fort Warren, and said it was a clear case of compensation. Earl RUSSELL said Mr. SHAVER had not claimed compensation, and it was not for the Government to do it for him; neither had he rebutted the charges against him. Earl RUSSELL deeply regretted the civil war in America, and expressed the hope that England would treat with forbearance any stretch of power not intended to injure British interests, nor to insult the British flag.

abstract: The steamship Columbia arrived at this port yesterday, from Havana on the 1st inst. She reports the United States steamer Harriet Lane had taken as a prize, off Matanzas, the schooner Virginia Adams. The news from Havana is not of special importance. Advices from Vera Cruz, to the 21st ult., had been received, however, which is of the highest importance. We give full translations elsewhere. The preliminaries to a peaceful solution of the Mexican question had been agreed upon, in an interview at Solodad, between Gen. PRIM, the Spanish Commander, and Gen. abstract: On Wednesday night Capt. MONTGOMERY, of WRIGHT'S Battalion, with his company, was surprised at Keittsville, Barry County, by 850 rebels, supposed to belong to McBRIDE'S Division, but who represented themselves as Texan rangers. They fired into the house occupied by our men, killing two and wounding one. One of the rebels was killed. The balance fled, taking with them about seventy horses.

abstract: The appointment by the President of ANDREW JOHNSON as Military Governor of Tennessee is in the exercise of a right incidental to the declaration of martial law. By this action, the substantive existence of the State of Tennessee, or its constitutional rights as a State of the Union, are not denied or abolished. Rather, the State, by its act of rebellion, having nullified, so far as it was con
lead_paragraph: -cerned, and so far as it was in its power to do so, the guaranties of the Constitution, the declaration of martial law and the erection of a Provisional Government are but the steps, necessary steps, preliminary to restoring it to its legitimate status. For, while the State or its Government are not and cannot be abolished, neither can the existence of the traitors who have seized the helm of administration be in any way recognized. So that, on taking military possession of the territory of this or any other rebel State, and until such time as political reorganization is accomplished, there can be no local Government there but such as the President, as Commander-in-Chief of the army, shall provide. In Tennessee, and, probably, in nearly all the revolted States, the period for the existence of this anomalous system will be brief. The people have the privilege of at once resuming all their ancient and Constitutional rights; and, when once the military power of the rebel Government is demolished, we have reason to believe, from their education, training and character, that they will not be slow to resume the franchises to which, as citizens, they have always been accustomed. In Tennessee, indeed, the loyal people are ready at once to enter upon the work of State reorganization. For the time being they succumbed to rebel authority which they were unable to overthrow; but, with National protection and aid, they will, according to the forms prescribed in the Constitution, speedily bring themselves and the State again in friendly relation with the General Government.
headline: {'main': 'The New Government for Tennessee.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The New Government for Tennessee.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The third sale of Government cotton took place yesterday at the Atlantic Dock, Brooklyn. One hundred and sixty-four bales were sold, varying in price from 25 to 53 cents. Thirty-four more bales were offered, but were not sold, owing to 45 cents only being offered for them. For the future Government cotton will be sent to a foreign market for disposal.

abstract: We published yesterday a remarkable as well as highly interesting letter from our Special Correspondent, " Galway," from Nashville, written immediately after the National army were in possession of the city, and before the first effervescence of chagrin and dismay among the people had given place to a more rational view of the situation. The report of our intelligent and truthful corre
lead_paragraph: spondent has, no doubt, created with many of our New-York readers, particularly such as expected from its antecedents better things from the capital of Tennessee, a feeling of momentary regret and disappointment. But already the later advices via Cincinnati begin to correct this painful sensation. The staid citizens of the place are not slow to discover the marked difference between the well ordered and well appointed army of the Union under Gen. BUELL, and the Texas Rangers, (and marauders,) who in very wantonness had destroyed their bridges, plundered their houses, and struck terror to their homes and families. The dispatch says that they admit the favorable contrast, and confess that unexpected quiet has succeeded violence and outrage.
headline: {'main': 'The State of Feeling at Nashville.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The State of Feeling at Nashville.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: To the Editor of the New-York Times  SIR: The disposition to be made of the Africans who are thrown upon the protection of the General Government by the progress of our armies, is a subject of transcendent importance at the present moment.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of thousands of this unfortunate people, and among them many of the most advanced intelligence, in the South, can now be colonized and made free and independent, without any other action on the part of the National Government than the gift of a settlement beyond the limits of our own territory. This can be done now. Hereafter it will be too late, when the Union is restored and the rights of all will stand again on the basis of the Constitution.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a petition from citizens of New-York was presented, praying for measures for the transmission of mails to Panama. It is in reference to the refusal of Commodore VANDERBILT to transport the mails. A bill regulating the pay of the Navy Department, was reported from the Committee on Naval Affairs. After some further business, the Confiscation bill was taken up, and Mr. MORRILL, of Maine, made a speech in favor of its passage, at the conclusion of which its consideration was postponed until to-day. The bill to define the pay and emoluments of certain officers of the army was debated, and the pay of chaplains fixed at $1,200 per year. The Senate, after an executive session, adjourned.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, notice was given of a bill in relation to Grand and other streets in this City; also, of one to provide for the formation of Cab Companies in New-York and Brooklyn; also, of one to facilitate the construction of a railroad through the Northern Wilderness. A bill to amend the act of 1861, regulating the Fire Department of this City, and giving the Board of Appeals power to review their decisions on subsequent information, was passed by unanimous consent. The bill to provide for the distribution of soldiers' allotments was passed; also, the bill to appropriate the proceeds of the State Tax to the support of schools. A bill to amend the Railroad law was introduced. It changes the law in relation to franchises.

abstract: There is no doubt that every person found in arms against the United States is guilty of an offence which justly forfeits his life, and, at least, a life estate in his property. Such, we may assume, is the legal category in which the rebellion places every man aiding or abetting it. But it is not always expedient, nor is it often practicable, to deal with a rebellion which has obtained the colossal proportions of the great Southern revolt according to the strict letter of the law. We have already recognized the South as a belligerent, and treat prisoners captured not according to the civil, but the military code. We have returned, without punishment, all except those taken in recent engagements. In proceedings against treason, we deal with the individual, and not a political organization.

abstract: To the Editor of the New-York Times:  In the Herald's money article of Feb. 25, appears the following extract from a letter written at San Francisco
lead_paragraph: "The Overland Mail is a perfect failure; letters are from thirty to forty days from New-York, and we frequently have no mail for a week together. The Overland gets enormous pay and the steamships do the work. Our people are more quiet than might be expected, simply because they have the steamers for all important matter."

abstract: editorial on European intervention
snippet: editorial on European intervention
lead_paragraph: The article sets out by noting the discrepancy between the original pretext of the expedition against Mexico, viz: indemnity for loss indicted, and the immense military and naval force employed. It then states that from an almost official source it learns that the establishment of a Constitutional Monarchy in Mexico is another object in view, and that there is no doubt that so soon as the Allied forces shall have restored the freedom of choice to the people of Mexico, the latter will unanimously select the Archduke MAXIMILIAN for their King.

abstract: The report  that the Nashville had made her way to the American side of the Atlantic, and had entered without molestation a North Carolina port, is confirmed. The only point in regard to which the later intelligence differs from the former report is in assigning Beaufort, N.C., instead of Wilmington, as the locality where the daring of the privateer and the negligence of our blockaders, enabled her to make a bar
lead_paragraph: bor. The account of the affair that comes from Norfolk states that the Nashville approached the blockading vessel off Beaufort, with the Union flag flying, went directly up under her guns, almost within hailing distance, and then, passing her, raised the rebel flag, and moved directly toward Fort Macon. It was quite in character that the Captain of a vessel stolen from loyal owners at the outbreak of the rebellion, should for the nonce steal the flag to which he has turned traitor, as men are said to steal the purple plush of Heaven to serve the Devil in; but this furnishes no excuse for the culpable carelessness of the naval officer on duty, who allowed himself to be deceived by this poor ruse. If the facts are as stated in the present report, we can hardly see how the Navy Department can avoid cashiering that officer, whoever he may be. There is one thing, at least, that the public will expect of the Navy Department: It is that the Nashville shall never leave the port she has entered. For, though her piratical career is now practically ended as it is, we want to see her and her Captain taken. It would violate all our instincts, both of poetical and of real justice, that the man who burned the Harvey Birch should be allowed to escape unpunished.

abstract: The Nashville, from Southampton, has arrived at Beaufort, N.C. She passed our squadron with the Union flag flying, and then raised the rebel flag, and went into the harbor unmolested. She was loaded with bank paper and other valuables to a large amount, but had no ammunition on board.
