abstract: Editorial on measures to be taken with Confederates in occupied states
snippet: Editorial on measures to be taken with Confederates in occupied states
lead_paragraph: By the arrival of the steamship Canada at Halifax yesterday, we have advices from Europe two days later than were brought by the Norwegian at Portland. Lord PALMERSTON had stated in the House of Lords that the negotiations relative to the San Juan affair had been suspended, in consequence of the civil war in America, but a joint provisional occupation of the island had been arranged by both Governments. The British Government, in response to a request from THE O'DONOGHUE, had refused to afford any information relative to British vessels running the blockade. It is reported that the traitor SLIDELL has had interviews with all the French Ministers, but they were of course of an unofficial nature. The anniversary of WASHINGTON's birthday was duly and patriotically celebrated in Freemasons' Tavern, London, the Bishop of Ohio presiding. Minister ADAMS responded to the toast, "The Memory of WASHINGTON."

abstract: The usual monthly meeting of the Chamber of Commerce takes place to-day. The Chamber having become a practical body, has taken to the discussion of subjects of practical interest. A little time ago the scheme of a telegraph to China, Siberia and Japan, was taken up and considerable influence extended toward carrying out the project. Another subject was a steamship line from California to China, and a favorable report has been returned by the Congressional Committee to whom it was referred. To-day a movement is to be made to get the indorsement of the Chamber to the new and elaborate postal bill now before Congress. Our citizens have suffered so much and so long for want of convenient postal arrangements, that many are disposed to give up in despair. One year we have a Postmaster-General from Arkansas or Tennessee, and he has about as practical ideas on the subject of a Post-office, as a codfish has of the science of horticulture. At another time the Post-office Committee is apparently made up of men who do not seem to know that New-Yorkers write ten times as many letters as the people of most parts of the Union. The residents of New-York City write one-tenth of all the letters written in the country, and the people of the State twenty per cent. We hope the Chamber will express the sense of the body on the measure now before Congress, and indorse the opinions and action so frequently expressed by our citizens.

abstract: SONS OF VERMONT. -- A meeting of the Committee of the Sons of Vermont was held at the New-York Headquarters of the State of Vermont, in this City yesterday, E.W. STOUGHTON, Esq., in the chair. It was voted to hold a general meeting of all the Sons of Vermont, at the Fifth-avenue Hotel, this (Thursday) evening, at 8 o'clock, to hear the report of the Reception Committee upon the arrangements made for the reception of the Seventh and Eighth Regiments and the two Artillery Batteries, upon their arrival in this City.

abstract: The new sloops-of-war Oneida and Octorara have returned to the Brooklyn Navy-yard, after very Successful trial trips. The officers' report to Commodore PAULDING are quite satisfactory. These vessels are already in commission, and may sail at any moment after taking in fresh provisions.
lead_paragraph: The keel of a new frigate has been laid in the ship-house where the Adirondack was built. She will be named the Ticonderoga, and will resemble as much as possible, both in dimensions and model, the frigate Lackawana, now in the course of construction. The latter vessel is progressing very favorably.

lead_paragraph: we do not feel at liberty to publish. Our correspondent gives us the particulars of the erection of the second National battery on the Savannah River, between Fort Pulaski and the city. It is located on Bird Island, in the middle of the river, nearly opposite Venus Point, the place where the other is erected. The guns were placed on it during the night of the 20th ult. Fort Pulaski is now completely cut off from communication with the city. The news of the great National victories had caused the greatest depression among the rebels of Georgia and South Carolina.

abstract: According to a  recent report, the number of paupers in England, which amounted to 835,129 at the end of the year 1860, has this year reached 892,990, showing an increase of about 58,000 during a year. This increase is particularly noticeable in the manufacturing districts, which more than any others have suffered from the dearth of cotton. It has been re
lead_paragraph: marked that in Yorkshire and Lancashire the number of paupers which at Christmas, 1859, had been 186,401, and in 1860 only 184,864, had risen at the Christmas of 1861 to 217,815, making a difference of 33,000 in a single year. These figures show better than any description the effect produced by the cotton trade paralysis.

abstract: Mr. GOTTSCHALK's concert announced for to-night is postponed, on account of engagements made elsewhere which could not be deferred, although owing to his great success here, an effort was made by the management to keep him in the City a few days longer. To-night, to-morrow night, and on Saturday night Mr. GOTTSCHALK plays in Washington; thence he proceeds to Baltimore, Philadelphia, and about the 17th inst. will return to New-York.

abstract: editorial on message
snippet: editorial on message
lead_paragraph: If proof were wanting of the patriotic ardor of the President for the peace and well being of the country, it would be found abundantly in the message sent yesterday to Congress. Mr. LINCOLN appreciates the infinite difficulty of the Slavery question. He evidently despairs of prostrating the institution by force of the war-power; he looks to its existence in full vigor, throughout the Gulf States at least, when the war shall have ended. The utmost reach of his practical dealing with the subject is to strip it of political influence in National affairs. To effect this capital object, there is certainly no way so sure as to destroy the identity of interest between Border Slave States and those at the southward; and this object the President's suggestion proposes to attain. It takes the form of a joint resolution submitted to the consideration of Congress. The possibility of one or more States discovering the impolicy of retaining slave-labor is assumed. To such the joint resolution offers pecuniary aid in the task of emancipation, by engaging to pay a sum prefixed for each enslaved negro set at liberty. This bounty the President evidently believes will turn the scale in favor of freedom. Satisfied of the good faith of the National Government in its professions of non-intervention in the legislation of the States, the States will be ready to look favorably upon a plan which, while it makes the merit of the act of emancipation their own, throws the cost elsewhere. And as the plan is adopted, one after another of the northerly Slave States will array themselves on the side of the free communities of the North.

abstract: Editorial on Confederate Comr. Yancey, en route to US from unsuccessful mission in Europe
snippet: Editorial on Confederate Comr. Yancey, en route to US from unsuccessful mission in Europe
lead_paragraph: -- If our blockaders along the Southern coast keep a bright look-out these days, some of them will have a chance to take no less distinguished a prize than Mr. Commissioner YANCEY. It is true, our jolly tars, who are now filling their pockets with the prize-money of numerous captured galleons, might be disposed to turn up their noses at the limited "loot" they would derive from the sale of the cargo in question. Nevertheless, we pray them not to slacken their vigilance on that account; for the whole country has a most especial interest in this capture.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a bill to promote the public peace on Sunday was introduced. It provides that nothing shall be sold on Sunday, excepting meat, milk and fish, and those before 9 o'clock in the morning. A bill to incorporate the Grand-street and Hoboken Ferry Railroad was introduced. STEPHEN BOGART is at the head of the list of corporators. The fare is limited to three cents. A petition was presented for the passage of a law to prohibit amendments to the Constitution. A bill to provide means for the payment of the awards for lands taken for the Canal Enlargement was reported favorably. A bill to compel all prisons in the State to keep United States prisoners was introduced. Bills were then considered in Committee of the Whole until the recess.

abstract: President LINCOLN yesterday transmitted a message to Congress, recommending the adoption of a joint resolution, to the effect that the Government will cooperate with any State which may adopt a gradual abolishment of Slavery, giving to such State pecuniary aid.
lead_paragraph: President LINCOLN yesterday transmitted a message to Congress, recommending the adoption of a joint resolution, to the effect that the Government will cooperate with any State which may adopt a gradual abolishment of Slavery, giving to such State pecuniary aid. He enters into an argument to show how such a line of policy would deprive the rebels of the hope of ever getting the Northern Slave States to join their Confederacy. He also days that such a proposition on the part of the General Government sets up no claim of a right by National authority to interfere with Slavery within State limits. He closes with the salemn words: "In full view of my great responsibility to my God and to my country, I earnestly beg the attention of Congress and the people to the subject."

abstract: LONG ISLAND COLLEGE HOSPITAL. Four hundred and nineteen patients were treated in the Long Island College Hospital during the month of February, 230 were medical cases, 41 diseases of women, and 148 surgical cases.
lead_paragraph: LONG ISLAND COLLEGE HOSPITAL. -- Four hundred and nineteen patients were treated in the Long Island College Hospital during the month of February, 230 were medical cases, 41 diseases of women, and 148 surgical cases. The diseases are classified as follows: Of the nervous system, 15; general system, 11; digestive organs, 60; genito-urinal organs, 59; lungs, 48; heart, 1; throat, 6; skin, 34; bones and joints, 14; eye, 8; ear, 1; fevers, 17; rheumatism, 8; fractures, 6; dislocations, 1; abscesses and felons, 20; ulcers, 9; contusions, 10; wounds, 11; burns, 3; hernia, 2; goitre, 1; tumors, 1; enlarged glands, 5; foreign bodies removed, 1; tongue-tie, 2; club-foot, 1; vaccinations, 14; unclassified and minor cases, 50; 700 prescriptions were dispensed.

abstract: If the rebels in this war had all acted as they all swore they would act, their conquest would certainly have been an appalling enough work. If every human being in the South, of both sexes, all colors, and all ages, had sternly ...
lead_paragraph: -- If the rebels in this war had all acted as they all swore they would act, their conquest would certainly have been an appalling enough work. If every human being in the South, of both sexes, all colors, and all ages, had sternly resolved to fight to the death against the soldiers of the nation, and had carried out that resolution -- if every regiment in JEFF DAVIS' service had battled till every man expired -- if then the Home Guards had taken up the fight and ruthlessly and without exception sacrificed themselves on the altar of rebellion -- if, as we advanced South, murderous sharpshooters and guerrillas had been concealed behind every tree, and bush, and rock -- if the women, old and young, had met us with daggers, and the boys and girls with cleavers -- if the negroes and mulattoes had taken up the horrid refrain and slaughtered our advancing soldiers without the slightest compunction -- and if then the heroic remnant still unslain had, with DAVIS, TOOMBS and WIGFALL at their head, retired to the ultimate ditch and there hewn down the minions of LINCOLN as fast as they approached -- it would certainly have gone rather hard with LINCOLN's minions and with us.

abstract: The intelligence from Mexico is interesting. According to the Vera Cruz correspondents of the two leading Cuban journals, there is a probability of peace being concluded between the Juarez Government and the invaders. On the 19th ultimo, the CONDE DE REUSS, Spain's representative, had an interview with Gen. DOBLADO, the Mexican Minister of Foreign Affairs, at the village of Soledad, and preliminaries were agreed on, which the Plenipotentiaries of England and France subsequently approved. The exact nature of the terms assented to was unknown when our authorities wrote, but the principal results of the conference were said to be that negotiations were to be opened at Orizaba for the settlement of differences; and that the allied troops were to occupy Orizaba, Cordova and Tehuacan, while the diplomats were at work, provided they were content to go back to their sickly quarters on the coast, should no pacific solution be attained. Such is the pith of our latest information from Mexico. Whether it reveals aught which would justify the sanguine anticipations of the Vera Cruz correspondents aforesaid, is somewhat questionable. Indeed it would be rather rash to assume that the interventionists have entered into these negotiations with honest intents. True, the Eco de Europa, the organ of the Allies in Mexico, asserts that the conduct of its patrons out there has been not merely honest, but actually magnanimous, "When the world knows," says this adulator, "the efforts which the Allies have used to give peace to Mexico, it will be filled with astonishment; when the Republic, which does not yet know it, knows it, it will be filled with astonishment and gratitude! Creditors pacifying the debtor; the strong begging of the weak; men of war making sacrifices for peace; armed Europe asking of a State, as it were unarmed, to consent to be happy through its counsel and its influence; these things were never before seen!" In a word, if we are to interpret the rhetoric of the Eco literally, the Powers which have combined against Mexico, are the most disinterested and philanthropic of nations. No selfish considerations, no ambitious yearnings, no hostile designs urged them to the enterprise, but feelings of sympathy, amity, and benevolence toward the Republic! The object of the expedition, the expedition itself, the seizure of Vera Cruz and its fortress, and every thought and act of the Allies, from first to last, savored of magnanimity! Yet how much more disinterested, how much more philanthropic, how much more magnanimous, would their conduct have been, had they practiced forbearance toward Mexico, not undertaken the expedition, and never thought or acted at all in the matter. In despite, then, of the Eco's panegyric, we maintain that the tortuous policy which the coalition has been pursuing in relation to Mexico, renders its honesty open to suspicion. To be negotiating for a compromise of differences with the JUAREZ Government, and, at the same time, to be plotting in Europe for the overthrow of that Government, and the establishment of a monarchy on its ruins, does certainly seem extremely like perfidy. This simultaneous diplomacy on the part of interventionists for purposes the most opposite, cannot surely be sterling in both cases. Either they must design to humbug the Mexican President, to amuse, until prepared to crush him; or they must not really mean to confer on the Austrian Archduke, the crown which they have offered him. They cannot possibly be acting in sincerity and good faith with the two personages, and as they can have no conceivable motive for trifling with MAXIMILIAN, it can be no great breach of charity to conclude that the Republican Magistrate is the victim.

abstract: A correspondent of the Richmond Dispatch. writing from Camp Mason, near Winchester, says the troops in that direction are improving in health, and but little sickness exist. A portion have received marching orders, but to what point is not known.
lead_paragraph: A correspondent of the Richmond Dispatch. writing from Camp Mason, near Winchester, says the troops in that direction are improving in health, and but little sickness exist. A portion have received marching orders, but to what point is not known. "It seems to be pretty well known that the enemy are threatening Winchester from Romney and Williamsport. 'Stone-Wall' JACKSON, of course, will be prepared to meet them."

abstract: -- The Sons of Vermont held a large and enthusiastic meeting at the Fifth-avenue Hotel last evening, there being about 200 of the Sons and descendants of the Green Mountain Boys present. After a lengthy and happy interchange of sentiments the Committee on Reception and Arrangements made a report that all arrangements had been completed for the reception of Vermont soldiers, and presented a badge with the Vermont coat of arms and the motto, "Welcome Sons of Vermont." The Committee also presented a beautiful banner, which was received with cheers, and the report adopted. It was voted to hold a reception at the Metropolitan Hotel this evening at 8 o'clock, and the "Sons" and their wives and daughters of all descendants of Vermoners are invited to be present. Tickets may be had at the Metropolitan Hotel.

abstract: -- This evening the celebrated comedian, Mr. J.S. CLARKE, takes his farewell benefit at this theatre, being the last night but one of an engagement which has now run through ten weeks. abstract: Yesterday morning the Ninety-eighth Regiment, Col. WM. DUTTON, arrived here from Albany On landing, the men were at once marched to the Park Barracks, where they will remain till further orders.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday morning the Ninety-eighth Regiment, Col. WM. DUTTON, arrived here from Albany On landing, the men were at once marched to the Park Barracks, where they will remain till further orders. The numerical strength of the regiment is nearly a thousand. Seven companies were recruited in Franklin County; the remaining three in Wayne county. All the men are uniformed and equipped, but have no arms. Before leaving, they will be supplied with Enfield rifles. Col. DUTTON graduated at West Point, and in the same class with Gen. MCCLELLAN. Annexed is a list of the principal officers:

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, another petition in favor of making Gen. WOOL a full Major-General, was presented by Mr. HARRIS, of New-York. Petitions were also presented in favor of emancipation. The Post-office appropriation bill and the Postal Money-order bill were reported back from the Post-office Committee, but not acted upon. A joint resolution, tendering the thanks of Congress to Flag-officer GOLDSBOROUGH, his officers and men, was adopted. The bill in relation to the pay of members of Congress was debated, and an amendment adopted making the mileage twenty instead of ten cents. The Senate, at 1 o'clock, went into Executive session and subsequently adjourned.

abstract: By an odd coincidence the journals of all cities of the South from Richmond to New-Orleans, have of late commenced a very lively crusade against whisky. It is really instructive to observe the dead earnestness with which these converts to ...
lead_paragraph: -- By an odd coincidence the journals of all cities of the South from Richmond to New-Orleans, have of late commenced a very lively crusade against whisky. It is really instructive to observe the dead earnestness with which these converts to the doctrine of Father MATHEW iterate the old stock arguments for teetotalism. And from their own showing there is a call for dead earnestness; for the picture they draw of drunkenness at the South, and especially in the Southern armies, is of the most intense and horrible kind. The holy JEFF. was indeed able to report in his late message that "a tone of earnest piety has pervaded our people;" but he might have added that it was accompanied by a tone of still more earnest potation. It appears that the presence of the rebel army in Virginia has caused no less than two hundred new distilleries to spring up in the State within the past six months. A Richmond journal says that in that city "drunken men reel out, tumble into the gutters, sprawl over the sidewalks, brandish knives and pistols, and oftentimes indulge in those deadly conflicts which fill our prisons with candidates for the gallows." And it was one of the most curious developments we have yet had that when the Union army entered Nashville the other day, their advent was hailed by Mayor CHEATHAM solely on the ground that it would give him power to put an end to the wholesale intoxication that was playing the devil with the city?

abstract: The British schooner Labrador, Capt. DAVIS, arrived yesterday from Ponce, P.R., reports, Feb. 26, lat. 37째 50', long. 72째 50', spoke British schooner W. Stairs, from New-York, bound to St. Domingo, and took from her Capt. BROWN and crew, five in number, of schooner Volunteer, of Millbridge, from Ponce, P.R., for Boston, abandoned at sea. Capt. BROWN reports, Feb. 24, lat. 37째 50', long. 72째 50', experienced a heavy gale from northwest, during which shipped a sea, which stove in deck, carried away rudder and wheel, rendering the vessel unmanageable, when the British schooner W. Stairs, STAIRS, from New-York for St. Domingo, came up and took us on board his vessel, and we were subsequently transferred to the British schooner Labrador, from Ponce for New-York, and brought to this port. During the gale, DAVID PINKHAM, seaman, of Millbridge, was washed overboard from the wheel and lost. The Volunteer was six years old, 178 tons burden, and owned by Capt. BROWN, RUFUS FICKETT and others, at Millbridge.

snippet: Editorial accusation of crimes committed by Confederates
lead_paragraph: While the British Press is so ticklish respecting our temporary closing up of the port of Charleston, and other, with sunken vessels -- while British humanitarians, led on by the London Times, are asserting that this civil war is brutalizing at least one of the belligerents -- meaning the North, of course -- it is curious to notice that, up to the present time, we have not seen, from the same quarter, any denunciation of the atrocious actions which have disgraced the Southern armies and people ever since the commencement of this struggle.

abstract: Editorial compares loyalty of J M Botts and treason of C J Faulkner
snippet: Editorial compares loyalty of J M Botts and treason of C J Faulkner
lead_paragraph: A Nineteenth Century Plutarch is wanted to draw whatever parallel there may be between JOHN MINOR BOTTS and CHARLKS JAMES FAULKNER. BOTTS has been arrested on his Virginia farm, and placed in a Virginia prison, FAULKNER has been released from his Boston prison, and has been visiting his Virginia farm. Both gentlemen have been Union men, with a difference. The Unionism of BOTTS has been of a sturdy, consistent type, keeping the unalterable tenor of its way through all the vicissitudes of party, denouncing on the one hand the extravagances of Abolitionism, and, with even more eloquence and fervor, denouncing the even more dangerous heresy of secession. He was in fact a Henry Clay Whig who survived himself. No allurements of the Jeff. Davis school have availed to draw him from his retirement into the active support of the rebellion. No terrorism has compelled him to revoke one loyal principle. His last audible word was for the Union. Then he was silent.

lead_paragraph: William Henry Hawkins, the steward of the ship Lammergeyer, was put on trial charged with murdering the captain of the ship with an axe. Mr. Spencer appeared as counsel for the prisoner, who is a colored man. The vessel was on her way from London to this country. The first mate, the carpenter, and the cook, were examined as witnesses to testify to the facts. Mr. Chilton was also examined to prove that certain stains on the prisoner's clothes were stains of blood. No evidence whatever was offered by the prisoner.

abstract: GOUPIL Co., or rather their successor, Mr. K NOEDLER. have reopened their attractive gallery within the week, and offer to the lovers of art several rare and peculiar specimens. A portrait, half-length of GOTTSCHALK, while eminently correct and faithful as a likeness, is too Frenchy for the popular taste on this side the water.
lead_paragraph: GOUPIL & Co., or rather their successor, Mr. K NOEDLER. have reopened their attractive gallery within the week, and offer to the lovers of art several rare and peculiar specimens. A portrait, half-length of GOTTSCHALK, while eminently correct and faithful as a likeness, is too Frenchy for the popular taste on this side the water. As a fair exponent of French portraiture, it is interesting and, possibly, good; but we confess to a liking for our own artists, or even a few of our English cousins, far beyond any regard which might possibly be entertained for such as this one.

abstract: Failing to win a battle; the next best thing a General can do is to make a good excuse for his failure. PILLOW does not give a valid excuse for FLOYD'S, and his own, and BUCKNER'S want of success at Fort Donelson.
lead_paragraph: Failing to win a battle, the next best thing a General can do is to make a good excuse for his failure. PILLOW does not give a valid excuse for FLOYD's, and his own, and BUCKNER'S want of success at Fort Donelson. Not that we think FLOYD is to be blamed for flying, or PILLOW for following suit, or BUCKNER for surrendering; but when PILLOW, in one part of his report, shows how the rebels must logically win the day, and then, in subsequent parts of the same document, tells how they lost it, we see the shallow ground on which he based his hopes.

abstract: Observations from Great Britain
snippet: Observations from Great Britain
lead_paragraph: In the Assembly on the 1st inst., when the bill to provide for the Public Defence was taken up in Committee of the whole, Mr. PHELPS, of New-York, said he did not intend to enter into any lengthened debate upon this question, which had already been very fully discussed, and on which many members of that body yet desired to be heard. But he wished to say a few words on one or two points which either had not been touched on at all, or on which he felt himself compelled to differ with those who had so ably argued on both sides of the question. He desired first to draw the attention of the House to the fact that the Government of the United States has already, through the action of our representatives in Congress, appropriated a large amount of money for the very purposes to which the sums set apart in this bill were to be devoted. He had on another occasion, a few days since, alluded to the action of the Government in this direction, and he was somewhat surprised that no reference had been made to this important fact in the elaborate and extended argument of the able Chairman of the Military Committee, (Mr. PIERCE.) But while the appropriations thus made for the public defence had been ignored in debate, much stress had been placed on the letter of our energetic Secretary of State, (Mr. SEWARD,) addressed to the Governors of the several loyal States, inviting State cooperation with the Federal Government, in putting our coast and borders into a proper condition for defence against an invading army. That member of the Cabinet deservedly enjoys the confidence and respect of the Legislature of New-York, and the policy he recommended in his letter, was doubtless, under existing circumstances, wise and patriotic. But it must be remembered that the appropriation by the Federal Government has been made since the letter of Mr. SEWARD was written, and, therefore, not alone from the altered condition of our foreign relations, but from the fact that the moneys then needed have been supplied since by the general Government, does the policy, prudent and necessary at that time, become of questionable propriety now.
headline: {'main': 'ENGLAND AND THE UNITED STATES.; Remarks of Hon. abstract: -- MAURICE SAND, who, it may be remembered, visited the United States last Summer in the suite of Prince NAPOLEON, and who is now publishing piquant papers touching what he saw, in the Revue des Deux Mondes, gives currency to a foolish canard that makes President LINCOLN ask the Prince, on the occasion of their interview at Washington, if he were not the son of LUCIEN BONAPARTE. The speech is, of course, as we have characterized it, only a foolish canard; but the Parliamentary Papers relating to the war in this country, which have lately been laid before the British Parliament, are disfigured by an official blunder quite as stupid as the reported speech would have been. This series of documents bears the title, "Papers relating to the civil war in the United States of North America." As they were carefully prepared by the Cabinet Ministers, presented to the Queen and laid before Parliament, we are led to the conclusion that Lords PALMERSTON and RUSSELL are both ignorant of the official name of this Government, which is "The United States of America," not of North America. We do not look at this as a vital matter; it is probable that this Government will survive the shock of a misnomer, and get along even under the designation of the "United States of North America." But it is precisely in regard to such matters that the English claim to be punctilious to a degree. Such a blunder on our part would have brought down a shower of ballista from the Times, Saturday Review, and their mates, aimed at what they would very likely call the ignorance and vulgarity of the "North Americans."

Such a blunder on our part would have brought down a shower of ballista from the Times, Saturday Review, and their mates, aimed at what they would very likely call the ignorance and vulgarity of the "North Americans."

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, the bill to prevent trade on the Sabbath was reported favorably, and the bill to amend the Usury laws was reported unfavorably. A bill to incorporate the Loaners' Association in this City was introduced; also, a general bill regardinq the construction of railroads in the State.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, the bill to prevent trade on the Sabbath was reported favorably, and the bill to amend the Usury laws was reported unfavorably. A bill to incorporate the Loaners' Association in this City was introduced; also, a general bill regardinq the construction of railroads in the State. The bill to appropriate $10,000 of the general fund to the People's College was passed; also, the bill to prohibit the sale of swill-milk. A resolution was adopted requiring the Excise Commissioners in this City to report, in twenty days, the number of licenses issued, the money received and the disbursements.

abstract: Should no other action be taken by Congress in reference to the recent Message of the President than the adoption of the resolution recommended, it must still constitute a most important era in our history.
lead_paragraph: Should no other action be taken by Congress in reference to the recent Message of the President than the adoption of the resolution recommended, it must still constitute a most important era in our history. It is the first instance in which Government has declared that its influence shall be exerted in favor of freedom, and that we should use the public revenues in weakening the political and military strength of one section, and elevating that of the other. The opinions of Mr. LINCOLN are in harmony with the fathers of the Government -- WASHINGTON, JEFERSON, MADISON, and their illustrious compeers. They earnestly desired to see Slavery extinguished, and believed it must gradually disappear under the influence of those benign principles they embodied in the Constitution, as a chart to be observed in spirit as well as in letter. But the result did not justify their expectations. Although Slavery was for a generation everywhere admitted to be an evil, the owners of the chattels had not sufficient force or moral sense to carry their convictions into practice. As it is not in nature for men to live forever in admitted wrong, the only alternative left was the ground finally assumed at the South, that Slavery in itself is good, instead of being bad; that it has God's blessing, instead of His curse. The logic to such a conclusion was irresistible. "All institutions," said the slaveholders, "Are the concretes of public opinion. If the opinion of the country be against Slavery, such opinion will, at some day, distant it may be, express itself in action, by virtue of which Slavery must disappear. But Slavery is right. The opinion against it is a prejudice, which can and must be made to give way to truth. Our task is to educate the North to a proper estimate of the institution. Through the North we must regenerate the world, and in this way place ourselves rectus in curia in the moral as well as in the political forum of mankind."
headline: {'main': 'The Recent Message of the President.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Recent Message of the President.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, the Special Message of the President, relative to cooperation with States desiring to abolish Slavery, was read and referred to the Judiciary Committee. A memorial from merchants of New-York, asking immediate action to provide for the transportation of the mails to Panama, was presented.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, the Special Message of the President, relative to cooperation with States desiring to abolish Slavery, was read and referred to the Judiciary Committee. A memorial from merchants of New-York, asking immediate action to provide for the transportation of the mails to Panama, was presented. Another memorial from New-York merchants was presented, calling attention to the cotton lands on the Southern coast. The bill to provide for the occcupation and cultivation of the cotton lands was then taken up, but before it was considered, Mr. DAVIS, of Kentucky, called attention to the fact that the Legislature of Kentucky some time ago requested his colleague, Mr. POWELL, to resign, and that fifteen days ago a resolution for his expulsion had been offered, but not acted upon. He desired action of some kind. Mr. TRUMBULL stated that the Judiciary Committee were proceeding as rapidly as possible with the case, and would make a report soon. Mr. POWELL expressed himself ready to answer to the people of Kentucky for his course, and said at the proper time he would make a brief statement to vindicate himself. The Cotton-land bill was then considered, and passed after some debate, 26 to 14. After an Executive session, the Senate adjourned until Monday.

abstract: Reports from around country
snippet: Reports from around country
lead_paragraph: We find in the Atlanta (Georgia) Confederacy, of Sunday last, the official report of Gen. PILLOW, who commanded the rebels at Fort Donelson. The report is very long, in striking contrast with the short and pithy report of Gen. GRANT. PILLOW took command of Fort Donelson on Feb. 8, and he says that he immediately set to work to improve its defences. This was done under the supervision of Major GILMER, Chief Engineer of Gen. A.S. JOHNSTON's Staff. Before the works were completed, PILLOW states, Gen. FLOYD, his senior in rank, had arrived, but he does not say whether the great thief took Command or not. He then says: "I had placed Brig.-Gen. BUCKNER in command of the right wing, and Brig.-Gen. JOHNSTON in command of the left. By extraordinary efforts we had barely got the works in a defensible condition when the enemy made an advance in force around and against the entire line of outer winks."

abstract: editorial on Lincoln views on emancipation; editorial on financial aspects of emancipation
snippet: editorial on Lincoln views on emancipation; editorial on financial aspects of emancipation
lead_paragraph: The President, in his important special message on gradual emancipation in the Border Slave States, has not pointed out the mode or means of pecuniary aid in the good work. But there is no mistaking his main purpose. He would make it the pecuniary interest of these States, as well as their interest in a domestic-economical sense, to take the initiative of gradual emancipation. He would have them invite and introduce free white labor, where slave labor has become, or threatens soon to become, unprofitable. If white labor, now comparatively inert, but in sufficient numerical force, is already in their borders, he would stimulate it to activity, by gradually removing the competition of slave labor, or by rendering it secondary in the mechanic and manufacturing pursuits, if not in agriculture itself, to free skill and industry. This change needs encouragement. It requires pecuniary relief from the taxation entailed upon the State under the old system. Virginia and Missouri, as examples, are burdened with a heavy, not to say overwhelming, public indebtedness, from which they neither hope or seek to escape. Virginia has engaged to pay $2,400,000 by annual interest, and as much more yearly by way of sinking fund on the great debt of forty millions. To attempt the industrial change suggested by the President, and to invite white labor into her rich valleys, and to the employment of her unemployed water-power, with this heavy charge of local taxation upon her State finances, and at the same time pay her equal quota of National taxation, would be to delay, if not to defeat, the desired object. It is here that the pecuniary aid of the General Government might appropriately come in, and with as little detriment to the lender as the borrower. The equivalent of an act for the gradual emancipation of Slavery, by declaring that all negroes born after a given period shall be free on attaining the age of 21 or 28 years, the interest upon the Public Debt of the Commonwealth would be assumed to be paid by the United States, less the ordinary revenues derived from the public works and bank stocks originally created by or with the proceeds of this debt. The equivalent would come back to the United States in a few years in the increased ability of the people to pay their quota of the National taxation; this ability being measured by the enhanced value of personal and real property under the free-labor system. If need be, the United States might assume at once, if not at 6 per cent., say at 4 or 5 per cent., the entire indebtedness, principal and interest, incurred by the Commonwealth for legitimate and loyal objects before this rebellion.
headline: {'main': 'Financial Aspect of Emancipation.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Financial Aspect of Emancipation.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: VALENTINE MAZ ZINI was yesterday arrested by the United States Marshal for violating an injunction issued against him to prevent his making or selling sewing-machines, infringing letters patent for a feeding device such as used in machines of the Grover Baker Company, the Wheeler Wilson Company, and I.M. SINGER Co.
lead_paragraph: VALENTINE MAZZINI was yesterday arrested by the United States Marshal for violating an injunction issued against him to prevent his making or selling sewing-machines, infringing letters patent for a feeding device such as used in machines of the Grover Baker Company, the Wheeler Wilson Company, and I.M. SINGER & Co. The owners of these patents are determined to prosecute all infringers, and that the orders of the Court respecting them shall be obeyed.

abstract: -- The summons "On to Richmond" rises again on the nation -- not now the clamor of a distracted public, but the thrilling appeal that comes from out the prison-house of Southern Unionists, held in durance by the traitor chiefs. The manifestations of Union sentiment, called forth by the late triumphs of the National aims, even in the rebel capital itself, have so alarmed the rebel leaders, that they have just been compelled to put Richmond and its environs, as well as the other chief cities of Virginia, under martial law. This has enabled them to cast JOHN MINOR BOTTS and a score of other Union men into prison. Late accounts from Richmond, which we publish to-day, show that they are doing the same by other Union men -- with tremulous haste hauling off to prison all whose fidelity is in any way doubtful. The loi des suspects is in full force, and obviously Richmond is under a reign of terror that emulates anything during the French Revolution. The voice of those noble Union patriots imprisoned by the traitor league cries to the Government and the country. Perhaps nothing is so fitted to stir a fever in the blood of all loyal men. May they soon obtain the longed for relief!

This has enabled them to cast JOHN MINOR BOTTS and a score of other Union men into prison. Late accounts from Richmond, which we publish to-day, show that they are doing the same by other Union men -- with tremulous haste hauling off to prison all whose fidelity is in any way doubtful. The loi des suspects is in full force, and obviously Richmond is under a reign of terror that emulates anything during the French Revolution. abstract: -- There is something decidedly good in the quiet persistence with which the Tuscarora sticks to her duty of watching the rebel privateers. Foiled, by the British Admiralty order, in her attempt to catch the Nashville, she promptly betook herself to the Mediterranean, to nab the Sumter, which, according to last accounts, was lying at Gibraltar, endeavoring to beg, borrow or steal coal enough to bring her back to America. We now hear that the Tuscarora is standing guard over the privateer, and under circumstances that are rather interesting. She has taken up her anchorage at Orange Grove, which, though bringing her within three miles of the Sumter, is still in Spanish waters. The sinister British provision which compels the armed vessels of one belligerent to wait twenty-four hours after the departure of armed vessels of the other belligerent, before leaving the port, will therefore have no application to this case; for while the Sumter is in a British port, the Tuscarora is in a Spanish port, though at such proximity as to bring the pirate ship within range of her long guns! The "situation" is decidedly an interesting one, and we may shortly expect to hear of a stirring catastrophe.

abstract: Editorial on rumor R A Toombs will be made Lt. Gen. in Confederate Army
snippet: Editorial on rumor R A Toombs will be made Lt. Gen. in Confederate Army
lead_paragraph: Readers of the TIMES are not recommended to believe that ROBERT TOOMBS has been made Lieutenant-General of the Confederate Army, with orders to carry the war into Pennsylvania and Ohio. Being simply a civilian, without even these trifling pretensions to military skill and experience which are claimed by his colleagues, the presumptions are strongly against his selection for the command of the Confederate forces at a critical moment like this; and much stronger against the plan of operations marked out for him. True, the rebels are weary of their military idols. SYDNEY JOHNSTON is loudly abused as a failure; FLOYD and PILLOW as cowards; POLK is a granny; BUCKNER a humbug. It has been observed that the presence of BEAUREGARD in the West seemed to be the beginning of ill-fortune. HUGER, commanding the all-important post of Norfolk, is the butt of the coarsest vituperation in the Petersburgh and Raleigh papers. WISE has laid down his epaulets. The entire generation of Generals is under the clouds, insomuch that the Confederate Congress has been considering, with favor, the plan of placing the military reins in a single hand, invested with absolute and plenary powers. But to give this power to TOOMBS is hardly the thing.

abstract: VERY QUESTION. -- The highly important letter addressed by the Postmaster-General to the Cooper Institute meeting, on Thursday, was omitted from our report of the meeting. We present it to our readers this morning. Judge BLAIR, takes a view of Southern sentiment in regard to Slavery which has at least the merit of novelty, while, from the writer's intimacy with the South, we may infer that it cannot be entirely wide of the truth. It will certainly surprise the Northern Abolitionist to learn that the Southern slaveholder is even more hostile than himself to the institution of Slavery; the excess of hatred on this side being measured by his sense of inability to get rid of the detested burden. There is especial interest attached at this moment to the views of this letter, because, emanating from a member of the Cabinet, it may be accepted as giving a sort of official interpretation to the Message of the President upon the some subject.

abstract: Our immediate community will remember that on Monday, the 10th ult., three regiments of Federal infantry, consisting of about 2,500 men, with a baggage train of [???] wagons, passed through this place en route from Booneville to St. Louis. Learning on the day after this column passed that several negro men had joined it on the march, evidently with the view of making their escape, and being assured, also, that some of the soldiers, as they encountered slaves along the road, had endeavored to entice them away, and that some of the officers afforded their owners no opportunity or facilities for their recovery, we immediately addressed Gen. HALLECK a letter on the subject, stating that the proceedings were not only wrong in principle, but damaging in their effects upon the Union cause, and suggesting that he issue a Central Order for an inspection of all troops for the discovery of fugitive slaves and for a more rigid enforcement of the Order heretofore made to military commanders not to allow slaves to enter their lines and to exclude all who had entered. This letter was dated the 11th ult. On the next day Gen. HALLECK replied as follows:

abstract: We made an advance on Saturday, demonstrating what we have all along suspected, that the enemy are determined not to make even a show of resistance anywhere in the neighborhood of Nashville. To crawl up at night and shoot a man or two on picket duty, seems to be the height of their ambition. They do not dare even to show themselves in broad daylight, at however remote a distance.

abstract: -- The accounts we now get, from our own side, of the entrance of the Nashville into Beaufort, take away none of the disgrace which attached to that affair in the rebel recital. The blockading vessel off Beaufort is, we learn, the steamer State of Georgia. The privateer was first seen at a distance of two miles, making toward them, and flying the American flag. The pitiful ruse seems to have thrown the commanding officer completely off his guard, and it was not till she had passed the blockader, and was making way under full head of steam towards Fort Macon, that all hands were piped to quarters. The whole affair is a disgrace and a humiliation, and should secure the prompt cashiering of the naval officer; for his conduct not only shows utter imbecility, but a clear neglect of duty. It is the instruction of the Navy Department to the commanders of blockading steamers that, the instant a vessel is seen, the decks are to be cleared for action. As for the ruse of the Nashville in hoisting the Union flag, so obvious and common a trick will hardly be urged in mitigation of the conduct of the officer in question. We understand that the President, who chafes at the escape of this notorious pirate-ship, has taken the matter into his own hands, and will see that the proper punishment promptly falls on the offender.

abstract: editorial on US attitude on occupation; editorial on military movements there; editorial on occupation
snippet: editorial on US attitude on occupation; editorial on military movements there; editorial on occupation
lead_paragraph: Did the Atlantic Telegraph exist, we should be able to note, day by day, the change rapidly taking place in European sentiment in respect to the American civil war on the one hand, and the Mexican expedition on the other. With regard to the first, a revulsion in favor of the North is now beyond content, while in relation to the second the public mind of the Continent, at least, seems to be settling down to the conviction that Mexico must have, nay, even desires to receive a European monarch.

abstract: The panic has subsided, and quietude takes the place of consternation. Contrary to the expectations of many, none of our troops are quartered in the city. Col. STANLEY MATTHEWS, of the Fifty-first Ohio, has been appointed Provost-Marshal. Under his military regimen the place is rapidly assuming its ancient appearance, and ere long reason will again control a people who have been maddened by the infatuation of secession.

abstract: We had an opportunity yesterday of conversing with a gentleman who left Memphis last Saturday, and reached St. Louis yesterday morning. He has been a citizen of St. Louis, but for some time past has been living at Memphis.

abstract: -- The telegraph is now in operation to Nashville, but the first news of the movements of our army in the West still continues to reach us by way of the far South. From this direction comes the intelligence that our forces have advanced from Nashville southward to Murfreesboro, and have occupied that point, while the rebels under SIDNEY JOHNSTON have retreated into Alabama. Whether the statements are true or not, we will not be likely to know assuredly until we hear direct from our own correspondents in Tennessee. But, until then, there is no special reason to doubt the truth of either of the rebel reports. It is altogether likely that it was the purpose of Gen. BUELL not to tarry long at Nashville with his main body, but to advance rapidly as far South as Chattanooga, on the Upper Tennessee River. This is the fundamental strategic position in Tennessee, and hardly less important as related to the adjoining States. It not only gives control of the entire vast line of the Tennessee River, but brings us into intimate relations with Georgia, North and South Carolina, and Alabama. It gives us possession of the railroad connecting all the lines in Tennessee and the Gulf States with the rebel States of the East; and is thus the key to the whole Southern system of railroads. For natural strength it is a position unsurpassed, located as it is just where the river breaks through the Cumberland Mountains. It has heretofore been reported that the rebels were retreating to this point to make a "stand;" but it would be as difficult to hold, and of as little value to them, as it is easily held and of great value to us. If the other part of the rebel report be true, that JOHNSTON has moved his forces to Decatur, Ala., it is probable that he only went down the Chattanooga road to Stevenson, and thence has taken the railroad west to Memphis. This view is supported by a statement in a letter from a reliable resident of Nashville, (published elsewhere,) who avers that Gen. JOHNSTON, before leaving that town, said he would not make a "stand" until he got west of the Tennessee River. So that, taking into account all the facts and probabilities in the case, there is no reason to discredit the rebel report that JOHNSTON has evacuated Murfreesboro, and that our troops have gone forward and taken possession. It is not at all likely, however, that Gen. BUELL will delay long at that point.
lead_paragraph: -- The telegraph is now in operation to Nashville, but the first news of the movements of our army in the West still continues to reach us by way of the far South. From this direction comes the intelligence that our forces have advanced from Nashville southward to Murfreesboro, and have occupied that point, while the rebels under SIDNEY JOHNSTON have retreated into Alabama. Whether the statements are true or not, we will not be likely to know assuredly until we hear direct from our own correspondents in Tennessee. But, until then, there is no special reason to doubt the truth of either of the rebel reports. It is altogether likely that it was the purpose of Gen. BUELL not to tarry long at Nashville with his main body, but to advance rapidly as far South as Chattanooga, on the Upper Tennessee River. This is the fundamental strategic position in Tennessee, and hardly less important as related to the adjoining States. It not only gives control of the entire vast line of the Tennessee River, but brings us into intimate relations with Georgia, North and South Carolina, and Alabama. It gives us possession of the railroad connecting all the lines in Tennessee and the Gulf States with the rebel States of the East; and is thus the key to the whole Southern system of railroads. For natural strength it is a position unsurpassed, located as it is just where the river breaks through the Cumberland Mountains. It has heretofore been reported that the rebels were retreating to this point to make a "stand;" but it would be as difficult to hold, and of as little value to them, as it is easily held and of great value to us. If the other part of the rebel report be true, that JOHNSTON has moved his forces to Decatur, Ala., it is probable that he only went down the Chattanooga road to Stevenson, and thence has taken the railroad west to Memphis. This view is supported by a statement in a letter from a reliable resident of Nashville, (published elsewhere,) who avers that Gen. JOHNSTON, before leaving that town, said he would not make a "stand" until he got west of the Tennessee River. So that, taking into account all the facts and probabilities in the case, there is no reason to discredit the rebel report that JOHNSTON has evacuated Murfreesboro, and that our troops have gone forward and taken possession. It is not at all likely, however, that Gen. BUELL will delay long at that point.

abstract: -- Mr. RUSSELL has, heretofore, monopolized the honors of a special traveling correspondent in this country, notwithstanding the London Star has been in receipt, from its own reporter, of letters marked with much intelligence and fairness. Hereafter, however, the Times writer will need to water his laurels. The London Spectator, a paper whose general ability is noted with more satisfaction in this country because it has uniformly discussed American topics with justice, and a pretty accurate understanding of those social and political problems which bewilder the English understanding, has sent forth a gentleman to retrace the steps of Mr. RUSSELL, and give an impartial representation of the ground coursed over by that gentleman. In the first of this interesting series, which we print elsewhere, the most noteworthy point is the obvious candor of the writer, and his determination to measure what he sees by a large and cosmopolitan standard, rather than by the tape-measure of a British shop-keeper. The few political prognostications he throws out are certainly unfortunate; but they, at least, manifest a docility which will soon be enabled to correct erroneous first impressions.

abstract: -- A highly injurious impression has been communicated to the public in regard to Gen. STEVENS, the able and active commander of a brigade of our army in South Carolina. He is represented as cherishing secret sympathy with the rebellion; as reluctant to deprive even rebel owners of their slaves; and as treating, not with indifference, but with brutal cruelty, the negroes, who have been left on his hands by runaway masters. These charges were formulated in a letter published in the Tribune a few weeks ago. A correspondent, whose letter appears in another column, and whose reliability we vouch for in the largest sense, replies to these accusations, and, we think, abundantly and thoroughly explodes them. Gen. STEVENS had the misfortune to be, when in civil life, a Democrat of what was absurdly called the "National" Party. But this fact, which should win from us the tenderest commiseration, and evoke a sentiment of charity and forgiveness, ought not to follow his present and future career, casting upon it the blight of suspicion and distrust. His course in South Carolina has not only approved him an accomplished and gallant officer, but has shown the sincerity of his dislike to treason, and its final cause.

abstract: A PICKPOCKET ON THE CITY CARS. AN EXCITING SCENE. Yesterday afternoon a very exciting scene occurred in the neighborhood of Canal and Hudson streets, owing to the ingenious exploits of a pickpocket on one of our City cars. Capt. JACOB BUSH, of the schooner John J. Houseman, drew from the Manattan Bank the sum of $250, in specie, and deposited it in a woolen mitten in a pocket of his overcoat.
lead_paragraph: A PICKPOCKET ON THE CITY CARS. -- AN EXCITING SCENE. -- Yesterday afternoon a very exciting scene occurred in the neighborhood of Canal and Hudson streets, owing to the ingenious exploits of a pickpocket on one of our City cars. Capt. JACOB BUSH, of the schooner John J. Houseman, drew from the Manattan Bank the sum of $250, in specie, and deposited it in a woolen mitten in a pocket of his overcoat. He took an Eighth-avenue car at the Astor House for the purpose of going to his vessel, then lying at the foot of Spring-street, North River, when the car arrived at the corner of Canal and Hudson streets, Capt. BUSH put his hand in his pocket to get money to pay his fare, when to his astonishment he discovered that his money was gone. He at once exclaimed to the conductor that he had been robbed on the car. At this moment a well-dressed and very respectable looking gentleman jumped from the car and ran swiftly along Hudson to Grand-street. Capt. BUSH, who is a man over 50 years of age, immediately pursued him, and by the aid of Officer FITZGERALD, of the Twenty-eighth Precinct, the culprit was caught and taken to the Station-house. When be found himself closely pursued, and a few moments previous to being caught, he threw the mitten containing the stolen money down an area in front of No. 19 1/2 Grand-street. A German, named ANDREW KIESSINGER, soon afterward found the money and conveyed it to the Twenty-eighth Precinct Station-house. On his way there, two of the confederates of the accused tried to persuade KEISSINGER to surrender the money to them for a consideration. Failing in this, they offered him a large sum to go away with the prize, and make no appearance at the Station-house. The honest German appeared at the Station-house, however, and delivered over to the Police Captain the stolen money. The accused, upon being taken before Justice QUACKERBUSH, at the Jefferson Market Police Court, gave his name as JOHN WILLIAMS. He is known to the Police as JOHN MULLIGAN. Justice QUACKENBUSH committed him, in default of $2,000 bail.

abstract: A HORRID MISTAKE -- THE WRONG CORPSE SENT. -- A member of one of our regiments on the Potomac -- an elderly man -- recently died in the Georgetown Hospital. His friends in this city wrote to have the corpse sent home. Tuesday evening, a box arrived per Express, addressed to the care of a relative, and containing, as was supposed, the body of the deceased man. What was the surprise and horror of the family to find, on opening the coffin, not the remains of their late friend, but those of a stranger!

abstract: -- The intimation regarding the movements of Gen. BURNSIDE, which we get by way of Fortress Monroe, to-day prepares us to hear stirring news from that quarter. The delay at Roanoke has been no longer than was necessary to obtain reinforcements and supplies; these having been received, the Expedition had advanced to Winton, on the Chowan River, and occupied it in force. From this point BURNSIDE was about to move, or had already moved, on Suffolk. We have repeatedly pointed out the great importance of this point. It is but twenty-two miles from Norfolk, is the point of junction of the two railroads leading from that city -- namely, the Roanoke and Seaboard, and the Norfolk and Petersburgh lines -- and its possession, by completely isolating Norfolk, necessitates the surrender of that city. Considering its extreme importance, therefore, we can readily believe the report that the rebels have transferred a large force to Suffolk to protect it, and are prepared to contest its possession hotly. BURNSIDE is just the man to give them all the light they can stomach; so that we may look out for warm work and a brilliant bulletin shortly.
lead_paragraph: -- The intimation regarding the movements of Gen. BURNSIDE, which we get by way of Fortress Monroe, to-day prepares us to hear stirring news from that quarter. abstract: A flag of truce from Norfolk to-day brought down the commandant of the French steamer. He represents that there is great excitement at Norfolk. abstract: Editorial on Davis military strategy
snippet: Editorial on Davis military strategy
lead_paragraph: It is an interesting study to note the difference at the present time in the South between the vaporing, gasconading followers and the clear-eyed military leader. The former talk loudly of all possible terrible means of war fare: of fearful and mysterious torpedoes, of mule-mounted cannon, of murderous machines; they propose to meet the iron-clad gunboats with heroic efforts at boarding; they are always just about to make some wonderful coup, such as the capture of Cairo or the invasion of Maryland. Then the desperate guerrilla warfare has glowing charms to their imagination; they are to follow the advancing hosts of the ruthless invader as the Spaniards followed the French; the deadly rifle is to decimate his companies at every cover or thicket; they will cut off his supplies, and then retreat to the mountains' and when at length they are driven to the last ditch, there, in gloomy and lonely desperation, they will die. Thus the aristocratic or popular organs of opinion at the South beguile the ardent imagination and supposed chivalric feeling of the armies. Whatever happens, they "never, never will be conquered," -- "Death, annihilation, before submission!" The chivalric Virginians on Roanoke Island probably took a solemn oath on their revolvers, before the late battle, that, rather than submit, they would die to the last man, and then blow up the magazine. And it is not an incredible thing, that before the gleaming bayonets of the New-York regiments appeared in their front and flank, they really believed themselves that they would never yield.

abstract: Propriety of introducing military drill and physical training into public schools discussed
snippet: Propriety of introducing military drill and physical training into public schools discussed
lead_paragraph: It is proposed to introduce into our public schools, as a part of the system of education, a course of physical training consisting principally of military drill. That the movement is already becoming extremely popular, is evidenced in the fact that during the past Winter it has been advocated and favorably mentioned in the messages of no less than five Governors of Northern States -- New-York, Massachusetts, Pennsylvania, Wisconsin and Minnesota -- and has had prominent notice taken of it by both the Superintendent of Public Education in our own State, and the President of the Board of Education in our own City - the former having introduced the subject into his annual report, and the latter having spoken thereon in his address upon reelection to office. The Governors of other States have also promised to lay the advantages of such an introduction into the schools of their States before their Legislatures at the proper season; and many of our leading educators and naval and military men have given a hearty approval of the movement.

abstract: The most important news this morning is from the Upper Potomac. Leesburgh is now in possession of the National forces. Col. GEARY, on Friday night, left Lovettsville with his whole command, and marching through Wheatland and Waterford, taking a number of prisoners on the way, reached the vicinity of Leesburgh at sunrise yes-
lead_paragraph: The most important news this morning is from the Upper Potomac. Leesburgh is now in possession of the National forces. Col. GEARY, on Friday night, left Lovettsville with his whole command, and marching through Wheatland and Waterford, taking a number of prisoners on the way, reached the vicinity of Leesburgh at sunrise yesterday morning, took possession of Fort Johnson' from which the rebels had fled, and soon afterward entered the town with flags flying and bayonets fixed. Gen. HILL, in command of the rebels' retreated precipitately toward Middleburgh, and our forces soon occupied not only the town, but all the surrounding forts. Many rebels are reported to have been taken prisoners, and large quantities of stores were captured. The importance of this success of the National arms can hardly be estimated at present.

abstract: The exact time at which the French Emperor conceived or received the idea of placing a Hapsburg on a Mexican throne, is a matter of controversy. A dispatch of M. THOUVENEL distinctly declares the project not to be of French origin at all.
lead_paragraph: The exact time at which the French Emperor conceived or received the idea of placing a Hapsburg on a Mexican throne, is a matter of controversy. A dispatch of M. THOUVENEL distinctly declares the project not to be of French origin at all. It sprang up, he intimates, in the desperate counsels of the Mexican reactionists themselves, who broached it first at Vienna, where they met no discouragement, and thence carried it to Paris. The correspondent of the London Times, writing from Paris, pronounces these statements deceptive. He asserts that the idea of enthroning MAXIMILIAN in Mexico is an old and favorite notion of NAPOLEON, who as far back as the summer of 1860, had sounded the Archduke and found him not unkindly disposed. Whether the balance of probability incline to the diplomatic or the newspaper correspondence, the reader is left to judge. We incline, however, to the view that, whenever the approval of MAXIMILIAN was obtained, it was procured by Mexican intrigues and without the direct interposition of the French Government. There is much reason to think the scheme had not recommended itself definitively to the mind of the Emperor, until after the triple treaty had been ratified.

abstract: The Cumberland, which was attacked and sunk by the rebel iron-clad steamer Merrimac, is a sailing sloop-of war, which has been engaged in the blockade of James River. She was a vessel of 1,726 tons burthen, was pierced for 24 guns, and carried 300 officers and men. She was built at Charlestown, Massachusetts, twenty years ago. Previous to the war she was in commission as one of the vessels of the Home Squadron, one was a leaky old affair, and her loss is by no means serious.

abstract: The Congress, which was captured on Saturday by the rebels was an old sailing frigate, employed also in blockading the Virginia waters. She was built at Kittery in 1841, was a vessel of 1,867 tons burthen, and was pierced for 50 guns. She was manned only by a few men of the Naval Coast Squadron, and was just about to be put out of commission, on account of unworthiness, when she was attacked by the rebels. In April last she returned from Montevideo, on the coast of Brazil, where she had been cruising; when she arrived here a large number of her officials, big rebels, resigned. She was retained at Boston, and in September last sailed for duty on the Southern coast.

abstract: We have news of the most exciting character from Fortress Monroe. The rebel iron-clad steamer Merrimac, about which so much has been said recently, came down from Norfolk on Saturday morning, accompanied by the steamers Yorktown and Jamestown, also iron-clad, and moving directly toward Newport's News engaged the sailing frigates Cumberland and Congress,
lead_paragraph: We have news of the most exciting character from Fortress Monroe. The rebel iron-clad steamer Merrimac, about which so much has been said recently, came down from Norfolk on Saturday morning, accompanied by the steamers Yorktown and Jamestown, also iron-clad, and moving directly toward Newport's News engaged the sailing frigates Cumberland and Congress, blockading the mouth of the James River. The Merrimac is represented to have resembled a submerged house, with the roof only above water. The two frigates opened fire upon her, but with no effect, as the heavy metal glanced from the slanting top of the Merrimac. Even at the distance of only one hundred yards, a full broadside from both vessels did her no damage. She ran against the Cumberland amidship, with a full head of steam on, staving a large hole in her side; then drew off and poured in a broadside, after which she dashed against the doomed vessel again, and left her in a sinking condition. She then turned against the Congress, and that vessel, having no regular crew on board, and seeing the hopelessness of further effort, lowered her colors, when she was boarded by the Jamestown, and all her officers were taken prisoners, while the few men on board were allowed to escape in boats. The Congress was then set on tire and left to her fate. The three rebel vessels then opened tire upon our batteries at Newport's News, which had been rendering what assistance was possible to the Cumberland and Congress, and the action continued for some time, when the Merrimac and her two companions drew off as far as Craney Island. The Minnesota, at the commencement of the action, in attempting to tow the Roanoke up' get ashore near the Rip Raps, and could render no assistance. It was supposed that the Merrimac would attempt to run the blockade on Saturday night, and preparations were made accordingly; but she appeals not to have made the effort. Meantime, on Saturday night the iron-clad Ericsson Battery Monitor, which left this port on Wednesday last, arrived at Fortress Monroe, and yesterday morning she was attacked by the Merrimac, Yorktown and Jamestown, but this time they met more than their match. After a five hours' contest, they were driven off, and the Merrimac retreated toward Norfolk in a sinking condition. The full particulars of this last action are yet wanting, but there is no doubt of the correctness of the report, as it is telegraphed officially from Washington, also from Fortress Monroe, by order of Gen. WOOL. The latter dispatch states that at times during the engagement the two iron-clad vessels were touching each other. The Monitor was uninjured.

abstract: Mr. HAMILTON BRUCE, Deputy-Collector and Storekeeper of the Port of New-York, has just published a Warehouse Manual and General Custom-house Guide, which is spoken of in the highest terms. In all Custom-house matters Mr. BRUCE "is to the manner born," having had twenty-five years' service in them, in one capacity of another.
lead_paragraph: Mr. HAMILTON BRUCE, Deputy-Collector and Storekeeper of the Port of New-York, has just published a Warehouse Manual and General Custom-house Guide, which is spoken of in the highest terms. In all Custom-house matters Mr. BRUCE "is to the manner born," having had twenty-five years' service in them, in one capacity of another. Upon the establishment of the Warehouse he was made Chief Clerk of the Division, having charge of it; which Division, by the present Collector, was put again fully in his charge. It is the most important in the Custom-house. It is not too much to say that no person in the Custom-house is more familiar with any branch of service, or more capable and efficient in their discharge. He has taken the above method of placing in the hands of the public, and of parties having business at the Custom-house, the routine of duty or office, entirely familiar to an habitue like himself, but often very complicated machinery to others. In doing this he has performed a most valuable service. The printed regulations of the Treasury Department, it is well known are very voluminous and loosely thrown together, with an index so meagre, and so badly prepared, as to render it about as difficult to find the desired information by any reference to it, as it is from the test itself. The work before us removes all those difficulties. It narrates, in a lucid and concise style, the whole routine of warehousing goods, with copious and judicious selections from the official regulations, giving the most explicit information in regard to bonded warehouses, appraisement of merchandise, damages, allowance, penalties, seizures, drawbacks, &c.; with full and accurate tables of foreign currencies, weights and measures; so that, although the design of the book is to treat principally of goods in bond, it will be found to be a most valuable guide to every branch of Custom-house business. It is a work that should not only be in the hands of every person engaged in commercial matters, but in every public library for general information and reference. We have no doubt it will have a large sale as a testimonial of the regard and esteem which the merchants of the City cherish toward its able and gentlemanly author.

abstract: For a Sea-piece, that fulfills all the conditions of dramatic art as completely as it is possible for a real event to do, commend us to the recital of the battle of Hampton Roads, which we publish to-day.
lead_paragraph: For a Sea-piece, that fulfills all the conditions of dramatic art as completely as it is possible for a real event to do, commend us to the recital of the battle of Hampton Roads, which we publish to-day. ARISTOTLE himself could not ask a nicer observance of the unities than it displays; and it needs no aid from the playwright's craft to throw the series of naval actions that took place off Newport's News, on Saturday, between noon and night, into the form of a dramatic composition, perfect in design and execution, with its beginning, middle and end, and its moral lesson all included.

abstract: Mr. GOTTSCHALK, assisted by the artists of the GRAU opera troupe, has given three concerts in Washington with great success, the sale of tickets having, we hear, to be suspended. The popular pianist will play in Baltimore and Philadelphia during the present week, and perhaps return to Washington. abstract: The new Ericsson battery, or, as she is now called, the Monitor, which left this port for Southern waters last Wednesday, has already had her first engagement with the enemy, and has come out victor. It appears that she arrived in Hampton Roads last Saturday night, just after the rebel battery Merrimac had been playing havou with our blockaders. She came to the rescue precisely at the right moment. Yesterday morning she was set upon by the Merrimac, the Jamestown and the Yorktown. After a live hours' light she drove them all off, the Merrimac putting back to Norfolk in a sinking condition. As the public will now be anxious to know something of the style and power of this iron-clad vessel, which has thus routed the famous rebel iron-clad floating battery, we append a full account of her, furnished by our correspondent, who accompanied her on a recent trial trip from this harbor.

abstract: The Minnesota, which was run ashore after doing good duty against the rebel steamers, is a screw-frigate of 3,200 tons', burthen, pierced for 40 guns, built at Washington Navy-yard in 1855, and was manned by 400 officers and men. She is one of our largest screw steam-frigates, and is what is termed an auxiliary propeller. Her engines are 450 horse-power. Two of her guns are of 11-inch calibre, capable of throwing balls of 160 pounds weight. She has made but one regular cruise since she was built, and that was in the East India waters, from which she returned in 1858. On her return, she went to the Charlestown (Mass.) Navy-yard, where she was overhauled and repaired throughout. In May she sailed from Boston, and did various coast duty, under Capt. SILAS D. STRINGHAM, who was flag-officer of the Atlantic blockading squadron. In August she was the flag-ship of the expedition at the capture of the Hatteras forts by Commodore STRINGHAM, and did effective and brilliant duty in that affair. In September she arrived in this port, with the captured Hatteras prisoners. Shortly after she again went South, but under another commander, and has been doing duty of late at or near Hampton Roads. It is not known whether much damage has been done to her in the engagement.

abstract: The rebel steamer Yorktown, which took part in the fight, was formerly used on the New-York and Virginia line of steamers, running from here to Norfolk, Petersburgh and Richmond. She is a side-wheel steamer of 1,400 tons burthen, was built in this City in 1859, and her size is as follows: Length, 251 feet; breadth, 34 feet; depth, 18 feet. She was seized by the rebels last Summer while in Virginia waters, and was taken to Norfolk and fitted out as a man-of-war. Her sides were plated with iron, and other means were taken to render her strong. Our correspondent at Fortress Monroe, writing on the 6th inst, says he saw her a day or two before when up the James River with a flag of truce, and describes her as quite a formidable looking and formidably armed vessel. She carried six broadside guns rifled, one of which was an Armstrong, and two pivot guns. We believe she was commanded by Capt. PARRISH, late of the United States Navy.

abstract: A SING-SING CONVICT ARRESTED.?Officer WILSON, of the Twenty-eighth Precinct, made an important arrest on Saturday, at the house of Mr. PETER CRAWFORD, in Varick-street. The prisoner is known to the policy as JOHN ANDERSON, alias Wilson, and is by profession a burglar. He was sentenced to the State Prison, about five years ago, for the term of 15 years, for having committed a burglary in this City.
lead_paragraph: A SING-SING CONVICT ARRESTED. -- Officer WILSON, of the Twenty-eighth Precinct, made an important arrest on Saturday, at the house of Mr. PETER CRAWFORD, in Varick-street. The prisoner is known to the policy as JOHN ANDERSON, alias Wilson, and is by profession a burglar. He was sentenced to the State Prison, about five years ago, for the term of 15 years, for having committed a burglary in this City. About three weeks ago he made his escape from prison in a very mysterious manner. Since that time the police of the City have been on the watch for him, but no trace of him could be obtained until he was found in the act of committing another burglary on Mr. CRAWFORD's premises. The prisoner was immediately conveyed back to Sing-Sing, where he has near ten years more to serve the State.

abstract: David O. Nichols by Joseph C. Howe, his Guardian, vs. The Sixth-avenue Railroad Company. -- This case was reported in the TIMES of Feb. 5. The action was brought to recover for damages sustained by the plaintiff, a lad, in attempting to get down from the driver's seat of a one-horse car, which, as alleged, had no brakes, and could not be readily stopped. The lad was attempting to get off while the car was still in motion, the horse being on a walk. The horse became frightened at something, and giving a sudden spring, the boy was thrown to the pavement and seriously injured.
