abstract: The very natural and becoming deference which one nation pays to the opinions of others, renders the American people profoundly solicitous as to the reception which Mr. LINCOLN'S recent Message is to encounter in Europe. Here, where the almost exclusive devotion of the popular mind for fifty years to the single topic has taught, will some degree ...
lead_paragraph: The very natural and becoming deference which one nation pays to the opinions of others, renders the American people profoundly solicitous as to the reception which Mr. LINCOLN'S recent Message is to encounter in Europe. Here, where the almost exclusive devotion of the popular mind for fifty years to the single topic has taught, will some degree of clearness, the nature and bearings of the Slavery question, the suggestions of the President meet nothing but cordial approbation. The popular understanding in Europe is less thoroughly cultivated. The subject has been remote, and has been regarded rather with the languid interest with which we treat faraway objects, than with that acute insight which aids our inquiry into matters affecting the National life. American Slavery is in Europe an abstraction; here it is a practical question, the solution of which employs every faculty. While here we fully comprehend the relation of the National Government to the institutions of the individual State, it has been almost impossible to convey any notion of this relation to the transatlantic inquirer. If the National Government have a right to coerce the people of separate States into obedience to its central authority, why has it not power to alter and amend their domestic institutions, where humanity so imperiously demands their amendment? If the Central Government has no right to prescribe the abolition of Slavery, the right of the States to secede is incontrovertible, and the war it wages upon the South is fratricidal and oppressive. These propositions have formed the entire ground work of European reasoning on the American issue, and may possibly prevent, a just appreciation of the measure, which the President, mindful of constitutional order, has wisely recommended. It may be asked, will the American people content themselves with a mere palliative, where an absolute remedy is in their hands? Why not declare the slaves of the South free by proclamation? Or, if compensation be determined upon, why not make its acceptance compulsory, as it was under the British abolition act? And unless the answer which springs to the lips of every intelligent American, finds some to utter it in Europe, and make understood there the well-marked limit between National and local authority, clearly showing the former to be a creature of delegated powers, exactly defined, while the residue of power remains to the State, and how the National Legislature has no more authority to meddle with Slavery in a State than it has to meddle with a suttee in India, fault, it is very likely, will be found with the Presidential project, as a delusive and wholly ineffective measure. We certainly believe a less imperfect idea of our political system has been recently diffused in Europe. It is beginning to be understood that the Union is something different from a more confederation; that the cohesion of the States is not purely mechanical. The more kindly feeling with which our Government and its cause are regarded in England, France and Germany, is clearly due to the light which Messrs. MOTLEY, STORY, WEED, and others, have been at pains to throw upon a subject which rebel emissaries had thoroughly muddled. The true theory of our Constitution is no longer an insoluble enigma. And if the better intelligence to which we are referring has become so current as to guide and influence, in some measure, the tone of the leading journals of London, Paris and Germany, we may anticipate a fair and equitable discussion of Mr. LINCOLN's proposition.

abstract: We hear of renewed clamors at Washington for an immediate advance of the army of the Potomac. Our successes at the West have fairly intoxicated the minds of some or our civic warriors at Washington, and they demand a movement in front, of the Capital without delay, and without the slightest regard to the circumstanced of the case. This unreasonable temper will, of course, be greatly encouraged by the news of this morning, that the rebels are actually in retreat.

abstract: We hope the recent news from Hampton Roads has somewhat reassured the timid souls who were certain, on Sunday night, that the Merrimac would speedily visit this harbor and lay New-York in ashes. Their magnificent project of sinking stone-boats in the channel, for the purpose of keeping her out, may safely be postponed for a few weeks. Naturally enough the exploits of the Merrimac excited some consternation, Her movements were bold and brilliant, and if she had met nothing more formidable than the ordinary wooden frigates of our navy, it is not easy to limit the amount of mischief she might have done. But it was absurd to suppose that, under any circumstances, she could have, been tempted to visit New-York. In the first place, it is very doubtful whether she could possibly stand the sea voyage. In the next, there is scarcely one chance in three that she could pass the forts that guard the entrance to the harbor. And in the third place, even if she could get in, it is not easy to see how she could possibly get out. In any event, she is not likely to enter upon such an adventure as a hostile visit to this port; and it is not worth while to destroy the harbor by way of protecting the City just yet.

abstract: The steamer Seth Low, Capt. COFFIN, from Fortress Monroe, in 24 hours, has just arrived at this port. She sailed hence on the 6th inst., at 10 A.M., with the battery Monitor in tow, the wind light from N. W. At 11 P.M. she made Barnegat light, wind N.W. On the 7th, at 4 A.M. Absecomb light was in
lead_paragraph: The steamer Seth Low, Capt. COFFIN, from Fortress Monroe, in 24 hours, has just arrived at this port. She sailed hence on the 6th inst., at 10 A.M., with the battery Monitor in tow, the wind light from N. W. At 11 P.M. she made Barnegat light, wind N.W. On the 7th, at 4 A.M. Absecomb light was in sight, and the wind was from the North and quite strong. At 10:30 A.M., made the Capes of the Delaware, the wind still blowing strong from N.N.W., and the sea breaking over the battery, when she set her colors Union down, and reported that the sea had broken in her smoke-pipes and put out the fires. She shaped N,W, for five hours to keep her head to the sea. The gunboats Sachem and currituck were in sight, but were unable to render any assistance. After five hours the wind moderated, and she arrived at Fortress Monroe at 9 P.M. on the 8th.

abstract: The capture of Fernandina and the forts defending it., and the rout of the rebels there stationed, virtually gives us military possession of the entire State of Florida. Through Fernandina we control the whole eastern coast line of the peninsula. On the
lead_paragraph: -- The capture of Fernandina and the forts defending it, and the rout of the rebels there stationed, virtually gives us military possession of the entire State of Florida. Through Fernandina we control the whole eastern coast line of the peninsula. On the southern Keys we hold alt the fortifications and positions of strength. On the Gulf line we have possession of Cedar Keys, and from thence we communicate by railroad across the entire peninsula to the point of beginning At the western extremity again we hold Fort Pickens; and it is only opposite that fortification, at Pensacola, that the rebels now make anything like an organized resistance. The State will, doubtless, speedily be declared under martial law-small bodies of troops stationed at Tallahassee, St. Augustine and one or two other points; and the loyalty of the people will be gradually developed, and the contraband cotton and rice of this fertile region will find an outlet to the markets of the world. There must be 150,000 bales of cotton now lying in Florida, besides rice, sugar and tobacco in great quantity; and there is little danger of the planters in a thinly settled region of country like that, getting so hot in their political excitement as to set fire to their cotton. The fact that commodore DUPONT took down some forty vessels with him in his expedition, looks as if some of them were intended for other work than carrying shot and shell. Florida has but a small white population, and the plantations are mostly large and the planters rich. The bulk of the settlers are from South Carolina and adjoining Slave States; and in politics it has always been but a tail to the Palmetto Oligarchy. A period of military drill would teach these violent and aristocratic rebels, one or two valuable lessons.

abstract: The affair of the Merrimac has proved incontestibly the absolute necessity of iron-clad vessels in naval warfare. All the experiments and speculations in the world become of little importance in presence of the decisive test which she encountered. All our best and
lead_paragraph: The affair of the Merrimac has proved incontestibly the absolute necessity of iron-clad vessels in naval warfare. All the experiments and speculations in the world become of little importance in presence of the decisive test which she encountered. All our best and most formidable wooden vessels proved to be utterly ineffective against her mail-clad sides; and nothing but the most fortunate circumstance that we had just completed one war vessel of the same sort, enabled us to resist her raid upon our naval defences. But for the opportune presence of the Monitor, we do not see what could have prevented the Merrimac from destroying every one of our vessels in Hampton Roads, and then proceeding by a similar process to clear the Southern coast of our blockading squadron.

abstract: There is reason to believe the rebel army, that has so long threatened the capital of the union, is preparing for immediate retreat. With
lead_paragraph: There is reason to believe the rebel army, that has so long threatened the capital of the union, is preparing for immediate retreat. The reports from the officer in command of the Potomac flotilla is that the batteries, which have decorated the right bank of the river, have been removed, the artillerists have gone, the blockade is ended. With equal confidence, the statement is made at Washington that Centreville and Winchester have both been evacuated. If, indeed, the forces on the river have been withdrawn, the fact raises the strongest presumption that -- Manassas itself is to be instantly abandoned. The river batteries were never so much designed to obstruct the approach to Washington, as to secure another most essential point. This was to prevent the crossing of the National forces, already in great strength on the left bank, and accessible to unlimited reinforcements from the reserve at Washington. Had Gen. HOOKER, in the absence of opposing batteries, effected a landing in the rear of Gen. JOHNSTON, the movement would not only have exposed that commander to the risk of being surrounded and captured, but would have severed the most important line of rebel communication with Richmond -- that by way of Frederickshurgh. These dangers the batteries have effectually guarded against. Their withdrawal naturally suggests that the occasion for their services no longer exists; in other words, that the insurgent army is making ready to retreat beyond Fredericksburgh.

abstract: The tide of triumph has set in so steadily and persistently, that it is difficult to keep with the torrent. A victory at the West is echoed by one from the East, and the sound scarcely dies away before the reverberation from a yet more distant West falls on the car. To-day we announce the splendid result of the pursuit of Gen. PRICE, It will be remem
lead_paragraph: The tide of triumph has set in so steadily and persistently, that it is difficult to keep with the torrent. A victory at the West is echoed by one from the East, and the sound scarcely dies away before the reverberation from a yet more distant West falls on the car. To-day we announce the splendid result of the pursuit of Gen. PRICE, It will be remembered that Gen. CURTIS, with Gen. SIGEL as his stalwart support, set off several weeks ago in chase of the fugitive Missourian. He pushed forward with relentless energy, reached the Arkansas line, passed it, and still PRICE retreated, counting, doubtless, on receiving sufficient reinforcements to enable him to make a stand in a position of his own selection. Happily for the cause of the Union, his plan succeeded. Joined successively by Gens. BEN MCCULLOCH and VAN DORN, with the united forces of Louisiana, Texas and Arkansas, and by MCINTOSH, with his Indians, he at last awaited the attack of CURTIS at a point not named in the dispatch of Gen. HALLECK, but probably at Boston Mountain, a ridge on the north side of the Arkansas this. For, at the latest previous advices, this point had been chosen for the conflict, and the Union troops were in its immediate vicinity. Of the action itself, we have no other information than that the engagement was extremely bloody, resulting in a loss on the National side of a thousand in killed and wounded. The defeat of the rebels is reported as complete.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a number of petitions and memorials on various subjects were presented ?among them a memorial asking Congress to permit no abridgment of the liberty of the Press. A bill to fulfill treaty stipulations with Hanover, regarding the abolition of the Stadt dues, was passed. A joint resolution was offered by Mr.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, a number of petitions and memorials on various subjects were presented -- among them a memorial asking Congress to permit no abridgment of the liberty of the Press. A bill to fulfill treaty stipulations with Hanover, regarding the abolition of the Stadt dues, was passed. A joint resolution was offered by Mr. GRIMES, of Iowa, and referred to the Committee on Military Affairs, giving it as the opinion of the Senate that no person should be appointed commander of a division except such as exhibit superior competency in command, or gallantry in conflict. A joint resolution, in accordance with the suggestion in the President's Special Message, tendering the aid of the Government to the States of Maryland and Delaware, and favoring voluntary emancipation, was offered by Mr. WILSON, of Massachusetts, but objected to by Mr. SAULSBURY, of Delaware, and laid over. The bill to encourage enlistments in the army was taken up, and after being amended by adding a bill to reorganize the cavalry, it was passed -- the number of cavalry regiments being reduced to thirty. The Confiscation bill was then taken up, and Mr. BROWNING, of Illinois, made a speech in opposition to it. At the conclusion of his speech a joint resolution of thanks to Commodore FOOTE was passed. The House bill providing a new Article of War, prohibiting officers of the army from returning fugitive slaves, was debated at considerable length, and finally passed as it came from the House, 29 to 9.

abstract: -- The resolution suggested by the Message of the President was before the House yesterday. On motion of Mr. ROSCOE CONKLING the rules were suspended to receive it, the vote being eighty-six to thirty-five. The opposition came mainly from the Democratic opposition to the Administration, strengthened by a few Border-State Representatives, among whom we regret to notice the name of Mr. CRITTENDEN. The vote, however, is very far from conclusive as to the sense of the House. The members from the Northern Slave States appear rather to demand time for reflection andconsultation with their constituents than to have taken a decisive stand against the measure; and should they hereafter give the support they cannot withhold with any propriety, it is hardly likely the Democratic minority will persist in opposition. We sincerely trust the House will yet give the resolution the moral sanction of a unanimous vote.

abstract: Brunswick we described last Thursday, when the rumor of its evacuation by the rebels reached us. It is eighty miles from Savannah, is situated upon a bluff on Turtle River, and is a port of entry with a very fine harbor, with 13 feet of water over the bar at low tide. The town has but a hundred or two of resi-
lead_paragraph: Brunswick we described last Thursday, when the rumor of its evacuation by the rebels reached us. It is eighty miles from Savannah, is situated upon a bluff on Turtle River, and is a port of entry with a very fine harbor, with 13 feet of water over the bar at low tide. The town has but a hundred or two of residents, and is the terminus of an uncompleted railroad running southward to Florida. Upon St. Simon's Island, which lies directly east of the mainland, the rebels had erected earthworks to guard the entrance into the ship-channel. These works were on the southern point of the island, and on Ickyl's Island opposite there were some minor defences. But the rebels a short time ago removed all the guns from these points and from Brunswick itself, for the defence of Savannah, which was adroitly menaced for this very purpose. The possession of Brunswick and Fernandina is valuable, in as much as they are all the seaports of any value between Port Royal and Key West, which is also in our hands. A brief study of the diagrams will show clearly both the relative and minute topography of the points mentioned.

abstract: In this Court, yesterday, before Judge MCCUNN, Daniel Cunningham, better known among the sporting fraternity as "Dad" Cunningham, pleaded guilty to an indictment for keeping a gambling-house, and was remanded for sentence on Saturday next. The counsel for the prisoner stated to the Court that his client had some time since abandoned the business on which the indictment stood against him, and requested until Saturday to show to the Court this, with other facts, which it was hoped would tend to mitigate his sentence.

abstract: Our readers will recollect in the diplomatic correspondence between Mr. SEWARD and Lord LYONS, published some time since, a complaint on the part of the latter of the conduct of one of our vessels, which, having taken a prize, sent her into port with the English flag flying under the American flag, and Mr. SEWARD'S prompt disavowal and apology for the act.
lead_paragraph: Our readers will recollect in the diplomatic correspondence between Mr. SEWARD and Lord LYONS, published some time since, a complaint on the part of the latter of the conduct of one of our vessels, which, having taken a prize, sent her into port with the English flag flying under the American flag, and Mr. SEWARD'S prompt disavowal and apology for the act. In another column will be found this morning the decision of Judge BETTS in the action brought to forfeit the vessel as a prize. The vessel was the schooner Jane Campbell. She, was taken off Beaufort, N.C. When first boarded by the steamer Stale of Georgia, she was found to have met with injury at sea, and gave the excuse for being in the place where she was found, that she was in need of repairs and supplies. Subsequently, on an examination of her cargo and papers, suspicious circumstances appeared, sufficient in the view of the Court to warrant the sending her in for trial, and the was accordingly seized and sent to this port. The crew of the seizing vessel were allowed to help themselves to her cargo; the Captain of another of our vessels, the Albatross, was allowed to carry away from her eight muskets and ammunition therefor; some of the claimants on board were taken off the vessel and carried to Baltimore, and there left to find their way to New-York, as best they might, and on the passage here the English flag was carried, as was before stated.

abstract: A special dispatch to the Republican, from Cairo, says Gen. POPE'S forces have reached New Madrid, and heavy cannonading had been heard in that direction. The enemy are there in strong force and gunboats from here will soon move down to assist Gen. POPE'S force. The enemy have been endeavoring to drive the latter back by throwing shells among them from their boats.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, after the presentation of petitions, notice was given of a bill to repeal all acts prohibiting foreign vessels from carrying the mails to Panama and Aspinwall. A resolution was offered by Mr. WILSON, of Massachusetts, that the Naval Committee be directed to inquire into the late naval engagement in Hampton Roads, and the destruction of property there. The bill providing for the purchase of coin was debated until the expiration of the morning hour, but not disposed of. The Confiscation bill wasthen taken up, and Mr. CARLILE, of Virginia, made a speech in opposition to it. Consideration of the Bill for the purpose of coin was then resumed, and it was finally passed, with Mr. FESSENDEN's amendment with regard to the amount of deposits. Mr. WILSON, of Massachusetts, offered an amendment to the Confiscation bill, in the shape of a substitute for the first section, which was ordered to be printed, and the Senate adjourned.

abstract: John S. Hicks vs. Newcomb Cleveland. -- This action was stated in the TIMES of yesterday. The suit was brought to recover damages for an alleged wrongful detention of personal property. abstract: Never, on any occasion, were greater successes chronicled than those we placed before our readers yesterday. Never was a campaign carried on, on a grander scale; nor one so well calculated to impress the imagination by the vastness of its plans, or the manner of their execution.
lead_paragraph: Never, on any occasion, were greater successes chronicled than those we placed before our readers yesterday. Never was a campaign carried on, on a grander scale; nor one so well calculated to impress the imagination by the vastness of its plans, or the manner of their execution. After months of quiet preparation, which foreigners took for imbecility and accepted as the success of the rebellion, and at which our own people were at times disposed to murmur, a simultaneous movement has been made along a line measuring more than five thousand miles -- that upon land swarming with soldiers; that upon sea with ships -- a movement that is so irresistible in its force as to be often unopposed, because resistance is hopeless. Upon the banks of the Potomac in the East, Tennessee in the centre, and Arkansas in the far West, the march is onward, and the effective blow struck at almost the same instant -- an offensive movement, directed by a common purpose and to a common end, however different may have been the resistance offered or the means and method of attack. Upon the other frontier of the rebels -- the sea -- our ships are everywhere present, from the capes of Virginia to the capes of Florida, seizing their maritime strongholds and driving them back into the interior. The coils we have thrown around them are drawing closer and closer, till no alternative will be left but destruction or immediate submission. The latter will be the means of escape, as the rebels, if we except the leaders, who may prefer ignominious death at their own hands than at those of the enemy, have not a cause that nerves to martyrdom.

abstract: Maj.-Gen. SAMUEL R. CURTIS, who comes so prominently before the public in connection with the battle and victory of Pea Ridge, is a native of Ohio, and a man of 54 years of age. He was a resident of New-York when, as a Cadet, he, in 1827, entered West Point; he was breveted Second Lieutenant Seventh Infantry, 1831, and next year resigned from the army. He devoted himself to the law and to civil engineering, and in 1837-9 was Chief Engineer of the Muskingum River improvement. He was for years an Engineer of the Ohio Board of Public Works, and in 1846 he was appointed Adjutant-General of that State. In June of that year, having prepared the military outfit of the Ohio volunteers for the Mexican war, he took the field himself as Colonel of the Third Ohio. At the close of his year's service he acted as Assistant Adjutant-General to Gen. WOOL; he was subsequently Civil and Military Governor of Saltillo; also, in 1847, of Matamoras, Camargo and Monterey. When he returned to the United States, he practiced law for a time, but when the State of Iowa entered on the project of removing the obstructions at the Des Moines Rapids of the Mississippi River, he was chosen Chief Engineer, and took up his residence at Keokuk. He was elected to Congress from Iowa, as a Republican member of the Thirty-fifth Congress, and reelected to the Thirty-sixth. On the breaking out of the war he resigned his seat to accept a commission as Brigadier-General, and in May last entered on his duties. He was assigned to duty in Missouri, which was then in the throes of revolution. He did much active service under FREMONT, and shortly after Gen. HALLECK look command of the Department, he was appointed to command the expedition intended to clear the rebels out of Southwestern Missouri. He left Rolla, in January, with a force twenty thousand strong, drove PRICE from Springfield, routed him at Cross Hollows, and now has defeated the combined commands of all the rebel Generals in Arkansas. Congress, a few days ago, signified their approval of his merits by appointing him a Major-General of Volunteers.

abstract: By the arrival of the steamship North American at Portland, we have advices frow Europe one day later than were received by the City of Washington. She left Liverpool on the 27th, and Londonderry on the 28th ult. The papers relating to our blockade had been laid before the British Parliament.
lead_paragraph: By the arrival of the steamship North American at Portland, we have advices frow Europe one day later than were received by the City of Washington. She left Liverpool on the 27th, and Londonderry on the 28th ult. The papers relating to our blockade had been laid before the British Parliament. Among them is a letter from Earl RUSSELLto Lord LYONS dated so late as the 15th ult., declaring that the fact of ships having successfully run the blockade was no proof of its inefficiency. He argues that a neutral State should exercise great caution regarding a de facto blockade, and ought not to disregard it unless the right of the blockade should be abused. The unemployed laborers at Liverpool had made some demonstrations, but had been peaceably dispersed by the Police.

abstract: -If ever man leaped into enviable fame it is the distinguished engineer whose creative genius constructed the battery which arrived so opportunely in Hampton Roads on Sunday to drive off the Merrimac, and save the country from untold disaster. The name of ERICSSON is on every lip, and is repeated with admiration and gratitude by rejoicing millions. We may mention, as an interesting fact, that so doubtful did the Government feel respecting the plan on which the Monitor was built, that she was not to be paid for until she should prove in battle her capability of doing all that was promised. She will now, probably, be paid for! We understand that a subscription paper is in circulation among our merchants, which is intended as a suitable testimonial to Capt. ERICSSON, for his services as an inventor, and that handsome sums were subscribed yesterday.

abstract: Manassas, the great Rebel stronghold in Virginia, has been evacuated, and the Union Flag now floats over the works there, which were occupied on Monday night by National troops. Persons in the vicinity allege that the evacuation was only recently resolved upon, and the removal of the guns was commenced only about a week ago the last rebel troops leaving on Friday last.
lead_paragraph: Manassas, the great Rebel stronghold in Virginia, has been evacuated, and the Union Flag now floats over the works there, which were occupied on Monday night by National troops. Persons in the vicinity allege that the evacuation was only recently resolved upon, and the removal of the guns was commenced only about a week ago -- the last rebel troops leaving on Friday last. They seem to have been laboring under the most intense panic, and a wild haste characterized their movements. Our troops found everything there in the wildest confusion. The works, however, were left entirely unharmed, with log huts capable of accommodating one hundred and fifty thousand men. The rebels also left behind them commissary and hospital stores in large quantities, besides wagons, tents, caissons, and other valuables. But the most remarkable announcement in regard to this remarkable flight, is that the division of rebel troops at Winchester, under command of Gen. JACKSON, has been left behind, and is consequently cut off and in imminent danger of capture. It was supposed at first that Winchester had also been evacuated, but dispatches received at headquarters yesterday state positively that JACKSON is still there. No better proof could be afforded of the haste with which the main army left Centreville and Manassas. Gordonsville is given as the point to which the rebels have retired. This is behind the Rappahannock River, and is in some respects a position equal to that at Manassas, though without the extensive fortifications of the latter place.

abstract: The location of the battle can be seen from any ordinary map of Arkansas, or of the United States. It was in the extreme northwestern part of the State, and in the northwesternmost county (Benton.) A range of hills (of the Ozark range) will be seen sweep [Continued on Eighth Page.]
lead_paragraph: The location of the battle can be seen from any ordinary map of Arkansas, or of the United States. It was in the extreme northwestern part of the State, and in the northwesternmost county (Benton.) A range of hills (of the Ozark range) will be seen sweeping from Missouri through this corner of the State, and from thence branching into the Indian Territory, where that section known as the Boston Mountain is found. Big Sugar Creek, near which the fight began, is a short distance north of Bentonville, the capital of Benton County, and Pea Ridge, which is a part of the mountain range, is but a short distance from the same town. Cross Timber Hollows, to and from which the rebels were chased, is four miles from the head-waters of the Osage Creek. The enemy retreated in two directions, part of them through one of the mountain defites toward the Indian Territory, and part in a southeasterly direction. At the time when Gen. CURTIS' report ends they were being pursued in both directions by our cavalry and infantry. The section of country where the battle took place is a wild, hilly region, where, in case of a rout, it would be extremely difficult to pursue the routed enemy.

abstract: United States steam transport Philadelphia HENRY BARTON Commander, from Fort Pickens March 1, Fort Jefferson, Tortugas, March 4, and Key West March 6th, 8 A.M., arrived last night. The Philadelphia took out from New York 116 head of cattle and 50 sheep, and landed them all without losing one.
lead_paragraph: United States steam transport Philadelphia HENRY BARTON Commander, from Fort Pickens March 1, Fort Jefferson, Tortugas, March 4, and Key West March 6th, 8 A.M., arrived last night. The Philadelphia took out from New York 116 head of cattle and 50 sheep, and landed them all without losing one. Left at Fort Pickens the United States steamer Mississippi, and brigs Elmir, PARKER, and Yankee, Blade, FAIRCHILD; three-masted schooner Meerschaum unloading stores; United States storeship Fearnol, Capt. TANCON, sailed for Ship Island March 1, taking the Philadelphia's mail for that place. Dark Tycoon arrived at Fort Jefferson, Tortugas, March 2, from New-York with four companies New-Hampshire Seventh; all well. Bark Snap Dragon and brig A.C. Meryman unloading stores for fort. Left at Key West United States brig Bainbridge, steamers Santiago de Cuba and R.R. Cuyler.

abstract: Col. GEARY, Acting Brigadier-General of troops here, made a personal reconnoissance yesterday as far as CARTER'S Mills. The trail of the retreating enemy was blackened with the ruins of granaries, ashes of hay and grain stacks, fences, etc. He found the bridge over Goose Creek had been burned after our occupation here on Saturday. The enemy have completely fallen back. The command continues to make captures from rank Secessionists.
lead_paragraph: LEESBURGH, Va., Tuesday, March 11.

abstract: -Speed will obviously be found quite as important an element in the new era of naval warfare, as impregnable sides. The Monitor has shown herself more than a match for the Warrior, as to the ability to give and take hard knocks, for the Warrior's sides have never been tested with half the shock of a 11-inch wrought iron globe, at short range, while her guns are far inferior to those of the Merrimac. But the Warrior sails sixteen and a half miles an hour, while the Monitor was not intended for above eight or ten. Once out of range, therefore, the Warrior could pass on conquering and to conquer. But the Stevens Battery, according to the unanimous report of the Board of Examiners, will run at above nineteen miles an hour, besides throwing 2,200 lbs. at a broadside -- 15-inch shot at that -- while the Warrior's broadside is but 1,554 lbs. We cannot tell how soon a European iron-clad frigate may thunder at our gates. Is it wise, then, to withhold $750,000 to finish this great engine of defence, when $15,000,000 is not too much for gunboats which the Warrior could simply run down without firing a shot?
lead_paragraph: -Speed will obviously be found quite as important an element in the new era of naval warfare, as impregnable sides. But the Warrior sails sixteen and a half miles an hour, while the Monitor was not intended for above eight or ten. Once out of range, therefore, the Warrior could pass on conquering and to conquer. abstract: The official bulletin of the National victory in Arkansas, leaves no doubt about the thoroughness with which the task of Gen. CURTIS has been done. The rebel force has been beaten and dispersed; hostile cavalry hang upon the rear of its escaping fragments. BEN McCULLOCH, the busiest of the conspirators in the Southwest, is among the slain. A better day's work has not been achieved since the war began.

abstract: At a time when we can reasonably look forward to a speedy supersedure of the blockade which for the past ten months the United States have established over the coast of the insurgent States, it is rather interesting to have assurance that the British Government considers it "effective."
lead_paragraph: At a time when we can reasonably look forward to a speedy supersedure of the blockade which for the past ten months the United States have established over the coast of the insurgent States, it is rather interesting to have assurance that the British Government considers it "effective." If the ways of Cabinet Ministers were not past all understanding, we might just entertain a wish that Her Majesty's Foreign Secretary had seen his way to giving us the distinguished assurance any time during the past six months, when the air has been thick with ominous whispers of foreign intervention. Late as it is, however, the declaration which Earl RUSSELL makes in his dispatch to Lord LYONS, dated Feb. 15, is highly satisfactory and gratifying. It appears that all the representations of JEFF.'s London Commissioners -- YANCEY, ROST and MANN -- touching the inefficiency and consequent illegality of the blockade, have proved unavailing. Facts have spoken louder than secessionist figures, and the Cabinet has rightly put over against the formidable schedule of vessels that the rebels claim to have run the gauntlet of our coast squadron, the general scope of the blockade which -- the rebels themselves being witnesses -- has been terrible in its completeness. The language of Earl RUSSELL is noteworthy. He declares that the fact of ships having successfully run the blockade does not prevent it from being effective, and he argues that neutral States ought to exercise great caution with regard to a de facto blockade, and ought not to disregard it unless the power of the blockade should be abused.

abstract: The nervous people who could not sleep on Sunday night, in anticipation of the advent of the Merrimac in our harbor to bombard New-York, now turn their fears in the direction of Washington, and are troubled lest the marine monster should go up and smash Congress as badly as it did the vessel of that name at Hampton Roads. There is one hydrographic fact that should allay their fears. The Merrimac draws twenty-three feet of water. At Alexandria -- below Washington -- the, channel of the Potomac affords but twenty feet. This would perhaps be an obstacle.

abstract: The schooner J.M. Chapman, Capt. A.J. CHAPMAN, belonging at New-London, Conn., arrived at this port Monday. She left the frigate Vermont, on last Thursday, in latitude 38째 45' N., longitude 68째 8' W. She was still drifting, but all on board were well, excepting Capt. PAULDING, who was slightly injured during the gale which disabled the Vermont. The Chapman lay by the Vermont from Saturday ( March 1) until Thursday, (March 6,) lending her all the assistance possible. Capt. CHAPMAN brings dispatches to the Government from Capt. PAULDING, and a steamer will be immediately dispatched to search for the disabled frigate.

abstract: The United States transport Oriental, Captain TUZO, arrived at this port at 10 o'clock last night, from Key West and Port Royal. She left Port Royal at 5 P.M. of the 8th, and experienced fine weather the entire passage.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a Bill to amend the Act for the speedy payment of the Volunteers of the State, passed a few days ago, so as to obviate the difficulty which has arisen between the State and General Governments, was passed. A Bill to repeal the Act to widen Tenth-avenue, Brooklyn, was reported.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, a Bill to amend the Act for the speedy payment of the Volunteers of the State, passed a few days ago, so as to obviate the difficulty which has arisen between the State and General Governments, was passed. A Bill to repeal the Act to widen Tenth-avenue, Brooklyn, was reported. Among the Bills passed was one to impose a tax on dogs, one to close a part of Partition-street, Brooklyn, and one to enforce the responsibility of Bank stockholders. The bill to confer power on the Metropolitan Police to inspect steam-boilers was amended so that no person shall be detailed for the duty unless a practical engineer, and ordered to a third reading. During the proceedings an announcement was made that Manassas had been occupied by the National forces, and it occasioned the greatest excitement for a time. After the adjournment three cheers for the victory were given with a will.

abstract: Official information, to-day, reports that the enemy formerly encamped back of and below Occoquan have retreated, destroying everything they could not carry on their backs. They left on Saturday. Our troops took possession this morning, and were welcomed by a part of the inhabitants with great joy. Every boat in the vicinity, and anything that would float, had been destroyed. The rebels told the villagers they were going to fall back to the Rappahannock.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Tuesday, March 11.

abstract: Before Justices Ingraham, Clerke and Leonard. James Shepherd vs. the People of the State of New-York Shepherd was tried at General Sessions, in December, 1857, for arson in the first degree, and found guilty. The offence alleged in the indictment was charged to have been committed in June, 1857. Sentence of death was pronounced upon him Dec. 21, 1857, and he was ordered to be executed on the 8th day of the following February.

abstract: The intelligence of the evacuation of Winchester, yesterday, was premature. It was Berryville that the reconnoissance reported evacuated. The latest intelligence from Winchester is to the effect that the town is occupied by at least one brigade of infantry. Other troops are also there. There is a strong suspicion that a portion of the forces which evacuated Centreville have been ordered to reinforce Winchester.

abstract: William Horace Smith vs. William A. Mead et al. -- This was an action on two promissory notes. The defence admits that defendants executed and delivered two promissory notes to plaintiff, but denies, on information and belief, that the description of the notes mentioned in the complaint is a true description of the notes delivered to plaintiff. It also denies, on information and belief, that plaintiff, at the commencement of the action, was the bona fide owner and holder or said notes.

abstract: Matter of the Will of A.H.P. Edwards The executor of this will, Hon. Edwards Pierrepont, instituted this proceeding to obtain a judicial construction of the will. The case was stated in the TIMES of Feb. 6. The testator died in 1857, leaving no children. His personal estate was estimated at $132,000. The real estate, as stated, was unproductive, consisting mostly of wild lands in the State of Illinois. It was valued at $30,000.
lead_paragraph: Before Justices Ingraham, Clerke and Leonard.

abstract: The general recognition by the public Press of all parties, and all degrees of opinion, on the subject of Slavery, of the conservative spirit of the President's Special Message, is a gratifying sign of the era of good feeling which is soon to succeed the present expiring rebellion.
lead_paragraph: The general recognition by the public Press of all parties, and all degrees of opinion, on the subject of Slavery, of the conservative spirit of the President's Special Message, is a gratifying sign of the era of good feeling which is soon to succeed the present expiring rebellion. There is a warmth of approval of the honest purpose of the Executive head of the nation, which denotes the strongest popular confidence, not only in his integrity, but in his will and ability to bring the whole country out of its great trouble. That with all this there should be differences of opinion as to the immediately operative action of his recommendation, was to be expected. But even these differences, we are happy to find, are accompanied by expressions of the utmost kindness for Mr. LINCOLN, and the highest appreciation of his patriotic motive.

abstract: Biographical sketch
snippet: Biographical sketch
lead_paragraph: The career of Gen. BEN. MCCULLOCH, who is reported by Gen. CURTIS as having been killed at the battle of Pea Ridge, is so well known that it is hardly necessary to recapitulate now. But, if he be killed, this will be the last of him. As, however, since the war began, be has not only been ubiquitous in his presence, but has been slain several times, he may, perhaps, turn up again. He is a Tennesseean by birth, and 48 years of age. He first became famous in his native State, as a bear-killer. In 1835 he went to Texas with DAVY CROCKETT to take part in the Texan revolution, and SAM HOUSTON assigned him to the artillery and made him captain of a gun. He afterwards settled in Texas and became celebrated in Indian fights. When the Mexican war broke out he raised a band of Texans on the Guadaloupe, whose services were accepted by TAYLOR. He was employed in scouting expeditions and took a hand in various battles of the war; for which services President PIERCE afterward appointed him United States Marshal for Texas. When the Mormon rebellion broke out, he was appointed one of the Peace Commissioners to Utah, though a more unfit person could not have been discovered in the country. When the present rebellion broke out, he was sought for by JEFF. DAVIS, and has been engaged everywhere, and in all sorts of rebel service. He took a body of Texans to Missouri and assisted Gen. PRICE in various engagements, and particularly in the battle of Springfield. After that he quarreled with PRICE, and retired with his army to Arkansas, and stationed himself at Fort Smith. When Gen. CURTIS gave the present chase to the rebels, he again came north to the Arkansas northern line, with all the other rebel commanders in that section; and has now fallen, a traitor to his country. In person he was remarkable -- six feet high, slender but athletic, and with the appearance and air of a frontier fighter. He was undauntedly a partisan leader of capacity' but was utterly unfit to command a large body of men.

abstract: Yesterday morning, about 12b of those who were wounded at Roanoke Island, or are disabled by sickness, arrived here from Philadelphia. Arrangements had been made for them, and as soon as they had arrived at Jersey City, they were transferred across the river to the City Hall Park Barracks, where many of them still are. Most of them are from the New-York Massachusetts, Connecticut and Rhode Island regiments. They left Roanoke Island last Thursday, on the Ellen S. Terry, and were to have been carried directly here, but were landed at Baltimore, and arrived, via Philadelphia, as stated. The agents of the Eastern States are making arrangements for the further transportation of the men to their homes. The Union Defence Committee have obtained a list of their names, and they will supply what is necessary in all cases where assistance is needful. They are all cheerful, appear satisfied; will probably all recover; and many, as soon as recovered, will return to their respective regiments. They were accompanied by a number of officers who have resigned, or returned on furlough. Lieut.-Col. MAGGI, of the Twenty-fourth Massachusetts, who has resigned, came, with them to Baltimore, whence he proceeded to Washington. The body of Lieut.-Col. MONTEUIL, late of the Fifty-third New-York, (D'Espineuil Zouaves,) was brought on with the wounded men, consigned to his regiment, and consequently was left there. It is probable, however, that it will soon be forwarded to this City. Some of the men from Massachusetts and Connecticut left for home last evening.

abstract: The Old Point beat has arrived. We learn through Lieut. HAYWARD that a copy of the Norfolk Day Book had reached Old Point. It contains a highly colored account of Saturday's fight, and pays a great compliment to the bravery of the crew of the Cumberland. It admits that some of the shot from that vessel entered the Merrimac. One shell killed 17 men and wounded Capt. BUCHANAN, who subsequently died.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday the bill providing for the construction of a railroad through the Northern wilderness was reported favorably. A bill to revise the act to create a Commission to amend the Charter of this City -- the same as the Assembly bill -- was introduced. The bill to transfer the duties of Inspectors of Steam-boilers to the Metropolitan Police was passed. A resolution was adopted requiring the Health Officer to report all receipts and expenses of the office for the year.

abstract: Three important War Bulletins have been issued by President LINCOLN, as Commander-in-Chief of the Army and Navy, and will be found in the TIMES this morning. The first is dated the 27th of January last, and directed that on the 22d of February ultimo, there should be a general move-...
lead_paragraph: Three important War Bulletins have been issued by President LINCOLN, as Commander-in-Chief of the Army and Navy, and will be found in the TIMES this morning. The first is dated the 27th of January last, and directed that on the 22d of February ultimo, there should be a general movement of the land and naval forces against the rebels, or, at least, a readiness for a general movement; and holds all officers to a strict responsibility for the prompt execution of the order. The second is dated the 8th instant, and directs the division of the Army of the Potomac into four army corps, as before announced -- placing the reserve, to be held back for the defence of Washington, under the command of Brig.-Gen. WADSWORTH, also to be Military Governor of the District of Columbia. The third is dated the 11th inst., and relieves Gen. MCCLELLAN of the command of the other Military Departments, in order that he may take personal command of the Army of the Potomac; directs that the Departments of Gens. HALLECK and HUNTER, together with so much of that under Gen. BUELL as lies west of Knoxville, shall be consolidated, and called the Department of the Mississippi, under the command of Gen. HALLECK; and further directs that Gen. FREMONT shall be assigned to a new Department, to be called the Mountain Department, between the Department of the Potomac and the Department of the Mississippi. The commanders of these several Departments are ordered to report directly to the Secretary of War.

abstract: The yearly export of saltpetre from Calcutta to the United States for seven years, from 1854 to 1860, inclusive, has averaged 108,709 bars; while the export of last year was only 83,554 bags--being the smallest of any year for eight years, and a falling off from the average of the past seven years of 25,155
lead_paragraph: The yearly export of saltpetre from Calcutta to the United States for seven years, from 1854 to 1860, inclusive, has averaged 108,709 bars; while the export of last year was only 83,554 bags--being the smallest of any year for eight years, and a falling off from the average of the past seven years of 25,155 bags; a deficiency which me reported purchase of our Government in England last November will scarcely make good. The stock at present in the United States, in the hands of importers and speculators is but 6,500 bags; and the quantity now on the way from Calcutta, 13,061 bags -- making a total of 20,164 bags.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, petitions against emancipation, from Kentucky, were presented. The resolution for the expulsion of Mr. PEWELL, of Kentucky, was reported back from the Judiciary Committee, with a recommendation that it do not pass. A joint resolution expressing the thanks of Congress to Lieut. WORDEN and the
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday, petitions against emancipation, from Kentucky, were presented. The resolution for the expulsion of Mr. PEWELL, of Kentucky, was reported back from the Judiciary Committee, with a recommendation that it do not pass. A joint resolution expressing the thanks of Congress to Lieut. WORDEN and the other officers and men of the Monitor was laid over. Mr. LATHAM, of California, introduced his bill to repeal all laws prohibiting foreign vessels from carrying the mails to Panama and Aspinwall. The joint resolution tendering aid to [???] desiring to emancipate slaves was received from the House and referred to the Judiciary Committee. The bill authorizing the Secretary of War to accept moneys tendered by States in payment of volunteers was passed. The bill to define the pay and emoluments of the army was debated at considerable length, and finally passed, 37 to 2. The section providing for a reduction of ten per cent. in Government salaries, excepting in certain specified cases, was retained. The bill for the abolition of Slavery in the District of Columbia was then debated until the adjournment.

abstract: Mr. W.W. Fosdick, whose death in Cincinnati on March 8, has already been noticed, was born in that city on Jan. 28, 1820. His father, T.R. Fosdick, was a banker, and his mother, the well known actress Julia Drake. Young Fosdick studied law in Louisville, and while practicing his profession in Covington, Ky., published the drama "Tecumseh," which gained him a wide reputation. Malmiztic, the Toltec, and the Cavaliers of the Cross, a novel, and "Ariel" and other poems, are his principal works. About the year 1851, Mr. Fosdick removed to this City, where he resided seven or eight years practicing his profession.

abstract: A WARNING TO BOYS. -- FATAL ACCIDENT. -- A boy named EDWARD DELAUHAUNT, whose parents reside at the corner of Bond and Pacific streets, fell from the roof of house No. 389 Atlantic-street, yesterday afternoon, and was instantly killed. The deceased was flying a kite on the top of the house, and, going too near the edge, lost his balance, and fell overboard. This is the third accident of a similar character that has happened in this city within three weeks.

abstract: WINTER GARDEN.--The spring season at this favorite establishment opened last evening under the favoring auspices of a brilliant night and a successful play. Miss MATILDA HERON made her rentree in a work from her own pen, called the "Belle of the Season," and was received with warmth by the audience. The play is too emotional in its interest to re
lead_paragraph: WINTER GARDEN. -- The spring season at this favorite establishment opened last evening under the favoring auspices of a brilliant night and a successful play. Miss MATILDA HERON made her rentree in a work from her own pen, called the "Belle of the Season," and was received with warmth by the audience. The play is too emotional in its interest to reflect the peculiar characteristics of the society with which it is supposed to deal. The situations tread upon each other with an impetuosity which, whilst it displays the generous vehemence of the authoress, does not accord with the accepted rules of the drama. Miss HERON's individuality is very marked and peculiar. in her writing it is as marked as in her acting, but we enjoy it most in the latter. Hence, whilst her part in the play does not, by reason of her great ability as an actress, seem to be hurried, all the other parts are precipitate, and, in some instances, intrusive if not superfluous. These defects of construction cannot be remedied in a work so slimly supplied with a plot as the "Belle of the Season." To account for the success of the piece we must turn to the dialogue and here we find great wealth of womanly sentiment and considerable dexterity in dealing with delicate themes of the heart. That Miss HERON obtained the sympathy of the audience, was abundantly demonstrated by the hearty applause which drew the lady before the curtain at the end of the fourth act.

abstract: -- Mr. ASHLEY's bill forthe reduction of the rebel States to a territorial condition, has come to grief. The House, by an emphatic voice, laid it upon the table, whence it will certainly be called at the Greek Kalends. With this evidence that the House of Representatives is indisposed to legislate; without constitutional warrant, we trust Mr. ASHLEY and his faction will be satisfied, turning their attention hereafter to matters of which the Congress has jurisdiction. It is no part of its business to dissolve a Union, we are just now trying somewhat expensively to restore.

abstract: Never was there a truer remark than, that of Mr. JEFFERSON DAVIS, in his Inaugural, that the rebels had undertaken more than they could carry out. They started with the assumption of being a first-class Power; at the same time, in all that constitutes real strength,
lead_paragraph: Never was there a truer remark than, that of Mr. JEFFERSON DAVIS, in his Inaugural, that the rebels had undertaken more than they could carry out. They started with the assumption of being a first-class Power; at the same time, in all that constitutes real strength, they are, for their numbers, the weakest people in the world. Labor among them being held in dishonor, they are without commerce, consequently without wealth; without mechanical training or skill, consequently without manufactures; without industry, consequently without self-respect, or steadiness of purpose or character. With such poverty in all that constitutes strength, it is remarkable with what temerity they have provoked a conflict with a people possessing all the qualities that constitute true national greatness. But having had the control of the Government for more than a generation, and having been accustomed to have every command promptly obeyed by the obedient, facile and ingenious North, they had no idea but that their commands, wherever uttered, would be followed by similar promptitude in results. But on severing themselves from the North, they found themselves like Anteus, powerless when disjoined from the source of their strength. How could a half million of men be armed, at the South, without the means of fabricating a gun? The rebels, to be sure, displayed considerable foresight in smuggling into their territories nearly all the arms possessed by the United States previous to the rebellion; but even these proved of very little account, as the North has, within one short year, supplied itself anew with arms ten times more effective than those stolen, so rapid is the progress of science in fabricating weapons of destruction. On every field the odds are infinitely in our favor from this cause alone. We have still greater advantages in our means for feeding and clothing our soldiers and in rendering them comfortable and healthy. But behind all this we have the advantage of having an abundance of money, of which the South are almost entirely destitute. Compared with the North, they never had any in their best estate. When the rebellion broke out, consequently, they were of necessity forced to provide means by an issue of credits, which became a common medium of exchange, not only between the Government and the people, but between the people themselves. The value of such medium is measured entirely by the degree of confidence felt in the stability and means of the Government issuing them. During the first ebullitions of passion, under the confidence created at the early successes in seizing undefended forts, mints and Custom-houses, Confederate bonds served, to an extent, the purpose for which they were issued. With the provision in the Confederate Constitution, that any State may retire from the Government at will, only a little time for reflection was wanting to destroy all confidence in the value of these bonds. Their market price soon sunk to one-half their nominal value, even in exchange for the irredeemable currency of the South But the success of the Union cause -- which has now destroyed all hope of Southern independence -- has put the finishing touch to them. They are to-day, in South Carolina, we have no doubt, regarded as worthless as are the preserved relics of the old Continental currency. Correspondents tell us that Confederate scrip is universally regarded with loathing, even by the rebels, not only from its utter worthlessness, but from the infinite losses already suffered from it. The amount issued measures the extent of these losses. Nearly all that the South could produce, or part with, during the year, is represented by it. But the end is not yet. A mere fiction, of which the evidence upon which it is written will soon disappear, has been made the basis of innumerable contracts, which will all be declared invalid under the laws of the United States, involving the property in the South in such interminable confusion that nothing but a bankrupt law, of which the greater portion of the people must take the benefit, can restore certainty and order.

abstract: The three important military orders, which we print this morning, throw a flood of light upon the recent history of the war. We now learn that since the 27th of January, if not before, the President has exercised actively his constitutional functions as Commander-inChief of the army and navy. From him di
lead_paragraph: The three important military orders, which we print this morning, throw a flood of light upon the recent history of the war. We now learn that since the 27th of January, if not before, the President has exercised actively his constitutional functions as Commander-inChief of the army and navy. From him directly issued the order which has realized the plans contrived by Gen. SCOTT and matured by Gen. MCCLELLAN; which has crowded the days with victories, and given new life, hope and energy to the country. With a patience only equalled by that of the people, he awaited the completion of the preparations without which his military subordinates assured him no army could move with a certainty of success; but the moment these were completed, the word was given, which set in motion the immense machinery of destruction, from the Atlantic to the Missouri line. The scheme of the campaign, the discipline of the troops, the elaboration of preliminary details, may be justly credited to others. Action and victory we owe directly to the President.

abstract: A SCIENTIFIC COMMENT.--In another column will be found a report of a highly interesting session of the Chamber of Commerce, held yesterday. The topic under discussion was the defence of the harbor, and, very appropriately, Capt. ERICS
lead_paragraph: A SCIENTIFIC COMMENT. -- In another column will be found a report of a highly interesting session of the Chamber of Commerce, held yesterday. The topic under discussion was the defence of the harbor, and, very appropriately, Capt. ERICSSON was called upon, and at some length addressed the meeting in regard to that splendid naval success, the Monitor. The letter of Chief-Engineer STIMERS, who superintended the construction of the battery, and who was in it during the engagement, and observed its qualities with a critical eye, will be read with great interest.

abstract: Editorial on fiscal ability of Union in war
snippet: Editorial on fiscal ability of Union in war
lead_paragraph: -- Superficial writers in this country and in Europe have so mystified themselves in the discussion of our financial affairs, that a settled conviction is in danger of establishing itself in unreflecting minds that this country is in imminent danger of insolvency, and will never be able to meet honorably the obligations incurred by the present war. "Financial difficulties," says our too partial admirer, the London Times, "must necessarily break up the Northern enterprise in ninety days or less;" and, under the irrational apprehension of some such impossible catastrophe, we find not a few persons, both within and without the walls of Congress, who smart under the insolent taunts and cynical sneers of our venal traducers.
headline: {'main': 'OUR FISCAL ABILITY', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'OUR FISCAL ABILITY', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: A private, named BAKER, deserted from the United States Artillery some time ago, and joined the rebels. He was taken prisoner at Fort Hatteras, and sent with the rest of the Confederates captured there, to Governor's Island, where he was recognized by a former comrade, and apprehended. The findings and
lead_paragraph: A private, named BAKER, deserted from the United States Artillery some time ago, and joined the rebels. He was taken prisoner at Fort Hatteras, and sent with the rest of the Confederates captured there, to Governor's Island, where he was recognized by a former comrade, and apprehended. The findings and sentence of the Court-Martial by which he was tried were read out on Friday evening, and are to the following effect: The prisoner to be confined, with hard labor, and to wear a ball and chain until the end of the war, and then to have his head shaved, to be branded with the letter D, and be drummed out of the service. He will forfeit all pay and allowances, and only such clothing as may be absolutely necessary will be issued to him.

abstract: A highly interesting meeting of the Chamber of Commerce was held yesterday afternoon, with a view to consider the harbor defences of NewYork. Resolutions were passed appreciatory of the recent victories of the National arms, and recognizing the services of especially Lieut. WORDEN, of the Monitor, and Capt. ERICSSON. The latter
lead_paragraph: A highly interesting meeting of the Chamber of Commerce was held yesterday afternoon, with a view to consider the harbor defences of NewYork. Resolutions were passed appreciatory of the recent victories of the National arms, and recognizing the services of especially Lieut. WORDEN, of the Monitor, and Capt. ERICSSON. The latter gentleman gave a most interesting statement concerning the capabilities and construction of the Monitor, and expressed the unqualified opinion that she would sink the Merrimac in three rounds should the vessels have another engagement. The Chamber expressed most decisively its disapprobation of the neglect through which the rebel monster, the Merrimac, was enabled to make such havoc among our vessels at Hampton Roads.

abstract: JEFF. DA VIS, in his late Message to the Rebel Congress, said that he was not only unwilling, but unable to believe that a large army should have surrendered as it did at Fort Donelson. We now learn that he has suspended Messrs. FLOYD (the thief) and PILLOW from their commands until they could give more satisfactory accounts of the affair. This is certainly hard on FLOYD, who is called by the Richmond Ex
lead_paragraph: JEFF. DAVIS, in his late Message to the Rebel Congress, said that he was not only unwilling, but unable to believe that a large army should have surrendered as it did at Fort Donelson. We now learn that he has suspended Messrs. FLOYD (the thief) and PILLOW from their commands until they could give more satisfactory accounts of the affair. This is certainly hard on FLOYD, who is called by the Richmond Examiner "the hero of thirty battles," to be suspended at a moment when there is such a brilliant opportunity for him to achieve further and greater glories in the field. It is no less severe upon PILLOW, who is so much needed at present for the defence of his beloved but beleaguered city of Memphis. Surely JEFF. DAVIS could not have carefully perused Gen. PILLOW's report of the battle of Donelson, which so clearly stated the reason for his own and FLOYD's want of success on that memorable occasion. PILLOW showed that the Union forces met him in a manner which he had not contemplated, and for which he was entirely unprepared; and whereas, he had provided for "rolling back our forces, cutting them up, and putting them to rout," he found, as he says, that they "would not retreat, but fought us and contested every inch of ground." Surely that ought to be a satisfactory explanation to the rebel President of FLOYD's and PILLOW's failure to secure a victory. As for JEFF. DAVIS's other charges, PILLOW had previously refuted them all. What will the so-called Confederate Government do, now that it has lost the services of its two greatest Generals?

abstract: 1st commencement of Medical College
snippet: 1st commencement of Medical College
lead_paragraph: The first annual commencement of the Bellevue Hospital Medical College of the City of NewYork took place on Monday evening, at Irving Hall, in the presence of one of the finest audiences over collected within the building. Not only was every seat, occupied, but many were obliged to stand throughout the exercises. About 7 1/2 o'clock the graduating class entered and took the seats reserved for them. They were soon followed by the Trustees of the College, Messrs. Simeon Draper, J.B. Nicholson, Moses H. Grinnell, Isaac Bell, Comptroller Haws and James T. Brady, and others of like prominence. These, together with the Faculty of the College, headed by ISAAC E. TAYLOR, M.D., their President, took seats upon the platform amid welcoming applause.

abstract: That was a remarkable admission of JEFF DAVIS, in his message to the rebel Congress, that his rebel Government "had attempted more than it had power to achieve." It stands out as one truth in the midst of a collection of remarkable falsehoods, true not only in the sense in which he meant it, but true in far more directions than he intended.
lead_paragraph: That was a remarkable admission of JEFF DAVIS, in his message to the rebel Congress, that his rebel Government "had attempted more than it had power to achieve." It stands out as one truth in the midst of a collection of remarkable falsehoods, true not only in the sense in which he meant it, but true in far more directions than he intended. The attempt to break up this Government will be found far more than the rebels have power to achieve, and the attempt to demonstrate that the Declaration of Independence is a lie, and that the enslavement of a class is the surest foundation of the freedom of the rest of the people, is one that not all the human race to-gether could accomplish, because the laws of God are mightier than any plans or wills of man.

abstract: Another bulletin is issued by Secretary STANTON this morning, which appoints Hon. JOSEPH HOLT and Hon. ROBERT DALE OWEN a Special Committee to audit and adjust all contract orders and claims on the War Department, and directs the manner in which examinations shall be made. It further provides that all contracts which may be found to have been procured through collusion with any officers of the War Department, or in which any such officer is in any way interested, shall be deemed fraudulent.

abstract: Among the gallant deeds of the present war, should be remembered that performed by the late HARRY B. HIDDEN, of New York City, First-Lieutenant of the Lincoln Cavalry. In anticipation of the advance of our forces upon Centreville and Manassas, LieutHIDDEN was ordered upon a reconnoissance. After
lead_paragraph: Among the gallant deeds of the present war, should be remembered that performed by the late HARRY B. HIDDEN, of New York City, First-Lieutenant of the Lincoln Cavalry. In anticipation of the advance of our forces upon Centreville and Manassas, LieutHIDDEN was ordered upon a reconnoissance. After several days' scouting, and with his command reduced to a sergeant and twelve men, on Sunday, the 9th, he fell in with the pickets of the enemy, a score in number, and drove them in, till finally he was suddenly surrounded by a hundred and fifty of the enemy. The alternative was to cut his way out, or to surrender at discretion. "Will you follow me?" said the unshrinking officer. "To the death!" was the unanimous reply; and through the rebel ranks they hewed their way, turning not to right or left, till they emerged from the forest at Sangster's Station, the enemy either fleeing or laying down their arms before them. After this daring action, and while making their way to the camp, with thirteen prisoners, one to each man, when one of the skulking assassins, who had laid down his arms, seized his musket and shot the retiring officer dead upon the spot. The ball entered the back, near the top of the shoulder, and passed out through the neck under the chin, severing numerous blood-vessels, whose profuse bleeding soon closed the career of one of the most promising men in the army. Lieut. HIDDEN was possessed of the most manly beauty, beloved by all who knew him, and by none more than his companions in arms. Gen. KEARNEY has stated that this charge has not been surpassed in gallantry by any during the war, and it is the general theme of conversation among those cognisant of it in Washingtion and Alexandria. The remains, which had been most carefully tended by Gen. KEARNEY and Mrs. SPRAGUE, wife of the Adjutant of the regiment, were brought to this city, yesterday morning, by his brother, EDWARD HIDDEN, and his brother-in-law, WM. H. WEBB, Esq.
headline: {'main': 'Death of Lieut. Harry B. Hidden, of the Lincoln Cavalry.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Death of Lieut. Harry B. Hidden, of the Lincoln Cavalry.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Board of Councilmen held a regular meeting last evening, at which the suggestions of the Comptroller as to the division of the surplus of the revenue of the Sinking Fund to City expenditures, was adopted, and the Legislature will be memorialized accordingly. The Tax Levy, to which the Aldermen had added over one million of dollars, was brought up, and the Board adhered to its original action, and the onus of the additional...
lead_paragraph: The Board of Councilmen held a regular meeting last evening, at which the suggestions of the Comptroller as to the division of the surplus of the revenue of the Sinking Fund to City expenditures, was adopted, and the Legislature will be memorialized accordingly. The Tax Levy, to which the Aldermen had added over one million of dollars, was brought up, and the Board adhered to its original action, and the onus of the additional taxes sought to be imposed is thus thrown upon the Board of Aldermen; and the Councilmen having adopted a resolution to adjourn until the 24th inst., the Board of Aldermen must either recede or the Tax Levy must go over. Mr. JONES (Ex-President) then offered a resolution directing the Comptroller to make application to the Legislature to raise such sum as may be necessary for the support of the City Government. After transacting some routine business, the Board adjourned until Monday, the 24th inst.

snippet: Report on Union advances in Virginia; Dispatches from Washington and report on Congress proceedings
lead_paragraph: Your correspondent at Washington yielded to the urgent desire of the military authorities not to discuss the impending campaign against the rebel forces in Virginia. But, beside the military affairs, there is nothing of sufficient interest here to occupy valuable space in your columns. For ten days, therefore, I have been silent. Now, however, that the campaign has opened, and the relations of the hostile armies are known to the world -- the rebels precipitately retreating, and the Union army in full pursuit -- the rigor of censorship relaxes with the necessity for it.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, among the petitions presented was one for an Industrial Home for cast out women, and one for the passage of the Metropolitan Health bill. The bill to enable the New-York Supervisors to borrow money in anticipation of the annual tax was by unanimous consent read a third time and passed, and is therefore a law. Notice was given of a bill to authorize the construction of a railroad in Twenty-sixth and other streets of this City. A motion to make the proposed prohibitory amendment of the Constitution the special order for Tuesday next was lost, but the vote was subsequently reconsidered, and the motion was carried, 15 to 11.

abstract: Editorial on bill in NYS Legislature to establish Broadway street railway
snippet: Editorial on bill in NYS Legislature to establish Broadway street railway
lead_paragraph: The Broadway Railroad project is again fairly before the State Legislature in a shape to invite intelligent discussion. The Railroad Committee in the Assembly has reported a bill authorizing the construction of the Road, on certain prescribed conditions. It is conceded universally that the Committee has acted in this matter exclusively from motives of public interest, -- that it is composed of members who are entirely free from the suspicions which have hitherto attached to legislative action on this subject, -- that they have given a patient and attentive hearing to whatever the friends and opponents of the project have desired to urge, and that the whole matter is brought openly, fairly and properly before the Legislature for its action. This is one very important point which the public has gained.

abstract: The artists of the up-town studio may certainly boast of one of the most elegant establishments in the City. Externally and internally, DODWORTH's little building, on the corner of Twenty-fifth-street and Fifth-avenue, is all that can be desired in a neat and limited way. A reception (to be sure) tests its capacity somewhat severely, and the numbers who are then jostled together are apt to lament the absence of the many spacious artists' rooms which form so pleasant a feature of the Ninth-street studio, and constitute, in fact, an apparatus by which the greatest crowd may be strained off in an agreeable way. The arrivals last evening began unusually early, and were so numerous that by 8 1/2 o'clock it required a skillful flank movement to get within reconnoitering distance of the pictures. Thence, until the time of closing, the brilliant little salon was densely packed with fair votaries of art.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, the Committee on Naval Affairs was instructed to inquire what is necessary to be done in regard to JOHN DAVIS, whose distinguished bravery has been brought to the notice of Government by Commodore DUPONT. The resolution giving the thanks of Congress to Commodore FOOTE and his officers and men was taken up and passed: also the resolution of thanks to Lieut. WORDEN and the officers and crew of the Monitor. The report of the Judiciary Committee on the case of Mr. POWELL, of Kentucky, was then taken up, on motion of Mr. DAVIS, who proceeded to make a speech in favor of his colleague's expulsion. Mr. POWELL announced his intention to reply, and after an Executive Session the Senate adjourned.

abstract: A portion of the Union forces reached this point to-day. The infanty followed the railroad track; the cavalry and artillery came by a longer route. Two deserters, Irishmen, came into our camp before starting, and immediately joined Gen. MEAGHEE'S forces. They report that there are two hundred foreigners who had been impressed, now scattered through the woods, intending to join our forces.

abstract: It was with a considerable degree of surprise that I learned, as I returned from Roanoke Island last evening, of the rumor which has been circulated in the City regarding the conduct of the "Hawkins Zouaves" on their recent expedition to Winton, N.C. They are charged with violent and disgraceful behavior toward the persons and property of some in, offensive inhabitants. I desire here to defend the Zouaves, and show to the public what the truth of the matter is; and, in so doing, I will be pardoned for an allusion to their conduct and behavior toward the people of Hatteras, among whom they spent many weeks and months of suffering and hardship.

abstract: AN INQUEST ON A SAILOR KILLED AT THE BATTLE OF HAMPTON ROADS. Coroner NAUMANN yesterday held an inquest at the foot of Cordandt-street, upon the body of EDWARD O. GARRITY, a marine, who died from injuries received at the time the Merrimac
lead_paragraph: AN INQUEST ON A SAILOR KILLED AT THE BATTLE OF HAMPTON ROADS. -- Coroner NAUMANN yesterday held an inquest at the foot of Cordandt-street, upon the body of EDWARD O. GARRITY, a marine, who died from injuries received at the time the Merrimac made the attack upon the frigate Congress, in Hampton Roads. Deceased was struck by a piece of shell in the right shoulder, during the action, and an hour and a half afterward he died. He was 19 years of age, and a native of Benson, Vermont. He had been connected with the frigate Congress since Sept. 12, 1861. The jury rendered a verdict in accordance with the above facts.
