abstract: I perceive that a special dispatch to the NewYork Tribune, of 11th instant, makes the statement that "Major HATFIELD, with two companies, was or- dered, on Sunday morning, to go to Fairfax Courthouse by the old Braddock road. They met the enemy a mile this side, but the rebels retreated, and our...
lead_paragraph: I perceive that a special dispatch to the NewYork Tribune, of 11th instant, makes the statement that "Major HATFIELD, with two companies, was or- dered, on Sunday morning, to go to Fairfax Courthouse by the old Braddock road. They met the enemy a mile this side, but the rebels retreated, and our troops entered the Court-house at noon yesterday." This is a perversion of the facts, and does injustice to Gen. KEARNEY, and Col. SAMPSON and his regiment, (the Fourth New-Jersey,) who, with two companies of the First Regiment New-Jersey, under Major HATFIELD, and a company of the Lincoln Cavalry, under Capt. STEARNS, occupied the town for the first time at about 4 o'clock on Sunday afternoon.

abstract: In your paper of the 5th inst. you have a leading article, referring to the highly interesting speeches of Mr. BRIGHT and Lord PALMEESTON on American affairs. But, as your remarks are not altogether supported by the speeches in question, that circumstance has determined me to endeavor to give effect to a desire ...
lead_paragraph: In your paper of the 5th inst. you have a leading article, referring to the highly interesting speeches of Mr. BRIGHT and Lord PALMEESTON on American affairs. But, as your remarks are not altogether supported by the speeches in question, that circumstance has determined me to endeavor to give effect to a desire I have for some time entertained of effecting, if possible, a better feeling between the British and American people -- a feeling of reciprocal kindness and good-will, such as there is every reason to think would prevail, if the Press and the public will only consent to be guided by facts, and for the future cease to indulge in the wild productions which emanate from the ever fertile imaginations of a certain class of sensation writers and venal mischief-makers. Perhaps I can best accomplish this, the purpose before me, by going back to the period when the balls first flew at Sumter -- an unnatural and shameful insult to the Stars and Stripes, and which, although a Britisher, I felt as keenly as any genuine Knickerbocker, and fully participated in the burst of indignation which the circumstance occasioned. Indeed, but for the domestic ties which in my case could not be disregarded I would have shouldered arms and been "off to the ball wi' the lave." As it was, I denounced the crime thus inaugurated not only against the Government of the United States, but against the whole civilized world. In the general excitement which ensued, all loyal citizens were up and armed as very porcupines, and in their honest zeal, ready to hurl a shaft in any direction, even where only mere suspicion pointed.

abstract: Another victory, or what is the same thing, another evacuation by the rebels, is chronicled this morning. New-Madrid is now in our possession the rebels having left it on Thursday night. Some fighting took place on Thursday between the rebel gunboats and our siege batteries. They left behind them a quantity of guns and stores. There is a report that Island No. 10 is also evacuated.
lead_paragraph: Another victory, or what is the same thing, another evacuation by the rebels, is chronicled this morning. New-Madrid is now in our possession -- the rebels having left it on Thursday night. Some fighting took place on Thursday between the rebel gunboats and our siege batteries. abstract: Editorial sees British sentiment more favorable to Union
snippet: Editorial sees British sentiment more favorable to Union
lead_paragraph: The tide of popular opinion in England in regard to our war upon rebellion has been turning in favor of the National cause for several weeks. The position of the Ministry has become more stable. The arts or intrigues of the Confederate emissaries in London to poison the British mind, and to misrepresent the effective nature of our blockade, are less damaging. Even the great cotton interest of Manchester has virtually taken sides with the North, as the surest means of reopening the cotton ports -- insisting that the blockade should be scrupulously respected until time is afforded for removing with the strong arm of the National authority the cause which rendered it necessary. The Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs is more and more of the same opinion, and the events arriving out from this side were, at the latest dates, daily vindicating the wisdom of his judgment. The Liberal Press throughout the Kingdom is also taking the part of the Government of the United States, as against the recognition of the rebellious conspiracy constituted at Richmond for its overthrow.

abstract: THE ERICSSON No. 2 The work on the new iron-clad steamer at the Continental Works, Greenpoint, is rapidly progressing, and the boat will be really for service in about three weeks. This craft was constructed at Mystic, Conn., and differs materially from the Monitor. Instead of being a floating
lead_paragraph: THE ERICSSON No. -- 2 The work on the new iron-clad steamer at the Continental Works, Greenpoint, is rapidly progressing, and the boat will be really for service in about three weeks. This craft was constructed at Mystic, Conn., and differs materially from the Monitor. Instead of being a floating battery it is simply a screw steamer covered with plates. It is 200 feet in length and about 36 feet deep, and modeled with a view to speed. The engines are ERICSSON's patent, and by means of a complicated system of levers work below the water line. In addition to the screw the vessel will be ship-rigged. The deck is covered with wrought-iron plates two inches thick. The sides are covered with iron plates 5 inches wide and 2 1/2 inches thick, overlapping each other so as to cover the bolt heads, and extend to four feet below the water line.

abstract: Our correspondent with the expedition which lately took possession of Fernandina, Fla., transmits us a number of letters, documents, memoranda, etc., which he picked up in the town after the hasty hegira of the in- ...
lead_paragraph: Our correspondent with the expedition which lately took possession of Fernandina, Fla., transmits us a number of letters, documents, memoranda, etc., which he picked up in the town after the hasty hegira of the inhabitants on the approach of the Union force. Among these, curiously enough, turns up a letter dated Washington, Jan. 7, 1861, written by YULEE, then United States Senator, addressed to "JOSEPH FINEGAN, Esq., Tallahassee, Fla.," which gives us a most interesting glimpse of the secret doings of the chief secession conspirators at that period. The telegraphic columns of the TIMES of that same day (Jan. 7, 1861,) contained the following Washington dispatch: "The Southern Senators last night (Jan. 6) held a conference, and telegraphed to the Conventions of their respective States to advise immediate secession." Now, the present letter is a report by YULEE, who was present at this "consultation," as he calls it, of the resolutions adopted on this occasion, transmitted to the said FINEGAN, who, by the way, was a member of the "Sovereignty Convention" of Florida, then sitting in the town of Tallahassee. The original of this remarkable historical document, which was probably written by YULEE in his seat in the United States Senate, is now before us. It is as follows:

abstract: Your remarks on the Broadway Railroad, to which, in common with most taxpayers, I am opposed, omit to mention one great objection to it, which is, that, if it is ever laid down, New-York will possess no avenue in which processions, or an army, can pass unobstructed.
lead_paragraph: Your remarks on the Broadway Railroad, to which, in common with most taxpayers, I am opposed, omit to mention one great objection to it, which is, that, if it is ever laid down, New-York will possess no avenue in which processions, or an army, can pass unobstructed. Leave us one main street on our narrow island, in which our brave soldiers can show themselves on a Peace, and on anniversary occasions. If the bill is to become a law, honor your journal by the advocacy of a stringent clause, compelling the corporation of the road, when formally ordered by the Mayor, to withdraw their cars and mules, during such hours as the people require the street for such commemorative occasions as they have hitherto used it for. F.

abstract: Hon. John Moore White, formerly a Judge of the Supreme Court of New-Jersey, and for some years a resident of Trenton, died on Sunday, the 2d inst., at his residence in Woodbury, Gloucester County, at the advanced age of 92 years. His disease was inflammation of the lungs. The Woodbury Constitution says: "Judge White was a native of Cumberland County, and a son of Major John White, a patriot of the Revolutionary war, who died soon after the battle of Germantown, from a wound received in that engagement. He came to Woodbury in 1807 or 1808, and has always resided here. He represented Gloucester County in the Legislature for several years, and was appointed Attorney-General of the State in 1833, and one of the Judges of the Supreme Court in 1838. A few years after the expiration of his Judgeship be became partially blind from a cataract in one of his eyes, which eventually affected both, and he became entirely blind. During this time he necessarily retired from all public business."
lead_paragraph: Hon. A few years after the expiration of his Judgeship be became partially blind from a cataract in one of his eyes, which eventually affected both, and he became entirely blind. abstract: Observations from Great Britain
snippet: Observations from Great Britain
lead_paragraph: It was worth a costly experiment to retain that rich Southern business, and New-York will be hard put to it either to win it back or to do without it. But the capitalists have now come to the conclusion that the game is on, and that the experiment is passing out of their hands. The suggestion to raise $150,000,000 yearly by direct taxation does not deceive them. They know very well that, even if the sovereign people would submit to endure a taxation as heavy as that of England, America could not continously raise more than 10,000,000 sterling annually. The rough calculation has always been that in capacity of taxation the proportion between the two countries is, that American dollars are equal to English pounds sterling. If we raise 50,000,000, exclusive of our customs. America probably could. If she pleased, raise $50,000,000, or 10,000,000 sterling. Such a possible revenue, even if it were not based upon the wild improbability that the Western States will consent to pay any such taxes, would be a very poor security for half the debt which has already accrued. In this state of things the commercial adage, that "the first loss is the best," comes into play, and the capitalists of New-York are now watching for the first opportunity when it may be safe to say openly, "This war must be settled somehow."

abstract: A Blue-Book, containing papers relating to the blockade of the ports of the Confederate States, was presented to both Houses of Parliament on the 26th ult. On the 15th of may, Consul BUNOH, in a dispatch to Lord JOHN RUSSELL, announced the blockade of Charleston on the 14th of May. One British ship, ...
lead_paragraph: A Blue-Book, containing papers relating to the blockade of the ports of the Confederate States, was presented to both Houses of Parliament on the 26th ult. On the 15th of may, Consul BUNOH, in a dispatch to Lord JOHN RUSSELL, announced the blockade of Charleston on the 14th of May. One British ship, however, had succeeded in effecting an entrance without being warned off, and, in consequence, procured an excellent freight. Even at this early season, however, MR. BUNCH admits that the presence of the Niagara had greatly alarmed the city; and, although little practical inconvenience was experienced; the business of the city being entirely over for the reason, yet it was apprehended that toward Autumn its pressure would be felt, when the importations for the Winter are made, and the new crop of cotton is in the market. "The detriment," he adds, "to British trade, both import and export, will be very considerable should the blockade be prolonged." On the 28th May the Consul wrote that the port was still open, but that no British vessels were at Charleston. On the 7th of June he announced the arrival of the Minnesota off Charleston, and again on the 12th June stated that the blockade was inefficient. The inefficiency, according to Mr. BUNCH, continued up to the 25th of July, and on the 16th of August the inefficiency still existed. The master of the privateer Dixie entered Charleston on the 19th of July, and made affidavit that he could see no vessel of the United States. On the 20th of August Mr. BUNCH again reported that the ports of North and South Carolina were virtually open. On the 4th of September he reported a continued laxity of the blockade. Vessels continued to enter and leave Charleston. No blockade to the southward. Mr. BUNCH having by this time been superseded, there are no further reports from him. Consul MURE, on the 18th of June, reported that the blockade of the MISSISSIPPI was strictly enforced. On the 23d of July Commander HICKLEY, of the Gladiator, reported that the blockade of the southern coast of the United States was merely nominal. He made a similar report on the 19th of August. On the 30th of July Consul MURE again reported that the blockade of the Mississippi was strict. Capt. DUNLOP, of Her Majesty's ship Jason, reported, July 23, that the American blockading squadron consisted of eleven vessels. At Savannah the blockading ships were too large to act against small vessels, but, in order to make assurance double sure, the Confederates filled up one or more of the channels with stone vessels. Commander LYONS, of the Racer, wrote from Nassau on the 11th July, as follows:

abstract: editorial reports negotiations to pub Maxmilian on throne are running into difficulty
snippet: editorial reports negotiations to pub Maxmilian on throne are running into difficulty
lead_paragraph: -A HITCH IN THE BARGAINING. -- The negotiations, intended to place the Archduke MAXIMILIAN on the throne of GUATEMOZIN, appear to hang fire. The exact nature of the difficulty is not stated; but the secret no doubt lies in what the lawyers might term a failure of consideration. France, who alone has been tricked into a support of the project, has discovered that Austria will give no territory in exchange for the appanage of her Archduke, and will lend no aid of ships or bayonets to maintain on his perilous seat the elect of a free people. All possibility of benefit to French interests, arising out of the present campaign in Mexico, is, therefore, terminated; and it only remains for the French Emperor to retire from the enterprise with the best grace attainable in the circumstances. The difficulties now referred to are doubtless raised for this object.

abstract: -- So the Presidentwas informed yesterday in these jubilant words; and though the dispatches concerning the victory are as yet very unsatisfactory, the information is at least positive of a very important success for our arms in the extreme southeastern corner of Missouri. We were prepared for the news. The position of affairs preceding the capture was briefly thus: The rebel forces, on evacuating Columbus divided into three columns; one going downto Memphis, another going to Jackson, (Tenn.,) where it is now fortifying; and a third locating itself at Island No. 10 and New Madrid. The column going to the latter points formed a junction with the rebels under JEFF. THOMPSON, who for the last half year have been ravaging all this section of Missouri. They hoped here to make a stand to interrupt the transit of the National army down the river, while the rebels at Jackson would prevent our passage to Memphis by railroad. But, even before the evacuation of Columbus, a National column under Gen. POPE (the same General, it will be remembered, who bagged twenty-five hundred Missouri rebels about three months ago) had'left the town of Commerce on the Missouri River, and marched southward by a somewhat circuitous route, with the intention of taking New-Madrid in the rear. We had news a few days ago that this force had reached the town, invested it, and was preparing to give the collective rebels battle. The details of the affair will doubtless reach us immediately. Not only has New-Madrid fallen, but, by this success, Island No. 10, impregnable or to be impregnable, in the rebel style, has also virtually fallen into our hands. Indeed, it is reported to be already evacuated. That suddenly famous isle is located in the river some distance above New-Madrid, though owing to a bend in the river, it is really a short distance south of it, in point of latitude. This success clears the way to the rebel forts at Randolph, from whence it is but a step to Memphis!

lead_paragraph: By the arrival of the steamship Africa at this port yesterday, we have advices from Europe two days later than were previously received. The papers relative to the Southern blockade had at length been presented to both Houses of Parliament. They are quite voluminous. The last dispatch is from Earl RUSSELL to Lord LYONS -- the one already noticed as expressing the belief of the Earl that the blockade is effective. The news from the Continent is interesting, but not specially important. The Liverpool cotton market was quiet and unchanged. Provisions were steady; Breadstuff's dull. Consols were unchanged.

lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, the resolution to authorize the Secretary of the Navy to make equitable arrangements with contractors of steam machinery who have failed to perform their contracts, was passed. A joint resolution was reported from the Military Committee, which authorizes the President to assign the command of troops in the same field or division, without regard to seniority. It also gives the President power to dismiss any officer, if he shall see fit' without a Court-martial. Objection was made by Mr. SHERMAN, of Ohio, and Mr. MCDOUGALL, of California, and the resolution was laid over. A bill to authorize the building of a steam iron-clad ram, and steam gunboats, and to complete the Stevens Battery, was introduced by Mr. HALE, and referred. Mr. HARRIS, of New-York, introduced his bill to confiscate the property of rebels, and it was referred. The case of Mr. POWELL, of Kentucky, was taken up, and Mr. POWELL spoke at considerable length in self-vindication. Mr. DAVIS replied to Mr. POWELL, and after some further debate, a vote was taken on the resolution to expel, and It was rejected, 28 to 11. The Senate went into Executive session, and afterwards adjourned until Monday.

abstract: Editorial on construction of marine batteries; Editorial on construction of marine batteries
snippet: Editorial on construction of marine batteries; Editorial on construction of marine batteries
lead_paragraph: We understand that the Navy Department expresses a decided preference for thick plates of iron armor for ships in preference to several strata of thin plates of the same aggregate thickness. The European practice would seem to confirm this view of the case. But the most obvious facts and principles are all to the contrary. The elaborate experiments of Mr. STEVENS show that while the pile of thin plates may be more indented, the solid plate of equal thickness is most shattered and weakened by a ball of given force. The thin plates bend individually, and the inner plates are hardly weakened at all; but the whole of the thick plate must either give way altogether or be weakened in every part. Its fracture is irregular, and generally greatest on the back side; and the effect, as a whole, is more destructive. The same facts were fully illustrated in the late engagement -- the first engagement of two iron-clad vessels -- at Fortress Monroe. While the turret of the Monitor, composed of 8 layers, each an inch thick, was only indented 2 [???] inches by a shot striking square and flat upon it, one of the solid bars or plates, 9 inches thick and 12 inches deep, forming a part of her pilot-house, was completely broken in two by a similar shot, and opened [???] inch on the back side. Thus 8 inches of thin plates stood better than 9 inches of solid iron. This was due, in some degree, to the connection of the thin plates with the surrounding mass, while the solid plate had only its individual strength. And this leads to another view of the subject.

abstract: Detailed report on present organization of Union Regular Army
snippet: Detailed report on present organization of Union Regular Army
lead_paragraph: The official Army Register for 1862, published by order of the Secretary of War, has been issued from the Adjutant-General's Office. Compared with previous Registers, it is quite a large book. The new Registers are always anxiously looked for by army officers, who, besides having a personal interest in the changes which are constantly occurring, are also desirous of seeing how their classmates and brother officers are affected. Many of the young officers who have not been in the service twelve months, will be gratified to find their names well up in the list of First Lieutenants, with a very early chance of being made Captains; and some of the old army officers, graduates of West Point, who have had to serve ten or eleven years before they got their companies, will not be very much pleased to find that, in lineal rank, they stand upwards of one hundred degrees below men who were appointed from civil life, nine months ago.

abstract: The repossession -- we can hardly call it capture -- of Fernandina, is told in all its details in the interesting letters of our special correspondents, which we publish to-day. The remarkable feature in the affair is that the rebels should have abandoned it without an attempt to defend it. A formidable government fort and several powerful earthworks rendered the place much stronger than any of the others along the Southern coast, whose possession they have stoutly contested with us. There is no manner of doubt that the force of five thousand men that had been stationed at this point, might have made a stout resistance, and done us great damage, to say the least. Its fall was, in fact, the logical consequence of our previous demonstrations on the coast, and there is not the smallest doubt that the whole seaboard south of Savannah is ours to-day, if we had but the force to occupy it.

abstract: Since writing my first communication, my attention has been called to an article substantially to the same effect, by Mr. SCHUYLER, in the Evening Post of yesterday. He mentions one of the facts which had intended in this communciation to adduce in support of the suggestions I then made.
lead_paragraph: Since writing my first communication, my attention has been called to an article substantially to the same effect, by Mr. SCHUYLER, in the Evening Post of yesterday. He mentions one of the facts which had intended in this communciation to adduce in support of the suggestions I then made. The case of the Empire, mentioned by him, would seem of itself to be sufficient proof, but in the present excited state of some of our citizens, it may not be amiss to call attention to a few more out of the many instances which can be brought to bear on the subject.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday several bills were reported favorably, among them the one to consolidate the several acts relative to the District Courts in this City. Notice was given of a bill for the appointment of a Receiver-General, and for the transfer to his hands of certain trust funds ...
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday several bills were reported favorably, among them the one to consolidate the several acts relative to the District Courts in this City. Notice was given of a bill for the appointment of a Receiver-General, and for the transfer to his hands of certain trust funds now in the hands of County Treasurers. Among the bills passed was one relative to terms of imprisonment in the State Prisons, and allowing convicts to earn a commutation of their sentences, and one to prevent Supervisors from holding any other town or county office. The resolutions complimentary to Gen. SCOTT, and providing for the presentation to him of an album, were referred to a Select Committee. The bill to repeal the Church Property act, passed in 1855, was debated in Committee of the Whole, but was not finally disposed of.

abstract: Editorial on Halleck command of Southwestern Military Depts
snippet: Editorial on Halleck command of Southwestern Military Depts
lead_paragraph: Now that the three Southwestern Military Departments lately under BUELL, HALLECK and HUNTER, are consolidated into one great Department under Major-Gen. HALLECK, operations in that section will be carried on with a unity of purpose and an energy of spirit, the lack of which heretofore has produced delay and confusion. The desultory movements undertaken, and, under the circumstances, necessary, in Kentucky, Missouri, Kansas, the Indian Territory and Arkansas, will now either entirely cease, or will be subordinated to the great purpose of expelling the armed rebels from the entire State of Tennessee, and from the States bordering on it southward to the Gulf of Mexico. Next to Eastern Virginia, this region is, both militarily and politically, the most important part of the rebel country. If the mountain lands of Northern Georgia and Northern Alabama are held by our troops, we will, with the foothold we already have in the mountains of Tennessee and Virginia, virtually have military control of all the vast slave region sloping southward from the Alleghanies. If the line of the Mississippi be in our hands, we likewise control the States bordering that great river on both sides to its mouth. In a political view, this region is no less important. The original school of secession conspirators looked almost entirely to the establishment of a great Slave Empire in the semi-tropical regions bordering upon the Gulf of Mexico. The Border States, to which we have thus far confined our military operations, were not expected nor desired to join the black oligarchic military Empire. They were looked upon rather in the light of outworks, to belong to the South, or to remain neutral, as they pleased, but really to be used as a barrier against the Abolition encroachments of the Northern States. At first extending from South Carolina to Florida, and sweeping from thence in a semicircle to the Rio Grande, the new Empire would speedily subjugate the feeble States of Mexico. Cuba and other West India Islands would be annexed, and all the negroes and peoples of other inferior races reduced to their normal condition of Slavery. The Gulf of Mexico would then form a central lake, round which would circle the States of the grand Confederation, whose corner-stone should be Slavery, and its rulers the lords of the plantation. This was the dream, fevered but gorgeous, of the conspirators who imagined they had fallen heir to the visions of AARON BURR -- such men as SLIDELL, JEFF. DAVIS, TOOMBS, RHETT and WIGFALL. The military possession of the States immediately south of Tennessee by our troops will at once and forever destroy all such hopes. Further, in the five or six States contiguous to the line of operation of which we are writing, the slave system of the South, to sustain which this rebellion was really and ostensibly inaugurated, has its greatest development. In the States bordering on the Gulf, and for some distance up the Mississippi, the population is divided into about one-half slave and the other half nominally free; while the slave element is massed in various districts, so as to give it there a prodigious predominance. This element is at once strength and weakness to the rebellion; but it is at our option to dispose of it in such a way as that it shall at least not add to the rebel power. Of this whole section of country, from our present lines of operation on the north to our line of operation on the southern Gulf coast, we give this morning a compact map; and in the brief space which it occupies will be seen the whole surface over which Gen. HALLECK has now to extend the National authority. As soon as that able Commander can march from his present position at Nashville, and take possession of Chattanooga in the east and Memphis in the west, and when in addition our forces on the coast take possession of Pensacola, Mobile and New-Orleans, the whole of the States of the Southwest and the Gulf will fall into our control. It would be utterly impossible to maintain a rebel army in the low, flat cotton-and-slave regions of central Alabama and Mississippi, while the national forces held possession of all the lines of communication, and stand invincible upon the front and rear. The rebels are now expelled from Missouri, the rebel army of Arkansas is routed, and, we believe that to-day here is not west of the Mississippi, five thousand effective rebels under arms. So that, to the work on the Gulf States and against the rebels there concentrated, Gen. HALLECK can bring the whole of the vast army lately in his own command, as well as the army lately in Kansas and Kentucky. It is probable that the National forces in Kentucky, added to that ready to begin operations on the Gulf, numbers not short of one hundred and fifty thousand soldiers. The field for their conquest is a vast one; the work is difficult; but with such a force, united under and inspired by such a leader, we doubt not that the task will be done, and effectively done, sooner than most people anticipate. When done, it will end what at one time appeared the most difficult labor in putting down the great revolt. It will then remain only that the rebel army in Eastern Virginia be destroyed and South Carolina well chastised; after which the rebellion, as a military fact, will be essentially disposed of.

lead_paragraph: It is now about one year since the first Tariff Act of 1861 was passed; it is almost one year since the Rebellion became a settled fact, and war was rendered inevitable by the bombardment of Fort Sumter. The time is a fitting one for a review of the effects of the passage of the former and the influence of the latter on the commerce and foreign trade of our country.

abstract: Editorial on loyalty of people of German descent
snippet: Editorial on loyalty of people of German descent
lead_paragraph: The arrest of the German Unionists in Richmond recalls, what the country can never forget, the loyal and patriotic stand taken throughout the country during this revolution by our German fellow-citizens. Some of the first militia regiments that marched from this City to save the Capital were largely composed of Germans. In the West, it is not too much to say that the German regiments, organized with such patriotic ardor in St. Louis and the vine districts of the southwestern counties, saved the State. Without the least hesitation or wavering they offered up themselves and their means in the cause of Freedom and the Republic. Many of their members were living in remote rural situations, surrounded by Secessionists; but regardless of all danger they pressed forward to fight for the good cause. Their houses were sacked and their pretty farms wasted, sometimes their families were murdered, but this did not deter these patriotic men. It must be remembered, also that these German regiments with which LYON, and SIGEL, and FREMONT made such rapid marches and dashing attacks, were by no means raw militia. Many of them had served in European wars; all had been thoroughly drilled in the National service at home. The well-known German regiment in Ohio -- the Ninth -- which decided, by a brilliant bayonet-charge, the battle of Mill Springs, and distinguished itself in so many skirmishes, was composed in part of old, experienced soldiers, who had seen service, and for the rest, of well-drilled Prussians.

abstract: Gen. MCLELLAN has issued a stirring address to the Army of the Potomac, which will be found in the TIMES this morning. It is dated at Fairfax Court-house, March 14. No one can read it without concluding that Gen. MCCLELLAN means now to redeem his promise that the war shall be a short war, though it may be a desperate one. He says the moment for action has arrived, and the whole tenor of his address proves that he means what he says.

abstract: Tombs, NYC, described
snippet: Tombs, NYC, described
lead_paragraph: This mansion of sepulchral denomination, as is generally known, is but a temporary abode for convicts, unless by especial order of the Court, which may designate this as their permanent quarters until their fate be consummated. This was the case of the wretched slave-dealer, whose career, so recently cut short in vindication of outraged law, is fresh in the memory of all. Three other men, under sentence of death, are permanently incarcerated within its walls. One of these has spent nearly five years amid his gloomy surroundings, in consequence of a stay of proceedings being instituted upon a writ of error Within the last year, since the Commissioners of Charity and Correction have taken charge of the City Prison, persons committed for intoxication have been transferred almost immediately to Blackwell's Island, which thins the population of the prison upon an average of forty a day. The number of "boarders" at present is three hundred, which is far below the figures of previous years. That the majority of all crimes have male representatives need hardly be recorded, and this explains why New-York State, having already three State Prisons, and is contemplating the establishment of a fourth, provides but one for females, which one is attached to Sing Sing.

abstract: David Hill died at his residence at Onondaga Castle, on the 5th inst., at the age of seventy-three years. The deceased was a leading and prominent Chief of the Onondaga tribe of Indians, and was among the first of that people to embrace Christianity, His age, shrewdness, commanding presence and native eloquence gave him much influence with that portion of his tribe which have embraced the gospel. He has long been known as Capt. Hill. He was among the friendly Indians who fought for the Stars and Stripes in the war of 1812, and was so distinguished for courage and daring deeds that he received commendations from both Gen. Jacob Brown and Winfield Scott, during the bloody, campaigns in which the battles of the "Cataract," Chippewa and Lundy's Lane were fought.

abstract: FUNERAL OF LIEUT. HARRY B. HIDDON. -- The funeral of this gallant young officer will take place at 1 o'clock, to-day, from the Fourteenth-street Presbyterian Church, corner of Second-avenue. The services will be performed by Rev. Dr. ASA D. SMITH, assisted by Rev. Dr. POTTS. A battalion composed of Companies A, D, C and G of the Twenty-second Regiment N.Y.S.M., under command of Lieut.-Col. LLOYD ASPINWALL, will act as general escort to the remains, and Company F, Seventy-first Regiment, with a corps of cavalry, will serve as a guard of honor. The battalion of the Twenty-second Regiment are requested by General Order No. 3, to form at 12 o'clock, M., on the north side of Union-square.

abstract: The Senate was not in session until evening. In the Assembly, numerous remonstrances were presented against the passage of the Concert Saloon bill; also against the Broadway Railroad. A bill was reported to prevent attempts to commit burglary and other crimes, by giving authority to arrest and punish for misdemeanor all persons holding burglar's tools in their possession, or known to be traveling in the cars, or elsewhere, with the intention of picking pockets. Among the bills reported favorably was one to facilitate the completion of the Adirondack Railroad; one to appropriate $10,000 to the People's College; one to incorporate the New-York Commercial Association; one for the preservation of game and fish, and one to regulate advertising in this City. The Annual Supply bill and the Annual Tax bill for general purposes were reported from the Committee of Ways and Means. The latter imposes a tax of 2 1/2 mills. The matter of the Prohibitory amendment of the Constitution and the Excise law was made the special order for Friday next. A bill for the relief of volunteers was reported from the Special Committee appointed to investigate the transactions of the State Military Board. It provides that every volunteer furnished with a uniform under the contract between PHILIP DORSHEIMER and BROOKS BROTHERS shall be reimbursed at the rate of $5 for an overcoat, $2 50 for a pair of pantaloons and $2 50 for a jacket, and appropriates $55,000 to carry out the purposes of the bill.

abstract: Of all schemers and planners, commend us to the Southern people. They were always so. They always were putting forth some marvelous idea, which was to bring about the most immense results, without trouble or expense. Speculators truly, who seemed always intent upon seizing those advantages at once which of right only follow long and ear nest toil, the very thing they most despised.
lead_paragraph: Of all schemers and planners, commend us to the Southern people. They were always so. They always were putting forth some marvelous idea, which was to bring about the most immense results, without trouble or expense. Speculators truly, who seemed always intent upon seizing those advantages at once which of right only follow long and ear nest toil, the very thing they most despised. But it always happened, by some strange fatality or perversity, that the results which they promised themselves did not come. There were always some things which they had not taken into account, or which they had considered too insignificant to have any influence, but which refused to yield when they had expected. And so, though they were always planning ways by which they might arrive at once at the prosperity of the North, yet the ocean lines of steamers persistently refused to visit Southern ports, manufactures refused to thrive upon their soil, and even a Southern literature failed to come forward at their call.

abstract: Affairs on Governor's Island are pretty quiet again, after the temporary excitement caused by the reports concerning the Merrimac on Sunday last. With the exception of drilling at the Castle William barbette guns twice a day, and mounting guard, the men have very little to do. In the Ordnance Department, however, business is brisk, and has been eve since the commencement of the rebellion. Two vessels are alongside the wharf now, one shipping columbiads, and the other taking in powder and ordnance stores of various kinds.

abstract: Editorial compares freedom of speech in Parliament and US Congress; Editorial compares freedom of speech in British Parliament and Congress
snippet: Editorial compares freedom of speech in Parliament and US Congress; Editorial compares freedom of speech in British Parliament and Congress
lead_paragraph: Certain proceedings have recently taken place in the British Parliament, which possess great interest for our own Congress, and which, in the present crisis, touch us in a very sensitive point. A member from Ireland, the O'DONOGHUE, for whom Americans are bound to cherish very kind feelings, for having manfully espoused their cause when the Trent imbroglio threatened serious consequences, took offence at words spoken in debate by Sir ROBERT PEEL, Secretary for Ireland, and failing to obtain retraction, sent a "friend" to arrange the terms for a hostile meeting. The Honorable Secretary, in the emergency, laid the matter before the head of the Government, Lord PALMERSTON, who forbade Sir ROBERT to accept the "invitation," informing him that he would lay the matter before the House as a breach of privilege for taking exception out of it for words spoken in debate. His Lordship, accordingly, made a detailed statement of the case; whereupon the Speaker pronounced the invitation to a hostile meeting to be a breach of privilege, and demanded an apology from the offender, which was made. Anything like a show of recusancy, would have been followed, no doubt, with instant expulsion.

abstract: Editorial on commerce in South
snippet: Editorial on commerce in South
lead_paragraph: There are battles in history which are not merely the deadly struggle of two hostile forces, but which, from their dramatic character, or from their results, become events or eras in human affairs. Romance and philosophy both cluster around them, and however unimportant in themselves, they become turning points in history. Such we conceive was the naval battle of Saturday and Sunday in Hampton Roads. No military scene on the stage, no combination of all elements of exciting interest in romance, ever equaled, for a moment, the intense excitement and fluctuating suspense of that remarkable conflict. It will be one of those events that our children and our children's children will read of over and over again, with undying interest.

abstract: address to the soldiers of the Army of the Potomac rings of action and of victory. He explains briefly the causes of the long delay in entering the field, but announces that at last the moment has arrived, and the Grand Army will now be brought face to face with the rebels. "I shall demand of you," says he, "great, heroic exertions, rapid and long marches, desperate combats, privations, perhaps." But "God smiles upon us, victory attends us." The address is a masterpiece, clear, comprehensive and inspiriting. The General has faith in his army, and the army confides in the General, and both are alike inspired with a common heroism. This authoritative declaration of immediate and decisive action disposes at once of all public impatience and criticism. The Commander will now show that while heretofore he has dared to wait, he has also courage and purpose, since the hour has come, to carry on the war with desperate and victorious energy. The week which opens to-day promises to be a stirring one. The hopes expressed by Gen. MCCLELLAN are participated in by all the people; and the prayers he offers to Heaven for success will today be seconded in all the churches.

abstract: VERY CHRISTIAN-LIKE RESIGNATION. A  frame of mind which resigns itself to whatever may befall, and finds "good in everything," is certainly one of the most desirable of blessings, especially when Providence puts one on the losing side of life. But the heroic lengths to which some of the rebel journalists carry this disposition are really sublime.
lead_paragraph: frame of mind which resigns itself to whatever may befall, and finds "good in everything," is certainly one of the most desirable of blessings, especially when Providence puts one on the losing side of life. But the heroic lengths to which some of the rebel journalists carry this disposition are really sublime. It seems that whatever successes we achieve are quite as satisfactory to them as to us, and the greater their loss, according to their own profession, the more their gain. We make a certain move; that proves invariably to be the very move they wanted us to make. We gain a position; they ask nothing better. But the ultimate sublimation of this Christian resignation is presented in the speculations of a Richmond journal, apropos of the capture of Nashville. Not only is it resigned that Nashville should slip from the grasp of the Confederacy; but it is not so sure but it would be the very best thing in the world for the "cause" should every city of the South fall into the possession of the Union force Hear him:

abstract: We are glad to see  that the Naval Committee, in the Senate, has promptly responded to the voice of the country, and has recommended an appropriation of $15,000,000 to the construction of iron-clad vessels of war, and $750,000 to the compleion of STEVENS' Battery.
lead_paragraph: -- We are glad to see that the Naval Committee, in the Senate, has promptly responded to the voice of the country, and has recommended an appropriation of $15,000,000 to the construction of iron-clad vessels of war, and $750,000 to the completion of STEVENS' Battery. The fight in Hampton Roads has demonstrated, more effectually than months or years of argument, the absolute necessity of iron-clad vessels to naval warfare. It proved incontestibly that half a dozen such vessels of the smallest size might defy and exterminate the most formidable wooden navy in the world. We cannot be too prompt in preparing to meet this new necessity.

abstract: The State Assembly hasadopted a resolution for the appointment of a Sub-Committee of the Whole, which, if properly constituted, will greatly expedite the public business. We hope now to see some of the many bills affecting our city interests brought before the Legislature for discussion and speedy action. The Health bill, the amended Charter; the bills reducing the fees of the Sheriff, Chamberlain, County Clerk and Register; the Broadway Railroad bill, and many others, are too important to be longer postponed, unless the action upon them is to be crude, hasty and unsatisfactory.

abstract: DAVID SMITH, D.D., of Durham, died at the residence of his daughter, Mrs. ELLSWORTH, in Fair Haven, Ct., on Friday, the 7th inst., at the advanced age of 95. Dr. SMITH was the third minister of the Congregational Church in Durham. He graduated at Yale College, in 1795, and was ordained in Durham in 1799, and was afterward chosen a Fellow of Yale College and a member of the Prudential Committee. In 1832, he was dismissed from his pastorate, having been pastor of the church nearly thirty-three years.

abstract: The first year of Mr. LINCOLN'S Administration is assuredly entitled to a favorable as well as honest verdict on its financial success,
lead_paragraph: The first year of Mr. LINCOLN's Administration is assuredly entitled to a favorable as well as honest verdict on its financial success. It has gone through a year of continued peril, not only to the National credit but to the Nation's existence, under trials upon the Treasury which might have staggered, if not overwhelmed more experienced statesmen. The ordeal to the Minister of Finance has no parallel in our Constitutional history; not even in the war of 1812-15. The burthen of public debt which that contest of three years with a foreign Power left upon the country, was only as three months expenditure in the present struggle against domestic rebellion. From a total of $45,209,000, the public debt then went up to $127,334,000 on final settlement of the war expenditure in 1816. We have now gone through only a single year of the existing war and such are the huge proportions of the army and the varied and costly nature of the naval and transport service engaged in it, that $300,000,000, or an average of nearly a million per day will barely suffice to foot the expenditure from the 6th of April, 1861, when the first order to reprovision Fort Sumter and reinforce Fort Pickens reached New-York, to the 4th of March, 1862. The prevailing impression, but certainly an erroneous, one tested by the actual figures, is, that for some months past, the average daily accumulation of debt is nearly or quite two millions per day. And whether this belief be erroneous or not, the Secretary of the Treasury has been compelled to encounter it in full force, in his periodical negotiations, and without disguising the real magnitude of his wants, to subject the National credit to at severity of trial accordingly.
headline: {'main': 'The Public Debt and National Credit.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Public Debt and National Credit.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: editorial on European aspirants to throne
snippet: editorial on European aspirants to throne
lead_paragraph: The Spanish Press has again taken up the cry in opposition to the candidature of the Austrian Archduke MAXIMILIAN for the throne of Mexico. El Siglo puts forward in his place theInfante Don SEBASTIAN, who, besides being a Spanish Prince, was born on the soil of America, in Brazil. Some of the Madrid journals are discussing this new suggestion with a good deal of vehemence, none of them, however, expressing any doubt as to the alacrity with which the Mexicans will accept the prince selected for them. It is now proposed by the friends of the European Coalition in America, that England, Austria, France, Prussia, Spain, and even Russia, should each have a candidate, and that a Congress be held in reference to Central and South America, at which princes shall be selected for each subdivision of that portion of the New World which may be agreed upon.

abstract: We are not likely to fall short of a liberal allowance of music this week, for Mr. GRAU'S announce ments alone are enough to keep the critic in a state of wild activity.
lead_paragraph: We are not likely to fall short of a liberal allowance of music this week, for Mr. GRAU's announce ments alone are enough to keep the critic in a state of wild activity. Not only does he play opera or concert, or both, on every evening, but in some instances he gives concerts in other cities simultaneously with those given here. Mr. GOTTSCHALK's provincial tour has been eminently successful, and sufficient to induce Mr. GRAU to send the pianist on a still longer trip. The concert at Niblo's Saloon to-night, and the Matinee to-morrow at Irving Hall, are the last entertainments at which Mr. GOTTSCHALK will appear previous to his departure for the West. The programmes are unusually interesting, almost every morceau this evening being fresh. On Wednesday the Academy of Music will once more open its portals VERDI's opera. "Un Ballo en Maschera," will be played; in the last act the Masquerade scene is to be interpreted by professional terpsichoreans instead of muffs, and necessarily in a way quite new to the work. The beautiful [???] has been engaged by Mr. GRAU, and will appear in this opera, and as Fenella, the dumb girl, in "Masaniello," which will be produced on Thursday evening. Mme. DE LUSSAN's debut will not take place until next week. We hear that Mr. GRAU has concluded not to give opera in Brooklyn. The pretensions and exactions of the Academy people render success there impossible. It is a melancholy fact, that only one or two performances have pain expenses since the theatre was erected. Mr. GRAU, who does all that he can for the public, consistently with something for himself, and who is amazingly fond of paying his artists and lessors in advance -- being in this respect quite phenomenal -- does not see the joke of paying a heavy rent for the privilege of losing money. So Montague-street is left out in the cold.

abstract: editorial on objections to ship; Editorial speculates on future of slavery
snippet: editorial on objections to ship; Editorial speculates on future of slavery
lead_paragraph: What is to be the effect of the war upon Slavery? is a question more easily asked than answered, but one which presents itself continually before the mind of almost every one. And naturally enough. The Slavery question has been so much before the people of late years that not only those who have made a specially of it, but every one at the North has had something to say upon it, and has come to recognize it as the greatest question of all which were devolved upon the American people to settle. And now when from the same quarter of the land whence in past years have arisen political controversies based upon this question, there has come up this tempest of rebellion, having the same source, it would be most extraordinary if we did not ask ourselves what was to be the effect of the war upon its cause; No one can tell this as yet, because it is not yet settled what steps are to be taken against Slavery in the prosecution of the war. If it is long enough and embittered enough by defeats on both sides, to lead our generals to declare the slaves free as a military measure, then, of course, the war will be the utter destruction of the system, bringing it to a sudden and violent end. And there are those who are impatient to have that course pursued, because they earnestly desire the overthrow of the systems and believe that such a sudden and violent destruction is the only way to reach the evil. And there are those, too, who argue, that we shall never establish a firmly cemented Union again, unless Slavery is first utterly overthrown.

abstract: There is no mistaking the purport of Gen. McCLELLAN'S stirring appeal to the powerful and well-trained army under his command. It means "On to Richmond!"
lead_paragraph: There is no mistaking the purport of Gen. MCCLELLAN's stirring appeal to the powerful and well-trained army under his command. It means "On to Richmond!" The hour has come for carrying to consummation the grand campaign which has thus far been marked by such splendid successes, and such substantial triumphs. The final blow may now be struck which shall annihilate the rebel army as an organized force, and crush the Government of the rebel Confederacy at its Capital.

abstract: NY Custom House activities described
snippet: NY Custom House activities described
lead_paragraph: The business of the Custom-house at this port continues to be very heavy, being still on the increase, exceeding that transacted at this season of the year 1861 by nearly one-half, and nearly equalling that transacted at this period of the year 1860. The high rates of duty now levied on most articles which we are compelled to import from foreign countries has had the effect to greatly increase the revenues from duties thus levied. The Supplemental Tariff act of last December, imposing a higher rate of duty than that previously levied on tea, coffee and sugar, went into effect at a most opportune moment. By the prompt passage of this act the Government has been enabled to receive large amounts of duties on these [???]. Indeed, the heavy receipts of the past two months were due to the high rates of duty imposed on these articles, rather than to an increased importation of general merchandise. The importation of sugar and coffee, in particular, was very heavy during those months. One of the principal features ef the business of the last week or two has been the increase in the quantity of tea imported, Of this, several large cargoes have recently arrived in vessels direct from China, and still more is on the way hither. One firm of this City engaged in the China trade, it is said, has, on its way to this country, tea on which duties to the amount of $200,000 will be required.

abstract: Gen. WADSWORTH appointment as Military Governor of the District of Columbia is an eminently judicious and wise selection. No man has entered into this war from nobler or more patriotic motives, or has brought to its duties greater energy, devotion and self-denial than he. We can readily understand that he would have greatly preferred a more active participation in the stirring incidents of the coming engagement than this post will permit him to take. He accompanied his Brigade as far as Manassas, and would gladly have remained with it, if the alternative had been allowed him. But obedience to orders is the first duty of a soldier. He will discharge the duties of his new position with vigor and practical wisdom.

abstract: --After fighting every inch of ground, and at last yielding the merit claimed to the plans of Mr. STEVENS, the critics make a vigorous stand at a last objection -- the guns on the top of the armor, rather than within it. They admit, indeed, that the loading and training apparatus and the carriages are protected, but they do not see why the guns, although covered with armor, will not be broken or shot away. Now, what are the facts? The shot-proof side of the Monitor's turret, several feet distant from the guns within it, protects those guns. Now suppose we place that shot-proof side six inches nearer the guns, does it not still protect them? Move the armor a foot nearer the guns, is the protection vitiated? Now suppose the armor touches the guns, is it not still as thick and efficient? Certainly it is, with the very great addition, however, of the strength of the guns themselves. The guns of the battery are four feet in diameter at the breech, upon which self-protected mass, there is to be, not only armor, but inclined armor, adding its resistance also, to the enemy's shot. Again, the hooping of guns is one of he latest and best methods of increasing their resistance to the bursting effect of their own fire, and this armor, therefore, serves a double purpose.

abstract: There was published in the TIMES, a few days since, a letter from a foreign officer of distinguished skill, on Gen. McCLELLAN'S plan of the campaign.
lead_paragraph: There was published in the TIMES, a few days since, a letter from a foreign officer of distinguished skill, on Gen. MCCLELLAN's plan of the campaign. The leading element of this analysis was the fact that the positions of the enemy are all central, while the Union army occupies the circumference of the circle. The cordon being practically complete, it only remained my the commander of the National forces to set in motion, a living radius of armed men, on foot and transport and gunboat, which, turning upon Washington as a pivot, should sweep everything before it, until the outer extremity should rest somewhere in Arkansas or Louisiana. This partial revolution effected, the retirement of the enemy from Manassas would be inevitable. It would become feasible for the head of the army to select a new centre of revolution, and by a fresh movement of his irresistible forces from a new base, complete the extermination of armed rebellion.

abstract: Article on origin of money order system in Great Britain; notes proposal before Congress to introduce system in US
snippet: Article on origin of money order system in Great Britain; notes proposal before Congress to introduce system in US
lead_paragraph: Among the various bills at present before Congress, there is one for the introduction of the money-order system into the postal regulations of the United States. In view of the passage of this measure, it is instructive to review the history and progress of the money-order branch of the postal system of Great Britain, as by this means we are enabled to arrive at some estimate of the benefits which we may expect to derive from the introduction of a like means of money transmission into our own country, and at the same time to form some idea of the additional revenue which the Post-office is likely to obtain from this source.

abstract: FATALLY INJURED BY A CAR. -- About 6 o'clock' yesterday morning, a laborer, named JOHN WOOD, was knocked down and run over by a car on the Hudson River Railroad, at the depot foot of West Twelfth-street. One of WOOD's legs was entirely severed from his body, and the other mangled in a shocking manner. He was immediately conveyed to the New-York Hospital, where the attending surgeon pronounced his case to be hopeless. No blame is attached to the driver of the car. WOOD has a family residing in Twenty-sixth-street.

abstract: Editorial on New Jersey attempts to have US Naval School moved from Newport, RI, to Perth Amboy
snippet: Editorial on New Jersey attempts to have US Naval School moved from Newport, RI, to Perth Amboy
lead_paragraph: The Legislature of New-Jersey has appointed a Commission to set before the Naval Committee of Congress the great advantage and powerful claims of Perth Amboy as a permanent location for the Naval School, it having been determined to remove it from Newport. With all due reverence for the majestic sovereignty of New-Jersey, we shall set our face like flint against the proposal until the Legislature shall appoint a Commission for another, though cognate purpose. We mean a Commission that shall lay down an exterior line for the Jersey side of the river, and prevent those obstructions that are threatening serious and lasting injury to the harbor of New-York. In 1857, the New-York Commission, of which Mr. BACHE, of the Coast Survey, was Supertendent, laid down an exterior line for both sides of the harbor. It has ever since been carefully observed on our part, and the late prompt decision of Judge ALLEN, of the Supreme Court, restraining COLNELIUS VANDERBILT from erecting a pier at the north end of the Battery, is an encouraging proof of a determination that large public interests shall not be permitted to be encroached upon by unscrupulous private speculators.

abstract: NYC celebration
snippet: NYC celebration
lead_paragraph: The Friendly Sons of St. Patrick celebrated the Anniversary of Ireland's Patron Saint by their customary dinner at the Metropolitan Hotel, last evening, the seventy-eighth meeting of the Society. The large dining-hall was set apart for the guests, tastefully ornamented with the interwined flags of Erin and America. The tables filled the room, and seated about three hundred guests. At the head sat Judge DALY, President of the Society, and on either side were Mayor Opdyke, Col. Nichols, of the regular army, James W. Gerard, Esq., Richard O'Gorman, Esq., A. Oakey Hall, Esq., Hiram Barney, Commissioner Nicholson, Henry R. Remsen, Elliot C. Cowdin, Francis Byrne, Edward Jenkins, Esq., Thaddeus Lane, Senator Bradley, James B. Kirker, Judge O'Conor, Judge Bonney, Judge Alker, Judge Hearne, Smith Clift, H.V. Vultee, John Savage, J.R.; Briggs, Eugene Kelly, Isaac Dayton, James Lynch, Alfred Roe, Robert Remsen, F.H. Churchill' Adam Bell, Joseph Stuart, Chas. R. Wyman,Thos. B. Aitken, Judge Hilton, John Kelly, N. Jarvis, Jr., and others of equal note. Among those present, the Bench, the Bar, and all branches of commerce, were fully represented. The repast was served with the well-known completeness that characterizes such occasions at the Metropolitan. The ornaments were particularly unique, consisting of a statuette of St. Patrick, illuminated cathedral, the Harp of Ireland, towers and pyramids, and, best of all, a bird at the head of the table which OAKEY HALL said was emblematical of the pheasantry of Ireland. An excellent band of music held forth Irish and American National airs throughout the evening. The repast having received full justice, the President, at exactly 10 P.M., commenced the literary portion of the exercises by the following address;

abstract: Every citizen, and certainly every stranger, has had abundant and frequent cause for thanks to MCEWEN, the Deputy Street Commissioner, who was the originator of the ground glass street sign placed in the gas lamps on the corner of every street and avenue in the City. Their great convenience has been abundantly tested and approved, but that there are some, who, from mischief or malice, seek to obliterate these useful sign-boards, is evident from the records of the office. During the past six months no less than 870 have been wantonly destroyed, of which only 100 were located below First-street. In Fifth-avenue, where no graceless scamps are expected or supposed to reside, no less than 100 have been broken or carried away; and this locality is only exceeded by the denizens of the Third, Fourth and Ninth avenues, the largest being the latter avenue, where 124 were demolished. In the lower portion of the City, and especially in those portions were rowdyism is assumed to be rampant, such as Mercer, Green, Grand, Broome and kindred streets, not a dozen signs have been destroyed or removed.

abstract: Yesterday being St. Prtrick's Day, it was celebrated by our Irish citizens in the most magnificent manner. For years past there has not been so grand as parade. All the Irish Societies in this City and Brooklyn were represented. But the crowning feature of the day was the appearance of the gallant Sixty-ninth, the same that fought so nobly at the battle of Bull Run.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a petition was presented from citizens of New-York, asking Congress to stop the agitation of the Slavery question' and attend to the restoration of the Union. A bill providing for the organization of the Army Corps, Staffs, &c., was reported from the Military Committee. The Committee on Territories was instructed to inquire into the expediency of so altering the boundaries of Kansas as to include the Indian Territory. The report of the Committee of Conference on the bill to provide for the purchase of coin was agreed to. A resolution was adopted instructing the Naval Committee to inquire into the expediency of making an appropriation for testing mail for war vessels. The joint resolution authorizing the President to assign the command of troops in the field without regard to seniority, was called up, but was recommitted to the Committee on Military Affairs. The Post-office Appropriation bill was debated, and an amendment was made, providing that all American vessels shall, when required, transport the United States mails for the usual compensation. The bill was then passed. The bill for the abolition of Slavery in the District of Columbia was postponed until to-day. The Senate then went into Executive session, and confirmed the appointments of several Brigadier-Generals, and afterwards adjourned.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, a petition was presented from citizens of New-York, asking Congress to stop the agitation of the Slavery question' and attend to the restoration of the Union. A bill providing for the organization of the Army Corps, Staffs, &c., was reported from the Military Committee. The Committee on Territories was instructed to inquire into the expediency of so altering the boundaries of Kansas as to include the Indian Territory. The report of the Committee of Conference on the bill to provide for the purchase of coin was agreed to. A resolution was adopted instructing the Naval Committee to inquire into the expediency of making an appropriation for testing mail for war vessels. The joint resolution authorizing the President to assign the command of troops in the field without regard to seniority, was called up, but was recommitted to the Committee on Military Affairs. The Post-office Appropriation bill was debated, and an amendment was made, providing that all American vessels shall, when required, transport the United States mails for the usual compensation. The bill was then passed. The bill for the abolition of Slavery in the District of Columbia was postponed until to-day. The Senate then went into Executive session, and confirmed the appointments of several Brigadier-Generals, and afterwards adjourned.

abstract: BLOCKADE OF THE RIO BRAVO. -- Through Havana comes the news that the mouth of the Rio Grande is vigilantly blockaded by the sloop-of-war Portsmouth. The right to close a river dividing our own from the Mexican Republic, may not be literally sustainable; but there is every reason to believe the exercise of a reasonable surveillance will not be objectionable to the Government of Mexico, or to that of any State preserving friendly relations with the United States. What is accomplished by a coast-guard at that particular point is not only a check upon intercourse between Texas and Cuba by way of Matamoras and Brownsville, but a demonstration that neither France or England is covertly nullifying the blockade by encouraging the shipment of Southern produce to Europe through Mexico. Thus justice is done to all parties, including the rebels, who alone suffer. Their afflictions are, however, only for a season. A few weeks and the blockade will be raised.
lead_paragraph: BLOCKADE OF THE RIO BRAVO. -- Through Havana comes the news that the mouth of the Rio Grande is vigilantly blockaded by the sloop-of-war Portsmouth. Thus justice is done to all parties, including the rebels, who alone suffer. Their afflictions are, however, only for a season. A few weeks and the blockade will be raised.

abstract: Flag-Officer FOOTE, attacked the rebel position at Island No. 10, in the Mississippi River, between Hickman and New Madrid, on Sunday, and at the date of the last dispatches, received from Cairo, previous to going to press, 4 P.M., on Sunday, the fight was still progressing. The flotilla left Cairo at 5 1/2 o'clock in the morning, and at 9 o'clock rounded to about three miles above the island, and prepared for action. The rebel position was found to be a very strong one, with a large number of guns mounted, and in addition a floating battery, and several gunboats. A battery above the island was first shelled by the mortar-boats, and the enemy were compelled to leave it several times, but returned to it again. Shells could be thrown into the fortifications on the island easily, and the place would doubtless soon be rendered untenable. The rebels, however, would most likely make a desperate fight, from the fact that Gen. POPE was below them at New-Madrid, in full command of the river, with heavy artillery and the fortifications deserted by them on Thursday night. The rebel force was estimated at from 15,000 to 20,000. P.S. -- Just as we are going to press a dispatch from St. Lousis announces that "Island No. 10 is ours!"

abstract: On BOARD THE MONITOR, Friday, March 14, 1862. The Monitor left the Navy-yard, New-York,  Thursday, March 6. The vessel had been for several day previous with fires banked ready for a start, but delay after delay occurred, much to the disappointment of all on board. When on Thursday the order was given to start, both officers and men were very much delighted.

abstract: RESIGNATION. -- We are informed that the gentlemen who were selected as the Advisory Committee of "The Union Home and School for the Education and Maintenance of the Children of our Volunteers," have recommended the discontinuance of the operations of the Association as at present organized, and have ceased to act as such Committee. They express the hope that an Association for the same purpose may be formed and duly incorporated by the Legislature. For the above reason, and in consequence of her delicate health, Mrs. Gen. ANDERSON has resigned the office of President of the "Union Home and School," which she has held.

abstract: Died, at the residence of his father, at Geneva, March 13, 1862, JOHN FOOT. Esq., of this City, counselor at law, son of Hon. SAMUEL A. FOOT, aged 26. The deceased rrised a company in Minnesota, which he led in the gallant and memorable charge of the Second Minnesota Regiment, at the battle of Mill Spring. Capt. FOOT, broken in constitution by the privations and hardships of the Winter campaign, reached home in time to breathe his last. Distinguished and successful beyond his years in his profession, brave and beloved as a soldier, he turned from the fleeting pleasures and honors of this world, giving his life to his country, and his example to his countrymen.

abstract: POSTING OUR NEIGHBOR. -- Our neighbor of the Evening Post must revise his Southwestern geography. Island No. 10 is not within two hundred miles of the Mississippi State line. The line between Kentucky and Tennessee strikes the river immediately opposite this island, rather above than below it, leaving the island in the State of Tennessee. All the islands of the river, from Cairo to New-Orleans, belong to the States on the East bank of the river. The village of Obionville, which the Post locates in Mississippi, is in Obion County, Tenn.

abstract: The news received from Mexico to the 4th inst. does not encourage the idea of a protracted stay of the European troops in the country. The preliminaries of La Soledad have not only been signed by the Allied Plenipotentiaries, but approved by JUAREZ. These inaugurate negotiations on the basis that the coming of the ships and soldiery was uncalled for by anything in the internal condition of the Republic; and so far as the reoganization of the Government is concerned, and the substitution of a monarchical or any other form for the present, the mission of the three Powers is ended. The only business left them is that which they have an unquestionable right to execute, namely, the collection of certain arrears of interest on the National debt, amounting, perhaps, to a hundredth part of the cost of the expedition Guarantees for the future will also be obtained, amounting to the current value of such very common commodities in the Spanish-American market.

abstract: REVIVAL OF TROTTING. -- A large number of staunch supporters of the turf held a meeting at the Hone House the other evening, for the purpose of reorganizing the Fashion Association Club. New rules and by-laws were made and adopted. Mr. CROCHERON, the enterprising and liberal proprietor of theCourse, will give $3,750 this Spring to be trotted for in purses, among which will be the great handicup purse of $500. A new grand stand has been built, and the stables and track have been put in excellent order. Many gentlemen of well-known position are members of the Association, so its success is almost assured.
lead_paragraph: REVIVAL OF TROTTING. -- A large number of staunch supporters of the turf held a meeting at the Hone House the other evening, for the purpose of reorganizing the Fashion Association Club. abstract: When Nashville had fallen, and thereby the rebel centre in Tennessee was pierced, there were but two or three other points of strategic value in that State for the rebels to defend. Of the first importance were Knoxville, in the eastern part of the State, and Memphis, in the extreme southwestern. The more immediately menaced of these points was Memphis, and to the defence of that place every rebel energy was turned, and every rebel soldier who could be spared was sent. There were but three approaches to Memphis immediately available for our advancing forces. One of these was by the Mississippi River from Cairo; another via the Memphis and Ohio Railroad, from the vicinity of Fort Henry; and the third, by our forces ascending the Tennessee River to the son them line of the State, from thence marching to Corinth, Miss., and there taking the railroad and approaching Memphis in the rear. The first of these routes, that by the Mississippi, the rebels, after being driven from Columbus, proceeded to defend by erecting earthworks at New-Madrid, which they mounted with a very large number of guns, and manned by a force eight thousand strong; they also fortified Island No. Ten, a short distance above the former point, stationed a strong body of troops there, and moreover, brought to its defence all the available rebel gunboats on the river, and an iron-clad floating battery; beside these, fortifications were erected at Randolph and other defensible points. To prevent our approach to Memphis from Fort Henry by the Memphis and Ohio Railroad, the rebels held possession of Humboldt on the line of that road, and of the town of Jackson, Madison County, twenty miles north of Humboldt, but on the line of the Mobile and Ohio Railroad. The latter position is naturally a good one, and, if properly strengthened, would prevent all approaches to Memphis from the Northeast. BEAUREGARD himself assumed the task of fortifying Jackson, and, to make the work still more perfect, he took counsel of BRAGG, who came up from Pensacola to give it, and for other purposes. The other line of approach to Memphis, that by the Memphis and Charleston Railroad, running into the city from the southeast, the rebels guarded by fortifying Corinth, (Miss.,) and by stationing Gen. SIDNEY JOHNSTON's force at Decatur, (Ala.) -- the latter body to menace the rear of any National force which might ascend the Tennessee River, and from thence attempt to march upon Memphis. These various positions -- New-Madrid, Number Ten, Humboldt, Jackson and Corinth --formed a grand defensive semi-circle guarding Memphis, and, according to the rebels, blocked our approach in every direction, except by a long march through Arkansas. After having thus fortified every route to the menaced town, the rebel newspapers announced its impregnability, and the citizens of Memphis proceeded to work themselves up to a frenzy of terror and apprehension.
lead_paragraph: When Nashville had fallen, and thereby the rebel centre in Tennessee was pierced, there were but two or three other points of strategic value in that State for the rebels to defend. Of the first importance were Knoxville, in the eastern part of the State, and Memphis, in the extreme southwestern. The more immediately menaced of these points was Memphis, and to the defence of that place every rebel energy was turned, and every rebel soldier who could be spared was sent. There were but three approaches to Memphis immediately available for our advancing forces. One of these was by the Mississippi River from Cairo; another via the Memphis and Ohio Railroad, from the vicinity of Fort Henry; and the third, by our forces ascending the Tennessee River to the son them line of the State, from thence marching to Corinth, Miss., and there taking the railroad and approaching Memphis in the rear. The first of these routes, that by the Mississippi, the rebels, after being driven from Columbus, proceeded to defend by erecting earthworks at New-Madrid, which they mounted with a very large number of guns, and manned by a force eight thousand strong; they also fortified Island No. Ten, a short distance above the former point, stationed a strong body of troops there, and moreover, brought to its defence all the available rebel gunboats on the river, and an iron-clad floating battery; beside these, fortifications were erected at Randolph and other defensible points. To prevent our approach to Memphis from Fort Henry by the Memphis and Ohio Railroad, the rebels held possession of Humboldt on the line of that road, and of the town of Jackson, Madison County, twenty miles north of Humboldt, but on the line of the Mobile and Ohio Railroad. The latter position is naturally a good one, and, if properly strengthened, would prevent all approaches to Memphis from the Northeast. BEAUREGARD himself assumed the task of fortifying Jackson, and, to make the work still more perfect, he took counsel of BRAGG, who came up from Pensacola to give it, and for other purposes. The other line of approach to Memphis, that by the Memphis and Charleston Railroad, running into the city from the southeast, the rebels guarded by fortifying Corinth, (Miss.,) and by stationing Gen. SIDNEY JOHNSTON's force at Decatur, (Ala.) -- the latter body to menace the rear of any National force which might ascend the Tennessee River, and from thence attempt to march upon Memphis. These various positions -- New-Madrid, Number Ten, Humboldt, Jackson and Corinth --formed a grand defensive semi-circle guarding Memphis, and, according to the rebels, blocked our approach in every direction, except by a long march through Arkansas. After having thus fortified every route to the menaced town, the rebel newspapers announced its impregnability, and the citizens of Memphis proceeded to work themselves up to a frenzy of terror and apprehension.
