abstract: By the steamer Roanoke, which arrived at this port yesterday, from Havana on the 12th inst., we receive advices from Vera Cruz to the 4th. The Government of JUAREZ had ratified the Convention agreed upon by Gen. PRIM and Senor DOBLADO, the details of which have already been published in the TIMES. The troops of the Allies had set out for Cordova, Orizaba and Tehuacan, as arranged, and everything seemed to indicate that the disputes in question would be settled amicably, and that guarantees would be obtained for the future. It appears that one of the stipulations made at the conference between Generals PRIM and DOBLADO was that no more troops should be landed. Under this, some Spanish troops returned to Cuba, and the expected French reinforcements under Gen. LORENCEZ were to return without landing. The English forces will return via Bermuda to England. Their mules, harness, &c., were sold to the French, who started for Tuhuacan on the 27th. Negotiations were to commence at Orizaba on the 1st of April. Meantime MARQUEZ, with fire thousand Mexican troops, holds the road from Vera Cruz to Mexico. An American citizen, belonging to Lowell, Mass., bearer of dispatches from the Washington Government to Minister CORWIN, was murdered on the 24th ult., while going from Vera Cruz to the City of Mexico. His name is ADDISON T. ARLEN.

abstract: NIBLO's SALOON. -- Mr. GOTTSCHALK's return was welcomed last evening by one of the most fashionable audiences we have yet seen at his very popular entertainments. Niblo's Saloon was crowded to its greatest capacity, and many who were unable to obtain seats were content to put up with the meagre accommodations of the lobbies and passages. The concert, for some reason which was unexplained, did not commence at the hour announced, but considerably later, and even then the order of the programme was not followed. Little irregularities of this kind ought not to exist in first-class entertainments, and we would suggest to Mr. GRAU the propriety of always explaining the cause thereof to the public. The programme was extremely interesting, and received the best of interpretation. Mr. GOTTSCHALK played superbly; his elasticity of touch, his power, his chaste use of the pedals, sympathetic delivery of melody, and brilliant execution of arabesques, were never more charmingly illustrated. Only a great and original artist like Mr. GOTTSCHALK could give thirteen successive concerts in New-York without wearying the public with his peculiarities. Mr. GOTTSCHALK was assisted in the vocal department by Miss CARLOTTA PATTI, Signor BRIGNOLI, Signor MANCUSI, and Mr. SANDERSON (piano.) Mr. CARL BERGMANN was the conductor.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, favorable reports was made on the bills authorizing the formation of Railroad Corporations, and reducing the tolls on canals. The amendments of the Assembly to the bill relative to the Board of Appeals for the New-York Fire Department, were concurred in. The bill, previously noticed, appointing a Receiver General of the State, and transferring to his custody the funds in the hands of the County Treasurers, was introduced. The bill to authorize the New-York Supervisors to raise money, and the bill to create a Court-house stock, were passed.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, the Indian Appropriation bill was reported back from the Finance Committee without amendment. A resolution was adopted calling upon the Secretary of the Navy for all the information in his possession..
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, the Indian Appropriation bill was reported back from the Finance Committee without amendment. A resolution was adopted calling upon the Secretary of the Navy for all the information in his possession relative to the Stevens Battery, the contracts made, &c. The joint resolution authorizing the President to assign the command in the field to any officer, without regard to seniority, was reported again from the Military Committee, without an amendment, striking out the clause giving him power to dismiss from service. The resolution was then passed. The bill to provide for judicial proceedings in the case of captured property, and for the better administration of the law of prizes, was passed. The resolution offered by Mr. STARKE, of Oregon, that the papers in his case be referred to the Judiciary Committee, was taken up. It was amended so as to refer the waiter to a Select Committee, and passed. The bill for the abolition of Slavery in the District of Columbia was then taken up, and Mr. HALE, of New-Hampshire made a speech in favor of its passage, at the conclusion of which the Senate went into Executive Session, and afterward adjourned.

abstract: Gen. BURNSIDE has chosen this time to take the country by surprise; for while all eyes were strained to follow the North Carolina Expedition, as it feels its way along the amphibious region lying between Roanoke and Norfolk,..
lead_paragraph: Gen. BURNSIDE has chosen this time to take the country by surprise; for while all eyes were strained to follow the North Carolina Expedition, as it feels its way along the amphibious region lying between Roanoke and Norfolk, not without some fear lost a powerful force from Manassas should precipitate itself upon and annihilate the unconscious army, he suddenly turns up at the other end of Pamlico Sound, with a bulletin announcing the capture of Newbern, after a contest far more desperate and bloody than has yet been fought anywhere along the seaboard. Our detailed correspondence of the battle of Newbern, by the same graphic and faithful hand that has illustrated the whole progress of the Burnside Expedition, will be found in other columns of this morning's TIMES -- as also a full list of killed and wounded in the engagement. The narrative bears eloquent testimony to the skill and conduct of the officers, and to the daring gallantry of the brave fellows, who stormed battery after battery, and drove the latent enemy from the security of their rifle pits.

abstract: Newbern is, according to the last census, a town of 5,434 inhabitants, and is the second largest town in North Carolina, being excelled in population only by Wilmington, it is one of the oldest towns in the State, and was formerly, and for a long period, its capital.
lead_paragraph: Newbern is, according to the last census, a town of 5,434 inhabitants, and is the second largest town in North Carolina, being excelled in population only by Wilmington, it is one of the oldest towns in the State, and was formerly, and for a long period, its capital. It has been, until the rebellion, a point of considerable trade, exporting grain, lumber, turpentine, tar and naval stores. Besides the county buildings, it contains several churches, two banks, a small theatre, and three newspaper offices, and is a pleasantly-situated, handsomely-built and old-fashioned place. It is located near the inland water-way of the State, at the confluence of the Trent and Neuse rivers, on the western bank of the latter stream, some forty miles from the southern extremity of Pamlico Sound. Our maps will show the topography of the place, the point of landing of our troops, their line of march along the river, between the river and railroad, and other important points mentioned in this morning's telegrams. The Neuse is here about a mile and a half, and the Trent about half a mile wide. The former stream is [???] by steamboats for about eight months in the year. The entrance from the sea is through Ocracoke Inlet. Steamboats used to ply from Newbern, along the inland waters as far as Elizabeth City, (also recently captured by Gen. BURNSIDE,) and other points north of Roanoke Island. From Elizabeth City, again there was canal communication with Norfolk, and until BURNSIDE took Roanoke, this long line of navigation was in possession of the enemy. The rebels have been engaged in strengthening the defences of Newbern ever since it was bruited in the early part of the Winter that BURNSIDE's expedition was to operate upon the coast of North Carolina. A recent number of the Richmond [???] contain-ously remarked: "Newbern is not without protection, but it is unnecessary to say what." Probably the editor referred to the line of shore batteries (mentioned in the dispatches) to prevent a land attack, and the fire-ships to destroy an assailing fleet; but the event has proved that even these did not avail to keep back our brave legions. There is but one railroad running through Newbern -- that from Beaufort, (N.C.,) on the northeastern shore, to Goldsborough, in Wayne County, where it connects with the Weldon and Wilmington Road, and the whole system of shore railroads running South.

abstract: Reports from around country
snippet: Reports from around country
lead_paragraph: First -- Iron armor, 6 3/4 inches thick, backed with 14 inches of the most impenetrable wood, and standing at the acute angle of one in two to the line of fire' is a vastly stronger protection than has over been applied or found vulnerable by any experimenters at home or abroad. At the same time, it is comparatively light, as its extent is reduced by confining it to the central part of the vessel -- by placing the guns (which are their own protection) outside of it, rather than within it, and by immersing the vessel to a deeper fighting draft. The parts of the vessel fore and aft the central casemate are also thoroughly protected by a horizontal deck, which is not only shot-proof, but a foot below the fighting water line. The water protection, as far as it can be judiciously employed, is at once the most perfect and the cheapest armor.

abstract: editorial again stresses need for completing it
snippet: editorial again stresses need for completing it
lead_paragraph: The Chamber of Commerce held a special meeting yesterday afternoon, for the purpose of acting upon the report of the Special Committee, appointed to proceed to Washington, and confer with the War Department relative to our harbor defences. The Committee reported that the plan recommended by the Government was that the cities of Boston, Philadelphia and New-York, should at once enter upon the construction of iron-clad vessels for the purpose of defending their ports against such attacks as might be made with vessels like the Merrimac. After a prolonged discussion, which was participated in by Messrs. Low, Opdyke, Capt. Ericsson, Capt. Nye, C.H. Marshall, Peter Cooper, Capt. Morgan and others, a Committee, was appointed to carry the recommendation into effect, for the better protection of the port of New-York.

abstract: The announcement made in the TIMES yesterday, based on statements made by Commodore  GOLOSBOROUGH, that the Burnside Expedition had gone to Newbern, N.C., prepared our readers in a measure for the glorious news which we...
lead_paragraph: The announcement made in the TIMES yesterday, based on statements made by Commodore GOLDSBOROUGH, that the Burnside Expedition had gone to Newbern, N.C., prepared our readers in a measure for the glorious news which we publish this morning. The fleet left Roanoke Island on the 12th inst., and entering the mouth of the Neuse River on the following night, landed the troops under cover of the gunboats, on the morning of the 13th, at Slocum's Creek. The men then marched some twelve miles up the river, and bivouacked for the night on the railroad, while the gunboats proceeded further up, and shelled a rebel battery. On the morning of the 14th the march was again resumed, and our men had proceeded but a short distance when the rebels were discovered. Their works consisted of a series of strong batteries, extending over a distance of two miles, and defended by about ten thousand men, with twenty-one guns in position, besides a formidable array of field artillery. The batteries of the enemy were taken one after the other -- the last and most formidable one, where the rebels had concentrated their whole strength, by a gallant bayonet charge, in which the Massachusetts Twenty-first and the New-York Fifty-first again figured conspicuously. The enemy then fled pell-mell across the Trent River, destroying the bridges behind them, and having a sufficiency of cars at hand, made their escape in the direction of Goldsborough, leaving everything behind them, and about three hundred of their number as prisoners. They attempted to burn the town of Newbern before leaving it, but succeeded in doing very little damage, the citizens extinguishing the fires as fast as kindled. The Neuse River was obstructed by sunken vessels and chevaux-de-frise, which interfered with the operations of our gunboats, consequently the credit of the victory belongs in a great measure to the land forces. The rebels also had scows filled with tar and turpentine, at Newbern, to send down the river to burn our fleet, but the tide did not serve them as they desired, and the project failed. The battle was undoubtedly one of the most desperate of the war. Our troops behaved with the steadiness of veterans, and only won their victory after nearly four hours of close fighting. We captured three light batteries of field artillery, forty-six heavy siege guns, large stores of fixed ammunition, and three thousand stand of small arms, and among the prisoners are one Colonel, three Captains and four lieutenants. They left a number of dead on the field, but as they carried off a large part of their dead and wounded, their lose cannot be known. Our loss is from ninety to one hundred killed, and some four hundred wounded. The rebel force was commanded by Gen. LAWRENCE O'B. BRANCH, formerly member of Congress from North Carolina.

abstract: Gen. LAWRENCE O'B. BRANCH, who commanded the rebels at the battle of Newbern, is a native of North Carolina, and 42 years of age. He graduated at Princeton College, New-Jersey, in 1838, and afterward entered on the practice of law. He was elected a Democratic Representative from North Carolina to the Thirty-fourth Congress, and reelected to the Thirty-fifth, in which he was a member of the Committee on Territories. He was in the House when the secession movement began, and vacated his seat just about a year ago. He went back to North Carolina and raised men for the rebel service. In November last the rebel Congress confirmed him a Brigadier-General, and he was appointed to command the troops on the southern coast of North Carolina. This is his first engagement, and for him it has proved a failure.

abstract: A more formidable barrier than the wooden wall of the Cumberland went crashing down on the memorable 9th of March before the iron beak of the Merrimac. The frowning ramparts of prejudice and old-fogyism, that have so long resisted the artillery of scientific progress, tumbled into ruin before the...
lead_paragraph: A more formidable barrier than the wooden wall of the Cumberland went crashing down on the memorable 9th of March before the iron beak of the Merrimac. The frowning ramparts of prejudice and old-fogyism, that have so long resisted the artillery of scientific progress, tumbled into ruin before the columbiads of official fear and popular clamor for improvement and protection. This is, perhaps, more strikingly evidenced in the total revolution of feeling with regard to the Stevens Battery than in any other fact of our history. As long ago as the War of 1812 the Messrs. STEVENS experimented on inclined armor for harbor defence, and consummated that grandest feature of cannon practice, the firing of shells horizontally. In 1841 they urged the Government, by documents which have ever since lain in the mouldy archives of the Department, to construct steam rams, iron plated vessels, driven by the submerged propeller, (invented by their father during the last century,) heavy guns, rifled cannon, elongated shot and shells covered with soft metal to prevent windage, and most of the other improvements which have begun to characterize and define the new era of naval warfare. For the last twenty-five years they have spent many thousands of dollars in experimenting upon the best means of carrying out those improvements, and in developing the great practical facts which the Government has adopted and will have to adopt, almost in detail, under the new regiare. They have advanced a quarter of a million toward the completion of the splendid vessel embodying these great features, a detailed and illustrated description of which will he found in other columns of this paper; they have actually built and worked many of the novel improvements -- such for instance as loading heavy guns by steam -- which men in authority laughed at until they were silenced by the results of actual trial; they have, until recently, concealed from the public the important results they have developed, at the sacrifice of all personal considerations, to oblige the Government; and they have not even demanded their due, when other men have reinvented and enjoyed the fruits of these very improvements. And what has been their reward? Opposition -- nothing but opposition -- public and private -- uncompromising and remorseless -- without precedent in the history of modern engineering progress. Their plans and memorials have been suffered to rot in the Government's vaults, while the information they have contained has been appropriated by other men, or kept from the light under bolts and bars. They have been encouraged to commence a ship of defence, of the most remarkable character and value, and to embark an immense fortune in it, merely to be abandoned and abused.

abstract: The steamer Commodore,Capt. STONE, so long and favorably known upon the Sound, has been chartered to the United States Government, and has just returned from Hatteras with important dispatches to the War and Navy Departments concerning the capture of Newberu. She was dispatched by the Secretary of War a week ago with dispatches to Gen. BURNSIDE, Lieut. CARRINGTON RAYMOND being bearer of dispatches. She made the run from Baltimore in the unprecedented short time of fifteen hours. She remained at Hatteras by direction of Gen. BURNSIDE, who, on the day she arrived, was moving toward Newbern. On Monday morning the Picket came down to Hatteras, bringing news of the capture of that place, and a bearer of dispatches to the Government. She left the Inlet at 8 o'clock, with a strong northwest breeze, and came safely out through that intricate and dangerous place. After passing Hatteras the wind hauled to the northeast, and blew quite fresh all day, causing a head sea. This staunch steamer, however, made excellent headway, and fully sustained her reputation as one of the best seaboats of her class. She arrived at Fortress Monroe early in the evening, and after delivering dispatches to Flag-Officer GOLDSBOROUGH, on board the Minnesota, proceeded up to Baltimore, where she arrived in just twenty-four hours from the Inlet. She had on board Lieutenant C. RAYMOND and Captain HAZZARD, bearer of dispatches, with several officers and a detail of men from the Twenty-first and Twenty-third Massachusetts, having in charge the remains of Lieut.-Col. MERRITT and Adjutant F.A. STEARNS. The reporters of the Press were also indebted to Capt. STONE, and to Mr. STONE, the obliging Purser, for a passage from Hatteras, and the many civilities extended them on board. The Commodore is at Baltimore, waiting orders.

abstract: By the steamship Anglo-Saxon, which arrived at Portland yesterday morning, we receive advices from Europe five days later. She left Liverpool on the 6th, and Londonderry on the 7th inst. The
lead_paragraph: By the steamship Anglo-Saxon, which arrived at Portland yesterday morning, we receive advices from Europe five days later. She left Liverpool on the 6th, and Londonderry on the 7th inst. The news is in some respects important. The news of the Fort Donelson victory had been received in England, and its importance was generally conceded. It caused an immediate advance in American securities, and a depression in cotton. The London Times, however, while admitting the recent successes of the National arms, says they have been gained in a region of country where the allegiance of the population was divided, and professes to believe they have brought us no nearer to a reconstruction of the Union; and the London Post hopes that the present state of affairs will be looked upon as affording grounds for a compromise of difficulties. The sales of the week in the Liverpool Cotton market footed up 31,500 bales, and the news from America had caused a decline of [???] The stock on hand was 440,000 bales, of which 166,000 American. Breadstuffs were easier, and Provisions dull.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a joint. resolution, was offered by Mr. KING, of New-York, authorizing the importation of arms, ordered by a state, free of duly, but it being announced that a bill on the same subject was in course of preparation, the resolution was laid over. The bill to secure pay, bounty and pensions to men in service in the Department of the West was passed. A bill to provide for the public defence, and to accept loans from the several States for that purpose, was introduced and referred. A resolution was reported from the Naval Committee, authorizing the Secretary of the Navy to place officers now on the retired list, on active service. The bill for the organization of army corps, etc., was passed after some debate, 29 to 9. The bill for the abolition of Slavery in the District of Columbia was then taken up, and Mr. DOOLITTLE, of Wisconsin, made a speech in favor of its passage. He was followed by Mr. POMEROY, of Kansas, on the same side, at the conclusion of whose speech the Senate went into Executive session.

abstract: It would be an emi
lead_paragraph: It would be an eminently cheerful and soul-strengthening thing to catch a rebel envoy, without the ensuing necessity of letting him go. If, therefore, YANCEY has been captured in his attempt to run the blockade, as a Philadelphia cotemporary would have us believe, let us be exultantthereupon, and let us make ready for him,in Fort Lafayette. Col. BURKE, or in Fort Warren, Col. DIMMOCK, a convenient chamber, devoid of an outlet on the British side. There let the arch-precipitator live and repair those fine diplomatic webs with which he failed to ensnare European crowns; for there is no foretelling the shifts to which he may presently he driven to save his neck from the haller lie singularly merits. No one of the Southern leaders was so active and efficient in promoting insurrection. While the rest conspired to carry out a programme prescribed by him, he was the apostle of revolt, the demagogue and whipper-in, who brought the masses of the misguided people to the point where they could be made available for the purposes of rebellion. Whoever appreciates the peculiar excellence and profitableness of his labors, will not dispute his title to an exceeding great reward. Room, therefore,for the precipitator in Fort Warren, not too far from BUCKNER, and, if possible, in the very apartment flavored by the recent occupancy of MASON and SLIDELL.

abstract: Orders have been received to transfer the political prisoners confined in Fort Lafayette to Governor's Island, and preparations have accordingly been made in Castle William for their reception. They were expected yesterday, but had not arrived up
lead_paragraph: Orders have been received to transfer the political prisoners confined in Fort Lafayette to Governor's Island, and preparations have accordingly been made in Castle William for their reception. They were expected yesterday, but had not arrived up to a late hour in the afternoon. Company C of the general service, commanded by Lieut. WOODS, which has been on doing duty at Fort Lafayette since that place was converted into a political prison, are expected to accompany the prisoners, and remain on Governor's Island to guard them, the garrison there being scarcely strong enough to provide a cordon of sentinels round the island. Fort Lafayette will be left in charge of the Fifth New-York Artillery.

abstract: -We are in daily receipt of a circular inquiring why the Tax bill makes no mention of Pennsylvania coal. The question appears, from the frequency of its repetition, to be an easy one to ask; but it is not so to answer. Perhaps the Committee judged that as Pennsylvania had enjoyed very nearly a monopoly of contracts, and other means of enriching itself at the expense of Government, during last year, it would be just to relieve it from the mortification of seeing its recently acquired opulence so soon reduced by the necessity of lending proportionate support to the Government. We are, at least, very sure that the fact of Mr. STEVENS' of Pennsylvania, being Chairman of the Committee, has nothing to do with the exemption

abstract: At about 3 o'clock on Tuesday morning last Officer CONRADY, of the Ninth Precinet Police, while patroling his beat, heard the cries of a woman for assistance coming from the house of PAUL O'NEIL, on Bedford-avenue. He entered the house, when a woman crawled from under a bed, to which place she had escaped to avoid O'NEIL'S blows, and demanded the protection of the officer.
lead_paragraph: At about 3 o'clock on Tuesday morning last Officer CONRADY, of the Ninth Precinet Police, while patroling his beat, heard the cries of a woman for assistance coming from the house of PAUL O'NEIL, on Bedford-avenue. He entered the house, when a woman crawled from under a bed, to which place she had escaped to avoid O'NEIL'S blows, and demanded the protection of the officer. O'NEIL thereupon ordered the officer to leave his premises, and seized upon him with a view of enforcing his command. CONRADY then arrested O'NEIL, and started with him towards the Station-house, but on the way there he made an attack upon the officer, and after a severe tussle, in which the officer had his clothes torn and was considerably bruised about the face, assistance was received from other officers, and the prisoner was for a time secured. After a little talk, O'NEIL promised to go with CONRADY to the station without further difficulty, and they started together, leaving the other officers to attend to their respective duties. O'NEIL had proceeded only a short distance when ho set upon the officer again, and another struggle took place, which ended in O'NEIL's freeing himself and starling off at a vapid pace to make his escape. The officer followed in hot pursuit until ho found his prisoner was likely to escape, when he fired a random shut and the ball entered the back of O'NEIL's head, killing him almost instantly.

abstract: Editorial on London Times views of US finances; Editorial on London Times views of US finances
snippet: Editorial on London Times views of US finances; Editorial on London Times views of US finances
lead_paragraph: The London Times, whose influence over public opinion in England is evidently not what it once was, has recently been indulging its well-known admiration for our National cause, and has demonstrated to its own satisfaction that its opinions as to the probable success of our present struggle are supported by the history, of modern England and of ancient Greece. The chief difficulty our too un generous, cotemporary has met with in these unappreciated labors has been the obstinate incompatibility between its facts and its deductions. Hence, its achievements have had the effect of raising considerable mirth at its own expense. Being thus derided at home and abroad for its historical parallels, the Times has sought a refuge in the less explored regions of political science. Our finances, it thinks, are our most vulnerable point. In that direction, therefore, it places its heaviest artillery. And such of the British capitalists as allow themselves to be influenced by its representations will certainly prefer 2 1/4 per cent. on investments in England to the tempting offer of thrice as much in the United States, with equal security.

abstract: If anything were wanting to perfect the claims of Gen. BURNSIDE to public respect and admiration, it would be supplied by his official narrative of the victory at Newborn. To
lead_paragraph: If anything were wanting to perfect the claims of Gen. BURNSIDE to public respect and admiration, it would be supplied by his official narrative of the victory at Newborn. To proofs of well-contrived strategy, cautious and successful leadership, and consummate gallantry under fire, Gen. BURNSIDE adds evidence of that rare modesty which not only arrogates no merit belonging to others, but is even anxious to place the fortunate result to the credit of those who originally planned the enterprise.

abstract: Commodore DUPONT is rapidly doing up what little work needs to be done for the complete repossession of Florida. We have news this morning that St. Augustine and Jacksonville, two of the largest towns in a state
lead_paragraph: Commodore DUPONT is rapidly doing up what little work needs to be done for the complete repossession of Florida. We have news this morning that St. Augustine and Jacksonville, two of the largest towns in a State which has none but small towns, had surrendered without a struggle, and that the flag of the Republic, has again been raised over the venerable walls of San Juan de Pinos, or as it is now designated. Fort Marion. This finishes naval operations in Eastern Florida. North of St. Augustine we now hold the line of the St. John's River. Fernandina, and Cumberland Sound: and south of it there is not a harbor until the Florida. Keys are reached -- which again are in our hands. It was hardly worth while for the rebel Government to recommend the entire evacuation of East Florida, for already we control it all -- and virtually, indeed, the whole State -- and coast, rivers, and railroads. Fernandina and Cedar Keys give us the termini of the railroad across the peninsula: Jacksonville gives us the eastern terminus of the road to Alligator; and there remains only two short lines in the western part of the State -- the most important one of which is probably also by this time in our possession. It would almost be worth while now for Comnodore by report take to pass around into the Gulf of Mexico -- take possession of St. Marks and Tallahassee. and establish that authority of the night States in the Capital. It is mite time that the contemptible usurpers, who have pretended to rule Florida for the past year, were driven into the swamps lately evacuated byBILLY BOWLING.

abstract: This fort, over which now waves the Stars and Stripes, is, as already mentioned, at the north end of St. Augustine, commanding the harbor. It is a very ancient work, having been built by the Spaniards over two hundred years ago, and was completed in 1756, under Governor and Captain-General Don
lead_paragraph: This fort, over which now waves the Stars and Stripes, is, as already mentioned, at the north end of St. Augustine, commanding the harbor. It is a very ancient work, having been built by the Spaniards over two hundred years ago, and was completed in 1756, under Governor and Captain-General Don ALONZO FERNANDO HEREDA, in the reign of Don FERDINAND VI. An old writer describes it as a casemated fort, with four bastions, a ravelin, counterscarp, and a giacis built with quarried shell stones, and constructed according to the rudiments of Marechal DE VAUBAN. Another describes it as above half a mile in length, regularly fortified with bastions, half bastions and a ditch. It had also several rows of the Spanish bayonet along the ditch, which formed so close a chevaux de frize, with their pointed leaves, as to be impenetrable -- the northern bastions built of stone.

abstract: The Town of St. Augustine, of which our troops have just taken peaceful possession, is the most ancient settlement in the United States, and has a history of romance and wonder unequaled by any place on the continent. It is a place of 2,000 inhabitants, situated on the northeastern coast of Florida, two
lead_paragraph: The Town of St. Augustine, of which our troops have just taken peaceful possession, is the most ancient settlement in the United States, and has a history of romance and wonder unequaled by any place on the continent. It is a place of 2,000 inhabitants, situated on the northeastern coast of Florida, two miles back from the Atlantic shore, on the south point Of a peninsular, connected with the mainland by a narrow isthmus, protected from the swell of the ocean by Anastasia Island, not sufficiently high to obstruct the sea breezes and a view of the ocean. It is in the form of a parallelogram, fronting east on Matanzas Sound, forming a harbor sufficient to contain a large fleet in safety. The city is one mile long, and three-fourths of a mile wide. The streets are narrow, and some of them very crooked, and the houses are generally built of stone, two stories high. It contains a splendid Roman Catholic Church and other houses of worship, and on the east is a fine large square, which forms a charming orange grove. The place is extremely salubrious, and has always been a favorite resort for consumptive and other invalids from the North. Fort Marion stands at the north end of the town, and completely commands the harbor Regular steam-packets have always ran between St. Augustine and Charleston.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, majority and minority reports on the apportionment of the Congressional Districts of the State were presented. The bill to cede to the United States jurisdiction over lands in Buffalo for the erection of fortifications was passed under a suspension of the rules. The bills relative to the Kings County Penitentiary, and to alter the map of this City, were passed; also the bill to amend the Fire Insurance law. The bill to repeal the Church Property act was moved forward to the first Committee of the Whole. The resolution to appoint a Grinding Committee was passed. A resolution approving the policy suggested by the President, regarding gradual emancipation, was presented, but laid over under the rule. A bill for raising money by tax, to defray the expenses of the New-York City Government, was referred to the New-York delegation. A Special Committee was appointed to present the proposed testimonial to Gen. SCOTT. The bill to repeal the Church Property act was then debated in Committee of the Whole until the adjournment.

abstract: We would remind our Legislators that the most shameless system of iniquity that ever existed in a civilized community disgraces our principal thoroughfares, while the law asked for by the Grand Jury, the Press and the public, for its suppression, two months ago, hangs fire in the Assembly. The cunning amendment of Mr. MCMULLEN, which would have the effect to increase the evil indefinitely, should be voted down, and the bill, as reported from the excellent Committee on Cities, passed into a law without delay. There will he enough of profligacy and vice left when the abominations of the "Gaities" and a score of Broadway brothels are squelched; it is due to decency and morality that these should secede -- or see "Stars."

abstract: The editor of an incongruous weekly print was the other day arrested in Washington, for publishing news contraband of war, and, after a salutary fright, was discharged. Another Washington journal, of small circulation, on Monday issued intelligence, the publication of which in the New-York papers was peremptorily forbidden. We refer to the appointment of Gen. HUNTER to the command in South Carolina, which was communicated to this paper on Saturday, but countermanded by the censorship at Washington. Nor is this charity, so indulgent at home, kept there. Not a journal in the Western States has paid the least attention to the rule. The movements of troops, the positions of the various forces the designs, as far as they can be ascertained of their several Commanders, are as freely given as it no order of Secretary STANTON, and no fear of MARTIN BURKE, filied their editorial souls. It is mainly, if not solely, to the New-York Press that the injunction applies; and, of course, while it utterly fails to, wrap military movements in secresy, it operates as a bounty and encouragement to journals less enterprizing and less observant of authority than those of this City. The intelligence which cannot be published in a New-York daily may be mailed to a Cincinnati paper, and printed there with impunity. If copied here again, the daring publisher would incur and no doubt receive, the penalty of the rule.

abstract: The Opera season was resumed at the Academy last night, under the greatest encouragement for the management, and to the delight of an unusually large audience. The addition of the Ballet, with Senorita CUBAS, was heartily welcomed in the masqurerade scene of "Un Ballo," and the performance warmly applauded. The now waltz of Signor BRIGNOLI was also a pleasant feature in this scene.

abstract: The process of educating the British Press into some trifling acquaintance with the American people, their struggle, and patience, and effectual resolve and energy, is slow, but, there is reason to think, not without a fair prospect of success. The London Times admits the conflict at Donelson to be a great and important battle. A concession of this sort is so marked an advance upon any previous judgment in our affairs, as to justify the most san guine expectations. We may even hope that When every rebel capital and seaport is in our hands, and every rebel shall have laid down his arms, to bring the London Press to the point of admitting the suppression of the rebellion to be within the bounds of possibility. But here, perhaps, we yield wildly to the present momentary gleam of encouragement. It may be deceptive.
lead_paragraph: The process of educating the British Press into some trifling acquaintance with the American people, their struggle, and patience, and effectual resolve and energy, is slow, but, there is reason to think, not without a fair prospect of success. The London Times admits the conflict at Donelson to be a great and important battle. A concession of this sort is so marked an advance upon any previous judgment in our affairs, as to justify the most san guine expectations. We may even hope that When every rebel capital and seaport is in our hands, and every rebel shall have laid down his arms, to bring the London Press to the point of admitting the suppression of the rebellion to be within the bounds of possibility. But here, perhaps, we yield wildly to the present momentary gleam of encouragement. It may be deceptive.

abstract: Our dispatches still fail to bring us the information that Island No. 10 has fallen into our hands, though the result of the contest there can hardly be in doubt. A dispatch from Commodore FOOTE to the Navy Department, dated Wednesday, states that the island is harder to conquer than Colum- bus would have been, as the shores are lined with forts, each one commanding the one above it.
lead_paragraph: Our dispatches still fail to bring us the information that Island No. 10 has fallen into our hands, though the result of the contest there can hardly be in doubt. A dispatch from Commodore FOOTE to the Navy Department, dated Wednesday, states that the island is harder to conquer than Columbus would have been, as the shores are lined with forts, each one commanding the one above it. He was gradually approaching,however, firing day and night, the mortar-shells doing great execution. One of them landed on the famous floating battery, and "cleared the concern in short metre." The enemy's flotilla, hemmed in between the island and New-Madrid, the position of Gen. POPE, had made another attempt to escape down the river, but was met with such a storm from Gen. POPE's batteries that it was forced to retreat again with severe loss -- one gunboat being sunk and several others badly damaged.

abstract: -- As an article in an evening cotemporary, respecting a temporary indisposition of Bishop POTTER of New-York, may be the cause of some anxiety to his friends and to members of the church at a distance, we are glad to be able to state that there is no occasion for any uneasiness, the illness having been a mere passing turn of faintness, owing to a slight disturbance of the system and the omission of the usual morning's meal. It occurred after a period of comparative leisure in the Diocese, and of uninterrupted health.

abstract: The action of the Government at Washington, in placing in the hands of ANDREW JOHNSON, United States Senator from Tennessee, the temporary Government that State, is one of the most important steps yet taken in the rebellion. It is really the first essay that has yet been made toward reconstruction.
lead_paragraph: The action of the Government at Washington, in placing in the hands of ANDREW JOHNSON, United States Senator from Tennessee, the temporary Government that State, is one of the most important steps yet taken in the rebellion. It is really the first essay that has yet been made toward reconstruction. Virginia, in theory, never left the Union, Gov. PIERPONT, with his Legislature chosen from the western counties, being recognized as the legitimate continuation of the Government which Gov. LETCHER and the previous legislature abdicated at Richmond. This State has not ceased to be represented in either House of Congress. In Maryland, the Executive remained loyal, while the disloyal Legislature was suppressed by a rescript from Washington, and has been succeeded by another, elected in pursuance of established law and usage. In Missouri, a loyal Convention deposed a disloyal Governor and installed another in his place. In Kentucky, both Governor (nominally) and Legislature remained loyal. In all the cases cited the States retained an independent position and maintained their previous relations to the Central Government.

abstract: Editorial on need for iron-clad navy
snippet: Editorial on need for iron-clad navy
lead_paragraph: SIDNEY SMITH used to say that if needed a surgical operation to get a joke into a Scotchman's skull; and, in like wise, it required the terrible surgery of Hampton Roads to arouse the Naval Committee of Congress to the importance of armored ships of war, if, however, our legislators were, previous to the combat between the Merrimac and the Monitor, chargeable with remissness in this respect, we are bound to give them credit for promptly acting on the light which that wonderful and epoch-making event has let into their minds. Senator DALE, as Chairman of the Senate Committee on Naval Affairs, has reported a bill appropriating fifteen million dollars for the commencement of an iron-clad navy. The terms of the bill are comprehensive and judicious, and provide for the construction of a steam-ram of five or six thousand tons burden, at a cost of a million of dollars or under, and appropriate $13,000,000 for the building of iron-clad gunboats, $783,000 for the completion of STEVENS' Battery, and $500,000 for extending the facilities of the Washington Navy-yard, so as to roll and forge plates for the armored ships. We trust the bill may pass without any further delay than is necessary to secure the most judicious investment of the money appropriated.

abstract: -- The confirmation of Mr. WAKEMAN as Postmaster for this City will be entirely satisfactory to the public. Since it was understood that a change was to be made, and Mr. TAYLOR, whose appointment was merely temporary and provisional, was to give place to a permanent successor, the propriety of bestowing the office upon the gentleman selected by the President, has been generally conceded. Mr. WAKEMAN is in all respects admirably qualified for the post. Popular in address, rapid and practical in his business habits, alive to the interests of the City and its people, fully abreast of the progressive and reformatory temper of the times, he will be sure to make the administration of the Post-office respond to the needs and convenience of the public.
lead_paragraph: -- The confirmation of Mr. WAKEMAN as Postmaster for this City will be entirely satisfactory to the public. Since it was understood that a change was to be made, and Mr. TAYLOR, whose appointment was merely temporary and provisional, was to give place to a permanent successor, the propriety of bestowing the office upon the gentleman selected by the President, has been generally conceded. Mr. WAKEMAN is in all respects admirably qualified for the post. Popular in address, rapid and practical in his business habits, alive to the interests of the City and its people, fully abreast of the progressive and reformatory temper of the times, he will be sure to make the administration of the Post-office respond to the needs and convenience of the public.

abstract: Editorial on newly established Southern military dept. comprising South Carolina, Georgia and Florida under command of Hunter
snippet: Editorial on newly established Southern military dept. comprising South Carolina, Georgia and Florida under command of Hunter
lead_paragraph: -- WORK FOR GENERALS HUNTER AND BENHAM. -- The good judgment of President LINCOLN has been in nothing more conspicuously displayed than in the creation of a new Southern Department, comprising the States of South Carolina, Georgia and Florida, to be under the command of Maj.-Gen. DAVID HUNTER. By reuniting the Western Department with that of Missouri he adroitly cut the knot of the Lane and Hunter imbroglio, which had become confused beyond any power to ravel, and at the same time relieved from comparatively unimportant duties an officer whose experience and skill are needed in the active operations of the Spring campaign.

abstract: Editorial says Tennessee is gradually returning to loyalty to Union
snippet: Editorial says Tennessee is gradually returning to loyalty to Union
lead_paragraph: The latest advices from Nashville and more favorable to the gradually returning sense of loyalty to the Old Flag. Gov. ANDREW JOHNSON had arrived at the seat of the Tennessee Government, and after addressing the people of Nashville from the steps of his hotel, in a most feeling and effective style, was conducted to the Capitol, where he took formal possession of the Government. The [???] of the address to the people is represented as one of the most extraordinary ever witnessed in the State. We can readily believe that if was so. The temporary separation of Tennessee from the Union was altogether a forced movement. There was no real heart in it, so far as the masses were consulted, if consulted at all. The political leaders, among the most desperate and unprincipled of whom was the Governor, ISHAM C. HARRIS, "did up" the whole business. They committed the people by a species of legislation before unknown to the Constitution of the State, and in direct contempt of the Constitution of the United States and once committed to what is called the Confederate cause, they were soon precipitated into armed rebellion against the Government. The consequence was that a large army was raised within the Middle and Western Districts of the State, to fight against the National flag. Even the sons of old Union men were impressed to fight for what was termed State sovereignty. Under such circumstances no great surprise ought to be felt that the return of popular sentiment in favor of the Government was slow. For the first week or two after Gen. [???] entered Nashville the signs of reaction were rather disheartening than otherwise. The people who had led the City after the fall of Fort Donelson were slow in returning. One-half the merchant stocks and shops of the city remained closed. The General Commanding, his Aids, and his army, were treated, for the most past, with sullen silence. They had to win their way to popular confidence, by slow degrees, and by the most scrupulous regard for the rights and immunities of private property, and the utmost deference to private prejudices.
headline: {'main': 'The Counter Revolution in Tennessee', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Counter Revolution in Tennessee', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: A dispatch from Fortress Monroe reiterates the announcement of the capture of YANCEY, though it still brings no tidings of where, when or by whom the distinguished capture was made. Bald as the statement thus is, there is, nevertheless, great likelihood of its truth; and, indeed, it may 'be remembered that we announced YANCEY's departure from Havana, in a rebel schooner, two or three weeks ago, and told our blockaders at the time that they would nab him if they kept a bright look-out. It is not one of the least pleasant turns of the wheel of fortune that YANCEY should be caught trying to run a blockade which he has proved over and over again to be of no account whatever. If he was only back again in Half-Moon-street, London, (don't he wish he was!) he would probably see fit to make some slight revision in his little missives to Lord JOHN, anent our "most inefficient" blockade. It appears, though, that he had himself misgivings as to his ability to make the "run" safely; for he not only gave hostages to fortune previous to starting, having cut off his long white locks at Havana, but he is furthermore stated to have been disguised as a sailor when taken. He did not succeed, however, in the role of the Ancient Mariner; for, while it is related of the great original that --

abstract: MICAJAH PHILLIPS, a colored man, died recently near Marietta, Ohio, at the great age of 125 years. He went to the West in 1796 with HERMAN BLENNERHASSET, as his slave, and continued with him till he died. He went to Ohio soon after, and resided in Harmar, opposite Marietta, for some years. He afterwards went to Watertown, where he resided for over fifty years. MICAJAH (CAJCE) was the slave of Col. BORREL, of York, Gloucester County, Va. At the death of Col. BORREL he went to his son-in-law, Rev. Mr. FOUNTAIN, with whom he lived at the time of the battle at Yorktown, and was then a waiter in the army. His descriptions of the battle were vivid, and are presumed to be true. There are persons living who have known him for sixty years, who place his age at fully the above. His exact age is not recorded. MICAJAH could read and write, having been taught by Mrs. BLENNERHASSET, of whom he always spoke in high terms of respect. He belonged to the Baptist Church, and preached to the colored population of Parkersburgh, Va., in early times.

abstract: The failure of our forces, land and naval, to capture Island Ten off-hand, has occasioned an almost ludicrous ebullition of popular petulance. The delay seems to be generally accepted as a defeat. Men of average courage rush madly into Wall-street and sell their Stocks, as if the crisis of the National destiny were upon them. Less than a battle and victory a day will no longer satisfy the public appetite. A day without them is lost, and is marked in the calendar with a black stone. An absence of good news is accepted as a reverse.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a petition was presented from the citizens of New-York, asking for the passage of a law for the protection and improvement of the Indians. The joint resolution allowing the claim of [???] O. ROBERTS, for the loss of the steamer Star of the West, was passed The joint resolution for cooperation with States desiring to abolish Slavery, was reported from the Judiciary Committee, with a recommendation that is do pass. The bill for the reorganization of the Navy Department was passed, after the adoption of some unimportant amendments. The bill for the abolition of Slavery in the District of Columbia was then taken up, and M. WILLEY, of Virginia, made a speech in opposition to its passage. A substitute for the bill was offered by Mr. CLARKE, of New-Hampshier. After an Executive session, the Senate adjourned.

abstract: Juvenile Delinquent Asylum near High Bridge, NYC, described
snippet: Juvenile Delinquent Asylum near High Bridge, NYC, described
lead_paragraph: As nearly as a careful police investigation can compute, there go to make up the population of this great free City, 40,000 delinquent and neglected children; 10,000 of these are given to criminal practices' as petty pilfering, cheating trades, &c., &c.; 10,000 others are beggars, often perforce of idle or vicious parents, who use their children as mere tools to bring them in a precarious livelihood as best they can. A third class, comprising a number equaling both the others, are unfortunates only, not criminally inclined, but wanderers, often parentless, and without a home or a resting-place at night more inviting to repose than the cavernous gloom of a discarded boat-boiler, which is shared in common with perambulating wharf rats; -- or if of the softer sex, the overshadowing security of an isolated "stoop" is more choice a position wherein to compose to slumber the unnaturally matured, brain and wearied limbs of childhood.

abstract: During the past week the slopes and hills in the immediate vicinity of Fairfax Court-house, thickly dotted with Union soldiers' tents, and exhibiting groups of baggage-wagons, lines of ordnance, masses of artillery and cavalry horses, and the outfittings and trappings of a large army, the soldiers themselves lounging carelessly upon the turf, or engaged in various pursuits, presented an attractive and interesting spectacle.
lead_paragraph: FAIRFAX COURT-HOUSE, Monday, March 17, 1862.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a bill to provide for an equitable adjustment of the accounts of the officers and sailors of the frigate Congress, and other vessels, was passed. The bill to establish a National Foundry, and the bill for the establishment of an Arsenal and Armory at the West, were referred to a Special Committee. The bill for the abolition of Slavery in the District of Columbia was then taken up, but the Senate Chamber being filled with smoke from the army bakeries in the building, no business could be done. An Executive session was held, and the Senate adjourned until Monday.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, a bill to provide for an equitable adjustment of the accounts of the officers and sailors of the frigate Congress, and other vessels, was passed. An Executive session was held, and the Senate adjourned until Monday.

abstract: editorial stresses importance of timing tax collection properly to aid industrial growth of nation; Editorial stresses importance of properly timing tax collection to aid industrial growth of nation
snippet: editorial stresses importance of timing tax collection properly to aid industrial growth of nation; Editorial stresses importance of properly timing tax collection to aid industrial growth of nation
lead_paragraph: No one who has had an opportunity to observe the operation of various methods of taxation in the heavily-burdened countries of Europe, can fail to have noticed the immense importance of judiciously fixing the time for the payment of taxes. To a farmer it would make a vast difference whether a certain number of bushels of wheat were taken from his seed or from his harvest, and in like manner any other citizen, engaged in industrial or commercial enterprise, will find it much easier to pay a given sum into the public Treasury at one time than at another.
headline: {'main': 'Revenue Collection and Industrial Growth.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Revenue Collection and Industrial Growth.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Iu, the Senate, yesterday, several bills were reported complete from the Grinding Committee  and the bill to incorporate the Forty-second-street Railroad was reported favorably. The bill to create the office of Receiver-General was also reported favorably; also the bill to amend the NewYork District Court Act. The bills to incorporate...
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, several bills were reported complete from the Grinding Committee, and the bill to incorporate the Forty-second-street Railroad was reported favorably. The bill to create the office of Receiver-General was also reported favorably; also the bill to amend the New-York District Court Act. The bills to incorporate the Methodist Missionary Association, and the Presbyterian Home, were ordered to a third reading. A bill authorizing the City of Brooklyn to raise over $100,000 for the Volunteers, was introduced by Mr. MURPHY, and immediately passed. The bill to provide means for paying the Canal indebtedness, &c., was debated in Committee of the Whole, and ordered to a third reading. The bill to repeal the Church Property Act was passed -- 19 to 3. The bill to divide the crime of murder into two degrees, and to define the crime, was passed -- 18 to 6. A number of other bills were passed -- among them the one to improve the Central Park.

abstract: A party of Massachusetts gentlemen met in Washington, at the rooms of Hon. lead_paragraph: A party of Massachusetts gentlemen met in Washington, at the rooms of Hon. Mr. TRAIN, on the 13th inst., to accompany him to the White House, and there witness the presentation of an elegant whip, made by a Massachusetts whip company. Mr. LINCOLN received the party in his council chamber, where Secretaries CHASE and STANTON were with him, and cordially greeted each one. Mr. TRAIN, holding the whip, made a few remarks and presented it to the President. Receiving the gift, Mr. LINCOLN examined it and then remarked:

abstract: HON. JOHN HUTCHINS My Dear Sir: I address you with that freedom which should ever exist between constituent and representative. I ought to say that efforts of individuals in both Houses of Congress during the present session have been very satisfactory to the people here, and we trust that the action of the whole body will hereafter be equally so.
lead_paragraph: HON. JOHN HUTCHINS -- My Dear Sir: I address you with that freedom which should ever exist between constituent and representative. I ought to say that efforts of individuals in both Houses of Congress during the present session have been very satisfactory to the people here, and we trust that the action of the whole body will hereafter be equally so. Indeed, some measures have passed both branches which accord with the public feeling. I think all were gratified at the movement toward emancipation in the District of Columbia; but it were wrong to disguise my own dissent from the proposition that Congress shall thrust its hand into the pockets of the people and take therefrom a million of dollars and hand it over to slave-dealers and slave-holders as a ransom for the victims whom they have robbed of their labor, their intelligence, their manhood.

abstract: Editorial holds press censorship ineffectual; urges its abolition
snippet: Editorial holds press censorship ineffectual; urges its abolition
lead_paragraph: -- However well intended may have been the censorship of the Press, the report of the Senate Committee, must, we think, show the immediate propriety of abrogating the office. So long as there was the slightest reason to believe the revision and suppression of telegrams withheld important military information from the enemy, the Press was unanimous in its submission to the regulation as a salutary public measure. But it was presently apparent that all military intelligence embargoed by the telegraphic censor, could almost as early reach the newspaper office by mail; and that, after all, the discretion of using or withholding the news lay with the publisher. And while this discretion, which needed no abortive censorship of a person with the tithe of the intelligence and sound judgment of an average journalist to assist it, uniformly excluded improper army news, it has also become demonstrable that every military movement of importance has been communicated to the enemy. Even at this moment, there are sure indications, in the disposition of the rebel army, that the plans of Gen. MCCLELLAN, carefully concealed by the newspapers, are in the hands of the rebel leaders. As a military precaution, the telegraphic censorship is simply a failure and vexation.

abstract: map and description of Confederate rout at Pound Gap by Gen. Garfield
snippet: map and description of Confederate rout at Pound Gap by Gen. Garfield
lead_paragraph: The subjoined little map will show the position and relations of the mountain gap, at which Gen. GARFIELD, the hero of the Humphrey Marshal battle of January last, has again routed the rebels, after an engagement of twenty minutes. The news of the event, which we published yesterday, came from Cattletsburgh, a town situated at the confluence of the Big Sandy River with the Ohio, at the northeastern boundary line of Kentucky. The Big Sandy (its west fork) is the stream by which Gen. GARFIELD gets supplies up to the headquarters of his army at Piketon; and as steamboats run from Piketon to Catlletsburgh, it is likely that the latter would be the point from which we would get news of action anywhere on GARFIELD's line. The date of the encounter is not given, but it must have been as far back as last Monday or Tuesday. If the rebel force was five thousand strong, as stated, it was probably composed of the debris of HUMPHREY MARSHALL's old force, increased by such recruits as have been gathered to the rebel standard in the mountains during the Winter. Whether the obese HUMPHREY himself was in command, we were not told. It is hardly likely that he would risk his skin a second time, since he so narrowly escaped with it before.

abstract: NYC letter delivery system described; probable changes noted
snippet: NYC letter delivery system described; probable changes noted
lead_paragraph: We are pleased to learn that there is a disposition on the part of the Government to consult more fully the convenience of our citizens in the delivery of postal matter. The present system is comparatively good, that is, it is not so wretchedly incomplete as its immediate predecessor, and yet it is far from being what it should and might be. During the last thirteen years there has been a very satisfactory improvement in the habits which the Post-office Department has brought to the fulfillment of its duties, especially observable in its disposition to meet, wherever practicable, all reasonable calls for enlarged public facilities. Lately its attention has been applied more particularly to the subject of City delivery, and in consequence there have been introduced many ameliorations, pefect possibly in theory, but which time and change of officers are needed to develop. The street boxes are recognized as a most valuable advance toward a better method, and where there was formerly but one collection of the deposited letters daily, there are now, when the duties of the carrier are fulfilled, five collections. Letters need not now be detained, as of old, from ten to thirty-four hours, at the Nassau-street office, but can be taken to the nearest station at once, and thence dispatched to their destination. It is hardly necessary to state that a conscientious compliance with such provisions as are now made by the Department would afford vast facilities to the writing public, and justify anticipations of a system as absolutely convenient as is enjoyed in London.

abstract: Gen. BEN. LOAN, of the Missouri State Militia, in command at St, Joseph, is stirring up the rebels by a very thorough application of Gen. HALLECK's order that they be put under bonds or ordered to quit the State, He has some half dozen "highly respectable" gentlemen in jail, a half dozen others have been ordered to emigrate, others have filed bonds ranging from $1,000 to $5,000, and to complete the list, he had served notices upon thirty individuals, giving them ten days to consider which of the three alternatives they will take. Among those ordered to leave the State are ISAAC N. SHAMBAUGH, member of the Legislature a year ago, among whose personal papers were found documents that will be of interest to the future historian who shall write up the secession of Missouri. The St. Joseph Herald -- a new Union paper -- says the proceedings of Gen. LOAN have thrown the "secesh" into great confusion, and those who had not been sent to jail were caucusing among themselves whether it would not be better for them to do so, as martyrs, than to make confessions of their guilt by giving bonds. The half-dozen already in jail were living like nabobs, supplied with all the delicacies by their friends outside. Major WM. N. ALBIN is the Provost Marshal of St. Joseph, and his guards arrest all who appear on the street without leave, after ten o'clock at night. Bar-rooms are imperatively closed day and night.

abstract: map and description of war in New Mexico
snippet: map and description of war in New Mexico
lead_paragraph: The lines of JEFF. DAVIS' rebellion extend over a vast region of territory. The westernmost of his bloody outposts is among the far-distant, wild mountains of New-Mexico, on the upper waters of the Rio Grande. Of the fierce battle that was fought there on the 2lst ult., at the hamlet of Valyerde, we have already given the particulars. The rebels and savages undoubtedly repulsed our forces on that occasion; but it was after an exhibition of individual occasion; which has given us one of the most glorious names of the war -- that of the gallant North Carolinian soldier, Capt. ALEXANDER MCRAE -- a name worthy to take rank with the undying names of LYON, BAKER and LANDER. Our troops, however, still continue to hold Fort Craig, which is situated on the opposite side of the river from Valverde. The rebels, after their success, pushed northward and seized the town of Albuquerque, and, at latest advices, were marching upon Santa Fe, the Capital of New-Mexico, and Fort Union, the strongest fort in the Territory. In the meantime, the regiment of Union volunteers which were raised last Summer in Colorado Territory, have left their quarters near Denver, and marched southward to reinforce Fort Union, and give battle to the Texan rebels. The march is a terrible one, through the mountainous, uninhabited savage deserts of Northern New-Mexico; but the regiment is composed of men who know no such word as difficulty. News may be now looked for any day of a battle at Santa Fe or Fort Union, which will be decisive of the fate of New-Mexico and Arizona. We give herewith a clear and correct maps of the locality of the late and pending battles, for which we are indebted to the kindness of Major J.T. SPRAGUE, of the United States Army.

abstract: Editorial on large and small iron-clad ships; Editorial on large and small iron-clad ships
snippet: Editorial on large and small iron-clad ships; Editorial on large and small iron-clad ships
lead_paragraph: The first principle of military or naval success is concentration of force. The force of a war vessel is the weight of her broadside. Iron mail, that the blow of a ton would shiver, might stand the blow of 500 pounds for hours. This much will certainly be admitted on all hands. Now a vessel's broadside depends, of course, upon her size. A small gunboat can only carry two or three pieces, and throw 200 to 300 pounds at a broadside -- while a first-class frigate can carry forty guns, and throw half a ton. But the cost of a large vessel is objected to; and it is gravely asked why five gunboats, throwing 220 pounds each, are not just as good, and a great deal cheaper, than a vessel which, like the Minnesota, throws 1,100 pounds -- both classes to be iron-clad? Let the facts answer. The Monitor may throw 340 pounds at a broadside, (if Capt. DAHLGREN will consent to her guns firing solid shot, instead of hollow shot, as they did at the Merrimac,) and her cost was $275,000. The Stevens Battery will throw 2,200 pounds at a broadside, and cost $1,250,000. In other words, the cost of the Monitor per pound of broadside is $808, while that of the Stevens Battery per pound of broadside is $568, or 30 per cent. cheaper. But this only half states the case; for while the small vessel can concentrate but 340 pounds upon one point, the large vessel can concentrate a ton. Or, with reference to the money, the Government already has in the Stevens Battery her cost, for a given weight of broadside would be less than half -- only 40 per cent. -- of that of the small vessel. Again, the casemate guns and other expensive and unnecessary features of the British Warrior -- a vessel of the same size but of less speed and broadside than the Stevens Battery -- have raised the cost to an excessive amount; while the large sums expended by the Messrs. STEVENS on their vessel, and not charged to the Government -- expenditures on the dry-dock, preliminary experiments, &c. -- and the employment of water-protection, which costs nothing, have greatly reduced the cost of this vessel below a fair contract price. Hence the remarkable fact, that although the Warrior throws but 70 per cent. of the Stevens vessel's broadside, her cost per pound of broadside is nearly three times as great. These facts are before Congress, and we do not expect to hear any more objections to the Stevens Battery on the ground of her cost as due to her size.

lead_paragraph: The contest at Island No. 10 is not yet decided -- at least it had not been on Thursday, at noon. The bombardment from the gunboats and the mortars, however, was steadily telling on the rebel positions. All the guns in the upper battery but one had been silenced, and one gun on the Island had been dismounted. The rebels are very strongly fortified, with casemates to their batteries. They have, it is believed, at least eighty guns, many of them of the largest size, and several of them rifled. They are also believed to have at least twenty thousand troops. They are unfortunate in having Gen. POPE below them at New-Madrid, as he interferes seriously with the efforts of their flotilla to escape. He allowed one of their gunboats to approach within fifty yards of a masked battery on Tuesday, and then sunk her, killing a number on board. Over a dozen rebel vessels, with the floating battery and the famous battering-ram of HOLLINS, are penned up between Gen. POPE and Commodore FOOTE, and will probably all be "bagged."

Here it has been the business of GARFIELD to watch, and wearying of the task, the Union leader suddenly swooped down upon the rebel encampment, and by one of those stalwart strokes he is accustomed to inflict, scattered its occupants. The President has, doubtless, something in store for this vigilant and meritorious officer.

abstract: Editorial discusses some advantages secured by war
snippet: Editorial discusses some advantages secured by war
lead_paragraph: One of the most valuable and beneficent results of the rebellion will be a Government which for the future shall he in harmony with the tendencies of the age and the genius of our people. For the greater portion of the last thirty years that of the United States has been a libel upon free institutions, and the determined foe to progress either in ideas or in material greatness, that did not give to Slavery the same area and moral and political power as Freedom. The North was to take nothing by virtue of its educated people, its literary culture, its inventive genius, commerce or wealth. The dead body and the live one were always to retain the same measure, fullness and strength, lest the balance between the two sections should be inevitably overthrown. The inventive brain is now the prolific father of children and States. Population succeeds in exact ratio as the means of existence and comfort are supplied. Starting with an equal division of the population, the North left the South behind, just so soon as science and mechanical skill came to the aid of labor. Unable to compete in such a field, the South sought, by seizing the political power of Government, to hold in check, and finally to place in a subordinate position an enterprising rival, that was both hated and feared. This superiority of the North was met in the only manner it could be -- by a strict construction given to the organic law, the Constitution of the country -- which was interpreted so as to leave the Government really no function, except the conduct of its foreign relations, and the maintenance and advancement of Slavery. While the grand characteristic of the age is progress in ideas, in social organization, in unfolding natural laws, and in subjecting them to the service of man, the whole tendency of the Government has been a retrograde one, to be in harmony with the tendency of the South, which was toward an abject despotism. It came to be utterly unconstitutional for Government to exercise any function that would promote the commerce of the country, because any such step would benefit the North to a greater degree than the South. We could not have a railway to the Pacific, because Freedom would take the larger share of the advantage of such a work. We could not improve the navigation of a river, or render safe the harbor of a lake, no matter how vast its commerce, for the same reason. Restraint, not expansion, must be the law at Washington, and characterize as far as possible every attribute or function of Government, as the only means of preserving the balance of power between the two sections.

abstract: MAILS. -- Mr. LYSANDER C. TUBBS, Postmaster of West Shaudaken, Ulster County, N.Y., was brought to this City yesterday in charge of Deputy Marshal HUNT, charged with stealing money from letters passing through his office, on two different occasions, the amount of money purloined being about $50. The accused was taken before United States Commissioner HENRY, who admitted him to bail in the sum of $1,500, Mr. DAVIS WINNE, of Kingston, becoming his bondsman. The examination is set down for April 10.

abstract: FLOTOW's popular and pleasing open of "Martha" was played here last evening to a fashionable but not overcrowded audience. The caste was exactly the same as last season, and therefore calls for but little comment. Signor BRIGNOLI was in admirable voice, and contributed, of course, very materially to the pleasure of the evening. Miss KELLOGG was as vivacious and charming as ever, and Mme. STRAKOSCH was also extremely good as Nancy. We have rarely heard the opera, as a whole, better performed. In the course of the opera, Signorita CUBAS introduced several of her characteristic dances, and was received with tremendous applause by the audience.

abstract: We had hoped to record before this the passage of the bill abolishing Slavery in the District of Columbia; but it is protracted by a deal of unedifying discussion on matters that have not the slightest practical relation to the question in hand. If all the bees in the bonnets of...
lead_paragraph: We had hoped to record before this the passage of the bill abolishing Slavery in the District of Columbia; but it is protracted by a deal of unedifying discussion on matters that have not the slightest practical relation to the question in hand. If all the bees in the bonnets of honorable gentlemen are to buzz out their foolish droning, we may as well give up hope of seeing anything done this session. Each has some pet hobby, some ethnologic figment, as to the equality of the races, the status of the negro, colonization or what not, which he exploits and expounds till he comes to regard himself as committed to his particular hobby; and so a plain subject is obscured, and a desirable measure indefinitely postponed. We call on some sensible legislator to bring back the question from the cloud-land of abstractions whither it has been carried, and restore it to its simple, practical proportions. There is in the country no real division of opinion as to the desirableness of the thing. In fact, if there is one question on which the minds of all loyal and enlightened men are agreed, it is that the ghastly anachronism of Slavery in the Capital of a free Government shall cease. Happily, the measure is wholly free from entanglements of all kinds; is in no wise complicated with any scheme of emancipation, general or particular; is not even the direct offspring of present events; but is the natural development of a mature and settled public policy. A generation ago it was discussed and advocated even by men of the Democratic Party. In 1847 Mr. LINCOLN, then a Whig Representative from the State of Illinois, offered a bill of the like scope and tenor, and Congress, by abolishing the slave-trade in the District twelve years ago, established the premises of which this is but the logical conclusion. In every sense, therefore, it is a just, feasible and timely measure. Besides, the honorable gentlemen who have pet ethnologic hobbies, each clashing with each, cannot do better than assist in the prompt passing of the bill, in some form, to the end that a practical experiment may be made in the District, over which the National Legislature exercises exclusive jurisdiction, as to the actual working of emancipation. It would be worth the trial, if for no other than its theoretic results.

abstract: The death of Mr. Dyer Tillinghast, of Buffalo has already been announced. He was born in Norway, Herkimer County, Feb. 13, 1798. He commenced the practice of the law as a partner of Judge Ford, of Watertown, with whom he studied his profession, in 1828. He remained at Watertown until his removal to Buffalo, in the Autumn of 1826. He was admitted a Solicitor in the Court of Equity for the Fifth Circuit at the January Term, 1824; a Counselor of the Supreme Court in May, 1825; a Solicitor in Chancery in March, 1826; a Counselor in the Court of Chancery in January, 1830. In 1832, he was appointed by Gov. Throop Examiner in Chancery, and in 1835, reappointed by Gov. Marcy. Mr. Tillinghast was the first City Clerk of Buffalo, having been elected in 1832. He was appointed Clerk of the Supreme Court in 1856, and held that position at the time of his death.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, the bill to incorporate the New-York College of Veterinary Surgeons was ordered to a third reading.  the Excise law, similar to the one introduced in the Assembly, was reported.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, the bill to incorporate the New-York College of Veterinary Surgeons was ordered to a third reading. A bill to amend the Excise law, similar to the one introduced in the Assembly, was reported. The Assembly amendments of the bill to allow attorneys residing in adjoining States to practice in our Courts were agreed to. The bill to amend the International Bridge Charter was passed. A resolution requiring City Chamberlains, County Treasurers and Clerks to transmit to the Clerk of the Senate, by the 1st of December, a report of all trust funds and securities in their hands as public administrators, was introduced. Additional testimony from the Select Committee appointed to investigate the acts of Harbor Masters, was reported. The Senate then adjourned until Monday evening.
