abstract: editorial on probability allied peace treaty will be signed
snippet: editorial on probability allied peace treaty will be signed
lead_paragraph: There is inherent probability in the news which comes from Mexico of the signing and ratification of a treaty of peace. The basis of the treaty had been arranged previously. It required modification in two or three points only, to make it acceptable to both parties, and as JUAREZ was inclined to yield almost anything that should rid Mexico of the abhorred presence of a foreign army, it is not likely any essential difficulty stood in the way of a perfect adjustment. That an Allied force remains for the present in Mexico may seem to contradict this view of the Presidential disposition. But this force has been materially curtailed. The British contingent has been wholly withdrawn, and even the British fleet has left the waters of the Gulf. Two regiments of the Spanish army have returned to Havana, and the remaining troops only linger, we have reason to believe, until the treaty shall have gone to Europe, received the ratification of the several Courts interested, and been returned thus perfected. It would be a palpable error for the expeditionary Generals to retire, until they had learned how far their diplomatic labors might prove acceptable to their respective Cabinets. Thus another of the disheartening war clouds which three months ago rested like a pall upon our people, has been dissipated. Three months ago, Western Europe seemed to be arming against us. All the preparations made by England, France and Spain against Mexico were understood by the most cautious observers to be ultimately intended for the discomfiture of the United States. The armada sent into the Gulf, so disproportioned to the requirements of the Mexican quarrel, was regarded as a preliminary step to the forcible rupture of the blockade, and the abstraction of cotton. The strongly-reinforced squadron of Admiral MILNE, and the French war steamers which frequented our harbors, were evidently destined to the same hostile service, and Canada was prudently armed against the resentment our people would naturally feel at any interference in favor of the South. When our fears ceased to wear this particular guise, they donned others scarcely less discouraging. The threatened imposition of a monarchy upon Mexico the American people could not view with indifference. The rebellion had not annulled the Monroe doctrine. That dogma might be in abeyance so long as our own intestine difficulties should last; but when internal peace should have been conquered, it would be our duty and policy to unseat the usurper, and expel his military supporters from Mexico. A foreign war had thus ceased to be a present, only to become a future evil of alarming proportions. But even this danger has disappeared. By the very prompt arrangement of the European difficulty, President JUAREZ, has secured the permanent independence of his country, has provided for the departure of the Allied army, and saved all necessity of that aid, which this Government would have felt obliged to afford him in circumstances less fortunate. Thus are events better than our fears. Let us hereafter confide in them more implicitly.

abstract: Mr. GREGORY, on the 7th inst., introduced into the House of Commons his long-threatened resolution, calling for papers relative to the blockade.
lead_paragraph: Mr. GREGORY, on the 7th inst., introduced into the House of Commons his long-threatened resolution, calling for papers relative to the blockade. A lively debate ensued, Mr. W.E. FORSTER, that steadfast and consistent friend of the North, leading off against the Irish member, and the Solicitor-General following with an assertion of the practical completeness of the blockade, and a vigorous argument against interference in any form with the American struggle. Mr. GREGORY had only called for papers, a demand which might have been conceded without an abandonment of the ministerial policy; but in its eagerness to mark in an emphatic manner its opposition to all intervention in American affairs, the House negatived Mr. GREGORY's motion without a division. This is certainly a pronounced rebuke of the faction in Parliament -- small and uninfluential at best -- that has put itself forward as the champion of the rebel "cause." It also sings the funeral knell of the hopes of the Richmond usurpers for British countenance. Earl RUSSELL has made official announcement that our blockade gives England no ground for complaint, and that so long as the rights of neutrals are not infringed, she must keep hands off. And now the Parliament of the people puts its seal to the same policy; so that we have the double satisfaction to see the British Cabinet clear itself of all suspicion of a sinister design in respect of our internal troubles, and the British nation vindicate its traditional love of fair play. On the whole, we are very glad the present discussion has taken place; for though Mr. GREGORY and his friends designed that it should benefit the South, for which they professed unbounded sympathy, it has rather had the effect to damage their cause, by showing, in a signal manner, how lame and impotent is the argument on which the Secessionist agents have rested their claim for British succor and interference.

abstract: A man named PATRICK  TRACY, residing at No. 13 State-street, was arrested yesterday, by Capt. SMITH, of the First Precinct, on a charge of beating his wife so that she cannot recover. Coroner NORRIS last evening made an ante- mortem examination, and the accused was committed to await the result of the injuries to his wife.
lead_paragraph: A man named PATRICK TRACY, residing at No. 13 State-street, was arrested yesterday, by Capt. SMITH, of the First Precinct, on a charge of beating his wife so that she cannot recover. Coroner NORRIS last evening made an antemortem examination, and the accused was committed to await the result of the injuries to his wife. The beating, it is alleged, took place on the 19th of January, since which time Mrs. TRACY has been at the house of her father under medical treatment. A warrant was issued for the arrest of TRACY, at the instance of his wife's father, immediately after the offence was committed, but was not served because it was thought she would recover. Yesterday, however, the physician in attendance notified the authorities that Mrs. TRACY could not live, and accordingly the warrant was served. TRACY says that his wife is dying from the effects of drinking intoxicating liquors, and not from any injuries he has inflicted.

abstract: We print elsewhere a letter from Mr. HAM- ILTON, Architect of that pretty structure, the Institute of Fine Arts, on Broadway, relative to his design for houses on the model so much in vogue in many of the leading capitals of Europe.
lead_paragraph: -- We print elsewhere a letter from Mr. HAMILTON, -- Architect of that pretty structure, the Institute of Fine Arts, on Broadway, -- relative to his design for houses on the model so much in vogue in many of the leading capitals of Europe. Several months ago, when our attention was first drawn to this plan, we took occasion to express a favorable opinion as to the very skillful and ingenious manner in which the designer had, in so comparatively limited a space, provided for eight families under one roof, all the accommodations and comforts of a complete house, and yet entirely distinct from each other. Another inspection of the plan has fully confirmed the opinion we then gave.

abstract: By the arrival of the steamship America at Halifax we receive advices from Europe two days later than by the Anglo-Saxon. The expected debate had taken place in the British Parliament on the subject of the Southern blockade.
lead_paragraph: By the arrival of the steamship America at Halifax we receive advices from Europe two days later than by the Anglo-Saxon. The expected debate had taken place in the British Parliament on the subject of the Southern blockade. Mr. GREGORY made a call for the correspondence on the subject and made a speech denouncing the blockade, and expressing strong sympathy for the South. Sir JAMES FERGUSON also took ground against the blockade, and called for the interference of the British Government to bring [it to an end. Mr. W.E. FORSTER denied that the blockade is ineffectual, and explained that a list of three hundred vessels handed in by Mr. MASON as having run the blockade had dwindled to nineteen, most of which had run out on dark and stormy nights. Mr. MILNES deprecated any interference, and the Solicitor-General also strongly opposed it, contending that the blockade had been as effectual as any other blockade in former times. At the close of the debate, a question was taken on Mr. GREGORY's motion for the correspondence, and it was negatived without a division. The rebel steamship Sumter was still at Gibraltar, watched by the Tuscarora, who held her position at Algesiras.

abstract: The nar-  row and sectional quarrels of parties in Canada are the root of all the complaints made by the United States, as to the legislation of Canada on commercial subjects. The Western or Upper Province has long been in favor of a just and lib- eral policy.
lead_paragraph: The narrow and sectional quarrels of parties in Canada are the root of all the complaints made by the United States, as to the legislation of Canada on commercial subjects. The Western or Upper Province has long been in favor of a just and lib- eral policy. Hence arises great difficulty in retaliation, for we should injure most those who have done us no willful wrong -- the people of Upper Canada, whose opinions are represented by the Toronto Globe -- a journal of independent character, and enjoying a larger circulation and more influence than any other in that Province. Its conduct throughout the present disturbances has been frank in speaking of our faults, but no less frank and friendly as to the intrinsic merits of the Northern cause.

abstract: We receive from Washington the highly-import- ant intimation that New-Orleans is now in possession of the National forces. This is given as the prevalent opinion in naval and military circles.
lead_paragraph: We receive from Washington the highly-import- ant intimation that New-Orleans is now in possession of the National forces. This is given as the prevalent opinion in naval and military circles. It is believed that Commodore PORTER's mortar fleet passed through the Rigolets, and reduced Fort Pike, commanding the entrance to Lake Pontchartrain, and thus secured an approach to the city in that direction for the forces under Gen. BUTLER, who at once extends the area of his Department by a movement of the first importance. It is supposed that the attack upon Fort Pike was made within two days after the departure from Ship Island of the steamer bringing North the last intelligence from that point.

abstract: Editorial on Confederate difficulty of adequately defending all their lines in Southwest
snippet: Editorial on Confederate difficulty of adequately defending all their lines in Southwest
lead_paragraph: The rebel President was correct in saying that, in attempting to defend the whole territory of the Confederate States, seaboard and inland, he had undertaken too much. If his army was twice as great as it now is, he would find it impossible to defend one-half of his present domain from the assaults of the naval and military forces that this Government has in the field. The National power and resources, as compared with those of the rebels, are overwhelming. We are everywhere acting on the offensive; and our columns are so disposed of, that we can advance or strike in the most unexpected quarters, and in the most fatal manner; while at no point, West, East, or on the seaboard, can the rebels succeed in advancing into our territory, or breaking our impregnable lines. Since Mr. DAVIS propounded his theory, three weeks ago, it has had some new and remarkable practical illustrations. He has failed to successfully defend Newbern or any part of the coast of North Carolina; he failed to defend Fernandina, St. Augustine, or any fort or harbor on the eastern line of Florida; he failed to defend Pea Ridge, or the strategic line of Arkansas; he failed to defend New-Madrid and Southwest Missouri; he failed to defend the Tennessee River, or to hinder our advance into Alabama and to the rearward of Memphis; he failed to defend Leesburgh or the Upper Potomac; he has failed on the Lower Potomac, and at Centrevillle and Manassas. At other points, seaboard and inland, soon to be assaulted, he knows that like failure must be certain and irretrievable. As he despondingly says, he undertook too much and failed.
headline: {'main': 'The Rebel Lines in the Southwest.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Rebel Lines in the Southwest.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: An unusual case of false pretences was brought before Justice BRENNAN yesterday afternoon at the Tombs. The complainant was MR. SAMUEL WHITCHURCH, of No. 63 Beaver-street, who makes a charge against EDWARD C. TAYLOR, brother of the Ex-Street Commissioner, lately deceased, in which he complains that on the 16th of October last, TAYLOR called upon him, and stated that RICHARD BELL, Jr., desired to borrow the sum of $47 35; at the same time requesting that the money might be given to him at once to deliver to Mr. BELL. TAYLOR promised that BELL would soon return the money with into rest. Believing these representations to be true, WHITCHURCH gave the applicant the money. WHITCHURCH also states in his affidavit, that at divers times between the 16th of October and the 20th of January last, TAYLOR applied to him for other moneys, stating that various persons, among whom were Hon. AMBROSE C. KINGSLAND, Ex-Mayor, Mayor OPDYKE, C. GODFREY GUNTHER,CORNELIUS K. SUTTON, J.B. AULD, MARTIN L. THOMPSON, and many others, were desirous of borrowing money. That he, WHITCHURCH, believing these representations of TAYLOR, loaned money to the amount of $9,119, upon TAYLOR promising to refund the whole sum in a short time. This promise the complainant alleges was not redeemed, and upon his making application to TAYLOR for the money, the latter stated that he had collected the money from the several parties for whom he borrowed it, but that he had reinvested the same in loans to HENRY W. GENET. Hon. WILLIAM H. LEONARD, Hon. JOSEPH SUTHERLAND, CHARLES C. PINCKNEY, MORGAN JONES, and others, who would soon repay the amounts for which they were severally liable. An investigation of the facts by WHITCHURCH, led the latter to believe that the statement made by TAYLOR as to whom he loaned the money war wholly and in every particular untrue. That, in fact, the money had all been applied to TAYLOR's own use. Afterward, in a conversation with WHITCHURCH, TAYLOR admitted that none of the gentlemen above-named had received any portion of the money. Upon this state of facts a warrant was issued by Justice BRENNAN, who, upon the prisoner being brought before him yesterday afternoon, committed him, in default of $10,000 bail, the accused being unable to produce sureties.

abstract: SWORD PRESENTATION. Among the recently exchanged Union prisoners that have arrived in this City from Richmond was Lieut. JOHN S. WHYTE, of Company B, Seventy-ninth Regiment, N.Y.S.M. He was with his regiment at the battle of Bull Run in July last, and gallantly discharged his duty on that eventful day, until taken prisoner by the rebels.
lead_paragraph: SWORD PRESENTATION. -- Among the recently exchanged Union prisoners that have arrived in this City from Richmond was Lieut. JOHN S. WHYTE, of Company B, Seventy-ninth Regiment, N.Y.S.M. He was with his regiment at the battle of Bull Run in July last, and gallantly discharged his duty on that eventful day, until taken prisoner by the rebels. He could easily have effected his escape, but refusing to desert his superior officer, Capt. FARRISH, who was unable to retreat, both were captured. Since that period, Lieut. WHITE has remained a prisoner of war in Richmond, until recently exchanged. Having announced his determination to rejoin his regiment in the field, and again fight the battles of his adopted country, a few of his intimate personal friends resolved to present him with a handsome sash, sword and belt, as a slight acknowledgment of their respect and esteem for his gallantry and patriotism. The presentation tool place at the Marshall House, No. 391 Bowery, and the occasion was a highly interesting and convivial one. Ex-Governor MCELYOY in an eloquent speech, in which he feelingly alluded to the long existing friendship between himself and Mr. WHYTE, and the high and honorable character the latter had always borne, presented the testimonial in the name of the friends present. Lieut. WHYTE responded in appropriate and feeling terms, and assured them that the remembrance of their kindly good feeling toward him on that occasion, would nerve his arm to wield the weapon they had just presented him in the hour of conflict. A splendid collation, liberally provided by the worthy host, Mr. MARSHALL, was then partaken of, and a regular feu-de-joie of champagne corks was kept up during the evening by those assembled.

abstract: Current scene, Havana and elsewhere
snippet: Current scene, Havana and elsewhere
lead_paragraph: The Spanish steamer-of-war Blasco de Garay arrived at Havana on the 13th inst. from Vera Cruz. She brings information that the English forces had re- embarked on board their ships, with the exception of two companies, which were to remain in the castle of San Juan de Ulloa. They were expected to leave when the steamer left, stopping, possibly, on their way at Havana, and proceeding thence to Bermuda. The correspondent of the Diario de la Marina, at Vera Cruz, says, in a letter to that journal, that H.B. Majesty's frigate Ariadne, bearing the flag of Commodore DUNLOP, would only remain.

abstract: Letters from Nashville state that Col. MANSON, Col. KISE and Adjutant KISE have been placed under arrest by Gen. THOMAS. It is alleged that Col. MANSON was arrested for leaving his brigade at the battle of Mill Spring, for a short time, in order to communicate with Gen. THOMAS, instead of sending an orderly, and that Col. KISE and Adjutant KISE share his fate for expressing their opinion of THOMAS in emphatic and somewhat unofficer-like style.

abstract: Editorial on heroes in war
snippet: Editorial on heroes in war
lead_paragraph: The present time is furnishing materials for history of the richest and most costly sort; and the future historian who shall, in a spirit in harmony with the spirit of this time, give any adequate description of the occurrences of the past year, will be sure of a lofty name among historians. Who shall he be who shall, with a steady hand, describe the position of the country a year ago? and who shall recognize and clearly set forth the mighty principles involved in the present contest? What pen of fire shall worthily describe the glorious uprising of last April? What language shall be bitter enough to characterize the infamy of the rebel leaders and their abettors? Who shall do justice to the many acts of heroism which have glorified the past year, and have lent to the Stars and Stripes, under whose folds they were done, an added lustre?

abstract: For a long time past the inhabitants of the north side of Staten Island, is the neighborhood of Factoryville and Port Richmond, have been almost nightly aroused from their slumbers by alarms of fire. So frequent and disastreus were these conflagrations, that many of the most wealthy citizens in the vicinity were unable to rest quietly in their beds, un- less a special watchman were employed to guard their premises.
lead_paragraph: For a long time past the inhabitants of the north side of Staten Island, is the neighborhood of Factoryville and Port Richmond, have been almost nightly aroused from their slumbers by alarms of fire. So frequent and disastreus were these conflagrations, that many of the most wealthy citizens in the vicinity were unable to rest quietly in their beds, un- less a special watchman were employed to guard their premises. A large number of buildings had been very mysteriously set on fire, and some of them were -- owing to the imperfect state of the Fire Department -- wholly consumed. An Episcopal church, five barns, three stables, four shops, two bath-houses, and four or five stores and dwellings have, within three months past, been in flames within an area of about two miles square, and property to the amount of over $12,000 has thus been destroyed. The state of things became alarming, and it was proposed by the poorer class of the inhabitants to organize a fire patrol. The wealthier class of citizens, however, whose Summer residences abound in this section, were for applying to the Commissioners of the Metropolitan Police for assistance. Foremost among the advocates of the former measure was a one-armed sailor, named JOE WILSON, alias JOSEPH DE BEARD, who had recently been an inmate of the Sailor's Snug Harbor, but who, for bad conduct, had been expelled. This man was strong in favor of a private watch, and solicited an appointment for himself. At length he became greatly incensed because the appointment was not granted to him. Application was made to Superintendent KENNEDY, by some of the leading citizens on the Island, and Detectives TIEMAN and ROACH were at once dispatched to find out and arrest, if possible, the guilty party. The suspicions of the officers soon fell on WILSON, and he was watched with great care. About this time the house of the latter was, at a late hour one night, discovered to be on fire. An examination of the premises showed that all his furniture and valuables were packed and carried out of the reach of the flames. These, with many other circumstances, induced the officers to arrest him. On Thursday he had an examination before Justice HAGGERTY, of Richmond County, when he was fully committed upon the charge of arson.
headline: {'main': 'Important Arrest of a Staten Island Incendiary.; A SAILOR IS CHARGED WITH HAVING SET FIRE TO A CHURCH.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Important Arrest of a Staten Island Incendiary.; A SAILOR IS CHARGED WITH HAVING SET FIRE TO A CHURCH.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Editorial on future of freed Southern Negroes
snippet: Editorial on future of freed Southern Negroes
lead_paragraph: We were glad to see, from Secretary CHASE's recent letter in relation to the Port Royal contrabands, or rather freedmen, that the Government is not wholly neglecting the condition of this class. It is of the utmost importance that their condition should be made the subject of careful investigation and judicious planning, based upon an earnest desire to do what is best for them. This is important, not alone on account of the cultivation of the abandoned plantations -- not alone for the sake of the next year's crop of cotton -- nor mainly on these accounts. It is important, on account of the freedmen themselves, and on our own account. For here are thousands of human beings whose status in society has suddenly been changed, who have been heretofore living under a system of laws especially directed against them, which has been at once overthrown, and nothing as yet put in its place; and these people are thrown upon our hands, and we are responsible for them. Heretofore when the sufferings and wrongs of the African race in our land have been brought up before us, we have shielded ourselves by saying that the matter was one entirely out of our control; that we could not, as individuals, exert anything but a moral influence, and not very much of that; and that it was very clear that the thing could not be reached by the General Government, and we could do nothing with the State Governments.

abstract: -- A correspondent, upon whose statements we are used to place entire reliance, writes us from London, in relation to Mr. DILLON, the Secretary of Legation at Turin, who, he says, "is an openly-avowed enemy of the Administration; who, if he is not a Secessionist, at least astonishes Italian statesmen with his want of sympathy for the Union cause; and who is doing so much harm that Mr. MARSH, his Chief, no longer associates officially with him. I am assured that both RATAZZI and RICASOLI have expressed their astonishment that the Government should permit such a man to retain office." We simply call attention to the subject, as one requiring the immediate action of the State Department.

abstract: Editorial on Government building of railroads for military use; Editorial on US Government building railroads for military use
snippet: Editorial on Government building of railroads for military use; Editorial on US Government building railroads for military use
lead_paragraph: It is understood that a general log-roll is to be attempted in Congress. The ostensible pretext is to open new railroads and connections, for the purpose of enabling Government to concentrate troops, with dispatch, upon points of military importance, by several routes, thus providing against the failure of one. The real scheme is to finish or undertake, with the Government's money, impracticable railroads, which the section to be traversed does not need -- for if it did, it would build them -- but out of which certain property and shareholders expect to realize "something handsome." In proof ofwhich, we beg the public to observe the character of the test project. It is that the Government shall indorse the bonds of the Reading and Columbia Railroad -- a line which, when built, will shorten the inland route from New-York, via Easton, to Washington, 25 miles, by cutting off the detour to Harrisburgh, and running directly from Reading to York, on the Northern Central, and thence to Baltimore, as before. The inland route via Easton and Harrisburgh is 306 miles long; that proposed via Reading and Columbia, is 281 miles, and the route via Philadelphia, is 228 miles.

abstract: A writer in the February number of Blackwood's Magazine, assuming war between England and the United States to be only deferred, addresses himself to the important question, How to prepare for such a contingency, and to conduct it when it comes. He takes it for granted that his countrymen will assail our harbors, burn our fleets, destroy our commerce, and keep our whole seaboard in a state of constant alarm.
lead_paragraph: A writer in the February number of Blackwood's Magazine, assuming war between England and the United States to be only deferred, addresses himself to the important question, How to prepare for such a contingency, and to conduct it when it comes. He takes it for granted that his countrymen will assail our harbors, burn our fleets, destroy our commerce, and keep our whole seaboard in a state of constant alarm. But, then, there is Canada; that will have to be defended; and, after a sketch of what has been done in former wars, the writer proceeds to show how this should be done. He does not overlook the great changes which have taken place during the last forty-seven years, and as the article is fairly written, and he is evidently well acquainted with his subject, we need make no apology for bringing his views and suggestions before our readers. One of the greatest changes, in a military point of view, has been the construction of the canals required to complete the means of inland navigation afforded by the St. Lawrence and the lakes; and this the writer conceives not to be an advantage on the side of England. "No dependence," he says, "can be placed upon a series of canals, any one of which runs within fifteen miles of an enemy's frontier. A few bags of gunpowder judiciously applied in a dark night, a few hour's work with pick and spade, by men who have won a brief command of the situation by guile or violence, would break up the whole channel." Nor does he derive much comfort from turning his eyes toward the Rideau Canal, much as it was at one time counted upon. It would never do, he concludes, to trust to navigation of this sort, assuming the command of the lakes to be as important now to the defence of Canada, as it was half a century ago. Nor do the railways offer any greater facilities. The Grand Trunk has its terminus in American territory, and is carried as far as Montreal on the right bank of the St. Lawrence, never further than sixty, and where nearest, within ten miles of the frontier. The only ports in North America accessible to British men-of-war and transports in Winter are Halifax and St. John, and the position of these relatively to Quebec is such that though, as the bird flies the. nearest of them is within three hundred miles of that city, a railway between them, which would be at all safe, could not be constructed except on a detour of more than 600 miles; and even then a point is at last reached to connect the line with the Grank Trunk which is within ten miles of the frontier. The writer is very angry with Lord ASHBURTON about this, and also for our possession of the fort at Rouse's Point, which commands the approaches to Montreal by Lake Champlain. "Their facilities of attack," says he, "are by these means greatly increased since 1814, for any number of troops may be moved by these various [American] lines; and so long as the lines continue open, an army, operating in front of them, can be supplied as well and almost as speedily front Boston and New-York as from magazines formed, as of old, at Plattsburg and Oswego."
headline: {'main': 'British Plans for the Defence of Canada.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'British Plans for the Defence of Canada.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Treasury Department, we learn from Washington, is now issuing certificates of indebtedness at the rate of nearly two millions a day. This will soon clear off the accounts that have been audited, but not paid, because of the want of Treasury Notes. Treasury Notes will be ready for issue again in a week or two. Certificates of indebtedness are bought by Washington bankers at ninety-six cents on the dollar. It is said that the arrears of money due to officers of the army amount to $10,000,000.

abstract: Mr. GRAU's short season at the Academy of Music will end with the present week. The few remaining performances promise to be of unusual interest; to-night, "Masaniello" for the last time; on Wednesday, DONIZETTI's beautiful opera of "La Favorita," with Mme. DE [???] (a debutante of whom report speaks highly) as Leonora; on Friday, "The Daughter of the Regiment," with Miss KELLOUG in a new part, and on Saturday, a matinee, when one or other of these works will be repeated. In addition to this full programme, Mr. GRAU announces a single performance at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, to take place on Thursday next.

abstract: Major-Gen. Hunter, lately appointed to the command of the forces at Port Royal, arrived at the Astor House late Saturday afternoon. Mrs. Hunter joined her husband at the hotel to-day, and was accompanied by S.W. Stockton, one of his Staff, the rest of whom were expected at the same time, but, owing to some delay, have not yet arrived. Gen. Hunter expects to sail for Port Royal to-morrow.

abstract: The ship James R. Keeler, Capt. DELANO, arrived at this port last night from London, reports, March 14, latitude 36째 04', longitude 61째 30', fell in with schooner Oliver H. Booth, sixteen days from Alexandria for New-York, supplied her with provisions, &c., and took from her six of the crew of ship Ocean Monarch, which foundered at sea on the 9th inst. The Oliver H. Booth had previously fell in with a beat belonging to the Ocean Monarch containing the second mate, carpenter, his son and nineteen of the crew of that vessel. They make the following report: The Ocean Monarch, Capt. PAGE, sailed from New-York, March 5, with a cargo of wheat, flour, &c, bound to Liverpool, and experienced very heavy weather; on the 9th, in latitude 38째, longitude 60째, during a violent gale from southwest, shifted cargo, and in wearing the ship was struck by very heavy seas, which swept the deck of everything movable, and the cargo reshifting the vessel suddenly sprung aleak to such an extent that it was impossible to do anything with it. The boats were ordered to be got cut, when four were immediately put overboard and alongside, the largest of which was soon filled, and cut adrift by one of the seamen in it, he supposing that more would get in and swamp it. They state that they then attempted to reach the vessel again, but could not, and she was soon out of sight. When they left Capt. PAGE, the first officer and the remainder of the crew were still on board the ship, and the boats alongside. She had then 19 feet of water in the hold, and was settling very fast. The carpenter had his leg broken in getting in the boat. After remaining 48 hours in the boat, they were picked up by the schooner Oliver H. Booth, from Alexandria for New-York, and, subsequently, six of them transferred to ship James B. Keeler, who supplied the schooner with provisions, cordage, and a chronometer, Cant. DELANO advising them to go to Bermuda, which they said they would do, as they were in want of sails, &c. They then shaped their course for that place.

abstract: Editorial on financial condition of Union; Editorials on Union finances
snippet: Editorial on financial condition of Union; Editorials on Union finances
lead_paragraph: We hear nothing of late from rebel sources of the financial exhaustion of the North and the bankruptcy of the National Treasury. From these causes, it was said, a few months ago, the Government would be compelled to stop the war, and recognize the separate Confederacy of the South. To the same effect ran the current of English journalistic opinion. The depreciation of United States Notes, and the appreciation of Gold, were to prove overwhelmingly disastrous to the Government and the people. Our legal tender measure could be viewed in no other light than as an inflated paper substitute for actual resources -- not as the substantive representative of such resources. So prevalent was this opinion abroad, as well on the Continent as in England, that an exchange of twenty-five per cent. against New-York, and a premium of ten or fifteen per cent. upon Gold, was freely predicted, and so confidently believed as to induce considerable speculations in Gold in this market, through January and February, based upon it. The belief was pardonable in certain Continental quarters, where the disastrous influence of civil outbreaks and exhaustive revolutionary was upon the finances and currency of the peoples engaged in them, has been painfully and repeatedly experienced in the last sixty or seventy years. From English authorities we were entitled to a different judgment, as well upon our material resources as upon the elasticity and endurance of a people kindred with themselves, and by no means wanting in the same practical skill and high credit for carrying on a great war, which were illustrated in their own eventful history from 1796 to 1821, from the rise of NAPOLEON as First Consul to his death at St. Helena, as the deposed Emperor of France. We were entitled to a different judgment also by contrast with the burden of public debt and taxation for its support at present endured by this kindred people. We entered upon the war with a debt no greater than six months' interest upon the present debt of Great Britain. We close the first year of the war with a debt no greater than twelve months' taxation upon the British nation. It was scarcely reasonable and much less generous, therefore, to assume that our National credit and resources were already about to be exhausted, because, like the Bank of England in 1797, the Associated Banks of New-York suspended their payments in specie and the Government thereupon created a lawful tender of United States Notes.

abstract: THE POLICE AND THE GAMBLERS AGAIN. -- The avenging victim of the gamblers, now in this City, led the Police to three different gambling establishments on Saturday afternoon, which they entered promptly. About fifty persons were captured, and conducted before Recorder HOFFMAN, charged with having been found in the gambling-houses No. 143 Fulton-street, No. 233 Broadway, and No. 119 Mercer-street. Some of them were committed for trial, but the greater number of them were discharged for want of sufficient evidence to hold them.
lead_paragraph: THE POLICE AND THE GAMBLERS AGAIN. -- The avenging victim of the gamblers, now in this City, led the Police to three different gambling establishments on Saturday afternoon, which they entered promptly. abstract: editorials on bill
snippet: editorials on bill
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, Saturday, the bill to incorporate the New-York College of Veterinary Surgeons was ordered to a third reading. A bill to amend the Excise law, similar to the one introduced in the Assembly, was reported. The Assembly amendments of the bill to allow attorneys residing in adjoining States to practice in our Courts were agreed to. The bill to amend the International Bridge Charter was passed. A resolution requiring City Chamberlains, County Treasurers and Clerks to transmit to the Clerk of the Senate, by the 1st of December, a report of all trust funds and securities in their hands as public administrators, was introduced. Additional testimony from the Select Committee appointed to investigate the acts of Harbor Masters, was reported. The Senate then adjourned until Monday evening.

abstract: -- The semi-official dispatch from Messrs. CUHRIN and ATKINS, two members of the rebel Congress from Tennessee, announcing that JEFF. DAVIS was going West, and calling on the people there to rally to his standard, was dated on the 11th inst. That was the very day on which our troops advanced and took possession of Manassas. Two days previous, the fight between the Merrimac and Monitor, and the discomfiture of the Merrimac, took place. The news had then just reached Richmond that our troops had occupied Leesburgh on the Upper Potomac; that they had crossed the Lower Potomac and possessed Cockpit Point; that BURNSIDE had an expedition all ready to start, it was supposed, for Norfolk; and that from almost every point of approach our troops were advancing upon the city which DAVIS had chosen for his Capital. No wonder that at such a moment he thought of moving to the Southwest. From there at least flight and escape would be comparatively easy. Since our troops came to a halt in their advance, DAVIS, it would seems bas thought he might remain at Richmond a little longer. The fact that he had such a telegram sent to Memphis, however, shows what his design is. He means to flee when the National army approaches. But, if the so-called President insists on running away to the Western wilds and mountains, will the so-styled Vice-President, poor, sickly STEVENS, be content to remain in Richmond, and sacrifice himself on the steps of the Capitol, or elsewhere? Will Mr. BENJAMIN, or any member of the rebel Cabinet, think it worth while to remain in his seat until pricked up by a National bayonet? Will RHETT and PRYOR, and their fellow-Senators and Representatives, have the Roman courage to remain at their posts when the enemy is at the city gates? Or will all these gentry do as the rebel Governor and Legislature of Tennessee have just done, dsert their Capital and Capitol and flee from point to point, until finally they draw up in Alabama, and hold conclave in a Sibley tent? If DAVIS really means tomove Southwestwardly, as he has caused to be announced, he had better start soon, for Number Ten and Memphis must how soon fall, and then there will not be a place of refuge for him even in the Southwest.

DAVIS was going West, and calling on the people there to rally to his standard, was dated on the 11th inst. That was the very day on which our troops advanced and took possession of Manassas. Two days previous, the fight between the Merrimac and Monitor, and the discomfiture of the Merrimac, took place. No wonder that at such a moment he thought of moving to the Southwest. From there at least flight and escape would be comparatively easy. Since our troops came to a halt in their advance, DAVIS, it would seems bas thought he might remain at Richmond a little longer. The fact that he had such a telegram sent to Memphis, however, shows what his design is. He means to flee when the National army approaches. But, if the so-called President insists on running away to the Western wilds and mountains, will the so-styled Vice-President, poor, sickly STEVENS, be content to remain in Richmond, and sacrifice himself on the steps of the Capitol, or elsewhere? Will Mr. BENJAMIN, or any member of the rebel Cabinet, think it worth while to remain in his seat until pricked up by a National bayonet? Will RHETT and PRYOR, and their fellow-Senators and Representatives, have the Roman courage to remain at their posts when the enemy is at the city gates? Or will all these gentry do as the rebel Governor and Legislature of Tennessee have just done, dsert their Capital and Capitol and flee from point to point, until finally they draw up in Alabama, and hold conclave in a Sibley tent? If DAVIS really means tomove Southwestwardly, as he has caused to be announced, he had better start soon, for Number Ten and Memphis must how soon fall, and then there will not be a place of refuge for him even in the Southwest.

abstract: Commerce and the Common Council have both taken steps to secure funds for defending this harbor against hostile visits from rebel vessels. The former have appointed a Committee to visit Albany and ask an appropriation from the Legislature, and the latter seek authority to borrow money. Neither of these bodies seems to be aware that the Legislature has already taken action on the subject, nor have the newspapers deemed it worth while to mention the fact. A bill has been ordered to its third reading in the Assembly, appropriating $300,000 to this object, and will probably receive immediate action in the Senate. If this amount is not sufficient to provide for immediate contingencies, the Legislature, on being convinced of that fact, will doubtless increase it.

abstract: Prince Bonaparte speaks, Senate, on power of Pope; Current scene; Speaks, Senate, on power of Pope; Prince Bonaparte speaks, French Senate, on power of Pope
snippet: Prince Bonaparte speaks, Senate, on power of Pope; Current scene; Speaks, Senate, on power of Pope; Prince Bonaparte speaks, French Senate, on power of Pope
lead_paragraph: On Saturday, March 1, Prince NAPOLEON addressed the French Senate upon the paragraph of the address relating to Rome. He said: "I shall not follow the example of the eloquent orators to whom I am about to reply. I do not wish any more than they to infuse the heat of passion into this debate; but I shall, endeavor to be as clear and precise as their conclusions have appeared to me obscure and mysterious. I admire the vast erudition of M. BONJEAN. The premises of his discourse completely satisfied me. The history, so comprehensive, so profound, so just in its appreciation, which he has given of the inconveniences of the temporal power in Rome was, I need scarcely tell the Senate, quite in harmony with my opinions. I equally applaud and approve the picturesque and ingenious comparison he has made of the two scales of the balance, one the temporal, and the other the spiritual power; and in the result of which he proved, as an invariable lesson of history, that the more the temporal power of the Popes ascends, the more their spiritual influence sinks down. But after these premises -- after this vast historical lesson -- what has been his conclusion? Can he have been serious in it? He argues that the Pope ought to be allowed to reign, but not to govern Rome. It is two years since that conclusion was sought to be applied -- a kind of bastard [???], giving to the King of Italy the Government and to the Pope a species of suzerainty or nominal dominion. But I say nothing new to the Senate when I observe that, whenever statesmen applied themselves to reduce this idea to a practical shape, the pen has dropped from their hands, and they have been forced to recognize that not thus can the solution of the Roman question be attained. Does not such a scheme fall, of itself to the earth before that energetic refusal, absolute for the present, for the future, for all possible eventualities, which the Court of Rome opposes to any compromise? What solution then remains, when one party to the arrangement declines even to discuss any scheme of settlement? There remains that which I propose and demand openly from this tribune, the withdrawal of the troops from Rome. I accept in advance the censure which may be cast on the views I maintain. Let them be denounced as extreme and radical opinions. It matters little whether they are extreme or radical -- the sole consideration of importance is, whether they are just. What has M. DE LA GUEERONIERE proposed in the midst of his elegant phrases, of his antitheses, of his encomiums, showered upon all the world alike, of the flowers of rhetoric with which he has covered Italy and the Popes, Pius IX. and VICTOR EMMANUEL, Count CAVOUR, and Cardinal ANTONELLI -- all very much amazed, no doubt, to find themselves united in that floral wreath with which he has encircled them? [Laughter.] What has he proposed? His rounded, sonorous, purposeless phrases have been but a declaration of impotence. He simply bids us to wait, and to do nothing. To wait for what? Wait until agitation more profoundly shakes mens' minds, and emotions burn up more vividly through Italy, France, and Europe? Until the deplorable divisions which agitate and separate us shall have attained their full destroying strength? Is it in the name of peace and of moderation that we are offered such counsels? I, for one, do not hesitate to say that those counsels are unwise and fatal, and I adjure the Government of this country not to follow them, There is one thing that must be done. The Roman question must be settled. The public mind ought to be quieted both as regards spiritual and material interests. We have had enough of this Roman question. It has done us much injury. It ought to be wound up. I do not hesitate to say that if France, through the organ of its Emperor, takes a firm decision, all this excitement will be stopped. The Emperor would thereby render the greatest service to France and to the whole of Europe. If the Emperor will once openly and decisively apply this solution, peace will be restored to mens' minds, and the agitations of factions will subside with the influence which provoked them. There is one word, gentlemen, which I should rather omit in my speech, and which I was sorry to see mentioned from the tribune -- Venice. There is agitation enough already; we have quite enough on our hands with the Roman question, and as Venice is not mentioned in the address, which would imply so much, I shall allude to it no more in my speech. I do not mean to say that we may not have to allude to it on a future occasion, but this is not the proper moment. I have arisen to-day without discouragement, but not without regret. Indeed, at the close of the discussions of the past year -- a year which has gone through so trying and feverish a crisis -- I had hopes that the Roman question was close upon its solution. I do not purpose entering into the history of this Italian question at such length as some preceding speakers have done. I will simply recall to mind the facts of 1861. An illustrious statesman dies; it was a serious incident, which might have had the most terrible consequences for Italy. How does the Government of the Emperor act? The Government of the Emperor, inspired by a just appreciation of the political situation, recognizes the Kingdom of Italy. That was an act which I cannot speak of in too high terms. The Emperor did not hesitate; he saw that the enemies of Italy might take advantage of that fatal death, and at the very moment that that death might have inflicted a blow upon the cause, the triumph of which we had assured beyond the Alps, he gave it that aid to which is attached the gratitude Italy feels for France. Let those who talk of new territorial arrangements of Italy to suit the Pope remember that when the Emperor recognized the new Kingdom, he aid not recognize merely a word, Italy is not a piece of caoutchouc, to be stretched out and compressed at pleasure. Last year we were bidden to have confidence, and to wait; we were told that there were some obstacles still to be encountered, but that they would disappear, that a little time and a little patience would arrange all. The year has rolled away, and nothing has been obtained. Ave, and if no other policy be pursued, this year too will roll away; years to come, nay centuries, will roll away, and you cannot charge the Court of Rome, because that Court, so long as it has nothing to fear, will yield nothing to reason." Prince NAPOLEON then recalled to memory the various attempts at compromise recently made by the French Government, and especially the memorable dispatch of M. THOUVENEL, with the reply of M. DE LAVALETTE, inclosing Cardinal ANTONELLI'S ultimatum. "Why," continued the Prince, "talk of concessions, after an answer like that? The Court of Rome borrows our soldiers, but rejects our counsels. She waits -- yes, there is her great strength; she waits -- for what? I will tell you. She does not hope, indeed, that France will reconquer with its soldiers the the integrity of her old territory for her. No; the Court of Rome knows us too well to indulge in such a dream. She knows too well also her own weakness to flatter herself that she can ever regain of her own power her lost provinces. But she hopes for a foreign auxiliary. She says to herself -- 'Keep up the agitation on the Italian question; never yield -- maintain the status quo -- the future may be big with tempests, and with those tempests may come a foreign army, which after having crushed Italy and perhaps France as well, will be strong enough to reconstitute for us the integrity of our territory. The answer of the Court of Rome to the advice of France, is an indiscreet appeal to Austria. But I shall not weary you by dwelling merely on this phase of the Roman question, and my own appreciation of it. Indeed, I distrust too much the warmth of my own feelings, which, perhaps, I could not restrain. Yes, I love only too warmly the cause of nations and of national liberty. But I district my own power to plead this cause, and I have therefore attempted, by long, serious, and conscientious labor, to sustain myself by arguments not of my own conception. I have sought those arguments in the [???] of diplomacy. I have gone back to the first dispatches which the Ambassadors of France wrote under the ancient monarchy. These extracts, when I pray the Senate to permit me to cite, have but one object -- to prove that the temporal power of the Pope for 150 years has been bad, always bad, no matter what changes of Pontiffs look place -- no matter what varying events have surrounded them. I shall then claim the light to conclude that that power is bad in its essence, even more than in its application; that it has not in it the elements of good government; in a word, that it fails, not because it wishes to be evil, but because it cannot be good -- because the very essence of its organization is evil." The Prince then quoted a variety of diplomatic and other papers, be-ginning with a letter addressed to LOUIS XIV. by the DUKE DE CHAULNES, in 1667, and coming down to CHATKAUBRIAND and LAMARTINE, all tending to show that the Papal Government of Rome was invariably either the most ruinously helpless, or the most actively injurious. Prince NAPOLEON then quoted the words of NAPOLEON I., which, he said, be would like to hear repeated by NAPOLEON III. In 1808, the Emperor said to the deputies of the old Roman provinces:

abstract: By the arrival of the steamship America at Halifax we receive advices, from Europe two days later than by the Anglo-Saxon. The Glasgow also arrived at this port yesterday. The expected debate had taken place in the British Parliament on the subject of the Southern blockade. Mr. GREGORY made a call for the correspondence on the subject and made a speech denouncing the blockade, and expressing strong sympathy for the South. Sir JAMES FERGUSON also took ground against the blockade, and called for the interference of the British Government to bring it to an end. Mr. W.E. FORSTER denied that the blockade is ineffectual, and explained that a list of three hundred vessels handed in by Mr. MASON as having run the blockade had dwindled to nineteen, most of which had run out on dark and stormy nights. Mr. MILNES deprecated any interference, and the Solicitor-General also strongly opposed it, contending that the blockade had been as effectual as any other blockade in former times. At the close of the debate, a question was taken on Mr. GREGORY's motion for the correspondence, and it was negatived without a division. The rebel steamship Sumter was still at Gibraltar, watched by the Tuscarora, who held her position at Algesiras.

abstract: The recent statement of Lord CLARENCE PAGET to the House of Commons, gave that body information that before the end of 1863, the British Admiralty would have floating twenty-seven iron-plated ships. These have been built upon one general plan, of which the Warrior, the Defence, and Black Prince are illustrations.
lead_paragraph: The recent statement of Lord CLARENCE PAGET to the House of Commons, gave that body information that before the end of 1863, the British Admiralty would have floating twenty-seven iron-plated ships. These have been built upon one general plan, of which the Warrior, the Defence, and Black Prince are illustrations. Great length, great bulk, great draft: conformity in leading points with the ancient naval models; batteries looking out of old-fashioned ports; the conspicuous novelties being the absence of keels, impenetrability to shot, and propulsion by a screw placed out of reach of danger. The expense of these floating monsters is monstrous indeed. A recent return shows the Warrior to have cost $1,774,425. The new armored squadron, if built at the same price, will therefore stand the Government in nearly $50,000,000.

abstract: The Tax levy sent to Albany by the Comptroller has been reported by the Committee on Cities to the Assembly. We notice that it authorizes the payment of some $95,000 to members of the Common Council, for salaries. This is in direct violation of the Charter, which expressly forbids any member from receiving compensation for his services. We should like to know howthe Comptroller can explain his recommendation of a payment thus directly and expressly forbidden by law. It is true this has been paid for the few years past, but it has been secured by the use of means, for part of the time at least, to which this present Legislature is not supposed to be accessible. We concede that Aldermen and Councilmen should be paid for their services, but not while the law forbids it. If it is desired to give them salaries, the Charter should be amended in that particular. We trust that this item will be stricken out of the tax levy, until the Charter shall be so amended as to permit its reinstatement.

abstract: The speech of Prince NAPOLEON on the Roman question, which we publish in another column, will be read with interest. It is a scathing exhibit of the evils of the temporal sovereignty, and a fervid and eloquent argument for withdrawing the French troops from Rome and thus allowing the work of Italian freedom and unity to complete itself. The doctrines which the Prince lays down undoubtedly express the views of the whole liberal world of France; and they acquire additional interest from the circumstance that NAPOLEON III. has latterly been willing that the Prince should seem to be his spokesman. It appears, however, that the bold programme put forth by his cousin, the son-in-law of VICTOR EMANUEL, was too much for the Emperor; and on the following day M. BILLAULT, official defender of the Government, declared, in his name, that Prince NAPOLEON's doctrines were not those of the Emperor, and, in fact, were in direct variance with them. Although Italian unity is now a fact which he would be very sorry to see disturbed, such was not the idea with which the Emperor first sent his eagles across the Alps. He did not go to Italy to dethrone sovereigns, or to destroy the power of the Holy See; but to enfranchise it from Austrian domination. What he wished for was the confederation of all the Italian States under the honorary presidency of the Holy Father The French Government "wished to conciliate the two extremes." This expression, without doubt, faithfully represents the actual position of NAPOLEON III. For, while there is every evidence that he personally sympathizes with the views of Prince NAPOLEON, he is at the same time convinced that if the troops were removed from Rome, and that city became the Capital of Italy, there would be no possibility of containing the exuberance of the Italian people, who would then throw themselves upon the Austrians in Venetia, and bring about a European war in which France would be obliged to take a part -- a sequence of events for which His Majesty is not at all ready. We do not see that the debate in the Senate has at all put the Roman question forward toward practical solution. It only brings out in a striking manner how seemingly helpless the Emperor of the French is before the dilemma that confronts him.

abstract: We have another victory to record this morning. A portion of Gen. BANKS' command, under Gen. SHIELDS, numbering only eight thousand, have fought the combined rebel forces under Generals JACKSON, SMITH and LONGSTREET, and signally defeated them. A preliminary skirmish took place on Saturday afternoon, about a mile and a half from Winchester, on the Strasburgh road, between a portion of Gen. SHIELDS' troops and the rebel cavalry, with four pieces of artillery, in which the rebel force was repulsed. It was then ascertained that the rebels were advancing in force, under the impression that Winchester had been entirely evacuated by our troops, and preparations were made to meet them. The great battle took place yesterday, three or four miles from Winchester, lasting from 10 1/2 o'clock in the forenoon until dark, and resulting in the total rout of the rebels, whose strength is put down at fifteen thousand. The losses in killed and wounded are reported to be heavy on both sides, but particulars could not be obtained last night. The rebels threw away everything in their flight, and our cavalry, at last accounts, were in close pursuit.

abstract: -- The Secretary of War is not disposed to permit his order for the suppression of war news to remain a dead letter. He has suspended three papers, two of them journals of respectable standing, for publishing intelligence respecting the movements of our army. The Boston Journal printed a letter detailing particulars of military affairs on the Potomac, which the simplest exercise of discretion, regardless of any rule, would have withheld. The offence of the Journal of Commerce and the Mercury consisted, we believe, in reproducing the Journal's objectionable correspondence. The military inquest to which the editors of these papers are to be subjected will have the good effects of teaching prudence to the Press, and of testing the power of the Government in the exercise of these extraordinary powers.

abstract: THE REBELS OFF FOR THE SOUTH. -- The battle below Winchester, so confident has been the belief that the rebels had withdrawn to a line very much further to the southward, has taken the public by surprise. Yet if the theory we have propounded in these columns be sound, there was no occasion for astonishment. We have given our reasons for believing that the rebels have no idea of making a stand anywhere in Virginia. The freedom with which the Richmond papers have argued the value of Gordonsville as a defensive position was enough to excite a suspicion that Gordonsville was not to be defended; but that it was only sought by the rebels when Manassas was evacuated, as an eligible point of departure for battle-fields in the distant South. Else as a better line of interposition between Washington and Richmond, Aquia Creek and Fredericksburgh would have been chosen. A few miles additional of railroad transportation would have carried men and artillery to those more advantageous positions. A report which in some degree confirms this view, and which comes from a source entitled to credit, represents Gen. GUSTAVUS SMITH, with sixty thousand men, as having passed over the Tennessee road for the Southwest within the last few days.

We have given our reasons for believing that the rebels have no idea of making a stand anywhere in Virginia. The freedom with which the Richmond papers have argued the value of Gordonsville as a defensive position was enough to excite a suspicion that Gordonsville was not to be defended; but that it was only sought by the rebels when Manassas was evacuated, as an eligible point of departure for battle-fields in the distant South. Else as a better line of interposition between Washington and Richmond, Aquia Creek and Fredericksburgh would have been chosen. A few miles additional of railroad transportation would have carried men and artillery to those more advantageous positions. A report which in some degree confirms this view, and which comes from a source entitled to credit, represents Gen. GUSTAVUS SMITH, with sixty thousand men, as having passed over the Tennessee road for the Southwest within the last few days.

abstract: The ship Rattler, Capt. ALMY, from Havre, January 27, reports that from February 9 to 25, experienced a continuous heavy gale from 8. to N.N.W., at times blowing a hurricane, during which time she drifted from lat. 48°, long. 35°, to lat. 36°. long. 33°. On Feb. 19, lat. 40°30, long. 35°10, a strong gale was blowing from W., with heavy squalls. The ship was heading S.S.W., with stormstaysail set, when a ship was observed to windward on the same tack. At noon, her colors were seen flying union down. At 3 P.M. she kept off, and ran down to the. Rattler, when she proved to be the ship Charter Oak, from Philadelphia, bound to Liverpool with a cargo of flour and grain. She was in a sinking condition, and requested the Rattler to lay by, and take the crew off. A boat in command of the second officer was sent. As the night was very dark, and a tremendous sea running the while, they succeeded, with much difficulty, in rescuing five of the crew of the Charter Oak, whose names are as follows: E.D. Jameson, first officer; Wm. Whitney, second officer; Wm. De Crop, seaman; Levi L. Whitney, and Francis Reed, boys.

abstract: The Board of Aldermen are not to be balked in their resolution to make the defence of the City a good thing for friends of the "Ring." They have raised a commission to take charge of the job -- men, the most of whose names have the advantage of being unknown to the public, but who are so unfortunate as to deserve the trust and confidence of the Common Council. The Legislature will, of course, take care that this foolish farce will not become a public calamity.

abstract: The strongholdsof the rebels are being captured, one after another, in ways most unexpected to them. They strengthen impregnably their front, only to find themselves "taken" in the rear. They guard their heads with helmets and suddenly receive a blow under the fifth rib. They put on their legs greaves of steel, only to find their shoulder-blade dislocated. In fact in no direction can they get us to strike on the spot or in the way for which they had provided. The latest example of the effect ofthe adroit strategy of the National Generals is in the fall of Fort Macon, on the southeastern coast of North Carolina. This was one of the regular United States fortifications, and was considered as the main defence of the whole coast line of North Carolina. The rebels did not see that there was any way in which this stronghold could be assaulted unless by a naval attack from the sea; and they did everything possible to strengthen it in that direction.Had we attempted to reduce it in this way, it would have required a large part of our naval force, and might have cost a thousand lives. But Gen. BURNSIDE captures Newbern, some thirty miles in the rear with a small force, and thereby cuts off all the available communications of Beaufort and Fort Macon; and both the fort and the town at once fall of themselves. So it has been at Columbus, Bowling Green, Somerset, Leesburgh, Manassas and many other important points. Those who despise military strategy, and consider that successful war must consist only of slaughter, will find additional food for reflection in this great but bloodless triumph.

abstract: Dr. W.N. LANE, a native of Peppnell, Mass, and Surgeon in the United States Navy, arrived in this City on Thursday last, from Key West, in the Rhode Island, and died of consumption the following Saturday day, at 4 1/2 o'clock, P.M., in his apartments at La Farge House. When the rebellion broke out, Dr. LANE left a large and lucrative practice in Boston, and enlisted in his country's service, from the duties of which death has, so soon relieved him. His age was 42 years.

When the rebellion broke out, Dr. LANE left a large and lucrative practice in Boston, and enlisted in his country's service, from the duties of which death has, so soon relieved him. His age was 42 years.

abstract: The perfect confidence now felt in regard to our foreign relations will put the public in the mood to peruse with calm satisfaction the great debate on the blockade which took place in the British Parliament, on the 7th of the current month, and to which we devote extended space in to-day's issue. While the question is one in which we are deeply interested, we are at the same time relieved from all anxiety that it will take any sinister issue, having already official assurance of England's determination to pursue a policy of non-interference in our affairs; so that we are in a position highly favorable for enjoying the purely intellectual aspects of a very important and historical debate.

abstract: In the House of Lords, on the 10th inst., Lord [???] rose to call attention to the blockade of the ports of the Confederate States of America and to move an address for copies of any correspondence upon the subject which might have taken place since the date of the papers which had been laid before Parliament. The noble and learned Lord said that his object was not to declare that the blockade ought to be raised, or any means to be adopted with that view, but to show that towards one of the belligerents in America -- the Southern or insurrectionary Power -- we had assumed an attitude which suspended, if it did not violate, neutrality, and that to restore neutrality some further action was necessary.

abstract: Gen. BURNSIDE is not satisfied with one, two, or three successes, so long as more work remains to be done. Immediately after the capture of Newbern, he started an expedition to Beaufort, which was already cut off from all chance of reinforcement by the rebels. We now have the result of this new movement. On the approach of our forces Beaufort was evacuated by the rebels, and Fort Macon was blown up. The steamship Nashville, too -- escape for her being found impossible -- was burnt. The rebels doubtless retreated down the coast toward Wilmington, which is some seventy-five miles distant.

abstract: THE SUPPRESSION OF NEWSPAPERS. Certain newspapers having flagrantly persisted in  the publication of military details, in violation of the Roles and Articles of War, and the orders of the War Department, thereby endangering the safety of our armies and the success of military operations, the Secretary of War has ordered the enforcement of the Penalties, and a special court-martial is to be assembled at Washington for the trial and punishment of the offenders.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON Monday, March 24.

abstract: The rebel Press, particularly the Charleston Mercury, is hard upon Mr. JEFFERSON DAVIS because the war in the Southwest goes wrong. This is unkind to Mr. DAVIS, who really has no means of making it go right. He has suspended FLOYD and PILLOW, and could do no less after discovering their shortcomings, if not their poltroonery; but he could not have done so before this discovery, at least without being badgered by his friends for apprehending FLOYD on suspicion, and dispensing with the services of PILLOW on the ground that he is an ass generally. The Mercury blames the chief of the conspiracy at Richmond for not suspending JOHNSTON. This sin is laid at his door as the evidence of his own incompetency. The reason why is, that JOHNSTON has suffered BUELL to get into Nashville; and that BUELL, by his "sweet" conduct toward the young men of Tennessee, is encouraging desertions of the Confederate cause. But neither JOHNSTON nor DAVIS would seem to be culpable on this account. After FLOYD and PILLOW ran away, from Fort Donelson, and left BUCKNER to surrender 13,000 or 15,000 troops, JOHNSTON had no adequate force to defend Nashville, nor is it his fault that BUELL makes himself "sweet" and the old flag popular among a people who were notoriously reluctant to desert the latter in the first place.
lead_paragraph: The rebel Press, particularly the Charleston Mercury, is hard upon Mr. JEFFERSON DAVIS because the war in the Southwest goes wrong. abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a resolution from the Legislature of New-Jersey was presented, which asks Congress to take immediate action for the defence of the coast of New-Jersey, Pennsylvania and Delaware, and proposing that the several States loan funds for the purpose. Various applications for a reduction of the proposed rates of taxation on certain articles were referred. A bill for the removal and consolidation of the Indian tribes was introduced and referred. A bill to promote the efficiency of the Corps of Engineers was introduced. The joint resolution to afford aid to States emancipating slaves was taken up and debated until the expiration of the morning hour. The bill for the abolition of Slavery in the District of Columbia was then taken up, the question being upon the amendment offered by Mr. DAVIS, of Kentucky, that the slaves should be colonized. The vote resulted in a tie -- 19 to 19 - and the casting vote of the Vice-President decided it in the negative. Mr. DAVIS then proceeded to speak against the bill at considerable length, arguing that the Government had no right to take the course proposed. At the close of his speech the Senate went into Executive session, and afterward adjourned.

abstract: By the arrival of the Bremen steamer Hansa from Bremen and Southampton on the 12th inst.', we receive advices from Europe three days later than those by the America. In the British House of Lords, on the 10th inst., Lord CAMPBELL called attention to the inefficiency of the blockade of the rebel ports, and moved for the correspondence on the subject. Earl RUSSELL replied to the proofs adduced by Lord CAMPBELL of the inefficiency of the blockade, and recounted the efforts made by the North to render it effective. He (RUSSELL) considered that the want of cotton in the English markets was the best test that the blockade was not an empty one. He trusted that within three months or sooner the war would cease, leaving the emancipation of the slaves, if possible, to be effected by gradual and peaceful means. He further said that no formal communication had been made by the French to the English Government on the inefficiency of the blockade. The motion for the correspondence was then withdrawn.
