abstract: Parliament discusses Southern blockade; opposes intervention; Confederate batteries reported strong; losses heavy on both sides
snippet: Parliament discusses Southern blockade; opposes intervention; Confederate batteries reported strong; losses heavy on both sides
lead_paragraph: In the House of Commons on the 7th inst., Mr. GREGORY said: Sir, before going into Committee of Supply I wish to call the attention of the House to a subject which I conceive to be one of the most important that can be brought under its notice. [Hear, hear.] Perhaps, Sir, I owe some explanation to the House for having chosen a supply night for the discussion of this question; but I trust the House will allow that I have not been infringing upon a Government night unnecessarily, because the public business has been proceeded with so rapidly that I think they, may well spare a night for the discussion of so important a question. [Hear, hear.] Then I think its was absolutely necessary not to postpone the consideration of this question any longer -- [hear, hear] -question involving matters of international law, and a question likewise affecting the welfare of the working classes of this country, [Hear.] I am now induced to select this evening for the discussion of this question, because my honorable friend, the member for Liverpool, (Mr. HORSFALL.,) has given notice of his intention, on Tuesday next, to call the attention of the House to attestions of international law; and I thought it was, most essential that this special question of the blockade of the porta of the Confederate States should not be mixed up with other question of international law without it forming, first of all, the subject of a separ-ate discussion. [Hear.] When, in the month of May last the malls brought over to this county the reply of Mr. SEWARD, the American Secretary of State, to Gov. HICKS, of Maryland, I confess that no one in this House reechoed more heartily than myself the expression whch the noble Lord the Foreign Secretary made use of when he said: "Thank God, we have hitherto refrained from all Interference in these American dissensions." Gov. HICKS, of Maryland, being a man of prudence and humanity, an being anxious to spare his State the horrors of civil war, proposed to Mr. SEWARD the mediation of England. Mr. SEWARD replied that, under no circumstances, would he submit their internal, ffairs to theto the arbitrament of any Foreign Power, and least of all to the arbitrament of a European Monarchy. Now, Sir, I think, had we been in the position of the United States, with dismemberment threatening every portion of her dominions, with a bloody civil war impending, we might have replied that we would not submit our internal dissensions to any Foreign Power; but I hardly think we would have thrown in the gratuitous affront; that, least of all, we should submit our Internal affairs to the arbitrament of an American Republic. Seeing then, that these were the sentiments which animated those to whom the destinies of the United States are confided, I assure the House I deprecate interference now as I deprecated interference then, quite as fully as the noble lord. But it may be in the recollection of the House that, early in the last session of Parliament, I gave notice of my intention to bring before Parliament the expediency of recognizing the Southern American Confederation. I can assure the House I did so without the slightest intention of advocating interference. I did so in the hope that the united action of France and England -- for I was in hopes that united action might possibly be procured -- would have given great moral weight to the many humane, benevolent and far-sighted men in the Northern States, who were anxious at that time for a peaceable separation; and that it would have induced the Ministers of the United States to pause ere they plunged their countrymen and themselves into the vortex of a ruinous, fratricidal, and allow me to add, in spite of the news recently arrived, what I firmly believe to be a hopeless contest. [Cheers from the Opposition benches.] When the night for the discussion of that motion came on, my honorable and gallant friend opposite appealed to me not to proceed with it; and that appeal was so evidently in accordance with the general wish of the House that I did not hesitate to acquiesce. My honorable friend, no doubt, thought that in the course of the debate expressions calculated to promote imitation might have been made use of, likely to endanger peace between England and America. Now, I can assure my honrable friend, that, so far as I was concerned, I should have made use of no irritating expression. I should have affirmed then, as, undeterred by what has occurred since, I affirm now, that secession was a right, that separation is a fact, and that reconstruction is an impossibility. I should have additionally stated that all my heart and sympathies were with one portion of the American people -- not that portion that is fighting for empire; but with that portion which is struggling for independence. [Cheers from the Opposition benches.] It I rejoiced to acknowledge these sentiments on the occasion of Bull Run, I am not going to slink from them now, on the occasion of Donelson. If that discussion had been permitted to have gone on, I should have endeavored to show the House what has since been better shown by Mr. SPENCE, in his admirable book on the causes of secession, and the right which the Southern States claim to separate. I should have endeavored to show that, in recognizing a Government which I consider to be a Government of stability de jure and de facto, we should have been acting in accordance with our usual practice; and, perhaps. I should have been tempted to quote a celebrated dispatch of the noble Secretary for Foreign Affairs upon the revolution in Italy, as bearing upon this question. I should have endeavored to show, not paradoxically, but I think conclusively, to those who hate Slavery and the Slave-trade in their heart, that separation of the United States was the circumstance of all others most likely to lead to the realization of their hopes -- [hear, hear] -- and that the reconstruction of the Union was the circumstance of all others most likely to lean to the strengthening of the one and the spread of the other. I should also have referred to the short-sighted and selfish commercial policy that now prevails, and which is openly acknowledged throughout the Northern States, and which, if it be not rendered hopeless and nugatory by the independence of the South, will not merely shut out from 30,00,000 of customers the manufactures of Europe, but will rely upon it, ere long, breed a crop of troubles most dangerous to the peace of this country. [Hear, hear.] I do not quarrel in the slightest degree with the House of Commons for the feeling that it expressed on that occasion. It was a proof, at all events, to the world at large, of concilation and good will. But I am sorry the discussion did not take place, because it would have come from an independent member, whose authority was nothing but a mere statement of his own opinions, and because I conceive that a free nation, accustomed to free comments on the actions of other nations, had no right to consider itself aggrieved by a free comment on an event of such enormous magnitude to the world as this. [Hear, hear.] And not only that, but became I believe the attitude of the House of Commons on that occasion was not interpreted by the United States as a proof of conciliation I and friendship, but that it was considered to be the result of fear -- [Cheers from the Opposition] -- and that it encouraged that opinion of which we have had so many practical proofs, that whereas it may be dangerous to [???] with France, any outrage and insult may be given to England with impunity. [Hear, hear.] Now, I am not going to press the subject of recognition, or say any more upon [???] at present, because, in my opinion, the great and pressing reason that induced me to bring it forward list year has passe away -- namely, the hope that the tide. of battle might be stayed. I shall confine myself throughout the remainder of the remarks that I am about to make strictly and closely to the question of the blockade. I shall not travel one inch beyond that question, lest I might provoke other honorable members to wander into discussions which are foreign to the notice when I have placed on the paper. [Hear, hear.] I think I may fairly say that this question of the blockade of the Southern ports of America is a question of the most vital importance, not merely to England, but to the whole world. It is a question of importance to Eng and as regards the national character for honor, good faith, and justice, and a regards the daily bread of multitudes of our working men. To the world at large it is a question of the most vast importance with regard to the interpretation of a great question of international law; it is a matter of importance in every part of the globe where the culture of cotton is likely to be brought about; and it is a matter of great importance as regards the manufacture of those articles which are likely to reach the continent of America, subject to the announcement that the country will receive from Her Majesty's Government. I must justify myself when I say that this is a matter in which the national character for good faith and justice is concerned.

abstract: At the time of the escape of the Sumter from Martinique, we took occasion to express our indignation at what, judging from this distance, and with our then lights, we regarded as the culpable negligence of the blockading officer, Capt. JAMES S. PALMER, of the Iroquois. Hurt by the suspicions and imputations which his conduct called out, Capt. PALMER immediately asked to be recalled, and demanded a Court of Inquiry. Owing to the exigencies of the service, a Court of Inquiry could not be accorded him, but his case was referred to the Naval Board, at Brooklyn, which, "having maturely considered the matter," fully exonerated him from any blame in the matter of the escape of the Sumter; and the Secretary of the Navy has just reappointed him to the command of the Iroquois. The official papers in the case, which we have seen, are further strengthened by the testimony of American residents at St. Thomas, who state the charges against Capt. PALMER are to their knowledge wholly groundless. We take pleasure in giving these facts the same publicity had by our animadversions. We may, perhaps, remark, however, that these animadversions were called forth not so much by the charges which were published against Captain PALMER, and some of which we took occasion to discredit from the first, as by a seeming want of pluck and gallantry on his part -- a lack which, in the state of the public fortunes and feelings at the time, was almost as bad as a positive crime. His peers, however, have acquitted him, and we willingly do Captain PALMER the justice of putting their verdict on record.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC.-"Masaniello" was played here last evening, and not withstanding a curious thinness in the attendance at almost all the theatres, attracted a very good audience. The performance was the best that has been given so far, signor BRIGNOLL being in unusually good voice. The opera will be repeated in Brooklyn on Thursday evening.
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- "Masaniello" was played here last evening, and not withstanding a curious thinness in the attendance at almost all the theatres, attracted a very good audience. The performance was the best that has been given so far, signor BRIGNOLI being in unusually good voice. The opera will be repeated in Brooklyn on Thursday evening.

abstract: MANN ENN, the present Tycoon of Japan, in return for the elegant sewing-machine sent to his predecessor, the late Tycoon, by the Wheeler & Wilson Company, has presented to the above firm, through Mr. TOWNSEND HARRIS, our Minister to that country, several very curious and valuable gifts, comprising five nieces of uncut velvet, of various patterns and colors, of about five yards each; and five pieces of rich silk, each one yard square, embroidered, in gold and brilliant colors, and depicting various birds and flowers; among the former are a number of singular-looking cranes, sombre in tint, and several gorgeous chanticleers, with hens and chickens around them. These pictures have been suitably framed, and, with the velvets which have been arranged in a glass case, containing CRAWFORD's beautiful statue of "Dancing Jenny," now adorn the wateroom of the Wheeler & Wilson Sewing-machine Company in this City. Those persons who take pleasure in seeing foreign curiosities should not neglect to examine these Japanese manufactures. The widow of the former Tycoon, as we have been informed by Mr. HARRIS, works the sewing-machine, which was sent to her, most successfully, and takes as much interest in it as do so many of our ladies at home. -- Home Journal.

abstract: From the following circular, lately sent to all the employes, it would appear that Collector BARNEY has -- in common with the public -- some curiosity to know who made the appointments at the Custom-house. We hope the Collector will share with the public the results of his questions. The subject is one which has engaged much popular thought, since a desk was bestowed on MALCOLM IVES.

lead_paragraph: At the meeting of the Board of Aldermen last evening Alderman DAYTON moved that the Board take immediate action on the application of the Independent Telegraph Company for the privilege of raising poles for their wires in the City of New-York. Alderman BOOLE, on behalf of the Committee having the subject in charge, stated that the subject was under consideration, and the Committee would report soon. With that understanding the matter was dropped.

abstract: The Board of Aldermen, last evening, accepted and adopted the report of a special committee recommending the immediate authorization of the issue of half a million of dollars of Harbor Defence Bonds, and the appointment of a commission to expend the money for our harbor defences. An ordinance was adopted appointing a commission consisting of Andrew Carrigan, Comptroller Hawes, John Dimond, Myers Coryell and Alfred Cardoza, to take measures, with the half million of dollars appropriated, to protect the harbor of New-York. The Legislature was memorialized to legalize the action of the Board -- should the Councilmen concur.
lead_paragraph: The Board of Aldermen, last evening, accepted and adopted the report of a special committee recommending the immediate authorization of the issue of half a million of dollars of Harbor Defence Bonds, and the appointment of a commission to expend the money for our harbor defences. The Legislature was memorialized to legalize the action of the Board -- should the Councilmen concur.

abstract: A collision occurred on the Harlem Railroad on the afternoon of the 20th instant, about a mile south of Millerton Station, between two freight trains, at which one man, a brakeman, was killed, and several others injured, and considerable damage done to the two trains.

abstract: That is a suggestive passage in the proclamation issued by the Mayor of Jacksonville, Fla., to the people there, announcing the determination to surrender the place to the National forces, since there were no means of resisting them, in which, after advising the citizens to remain at home and attend to their business, he encourages them by saying: "It is the opinion of our most experienced and intelligent citizens (and I think a most correct one) that if the enemy meets with no resistance, private property will be respected and unarmed citizens will be allowed to pursue their usual occupations." It conveys to us a good deal of information as to the state of things which had prevailed there, and which, doubtless, prevails throughout the South. One is tempted to ask, on reading it, what this Mayor had been about to have had no better idea of our troops than this? To be sure he has the opinions of the "most experienced and intelligent citizens" to back him up in his statement about them, but he manifestly distrusts even their opinions, and though he hopes for the best, would not be very much surprised if the National troops, on taking possession of the place, should proceed to rob and murder on every hand. How could he have such distrust? What reason could he have had for doubting for an instant that private property would be respected, and "unarmed citizens allowed to pursue their usual occupations?" Could he have mentioned an instance in which any other course was adopted? It has been the boast of our army that this was always the case, and as they march southward, over ground once held by the rebels, the testimony is strong that their course in this respect compares most favorably with that of the rebel soldiery.

To be sure he has the opinions of the "most experienced and intelligent citizens" to back him up in his statement about them, but he manifestly distrusts even their opinions, and though he hopes for the best, would not be very much surprised if the National troops, on taking possession of the place, should proceed to rob and murder on every hand. How could he have such distrust? What reason could he have had for doubting for an instant that private property would be respected, and "unarmed citizens allowed to pursue their usual occupations?" Could he have mentioned an instance in which any other course was adopted? It has been the boast of our army that this was always the case, and as they march southward, over ground once held by the rebels, the testimony is strong that their course in this respect compares most favorably with that of the rebel soldiery.

abstract: A special to the Chicago Tribune, dated Saturday night, says the gunboat Mound City fired twenty shot at the middle batteries with considerable effect. Our officers, with a glass, counted five rebels killed at a single shot. On Saturday our mortars fired with considerable regularity, but the results were not ascertained, owing to the unfavorable state of the weather. The balloon roconnoissance did not take place.

abstract: Affairs at Island No. 10 are in statu quo, and the mortarboats are firing regularly, but very moderately about once an hour. The rebels do not reply. There are not so many tents visible. Some reports say that they are leaving. No balloon reconnoissance has yet been made, on account of high winds.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO, Tuesday, March 25.

abstract: Among the first, if he were not the very first, of the public men of Great Britain to afford aid and comfort to the rebels, was Mr. GREGORY, the Irish member of Parliament for Galway.
lead_paragraph: He did not wait for the battle of Bull Run; but in the very beginning of the session of 1861, brought forward a motion to recognize the "so-called Confederate States." The common sense of the House put a quiet, but very effective extinguisher upon Mr. GREGORY'S enthusiasm, as far as its public exhibition was concerned, by giving him assurance beforehand that his motion would not be entertained.

abstract: Beyond the fact of a fight and a victory in the valley of the Shenandoah, we have little for which to thank the mail and the telegraph. The fight which we know began on Saturday, has resulted in the utter route of the enemy. At the latest advices he was in ruinous flight, pursued sharply by our forces. But in what strength he came to the contest, and with what strength he was met, and what were the particulars of the prolonged conflict, and with what losses we came out of it, these are circumstances for which we must wait patiently. The fact of victory complete, and redounding incalculably to the credit of Gens. BANKS and SHIELDS, their officers and men, should perhaps content us for the present.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, the bill in reference to administering the oath of allegiance to American citizens in foreign coutries, was reported from the Committee on Foreign Relations.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday, the bill in reference to administering the oath of allegiance to American citizens in foreign coutries, was reported from the Committee on Foreign Relations. The resolution to transfer the Superintendency of the Capitol Extension and Dome, from the War Department to the Department of the Interior, was called up and adopted after debate -- 34 to 3. The bill for the Abolition of Slavery in the District of Columbia, was then taken up, and Mr. WILSON, of Massachusetts, made a speech in favor of its passage. He was followed by Mr. KENNEDY, of Maryland, in opposition to it. The debate continued until the adjournment.

abstract: To-day Major-General HUNTER, accompanied by Gen. BENHAM, take his departure for his new field of operations in the lately created Department of the South. Embracing, as it does, the original home of secession, and the present heart of the rebellion, his Department will be one of the most important, as it will certainly be one of the most difficult, of military trusts. But Gen. HUNTER is no untried man. From his earliest years this distinguished soldier has seen the roughest of frontier work, while his late administration of the Department of Kansas has been pleasing even to the people of that State so difficult to please, and no commander could have been selected whose soul is more in his work than he. Gen. HUNTER's qualities of boldness, rapidity and success, reinforced by the skill and gallantry of Gen. BENHAM, will make a strange contrast with Gen. SHERMAN's torpor and incompetence. The public will follow him with confidence and hope as he proceeds on his important mission.

abstract: editorial on continued hold-out of island
snippet: editorial on continued hold-out of island
lead_paragraph: -- It is just ten days since the National guns opened fire upon Island Ten; and though the bombardment has been going on steadily but slowly ever since, the island still holds out against the United States. Commodore FOOTE has been compelled to adopt an entirely different style of tactics from that in which he has heretofore achieved fame. At Fort Henry and fort Donelson he ran his boats close upon the enemy's water batteries, but on this occasion he engages them at the long taw of between two and three miles. This makes the fight less exciting than it would otherwise be, and greatly lengthens its duration. But the reports of successive days' work show that the reduction of the stronghold is certain. A large number of the heavy rebel guns have been dismounted, both of the island and of the shore batteries; and, at latest reports, the rebels appeared to be evacuating the island and getting over to the eastern mainland, preparatory to a retreat Southward. The "situation" at this Southwestern battle-field is quite interesting; -- the fortified island in the river, supported by the rebel batteries on the eastern shore, and by the rebel gunboats, floating battery and ram, which closely hug the island itself; above the island, a couple of miles, the National gunboats and mortar floats in constant play; below the island, on the western shore of the river, Gen POPE's open and masked batteries, and his large land force, preventing a rebel retreat down stream; while, furnishing the rebels their only means of retreat, on the eastern shore there is a narrow road, leading through the swamps to the railroad, which runs southward. By, this route the rebel islanders expect to make, or are now making, their exit, with the purpose, most likely, of moving to Jackson, and there reinforcing BEAUREGARD, perhaps, going down the Mississippi to Fort Randolph, the next stronghold on the river. But, if we are able to hold them any length of time at Number Ten, they will give us an opportunity of cutting off even this solitary line of retreat, and bagging the whole of this division of the rebel army. It is to be hoped the opportunity will be embraced.

abstract: The victory achieved by our forces near Winchester bids fair to prose one of the most important of the war. Information received in Wash
lead_paragraph: The victory achieved by our forces near Winchester bids fair to prose one of the most important of the war. Information received in Washington yesterday shows that our army was at Strasburgh yesterday morning; and a later dispatch, from Gen. BANKS to Gen. SHIELDS, dated five miles beyond Strasburgh, states that the enemy was still in full flight, with our forces in hot pur suit. Gen. BANKS states that the losses of the rebels must have been enormous. They had abandoned wagons along the road filled with dead and dying, the houses on the route were found crowded with wounded and dead, and the dwellings in the towns adjacent to the battle-field of Sunday, were also found filled with wounded. Our artillery was making terrible havoc among the enemy in their flight, and the rout, it was believed, would prove one of the most dreadful of the war. The details of these stirring events have not yet come to hand, and owing to the want of proper facilities, no list of the National killed and wounded has yet been telegraphed.

abstract: Editorials on London Times stand on war
snippet: Editorials on London Times stand on war
lead_paragraph: The London Times insists on having a hand in the American struggle. Three months ago it was for armed intervention, and it was only the strong predisposition of the British people to peace that checked the desire of the small but influential party of which the Times is the mouthpiece, to take a vigorous part in the fight. Happily, the timely spirit of concession on the side of our Government reinforced the peace party in England, and balked the Times. To-day, always eager for the fray, the Times urges a peaceable intervention. Great Britain is recommended as a mediator between the warring sections. The North, we are instructed, has now recovered the lost prestige of arms. Its superiority in the field, as well as in the Council Chamber and the Treasury vault, is demonstrated. There is every reason to believe that it will accept an offer of friendly arbitration, which shall bring this ineffectual contest to an end, and leave the beatitude of the peacemaker to be shared by John Bull and Don Pacifico:

abstract: The annexed are the correct particulars of this notorious steamer, first reported to have been burned by the rebels, but now said to have been captured at Beaufort, N.C., on the evening of the 20th of March: Length on deck, 216 feet: breadth of beam, 34 feet, depth of hold, 14 feet 8 inches; depth of hold to spar deck, 22 feet; draft of water at load line, 12 feet; tonnage, 1,200 tons. Her frame was of white oak chestnut, cedar, &c., and was fastened with copper, &c. Her floors were molded 14 1/2 inches; sided, 14 1/2 inches, and her frames were 29 inches apart at centres. She was fitted with a side lever engine, with one cylinder 86 inches in diameter and a stroke of piston of 8 feet. Her water-wheelswere 12 feet in diameter, and of iron. She was also fitted with two return flue boilers, built in 1860. Her rig was that of a foretopsail schooner. She was [???] in New-York in 1853, by WM. COLLYER, and her machinery was constructed by the Novelty Iron Works.

abstract: -A  CHANCE FOR THE CHARITABLE. The heroism and the triumphs of the National soldiers in North Carolina have already been fully chronicled by the Press; and Roanoke and Newbern among battles, and Gen. BURNSIDE among commanders, and the Eastern troops among soldiers, now stand in the foremost rank in the mind of the nation.
lead_paragraph: -- A CHANCE FOR THE CHARITABLE. -- The heroism and the triumphs of the National soldiers in North Carolina have already been fully chronicled by the Press; and Roanoke and Newbern among battles, and Gen. BURNSIDE among commanders, and the Eastern troops among soldiers, now stand in the foremost rank in the mind of the nation. The roll of the dead at the last sanguinary battle contains over a hundred names, every man a hero. For thesetheir country can now do nothing but honor their memories. But there still live nearly five hundred wounded men who, less than a fortnight ago, faced the rebel batteries along the Neuse River, and were enfiladed by the rebel cannon. Many of these were severely wounded, others maimed for life, some made invalids for months and every day sees the number of the battle-tried heroes lessened by death. Some sixty of the badly-wounded men have been sent eastward by Gen. BURNSIDE, and arrived at this port last night. They are mostly poor men, and nearly all New-Englanders. They need aid, attention and kindness while they are in our midst, and whatever they need, we are sure that the ever-generous citizens of New-York are anxious to furnish. Some of them were taken from the vessel last night to those friendless, dismal sheds, the Park barracks, and some were left on hoard the ship that brought them. This is not as it should be. The barracks constitute a horrible hospital for suffering men, a wretched place for physicians to operate, and a fearful, chilly spot to die in. New-York should do better than that; its patriotic citizens should make more Christian provision for the brave men who may be unfortunately cast on their charity. And it will do so as soon as the facts are laid before it. We have learned that the Sanitary Commission did what was possible under the circumstances to relieve these men; but, after all, that did not amount to anything like comfort for them. The Government has made no suitable provision for them, and the duty falls back upon private beneficence. Let every man and woman who desires the benediction of Heaven, and who loves the land for which those our countrymen have offered their lives, see that this morning does not pass away without furnishing aid that will relieve at least one soldier. The citizens and ladies of Louisville have won the gratitude and admiration of the whole country for their untiring self-devotion to the wounded and sick Union soldiers of the West. Those of New-York have been negligent and dilatory. The newspapers of New-England complain of the way in which the wounded at Roanoke were treated when here. Such things must not be permitted to occur in future.

abstract: By the arrival of the steamship Nova Scotian at Portland, we have advices from Europe two days later than were received by the Hansa. There is little news of interest.
lead_paragraph: By the arrival of the steamship Nova Scotian at Portland, we have advices from Europe two days later than were received by the Hansa. There is little news of interest. The Paris Patrie pretends to have information, obtained from a member of the British Cabinet, to the effect that an amicable separation will take place between the North and the South about June. The Patrie does not state the authority upon which the member of the British Cabinet bases his declarations. The London Times has a curious view of the probable effect of the recent victories achieved by the National arms. It believes that they will lead to a separation, and peace between the Northern and Southern States. In the Liverpool cotton market cotton had declined one half pence per pound. Breadstuffs were tending downward, and provisions were quiet and steady. Consols for Money were at [???], and American securities were firm.

abstract: Commander RODGERS, in his official report of the capture of Augustine, Florida, dedescribed the state of feeling in that part of the country in the following terms: "I believe that there are many citizens who are earnestly attached to the Union, a large numher who are opposed to it, and a still larger number who care very little about the matter." We believe this classification...
lead_paragraph: Commander RODGERS, in his official report of the capture of Augustine, Florida, dedescribed the state of feeling in that part of the country in the following terms: "I believe that there are many citizens who are earnestly attached to the Union, a large numher who are opposed to it, and a still larger number who care very little about the matter." We believe this classification good, not only for Florida, but to afford a fair exhibit of the temper of mind of the population of the whole South. It is precisely the experience our Union armies have everywhere met with in their advance into the insurgent States. In some sections the presence of the National troops has been hailed with genuine and unaffected demonstrations of joy -- it was so at Florence, Ala., and up the Tennessee. In other sections, the most stubborn and virulent animosity has been shown -- it has been so in South Carolina; and though some of our soldiers at Port Royal have amused themselves in taming a crocodile, we have yet to hear that they have succeeded in taming a South Carolinian planter. Not that we have any doubt of the success of the experiment under the right conditions; we simply mean that there has been no spontaneous exhibition of loyalty among the class named. But no doubt the frame of mind of the largest proportion of the Southern population is accurately portrayed in the phrase we have quoted -- they "care very little about the matter." They are neither very much of Secessionists nor very much of Unionists, and had just about as lief that the one cause should triumph as the other. They have accepted the rebellion, if that term can be applied to a mere passive acquiescence; and were, under the first effervescence of excitement, even ready to enter the rebel army: but this artificial stimulus has long ceased to be operative, while the bitter experience of those in the ranks, and the distress of those at home, have wrought their inevitable reaction. These, therefore, wherever our armies show themselves in the insurgent States, will quietly submit to the old authority -- without ardor or enthusiasm, or, indeed, any sentiment worth speaking of, but a feeling of selfish satisfaction at being relieved of the suffering and loss which the rebellion brought to their door.

abstract: Yesterday afternoon, Commodore LEVY, U.S.N., whose death took place at his residence in St. Mark's-place, last Saturday, was buried. According to Jewish usage -- deceased having been an Israelite -the body was placed in a plain wooden coffin, bearing no inscription. Rev. Dr. LYONS, Rabbi of the Shearith Israel Congregation, in West Nineteenth-street, performed the burial services. Shortly after 2 o'clock the body was placed in the hearse, and was conveyed to the Salem Fields Cemetery, where it was interred. Acting as escort were three companies of marines, under command of Capt. HAYWOOD, and a detachment of eighty men from the ship of the line North Carolina. The Navy-yard Brass Band was also in attendance and played the Dead March in Saul. Capts. R.W. Mead, Delano, Thompson and Garland, and Drs. Wm. B. Mann and Wm. S. Fort acted as pull-bearers. Arriving at the cemetery, the deceased was placed in the receiving-house, when the mourners, in accordance with Jewish custom, made the circuit of it seven times, chanting the while verses illustrative of the mercy of God and the mortality of man. Finally the body was lowered into the grave, when the three nearest relatives offered up a prayer, threw dust upon the coffin, and the obsequies were finished.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday afternoon, Commodore LEVY, U.S.N., whose death took place at his residence in St. Mark's-place, last Saturday, was buried. According to Jewish usage -- deceased having been an Israelite -the body was placed in a plain wooden coffin, bearing no inscription. Rev. Shortly after 2 o'clock the body was placed in the hearse, and was conveyed to the Salem Fields Cemetery, where it was interred. Acting as escort were three companies of marines, under command of Capt. HAYWOOD, and a detachment of eighty men from the ship of the line North Carolina. abstract: The Patrie is to Paris  what the Herald is to New-York an audacious coiner of news, and a covert supporter of the Southern rebellion.
lead_paragraph: -- The Patrie is to Paris what the Herald is to New-York -- an audacious coiner of news, and a covert supporter of the Southern rebellion. The latest forgery of the Parisian journal is, as usual, in the interest of its rebellious friends. It consists in a scheme of compromise which, it says, has been arranged between the Governments of Mr. LINCOLN and JEFF. DAVIS, in accordance with which the war will be brought to an end in June. The secession of the Gulf and Atlantic Slave States will, we are told, be accepted as a fact, while Tennessee, Kentucky and Missouri will be retained by the North. A frontier without custom-houses, repeal of all fugitive laws and treaties, and prospective emancipation, are the conditions proposed by the rebels as an equivalent for their independence, and accepted by the Federal Government. It is needless of course to warn an American reader of the folly and falsity of such fabrications. But in Europe their inanity is less conspicuous. There they serve the fallacious purpose of showing what sacrifices the South is ready to make for peace, and how relentlessly and cruelly the North persists in war. Fortunately, the labor of the Patrie is laggard and too late.

abstract: -Our readers will recollect that when  the proposition to create a Solicitor of Customs for this port was brought forward some two months ago, its adoption was strongly urged on the ground of saving expense to Government, because it would prevent the employment of extra counsel in revenue causes, for which, as was said, the Government was paying at the rate of $20,000 a year.
lead_paragraph: -- Our readers will recollect that when the proposition to create a Solicitor of Customs for this port was brought forward some two months ago, its adoption was strongly urged on the ground of saving expense to Government, because it would prevent the employment of extra counsel in revenue causes, for which, as was said, the Government was paying at the rate of $20,000 a year. We expressed our doubts both as to whether it would save the employment of extra counsel, and whether that expense amounted to anything like that sum. But we suggested that the actual facts could easily be ascertained by an examination of the accounts, and that till we had those facts, it was hardly worth while to argue on the point.

abstract: The report that the rebels, on the approach of Gen. BURNSIDE'S force to Beaufort, had burned the Nashville, accorded so well with the passion developed in these people for conflagrations, sulphureous smoke, blue-lights, sheet-iron thunder, and the like, that, given a dash of credulity, nothing seemed more likely to be true.
lead_paragraph: The report that the rebels, on the approach of Gen. BURNSIDE's force to Beaufort, had burned the Nashville, accorded so well with the passion developed in these people for conflagrations, sulphureous smoke, blue-lights, sheet-iron thunder, and the like, that, given a dash of credulity, nothing seemed more likely to be true. But, besides its general probability, her valorous commander, PEGRAM, had given out, with ominous nod, that he would never, never, never allow the craft to be taken, and it was stated in the London papers that valves were so arranged that he could blow her out of the water at a moment's notice. The later tidings received, however, assign a far more satisfactory though not so theatrical an end to the Nashville, which, instead of shooting up in flames athwart the sky, as an illustration of Southern ultimate destruction in the maritime line, has, we learn, fallen into the hands of the blockaders, and is now on the fair way of being restored to her rightful owners. For it must be borne in mind that the Nashville is stolen goods, being mainly the property of loyal owners in this City, a circumstance which makes her recovery all the more satisfactory; for while we have no great objection to the rebels' burning ships or anything else that belongs to them, if that sort of feu de jois afford them any gratification, we have a most "Yankee" opposition to their using our property to make their bonfires withal. Why PEGRAM did not do something desperate we are left to conjecture. He seems to have hoped he would be able to run out of Beaufort with as much ease as he ran in; and seeing the advance of the National force, he put on steam and rushed into the arms of the Yankee blockaders. This must certainly be a very prosaic finale for this notorious craft in the estimation of those ardent Southern imaginations; but it suits the "Yankee" notion pretty well.
headline: {'main': 'The Fate of the Nashville.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Fate of the Nashville.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: U.S. steam transport George Peabody, Capt. TRAVERS, from Newbern, N.C., March 22, in ballast, to the U.S. Quartermaster, arrived at this port yesterday. She left in company with the steamer NewBrunswick for New-York, and passed over the Swash on Sunday, at 11 A.M. Found at the Inlet the steamer Port Royal, from New-York, all well.
lead_paragraph: U.S. steam transport George Peabody, Capt. TRAVERS, from Newbern, N.C., March 22, in ballast, to the U.S. Quartermaster, arrived at this port yesterday. She left in company with the steamer NewBrunswick for New-York, and passed over the Swash on Sunday, at 11 A.M. Found at the Inlet the steamer Port Royal, from New-York, all well. She left at the Inlet the steamers New-Brunswick and Louisiana, having on board many of the sick and wounded from Gen. BURNSIDE's Division. The steamer S.R. Spaalding left the Inlet for Fortress Monroe an hour previous to our departure, having on board some of the sick and wounded transferred from the Louisiana. At 3 P.M., Cape Hatteras light bearing northwest, passed steamer Suwannee, bound south, probably to Hatteras Inlet. At 5 P.M., passed steamer Eastern State, bound to the Inlet.

abstract: A statement, through inadvertence, found place among our Washington dispatches on Saturday last, to the effect that Mr. RIGGS, of the well-known banking-house of RIGGS & Co., is largely interested in whisky speculations, and, as a dealer in the article, is endeavoring to procure a modification of the new tax provisions. We are authorized to say there is no truth whatever in such rumors. Mr. RIGGS is not and has never been an owner of whisky, and is in no way interested in the excise upon the beverage. The character of Mr. RIGGS, and of his house, is of itself a sufficient refutation of the story.

The character of Mr. RIGGS, and of his house, is of itself a sufficient refutation of the story.

abstract: Last evening, twenty-three wounded soldiers arrived in this City from Newborn, by way of Baltimore. Of arriving here they were at once conducted to the Park Barracks, where everything possible was done to ameliorate their condition. Several surgeons...
lead_paragraph: Last evening, twenty-three wounded soldiers arrived in this City from Newborn, by way of Baltimore. Of arriving here they were at once conducted to the Park Barracks, where everything possible was done to ameliorate their condition. Several surgeons volunteered to dress their wounds, among whom were Drs. D.L.D. Sheldon, J.P. Mann, Geo. H. Marvin, James H. Anderson, Henry S. Plimpton, and G.W. Carleton. Lieut. BARKER, of the Fifty-first Regiment New-York Volunteers, was in charge of the men. Annexed is a list of their names:

abstract: Barnard et al. vs. Keislen -- The above motion, to which we referred in our list of decision in our issue of the 24th inst., by its adverse decision to the applicant, will afford a precedent for the guidance of our Courts, as to some of the points of the English Bankrupt Law of 1861. The action is based on the fraudulent conversion by the defendant of some $150,000 worth of merchandise consigned to him by the plaintiffs, who are English Bankrupts, under the recent Act of Victoria, and the defendant denies the right of the plaintiffs to sue him individually.

abstract: It is a notable circumstance that the rebel leaders are now making prodigious efforts to disarm all their own citizens, by a compulsory calling in of firearms of every kind. Though the blind put forth is that the measure is prompted by the scarcity of arms, and it is given out that they will be paid for, (in Confederate scrip,) it is very evident that it springs from a determination to render the people as helpless as possible, for the purpose of preventing them from originating counter-revolutions. The Richmond usurpers, while stoutly denying abroad the existence of a spark of Unionism, either latent or patent, nevetrheless take good care to act at home on the very sound theory that a deadly hostility to them is rapidly developing, and that the safe plan is to render this hostility as inoperative as they can.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, the bill to incorporate the New-York Homoeopathic Medical Society was ordered to a third reading. The bill to alter the Commissioners' Map of Brooklyn was recorded favorably. Among the bills passed was one to compensate bona fide purchasers of wild lands for improvements made thereon. The bill to incorporate the New-York Commercial Association was ordered to a third reading; also the hill relative to lands under water in the City of Brooklyn.

abstract: But the Government have two more serious embarrassments on hand than this little mishap of the Victoria I mean the Mexican mess, and the Longford election. If I may believe what I hear, the former is about as perplexed and disheartening an imbroglio as ever a luckless enterprise was involved in. The premature action of Spaid threw out the whole plans and policy of our Minister in Mexico.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a petition from citizens of New-York, asking the passage of a Bankrupt Law, was presented by Mr. HARRIS, who also presented a petition asking for the liberty of the Press.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, a petition from citizens of New-York, asking the passage of a Bankrupt Law, was presented by Mr. HARRIS, who also presented a petition asking for the liberty of the Press. An extract from the Detroit Tribune was read by Mr. LATHAM, of California, stating that a document had been found disclosing the existence of a traitorous league formed for the purpose of overthrowing the Government, and implicating, among others, Ex-President PIERCE, of New-Hampshire. Mr. LATHAM offered a resolution calling upon the Secretary of State for any correspondence or other information he might have upon the subject. Mr. CHANDLER and Mr. HOWARD, of Michigan, both asserted that they knew of the existence of such an organization. The resolution was adopted. The joint resolution offering pecuniary aid to those States desiring to abolish Slavery was taken up and debated at considerable length. Several amendments were proposed and voted down. Consideration of the resolution was finally postponed until to-day. Resolutions tendering the thanks of Congress to Gen. BURNSIDE and Commodore ROWAN, and to their officers and men, were referred. The bill to abolish Slavery in the District of Columbia was then debated until the adjournment, without definite action.

abstract: The steamer Columbia, which arrived here last evening, brings us news from Mexico through Havana sources, but nothing of political importance beyond the near arrival of the French troops at Tehuacan. A dreadful explosion, with frigthful loss of life, had occurred at the barracks where the Mexican army was quartered, eight leagues from Orizaba; the number of killed and wounded is estimated at 1,300, and the building in which the explosion took place was blown to pieces. An attempt had been made to murder Gen. ALMONTE. The French war-steamer Canada had arrived at Vera Cruz with fresh troops.

abstract: FALSE ARREST. -- Mr. ELIJAH H. KIMBALL, in the City Court, yesterday, recovered $450 damages against THOMAS LYNCH, for a false arrest. It is alleged by LYNCH that KIMBALL bought $50 worth of liquors of him, and refused to pay for them. LYNCH, for the purpose of getting "satisfaction" where he could get no money, caused KIMBALL to be arrested while in one of the city railroad cars, as a thief, and for this act the suit was brought and the above-named amount of damages awarded.
lead_paragraph: FALSE ARREST. -- Mr. ELIJAH H. KIMBALL, in the City Court, yesterday, recovered $450 damages against THOMAS LYNCH, for a false arrest. abstract: The steamship China, which arrived at this port yesterday, was launched from the yard of MessrsNAPIER  SONS, at Govan on the Clyde, on Oct. 8, 1861. Her length of keel and fore rake is 322 feet her breadth (molded,) 40 feet; her depth, 29 feet and...
lead_paragraph: The steamship China, which arrived at this port yesterday, was launched from the yard of Messrs. NAPIER & SONS, at Govan on the Clyde, on Oct. 8, 1861. Her length of keel and fore rake is 322 feet; her breadth, (molded,) 40 feet; her depth, 29 feet and her extreme length is 340 feet. Her burden is 2,600 tons and she is driven by oscillating engines of 550 nominal horse power, provided with patent surface condensers, in addition to the ordinary condensers. The greatest possible care has been taken in every detail of her construction to insure the comfort and safety of her passengers, and it is the statement of her builders that she is the finest steamer in every respect which the Clyde, famous for its noble vessels, has yet produced.

abstract: Never were want of foresight, of system, and of organization more forcibly or more painfully exhibited than upon the arrival here of a detachment of wounded soldiers, from Newbern, on Tuesday night.
lead_paragraph: Never were want of foresight, of system, and of organization more forcibly or more painfully exhibited than upon the arrival here of a detachment of wounded soldiers, from Newbern, on Tuesday night. They were expected, their probable landing at that time having been announced in the evening papers of Tuesday; and yet, to our shame, there was no more provision made for them than there could, and would, have been made, had the same number of wounded men been suddenly found in the Park at a time of absolute peace. Neither beds, bandages, food nor attendance at all adequate to the emergency had been provided; and our poor fellows found themselves set ashore in the wealthiest city of this continent, suffering from wounds which had never been thoroughly dressed, with their sufferings aggravated by their journey, and on a cold, blustering March night, no comfort awaited them, no welcome greeted them. A few surgeons and private citizens of other callings, hastily gathered, did what they could for them; but although only between eighty and ninety arrived that night, there were not even bandages and lint enough at hand to make a single change in the dressings of all; and some had their wounds bound up again in the same bandages in which they had been for twenty-four hours. With few exceptions, an unmitigated pine table was their only couch. In short, their condition, under shelter and with food enough to sustain them, could hardly have been worse.
headline: {'main': 'Our Returning Wounded', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Our Returning Wounded', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. Mine. DE LUSSAN made her debut, last evening, before an audience that was both distinguished in numbers and character.
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- Mme. DE LUSSAN made her debut, last evening, before an audience that was both distinguished in numbers and character. The opera selected for the occasion was "La Favorita" -- a work which has always been a favorite with our public, but has been laid on the shelf of late, owing to the dearth of dramatic singers. It argues well for Mme. DE LUSSAN's self-reliance that she selected so important and exacting a role as Leonora. Perhaps a milder ordeal would have been better, but under the circumstances, it was passed through with a fair share of success. Although visibly affected by stage-fright, and consequently deprived of the full benefit of her powers, Mme. DE LUSSAN succeeded, in the first act, in creating an extremely favorable impression. Her voice is a mezzo-soprano, of good compass and quality, which the lady uses judiciously, but with an energy at times not conducive to good intonation. It appears to be worn in the middle register and afflicted with a tremolo throughout, a serious blemish, which, like singing out of tune, we hope to see removed on future performances. That the lady possesses talent, is as evident as the fact that her voice is naturally full and pleasing. But we could not help remarking that the first act was by far the best, notwithstanding the great trepidation under which the lady labored. The fatigue of the unaccustomed effort became more and more noticeable as the opera progressed, and hence the opinion we have formed is based almost exclusively on the section we have referred to. Madame DE LUSSAN was called out during the evening and gallantly bouquetted. Her friends, indeed, were more than satisfied with her success.

abstract: entertainments which have enlivened the past season, few have been more attractive, or afforded more pleasure, than the musical soirees held by the pupils of Mrs. EDWARD SEGUIN, at her residence in Twenty-first-street. On Monday, the entire score of "Norma" was sung before a delighted assemblage of friends, and the opinion was unanimous that no performance in this City, off the boards of the opera, has ever surpassed it. The honors of the evening were cheerfully and justly accorded to Norma, whose music was truthfully and beautifully rendered by the young lady whose success at a recent private charity concert, given at the residence of one of our wealthiest citizens, was so marked. Mrs. SEGUIN is one of our most honored teachers, and may well be proud of some of the pupils whom she has graduated.

abstract: A WOMAN CHARGED WITH FRAUD -- LAWYERS THE VICTIMS. -- MARY ANN JAGGERS, aged about 50 years, residing at No. 31 Northmore-street, was brought before Justice KELLY, yesterday, by Detective WILSON, upon the charge of false pretences. The prisoner called upon JOHN B. MOORE, a short time since, and represented to him that she had recently had a fortune left her of over $75,000; and requested him to invest $50,000 of it for the benefit of her children. She was not particular about the rate of interest, and promised to let MOORE, -- whom she wished to make her agent, -- have all the interest over three per cent. which could be obtained on the money. The investments were to be made in his name, and he was to have the entire charge of the funds. During the negotiations, Mrs. J. stated that she had a few small bills to pay, and MOORE, not suspecting anything wrong, was persuaded to advance her the sum of $173. He soon discovered, however, that the woman's representations were all unfounded, and that the deeds, bonds, notes, &c., which had been left with him were worthless. About the same time three other gentlemen of this City, viz.: D.B. PIKE, W.B. SMITH, (lawyer, of No. 114 Nassau-street,) and Mr. PARKER, of the Register's Office, were swindled by the accused -- the two former of $100 each and the latter of $170. The same story was told to these gentlemen as that which was related to MOORE, and in this way she succeeded in borrowing the amounts of money above-mentioned. Jestice KELLY held her for examination.

abstract: current status of intervention
snippet: current status of intervention
lead_paragraph: The conjoint raid into Mexico has been the subject of discussion in the French Legislative Chamber. The Liberal party took manful ground against the Government for thus deserting the traditions of the country by forcible intervention in the domestic affairs of another people, and argued cogently the folly of levying war on a grand scale to collect a debt of $150,000. The apologists of Government denied any intention to interfere forcibly with the institutions of Mexico. They stated the motive of the Government to be, beyond the recovery of debts justly due French subjects, the protection of the lives and property of such of those subjects as are resident or transient in Mexico. The proverbial insecurity of life among the Mexicans was presented clearly. It is the highest duty of a Government to protect its citizens wherever enterprise may carry them; and the fulness of time had been reached for obtaining strong guarantees from the Government of Mexico for the safety of Frenchmen. If in procuring these guarantees the assistance of French arms shall be voluntarily solicited by the Mexican people as an aid to reforming their political system, and inaugurating the reign of order, the Imperial Government is not disposed to withhold such aid; nor, on the other hand, is it disposed to thrust it upon the nation unasked. With this explanation of M. BILLAULT, the Legislative body was satisfied. Indeed, what attribute of purity and disinteredness was wanting to the policy of France?

abstract: The fidelity of the police to their duty and their oaths produces discomfort among the gentlemen of the Sunday tap. They cannot well see why they should not break a dozen laws in peace, if they only do it behind the door. Policemen are required to "prevent...
lead_paragraph: The fidelity of the police to their duty and their oaths produces discomfort among the gentlemen of the Sunday tap. They cannot well see why they should not break a dozen laws in peace, if they only do it behind the door. Policemen are required to "prevent crime," as well as arrest offenders;" and knowing that crime and rum are bedfellows, they are as much bound to stay the unlawful sale of rum as they are to catch the drunkard or the rowdy manufactured by rum, and they arc specially charged by the laws and by their instructions to stop the Sunday traffic in the means of intoxication.

abstract: The Post and Tribune have, with characteristic modesty, constituted themselves an ecclesiastical council in the matter of Calvary Church. Dr. HAWKS, it seems, after years of acceptable ministrations, has tendered his resignation to the vestry of that society. The motive is said to be a divergence of political sympathies, the Doctor, as a native of the South, hesitating in his support of a war directed against his Southern kinsfolk, while the congregation is eminently loyal. We are not aware that this difference has impaired the efficacy of the Pastor's labors. It has certainly not impaired the strength of intellect, the varied and thorough learning and culture, and the rhetorical graces which place Dr. HAWKS among the leading divines and pulpit orators of the country. He has not so obtruded his private political opinions upon his people as to give offence; a fact sufficiently manifested in the refusal of the vestry to accept his resignation. The step seems to have been taken purely at the suggestion of a too sensitive conscience, and upon the impulse of private reasons, that if made public would only add to the esteem with which Dr. HAWKS is regarded in the community; and the force and pressure of which can only be appreciated by himself. When, therefore, our meddlesome cotemporaries obtrude their advice they do so to parties who may reasonably protest against the impertinence. They know nothing of the motives animating the clergyman; they entirely fail to understand or sympathize with the devotion of his flock. And as a rule, the case of the diocese is so safe in the hands of Bishop POTTER, that Episcopa lians generally will be willing to dispense with the oversight of these self-consecrated bishops in partibus.
lead_paragraph: The Post and Tribune have, with characteristic modesty, constituted themselves an ecclesiastical council in the matter of Calvary Church. Dr. HAWKS, it seems, after years of acceptable ministrations, has tendered his resignation to the vestry of that society. The motive is said to be a divergence of political sympathies, the Doctor, as a native of the South, hesitating in his support of a war directed against his Southern kinsfolk, while the congregation is eminently loyal. We are not aware that this difference has impaired the efficacy of the Pastor's labors. It has certainly not impaired the strength of intellect, the varied and thorough learning and culture, and the rhetorical graces which place Dr. HAWKS among the leading divines and pulpit orators of the country. He has not so obtruded his private political opinions upon his people as to give offence; a fact sufficiently manifested in the refusal of the vestry to accept his resignation. The step seems to have been taken purely at the suggestion of a too sensitive conscience, and upon the impulse of private reasons, that if made public would only add to the esteem with which Dr. HAWKS is regarded in the community; and the force and pressure of which can only be appreciated by himself. When, therefore, our meddlesome cotemporaries obtrude their advice they do so to parties who may reasonably protest against the impertinence. They know nothing of the motives animating the clergyman; they entirely fail to understand or sympathize with the devotion of his flock. And as a rule, the case of the diocese is so safe in the hands of Bishop POTTER, that Episcopa lians generally will be willing to dispense with the oversight of these self-consecrated bishops in partibus.

abstract: editorial on Border States Congressmen's reaction to message
snippet: editorial on Border States Congressmen's reaction to message
lead_paragraph: Mr. HENDERSON, the newly appointed Senator from Missouri, has signalized his debut in the Senate by showing that one at least of the representatives from the Border States is able to appreciate the crisis, and to measure his duty. The President's Emancipation Message has proved indeed too serious a test for the patriotism of the Border State Members. A few of them, like Mr. BLAIR of Missouri, who acts in accordance with settled principles, have adopted the Presidential policy with enthusiasm. The greater number of them, on the contrary, array themselves boldly against the plan; some of them dare to impugn the lofty motives of Mr. LINCOLN; and there is a general agreement in the sentiments, that the proposed resolution is a more or less decisive interference with State rights; that it is a cover for the secret assaults of the Abolitionists; and if adopted, that it will become possible to discuss Slavery in Kentucky as we discuss a tariff or tax in New-York, namely, without fear of immediate evisceration. These results, such men as POWELL, and DAVIS, and SAULSBURY, denounce unreservedly; and they presume to threaten unspeakable alternatives should Congress venture a response to the executive suggestion.

abstract: -- The telegram sent from Washington last Sunday, in regard to the probable capture of the City of New-Orleans, has not yet been verified by any arrivals from our Gulf contingent. A Memphis paper has indeed announced that Fort Pike, which guards the passage-way from Lake Borgne to Lake Ponchartrain, was in our hands; but we have no news of any general assault on the works lining the shore of the latter lake, in the rear of the city, nor on those upon the river, below the city, much less of the capture of the city itself. It is not likely, indeed, that Gen. BUTLER would think it prudent to actually occupy a metropolis which, according to the last census, had a population of nearly two hundred thousand souls, with the small force under his command; and such a thing as bombarding or destroying the Crescent City is of course not intended. New-Orleans is known to be fortified in the most extensive and formidable manner at every direction of approach. If the rebel papers have not exaggerated in their description of these fortifications, there never was a city so strongly defended since mankind began to build cities. To reduce these works will require the labors of the mortar fleet, and of the naval and land contingent, for not a few days. Should we succeed in destroying and capturing these defences, and getting naval control of the river and the lake, we can then hold the city at our mercy, and give the Union clement a chance to assert itself. It would not be at all surprising if the first decisive demonstration in favor of the Union in the South should take place in the greatest city of the South. If our mortarboats and gunboats succeed in forcing the passage of the river, it will also give us an opportunity of ascending its stream a few hundred miles, and making a combined assault upon Memphis and the great rebel army there, in front and rear.

lead_paragraph: George P. Naylor et al. vs. Francis A. Hoffman et al., and one other case. -- The particulars of the former of these cases were stated in the TIMES of the 18th February last. The facts in each are the same, and a statement of one is a report of the other. abstract: The habeas corpus case of John Ireland and Alex. Matthews, arrested for selling liquor on Sunday was resumed yesterday morning, before Judge Mc'CUNN. As on the previous day, a large concourse of spectators were in attendance at the opening of the Court. Assistant District-Attorney WHITEHEAD stated
lead_paragraph: The habeas corpus case of John Ireland and Alex. Matthews, arrested for selling liquor on Sunday, was resumed yesterday morning, before Judge MCCUNN. As on the previous day, a large concourse of spectators were in attendance at the opening of the Court. Assistant District-Attorney WHITEHEAD stated that the prosecution were of the opinion that this was not the time or place to obtain a judicial decision upon the constitutionality of the State Legislature in reference to the Sunday liquor traffic -- the proceeding being merely a writ of habeas corpus to inquire into the cause of the detention of the defendants. To avoid, therefore, any difficulties that might arise out of the case, he moved that the parties under arrest be discharged.

abstract: Our dispatches from Island No. 10 do not tell of much progress made in the reduction of the rebel position, though we may at any time, our correspondent intimates, be surprised with the intelligence of some telling blow delivered in the right place. A reconnoissance down the Missouri
lead_paragraph: Our dispatches from Island No. 10 do not tell of much progress made in the reduction of the rebel position, though we may at any time, our correspondent intimates, be surprised with the intelligence of some telling blow delivered in the right place. A reconnoissance down the Missouri shore on Wednesday resulted in the arrest of three prominent residents of the locality, who made some important disclosures. Two thousand negroes, it appears, are employed by the rebels on the Island and shore batteries, forty of whom have been killed by our shells, beside sixty-five rebels, including two Lieutenants. The upper battery, as conjectured, has been abandoned, but the other shore batteries are being strengthened. The rebels, who are fifteen thousand strong, have removed their encampment out of range of our guns.

abstract: A momentary panic was excited yesterday morning by the news of the Merrimac's readiness for sea. The story was necessarily untrue, for no amount of preparation can fit for sea a vessel so deeply laden that her ports are on the water's edge. That such is the fact we have the uniform evidence of those who watched the razzia of the other day. Whatever mischief the monster is to do, will be done in Hampton Roads, where, warned at last, the Navy Department has made proper arrangements to receive and handle her. There is not the most trifling ground for apprehension.

abstract: The Sons of Massachusetts will meet at the Astor House this afternoon at 3 o'clock, to join in the obsequies of Col. SLOCUM, Major BALLOU and Capt. TOWER, of the Second Rhode Island, who fell at Bull Run, and whose bodies were recently disinterred. Gov. SPRAGUE, of Rhode Island, and Staff, will be present, and the Seventy-first and Thirty-seventh Regiments New-York State Militia, with all the officers of the Division, are to turn out. The Sons of Vermont and Connecticut will likewise join in the ceremonies.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, the Committee on Naval Affairs was instructed to inquire whether there was any laxity on the part of any of the blockading vessels, and especially at Charleston. The joint resolution to give pecuniary aid to those States desiring to abolish Slavery was taken up, and Mr. HENDERSON, of Missouri, made a speech in favor of its adoption.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, the Committee on Naval Affairs was instructed to inquire whether there was any laxity on the part of any of the blockading vessels, and especially at Charleston. The joint resolution to give pecuniary aid to those States desiring to abolish Slavery was taken up, and Mr. HENDERSON, of Missouri, made a speech in favor of its adoption. A bill was reported from the Finance Committee to allow States to import arms free of duty. The Naval Appropriation bill was then considered. Mr. HALE, of New-Hampshire, offered an amendment to appropriate $783,294 for the completion of the Stevens battery. This proposition was debated until the adjournment, and encountered considerable opposition from members representing constituencies distant from the seacoast. An amendment offered by Mr. SHERMAN of Ohio, providing that payment to Mr. STEVENS shall be contingent upon the success of the enterprise, was pending at the adjournment.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, the bill to provide for the payment of the Canal Enlargement debt was  ordered to a third reading. The Assembly amendments to the bill concerning the Erie Railroad were concurred in. The bill to regulate the use
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, the bill to provide for the payment of the Canal Enlargement debt was ordered to a third reading. The Assembly amendments to the bill concerning the Erie Railroad were concurred in. The bill to regulate the use of public highways was passed. The New-York delegation made a report on the memorial of the Commissioners of the Land-Office, asking for the sale of certain lands on New-York harbor. They recommend the passage of a bill repealing the act of Aug. 17, 1860, authorizing the sale of certain lands belonging to the State, and recommending the City of New-York to purchase the same. The report was referred to the Judiciary Committee.

abstract: Editorial on observations of London Times
snippet: Editorial on observations of London Times
lead_paragraph: The London Times draws from the late discussion on the blockade in Parliament, two or three conclusions for the especial benefit of people on this side of the water. The North, it says, will learn from it "how unjust way the suspicion that we took advantage of the Trent affair in order to obtain an excuse for liberating the cotton of the South." There is some truth in this and some error. We undoubtedly thought that the cotton was a temptation to England. But we considered the action of England in the Trent affair as springing far more from the hostility of her aristocracy to our institutions, which have been so long a thorn in their side. And we considered the want of cotton rather as a weapon used by this unscrupulous party to drive the people of England into the adoption of measures which would, they thought, secure the result which they desired, in the permanent disruption of this country. We do not see much in the debate to convict us of injustice in this suspicion. But we do see, and we heartily rejoice to see, that the efforts of this party are less likely to secure success than ever; that those who are in sympathy with us and our principles are stronger than ever before, and that the day may not be far distant, when the voices of malignant carping, and the whispers of unjust suspicion, will be entirely overborne by notes of hearty sympathy and good fellowship, and when even the London Times will join in swelling the chorus of acclaim which ever waits upon success. We already see in its columns symptoms indicative of this result. Who would have believed, three months ago, that we should find in that paper a confession that "nobody can deny the colossal scale, the multifarious plan and the exhaustive energy of the operations of the Federal Government?" The words sound strangely after the diatribes upon our utter lack of plan, the inefficiency of the means employed, and the inertness and incompetency displayed by us, to which, we have been accustomed from that quarter.

COLLIVER and crew, of the British brig Billow, whom they rescued from that vessel on the 27th February, in lat. 42째 N., lon. 38째. Capt. COLLIVER states that he sailed from St. Johns, N.F., Feb. 13, for Liverpool, with a cargo of 170 casks of oil and 70 casks of molasses, and on the 17th February, lat. 45째, lon, 36째, experienced a gale from N.W.; lost her rudder-head, fore and maintopmasts, and all his sails and shipped a sea, which stove the bulwarks and washed overboard everything moveable on deck, and caused the vessel to spring aleak. When he left her she had three feet water in the hold. She was built at Windsor, N.S., in 1850, 121 tons burden, and owned by J.T. & A.S. DE WOLFE.

abstract: The various and contradictory reports that came to us on Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday, in regard to the fate of the rebel steamship Nashville, have now, apparently, brought-up with the fact that she was neither burned by the rebels nor captured by us, but that she has again escaped to sea.
lead_paragraph: The various and contradictory reports that came to us on Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday, in regard to the fate of the rebel steamship Nashville, have now, apparently, brought-up with the fact that she was neither burned by the rebels nor captured by us, but that she has again escaped to sea. The story of her burning was based upon the fact that some vessel was seen afire in the harbor of Beaufort; but it has turned out that what was really on fire there was an old North Carolina bark: the story of her capture was predicated upon the theory that, as she had been seen by our soldiers to run out of the harbor of Beaufort, therefore she must necessarily have been caught by the blockading vessels which were watching for her. But the statement that she has escaped to sea has a firmer foundation than either of the others; for it comes direct from one of the blockading ships which she passed on her way out, and which, it seems, fired several ineffectual shots, with the hope of provoking a fight. The next, probably, that we shall hear of this audacious pirate will be, that, after coaling at some one of the West India Islands, she has crossed the seas and entered the harbor of Southampton, which she left on her way hither only a few weeks ago. Whether or not, by way of diversion, she will burn a few of our merchantmen on her passage across, and carry their crews in irons into an English port; and whether or not, on her return to Southern waters -- perhaps a few weeks hence -- she will bring a cargo of Enfield rifles and rifled cannon, to be used by the rebels at some new Newbern, a very short time will tell.

abstract: Mr. SPENCER'S appeal for "justice" to his clients, in the hearing before the City Judge yesterday, and for Sunday liquor selling generally, though it may have touched the sensibilities of the five hundred publicans present, had a very equivocal squint to outsiders.
lead_paragraph: Mr. SPENCER's appeal for "justice" to his clients, in the hearing before the City Judge yesterday, and for Sunday liquor selling generally, though it may have touched the sensibilities of the five hundred publicans present, had a very equivocal squint to outsiders. Poor injured innocents! Why should'nt a Judge sit up all night to keep the baleful "stars" from untimely or ungentle shining on your spirits? Why interfere with the social enjoyments of some ten thousand citizens' whose overflowing hospitality has a "latch. string out" for every comer, if he has a dime to spend? Why "decorate" policemen with citizen's dress, and suffer them to go where crime and drunkenness are bred, instead of keeping them in buttons, and on the chase for full-fledged criminals?

abstract: -- Seven months have elapsed since many hundreds of loyal lives were laid down on the fatal field near Manassas, and the bodies of the slain were hurried -- some (alas! that we have to write it!) with unchristian indignities -- into unhonored graves. The Winter winds have swept over their resting-place, far away from those they loved, and Spring grasses and flowers have begun to festoon those graves in the battle-field. The progress of events, meanwhile, has again given the nation possession of that locality so sadly interesting to many thousands, and the foot of affection is now for the first time able to make its pilgrimage to the resting-place of the lost. Since the sad privilege was accorded, several persons have availed themselves of the opportunity to disinter the remains of friends, and bring them home for sepulture in the soil they loved. The public is already informed of the recent exhumation of the bodies of Col. SLOCUM, Maj. BALLOU, and Capt. TOWER, three gallant soldiers of the Second Rhode Island Regiment. This sad duty was performed under the direction of their kind-hearted and sympathetic leader, Gov. SPRAGUE, who, with BURNSIDE, was with his men on the field of Bull Run, that fatal day; and the remains were yesterday received in this City with appropriate solemnities, and will lie in state at the Astor House until the hour of the funeral ceremonies to-day, when they will be taken for interment in Rhode Island and Connecticut. The private grief is for those near by kinship to the dead; but such marks of respect as a city may show, by the solemn procession, the dirge-music, and the flags at half-mast, will testify to the honor in which New-York holds all such, from whatever State, as fall in defence of the Republic.
