abstract: April
snippet: April
lead_paragraph: Harper's New Monthly, for April, just out, excels its predecessors for the year in many respects. The illustrated papers with which it opens are remarkably good. "Pambookat; A Fairy Tale of the Malays," is the first of these, and, with rich and tasteful illustration, gracefully romanticises the wonders of the steam-engine, the electric telegraph, the sewing-machine, chloroform, &c. "Caricature and Caricaturists," with its odd, quaint pictures, is a gem of criticism and research. "The Building of the Ship" is the third pictorial paper, and is alike valuable and interesting. Continuations of "Orley Farm," by ANTHONY TROLLOPE," "The Adventures of Philip," by THACKERAY, and of "Mistress and Maid," by Miss MULOCX, are prominent features. We are not of the number, however, who admire the nondescript cuts that accompany the former two productions. The original designs of our home artists are better in every particular. The latter are brighter, more graceful, more expressive, and infinitely less affected. The American drawings connected with "American History, Biography, Industry, Character and Scenery" afford positive relief after the contemplation of the sombre, blurred, slovenly or overstrained designs with which some of the latter English novels have been deformed. This very number of Harper's affords abundant proof of our assertion. Two or three good stories, such as "Calico and Chatterbox," "My Special Contributor," and as many excellent sketches, including "Camp Life at the Relay," "Shays' Rebellion," "Fitz-Greene Halleck," and "The Contest in America," an essay from Fraser's Magazine, by JOHN STUART MILL, with the ever-welcome Editor's Easy Chair, Drawer and Foreign Bureau, and the usual supplement of Monthly Fashions and Caricature, complete this acceptable number.

abstract: Yesterday afternoon, the bodies of Col. SLOCUM, Maj. BALLOU and Capt. TOWER, who fell at the battle of Bull Run, arrived in Jersey City at 2 o'clock. The remains of the gallant men were at once transferred to the three hearses that were in waiting, two of which were drawn by two, and the other by four horses. On arriving at this City, Company A, of the Seventy-first Regiment, under command of Capt. TOMPKINS, was in waiting to act as an escort to the Astor House, where the bodies will lie in state.

abstract: Editorial on reconstruction of state government in Tennessee
snippet: Editorial on reconstruction of state government in Tennessee
lead_paragraph: The last advices from Tennessee add to the number of able and prominent men who have intimated their readiness to cooperate with Gov. JOHNSON in reconstructing the State Government. We cannot vouch for the weight of authority upon which certain prominent names have been mentioned, but in nearly every instance we know that most, if not all, the antecedents of such gentlemen as BAILIE PEYTON,A.O.P. NICHOLSON, CAVE JOHNSON, WILLIAM B. CAMPBELL, WILLIAM H. POLK, and WILLIAM B. STOKES are in favor of the Union. Mr. NICHOLSON was the colleague of Mr. ANDREW JOHNSON in the United States Senate; a moderate, conservative man, opposed to Nullification, as propounded by Mr. CALHOUN, and to Southern rights, as urged by the South Carolina delegation in the Nashville Convention of 1850. He declined to return to the Senate, at the special Session in July, in deference to the action of the State Legislature in June, but took no active part in the rebellion. A Baltimore contemporary states that he has written a letter professing his cooperation with Gov. JOHNSON in the good work of restoring order and authority to the State Government, as part of the National Union. Ex-Gov. WILLIAM B. CAMPBELL was ready last Summer to oppose secession, but shrunk from the prominence which many of his Union friends desired to give him, because of the defection of BELL and HENRY and the EWINGS. In regard to the position of WILLIAM H. POLK, there has at no time been a serious doubt. He was among the first to escort JOHNSON to the capitol on his arrival at Nashville. Mr. STOKES is an Ex-Member of Congress, representing the Mountain or Upper Cumberland District of the State, in which Gov. CAMPBELL also resides. We have seen nothing direct from Mr. CAVE JOHNSON or Mr. PEYTON in reference to their cooperation with Gov. JOHNSON, but, as intimated above, their opposition to the whole secession movement is well understood, both at home and abroad.

abstract: -- The action of the District-Attorney, discharging MATTHEWS and IRELAND from arrest, left no case for Judge MCCUNN to adjudicate; and so his opportunity for embarrassing the Police in their praise worthy interference with Sunday dram-selling is lost. But a Judge whose zeal keeps him awake of nights, is not to be baulked thus. He procures the institution of proceedings before himself to vindicate his own dignity and, on the application of his own counsel issues an attachment for contempt of Court against the Captain of Police who waited till the light of day to make his return to a writ issued at midnight!
lead_paragraph: -- The action of the District-Attorney, discharging MATTHEWS and IRELAND from arrest, left no case for Judge MCCUNN to adjudicate; and so his opportunity for embarrassing the Police in their praise worthy interference with Sunday dram-selling is lost. He procures the institution of proceedings before himself to vindicate his own dignity and, on the application of his own counsel issues an attachment for contempt of Court against the Captain of Police who waited till the light of day to make his return to a writ issued at midnight!

abstract: Editorial on British views
snippet: Editorial on British views
lead_paragraph: A number of our columns we surrender this morning to a documentary history of the intrigues which begot the European expedition to Mexico. For this narrative we are indebted to the Parliamentary blue book recently submitted to the House of Commons; a source we are at pains to mention, because it fully authenticates the extraordinary story. A story most extraordinary indeed, and most interesting. Early in the Fall of last year, the Spanish Government gave official warning to the Cabinets of Franco and Great Britain of its intention to submit its claims upon Mexico to the adjudication of arms. At the same time it expressed an earnest desire to have the cooperation of the two Powers addressed, whose claims were even more important than those of Spain. The proposition was favorably entertained. But at the very outset the British Ministers demanded guarantees that the expedition should not be used to interfere with the domestic affairs of the peccant Republic. No pretence, Earl RUSSELL exacted, should be permitted to authorize the substitution of a new form of government for that created by the Mexicans themselves; or to use the language of his dispatch, he insisted upon a preliminary declaration by the combined Powers.

abstract: The regular soldiers who have been stationed on Bedroe's Island during the last six months, were transferred to Governor's Island yesterday, as we stated they would be, some time ago. These are part of the Texan soldiers surrendered by TWIGGS, and are now known as Company F, general service, and are commanded by Lieut. BROOME, of the Seventh infantry. They will be quartered in the garrison, Fort
lead_paragraph: The regular soldiers who have been stationed on Bedfoe's Island during the last six months, were transferred to Governor's Island yesterday, as we stated they would be, some time ago. These are part of the Texan soldiers surrendered by TWIGGS, and are now known as Company F, general service, and are commanded by Lieut. BROOME, of the Seventh Infantry. They will be quartered in the garrison, Fort Columbus. Bedloc's Island is now in possession of three companies of the Fifth New-York Volunteer Artillery. The only regular soldier left there is the Ordnance Sergeant.

abstract: ARREST A YOUNG FEMALE THIEF. -- A girl 16 years of age, named ELISA RILEY, was arrested last evening, on a charge of stealing about $50 worth of wearing apparel from Mrs. JAMES HOGAN, with whom she resided, at the corner of North Fifth and Grand streets. ELISA is one of the gang who have committing a large number of clothes-line robberies during the past year. At the last term of Court, five of them, JOHNSONS and RILEYS, were sent to the State Prison, and the accused and two other girls were sent to the country jail. When arrested, the girl had on a silk dress, shawl and other articles that she had stolen.

abstract: -- The Staats Zeitung of yesterday is quite communicative and jubilant. It informs its public -- without thinking, apparently, that any but Teutonic eyes would read -- that the bill for the suppression of the Concert-saloon brothels, is to "suffer very vital modifications," after the "practical social point of view" of the Zeitung, expressed in its former articles, i.e., so as to conform it to the superior morality of heathenish Greece and Rome, instead of the effete Christian code! It then quotes the proposed substitute, which Mr. MCMULLEN, of Brooklyn, is to introduce. The principal features of this substitute -- which the Zeitung informs us are already "recognized" by the members of the Legislature -- are monthly licenses for theatricals, etc., to be issued by the Police Commissioners, with Police surveillance, but no exclusion of "Pretty Waiter Girls," dram-selling, or any other abomination. "The law-makers," it says, "are convinced that many of the waiter-girls prefer a situation in a public place of amusement, for their own support and that of their relatives, to a more corrupt means of livelihood, like many of their sisters."

abstract: James M. Porter vs. James C. Willett, Sheriff, ?This was an action to recover the possession of a quantity of hardware, sold by the defendant in 1858, andor an execution against one Thomas Smith, of No. 258 Pearl-street, in this City.
lead_paragraph: James M. Porter vs. James C. Willett, Sheriff, &c. --This was an action to recover the possession of a quantity of hardware, sold by the defendant in 1858, andor an execution against one Thomas Smith, of No. 258 Pearl-street, in this City. The executions were issued in April and May, 1858. Appeals were taken from the judgments, and were pending until November, 1858, when they were affirmed. The defendant then sold the property under the executions. The plaintiff claimed title under an alleged purchase by him in January, 1858, on account of a previous debt due to him for borrowed money. The defence set up was that the business was carried on in the name of Smith until after the sale, and alleged that the bill of sale was either not made at the time alleged to have been, or if it was so made it was fraudulent as to the creditors of Smith.

abstract: If we are to believe the Richmond rebel authorities, Capt. PORTER will find it impossible to push his mortar fleet up the Mississippi to New-Orleans. Forts Jackson and St. Philip are represented as not only impregnable, but terribly destructive of any water craft that may attempt to pass under or by their guns.
lead_paragraph: If we are to believe the Richmond rebel authorities, Capt. PORTER will find it impossible to push his mortar fleet up the Mississippi to New-Orleans. Forts Jackson and St. Philip are represented as not only impregnable, but terribly destructive of any water craft that may attempt to pass under or by their guns. The forts are said to be manned by three thousand soldiers, many of them expert gunners, besides which a temporary dam has been thrown across the river, to overcome which will consume more time than would be required to blow the mortar fleet out of water. Curious enough the same authorities say little or nothing about the defences of the city against an attack from Lake Pontchartrain, which communication approaches within six miles in the rear, with a good road at one point directly into the City. The land attack by Gen. BUTLER, whenever attempted, will undoubtedly be made from this direction. The Southwest Pass, from the Gulf into the Mississippi, is 120 miles from New-Orleans. The latest advices represent Capt. PORTER as having taken this Pass. It remains to be told whether he will be able to encounter successfully the Forts Jackson and St. Philip.

abstract: If Mr. Secretary WELLES has sometimes been accused of being decidedly "slow," he has certainly just given a proof of something very like the opposite quality. At a time when the Fifteen Million Appropriation bill for iron-clad vessels was hanging fire in the Senate, he suddenly hurled a balista into that body in the shape of a demand for just double that amount for the self same purpose.
lead_paragraph: If Mr. Secretary WELLES has sometimes been accused of being decidedly "slow," he has certainly just given a proof of something very like the opposite quality. At a time when the Fifteen Million Appropriation bill for iron-clad vessels was hanging fire in the Senate, he suddenly hurled a balista into that body in the shape of a demand for just double that amount for the self same purpose. Whether Mr. WELLES thought Congress would show more alacrity in voting thirty millions than fifteen, we know not -, but the stroke had certainly the merit of being courageous. We publish, in another column, the communication of the Secretary to the Senate Naval Committee; it fully recognizes the revolution in naval warfare, made by the contest between the Merrimac and the Monitor, and embodies the deductions made by the Department from that event. These deductions, if not novel, are certainly sensible and practical; and the only fault we are disposed to find with the Secretary's stupendous scheme is that, while providing completely for future contingencies, it says nothing of our immediate needs. It is the promise of a splendid banquet next year to a man who must starve in the interim. Mr. WELLES asks an appropriation of a hundred thousand dollars "for targets and experimental practice;" but suppose, in the meanwhile, the rebels bring out the half dozen Merrimacs they have about ready, and make a "target" of our fleet and try "experimental practice" on our seaboard cities?

abstract: Charles F. Schmidt and Henry E. Schmidt vs. Philip Brasher. This action was brought by the plaintiffs, wine merchants, against the defendant, who is a broker in wines and liquors, to recover $500 dam-  ages for negligence in delivering to one W.D. Ingersoll five one-quarter casks of brandy, sold by defendant as broker, for account of the plaintiffs, for cash, without having first exacted the cost from Ingersoll.
lead_paragraph: Charles F. Schmidt and Henry E. Schmidt vs. Philip Brasher. -- This action was brought by the plaintiffs, wine merchants, against the defendant, who is a broker in wines and liquors, to recover $500 damages for negligence in delivering to one W.D. Ingersoll five one-quarter casks of brandy, sold by defendant as broker, for account of the plaintiffs, for cash, without having first exacted the cost from Ingersoll. It appeared on the part of the plaintiffs, that at the request of the defendant, they delivered to him the bill for the brandy, and an order upon the warehouseman to deliver the brandy to Ingersoll, and the defendant delivered to Ingersoll the order and bill, which was never paid. There was no claim that there was any fraud or collusion on the part of the defendant.

abstract: Wm. H. Williams vs. The Coney Island and Brooklyn Railroad Co., et al. -- This case was stated in the TIMES of the 27th. The action was to restrain the defendants from forfeiting a contract made with plaintiff, as alleged, whereby he agreed to lay the track, furnish cars and build stables for the Company. The plaintiff obtained an injunction and the defendants moved to dissolve it. The Court now decided as follows: The motion is granted, costs to abide event, unless plaintiff within thirty days completes his contract in all respects as required to be performed, by Sept. 15, 1861, except as to terminus of road as to Fifteenth-street, and as to both buildings for the Company, and unless he completes the terminus of the road within thirty days after right of way is obtained and served on him, and in Fifteenth-street within thirty days after grading.

abstract: -- An artist like Mme D'ANORI -- who made her rentre here last evening -is needed at intervals, (the shorter the better,) to teach our younger favorites how to sing. It is no injustice to the latter to say that, compared with her, we have had no singer worth mentioning for some years. In execution she is perfect, doing all that can be done in musical phraseology with an intelligence and grace which cannot be excelled. Her reception, last evening, was all that could be desired -- and the performance, on her part, left nothing to be wished for. The remaining distribution was good, but nearly all the artists seemed to be laboring under bronchial difficulties. Even Signor BRIGNOLI seemed to be under the weather. Signor MANCURI infused much spirit into the part of Figaro, but vocally he was hardly capable of doing full justice to himself. Signor SUSINI was, as usual, out of voice, and an incumbrance to the opera from beginning to end. The orchestra was under the direction of Mr. MAX MARETZEK, and acquitted itself excellently.

abstract: Twelve years ago, HENRY CLAY, speaking in the United States Senate, uttered the memorable words: "I say in my place, never will we, who occupy the broad waters of the Mississippi and its upper tributaries, consent that any foreign flag shall float at the Balize, or upon the turrets of the Crescent City ...
lead_paragraph: Twelve years ago, HENRY CLAY, speaking in the United States Senate, uttered the memorable words: "I say in my place, never will we, who occupy the broad waters of the Mississippi and its upper tributaries, consent that any foreign flag shall float at the Balize, or upon the turrets of the Crescent City -- never, NEVER!" It is over a year now since other flags than the Stars and Stripes -- the miserable three-barred bunting of rebellion, and the yellow Pelican rag -- were raised upon these turrets; and for all that time until now have they flaunted defiance in the face of the nation, and barred out from their heritage those who dwell on the upper tributaries of the father of waters. The time is now at hand, however, if it has not already arrived, when these alien emblems shall be torn down and made the winding-sheets for secession, to be replaced once more on Balize and turret by the flaming symbol of Union and Nationality.

abstract: FAIR FOR THE BENEFIT OF THE FIFTH-AVENUE BAPTIST CHURCH. The ladies of Dr. ARMITAGE'S Church, in Fifth-avenue, are now holding their second fair in the large hall No. 500 Broadway. A debt skill lingering over their church building is to be canceled, and they have thus far been encouraged in their labor by a generous patronage.
lead_paragraph: FAIR FOR THE BENEFIT OF THE FIFTH-AVENUE BAPTIST CHURCH. -- The ladies of Dr. ARMITAGE's Church, in Fifth-avenue, are now holding their second fair in the large hall No. 500 Broadway. A debt skill lingering over their church building is to be canceled, and they have thus far been encouraged in their labor by a generous patronage. The domestic and useful articles upon their tables are so blended with the more fanciful productions of taste as to render both doubly attractive. The "treasury" and "post-office" are enveloped in the most graceful disposition of our National colors, and inspire the patriotic visitors to a closer inspection of still greater charms which lurk half-concealed in their shadow. It is intended to close the fair on Monday, when some choice and expensive articles will be offered at a price far below their real value, while others, by generous contributors to a good cause, will be overrated. No raffling will take place.

abstract: We have a story by telegraph this morning, that a large force of the rebels is concentrating for a stand on the Rappahanock River -- perhaps at or near Fredericksburgh. The numbers are not given. The intelligence is altogether vague, and we deem it extremely questionable whether the "stand" referred to will actually be made. The Gulf State troops are not believed to be at or near Fredericksburgh, nor is it probable that they remained long, on their retreat from Manassas, at Gordonsville. A story more plausible than the one now referred to, is, that Gen. GUSTAVUS W. SMITH has gone to the Southwest with a large number of the regiments recently at Manassas. One rumor places the force under his command as high as 50,000, though like most other recent calculations of the rebel strength, this is probably an outside number. Assuming it to be any way near the truth, the movement to the line of the Mississippi would leave Gen. JOSEPH E. JOHNSTON in command only of the Virginia forces proper, and it is extremely doubtful whether these will be concentrated in sufficient numbers at any one point between Washington and Richmond, or Fortress Monroe and Richmond, to give formidable battle to the advancing columns of MCCLELLAN. The fight at Winchester was an accident, -- not a deliberate stand by the rebel general, and whatever other fights may take place this side of Richmond will probably be from a similar cause.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, among the petitions presented was one from citizens of New-Jersey, against further traftic and monopoly in the public lands.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, among the petitions presented was one from citizens of New-Jersey, against further traftic and monopoly in the public lands. A bill from the Committee on Pensions, to prevent the allowance of pensions to the widows and children of revolutionary soldiers, unless their claims were established, was passed. A motion was made by Mr. GRIMES, of Iowa, to take up the resolution declaring that no more Brigadier-Generals shall be appointed, unless for gallantry in action, but it was negatived after considerable debate. The bill remitting the duties on arms imported by States was passed. The Naval Appropriation bill was then taken up, the question being on inserting an appropriation for finishing the Stevens Battery. After a long debate, the amendment offered by Mr. SHERMAN, of Ohio, to the effect that Mr. STEVENS shall not be repaid the money expended by him unless the vessel shall prove successful, was adopted. A further amendment, that the money appropriated shall not be paid unless the Secretary of the Navy is of opinion that the vessel will be efficient, was adopted. An appropriation of $13,000,000 for iron-clad vessels, and another of $25,000 for casting heavy ordnance at the Washington Navy-yard, were added, and the bill finally passed. The Senate then adjourned until Monday.

abstract: It is so rarely of late that we have had the pleasure of agreeing with the London Times upon affairs and events in this country, that we shall not allow the first notable opportunity of doing so to pass unheeded.
lead_paragraph: It is so rarely of late that we have had the pleasure of agreeing with the London Times upon affairs and events in this country, that we shall not allow the first notable opportunity of doing so to pass unheeded. In its number of March 10, the leading British journal remarks that if Americans "can find time carefully to consider the debate in the House of Commons provoked by Mr. GREGORY's motion of Friday last, they will find many things to excite their wonder, and some that might lay claim even to their admiration." That debate -- given in full in our columns -- with the comments which we thought its importance demanded, cannot have failed to awaken in our readers, to a great degree, at least, the emotions which our London cotemporary supposed it would. But we are quite as sure that they, with us, would transpose and slightly modify the terms of the proposition which we have quoted, and say that this debate was the occasion to them of much more admiration that surprise. There was nothing in it to excite our wonder, though we were somewhat surprised to see such few and feeble efforts made in support of Mr. GREGORY's very clever and adroit statement of his untenable case, and so calm, decided, and vigorous a tone, in the speakers who led the overwhelming opposition to his motion. We looked for a fiercer onslaught and a more apologetic defence. We expected the cry, "Down with the blockade," to rise from a chorus of voices, and the answer to be, "Wait." On the contrary, the demand came in the form of almost isolated audacity; and the reply is that of a rebuke: "The blockade is one which the honor and the interest of Great Britain alike demand that we should respect. The proposition of the member for Galway is both injurious and indecorous."

abstract: Private advices from London, of the 15th inst., state that Mr. FIELD, with other leading gentlemen and capitalists, interested in the Atlantic Telegraph Cable enterprise, were to meet Lord PALMERSTON at noon on the 21st inst., and that the prospect of a satisfactory termination of negotiations with the Government, in regard to raising the necessary capital to secure the proposed new cable, were very encouraging. Mr. FIELD confidently expected to return to New-York at an early day, with assurances of the earnest cooperation of the British Government in the great undertaking which he has so long and ably endeavored to bring to a successful issue.

abstract: The citizens of St. Louis have just had made for them a handsome sword, which they intend presenting to Major-Gen. FREMONT. It is a magnificent affair, and cost upward of a thousand dollars. The blade is of the finest Damascus manufacture, chased in gilt, and bears the Latin word Vero. The scabbard is a heavy one, of sterling silver, finely gilded. The terminating and lower bands of the scabbard represent oak leaves. The upper band is very heavy and rich in appearance; the top part of it represents a casque, with plumes, battle-axes, spears and lanceheads, on the obverse. In the centre, in relief, is a "three-fourth" miniature bust of Gen. FREMONT, in solid gold. This miniature is inclosed in an oval of small diamonds. On each side is a figure of Fame, with trumpet. At the bottom, pendant wreaths of oak-leaves reach to the other side, and there enfold a Roman sword. The hilt is heavy and all gilt. The "grip," or handle, has a niche at the back, in which stands a statuette, four inches in height, of America crushing the rebellion. The figure is a female formed of oxydized silver. In her right hand she holds a sword, the point of which is in the mouth of a dragon at her feet. Back of this figure, and on the guard -- where the guard curves over the scabbard -- is an oval medallion, in blue enamel, bearing Gen. FREMONT's initials, (J.C.F.,) in small diamonds. The letters are scrip capitals. This medallion is also supported by two figures of Fame. On the crest or head of the "grip" is a bust of Medusa, in oxydized silver. The guard is wreathed with oak leaves, and secured by a garter or band.
lead_paragraph: The citizens of St. Louis have just had made for them a handsome sword, which they intend presenting to Major-Gen. FREMONT. It is a magnificent affair, and cost upward of a thousand dollars. The blade is of the finest Damascus manufacture, chased in gilt, and bears the Latin word Vero. The scabbard is a heavy one, of sterling silver, finely gilded. The terminating and lower bands of the scabbard represent oak leaves. The upper band is very heavy and rich in appearance; the top part of it represents a casque, with plumes, battle-axes, spears and lanceheads, on the obverse. In the centre, in relief, is a "three-fourth" miniature bust of Gen. FREMONT, in solid gold. This miniature is inclosed in an oval of small diamonds. On each side is a figure of Fame, with trumpet. At the bottom, pendant wreaths of oak-leaves reach to the other side, and there enfold a Roman sword. The hilt is heavy and all gilt. The "grip," or handle, has a niche at the back, in which stands a statuette, four inches in height, of America crushing the rebellion. The figure is a female formed of oxydized silver. In her right hand she holds a sword, the point of which is in the mouth of a dragon at her feet. Back of this figure, and on the guard -- where the guard curves over the scabbard -- is an oval medallion, in blue enamel, bearing Gen. FREMONT's initials, (J.C.F.,) in small diamonds. The letters are scrip capitals. This medallion is also supported by two figures of Fame. On the crest or head of the "grip" is a bust of Medusa, in oxydized silver. The guard is wreathed with oak leaves, and secured by a garter or band.

abstract: The Assembly has ordered the Metropolitan Health bill to a third reading. If any doubt dwells in the minds of the majority as to the propriety of passing it, we suggest one of those comprehensive legislative visits to the City, not uncommon in other years. New-York will be found engulfed in an ocean of dust, whirled higher than the chimney tops by March winds. All the filth, which HACKLEY has been paid for removing and did not remove, has left the grub condition of mud, and takes broad flights in the air on the wings of the wind. No chemical analysis can separate or describe the vile constituents of this slime, which having tramped through all Winter, we now draw into our lungs, and involuntarily clothe ourselves with as with a garment. What pulmonic and miasmatic diseases must go with these inspired impurities, what but the tables of mortality shall tell? And yet we have a City Inspector, Health Officers, Hackleys, paid salaries, and steady drafts on the Chamberlain; all the frame-work and much of the filling-in, in fact, of machinery for the protection of the public, and yet the public is as unprotected as if all these mercies had not been vouchsafed. With the actual system it might be possible to have civic cleanliness and health, had we true men to enforce it. But not having these, we want a system which shall insure efficiency, and give us honest administrators. So let the Health bill pass.

abstract: The notorious female slaver, who was driven from this her native City, last Summer, owing to the action of the United States authorities in respect to those engaged in the Slave-trade, died recently in Cadiz, Spain, under circumstances of the most melancholy character. At the time she left this City, three charges were brought against her.
lead_paragraph: the notorious female slaver, who was driven from this her native City, last Summer, owing to the action of the United States authorities in respect to those engaged in the Slave-trade, died recently in Cadiz, Spain, under circumstances of the most melancholy character. At the time she left this City, three charges were brought against her. She was found to have been engaged in fitting out three vessels for the Slave-trade, and indictments to that effect were found by the Grand Jury. She made her escape very suddenly, when she found the evidence was accumulating against her. Information received by the last steamer states that she, having heard of the failure of her vessels on this side; that three indictments were hanging over her here; and that the registers of three vessels which she had chartered in Cadiz for the same business, had been withdrawn by the Consul, it is believed that she fell back into some of the bad habits which she had contracted while pursuing her masculine business in New-York, and soon terminated her existence by the bottle. Mrs. WATSON's maiden name was MARY JANE LACKEY. She was born in Frankfort, between William and Gold streets. She was divorced from her husband several years ago, and with the exception of a brother, who is a very respectable official of this City, she had no relatives in this country.

abstract: Since the question of introducing military drill as a regular exercise in our public schools has acquired new importance from the bill now pending in the State Legislature, it may be interesting to many to know how far the plan has already been tested, and with what results.
lead_paragraph: Since the question of introducing military drill as a regular exercise in our public schools has acquired new importance from the bill now pending in the State Legislature, it may be interesting to many to know how far the plan has already been tested, and with what results. We have recently had a most satisfactory exhibition of a private military academy, but it must be remembered that the Public Schools differ from such, in that they are composed of all classes of social condition, and in far greater numbers. It becomes necessary, therefore, to select from among these such boys as display aptitude for the stricter disciplines of military tactics. This has been done in two, at least, of our first-class schools, and in one it has been carried to a great degree of perfection, so that the youthful company of cadets can bear comparison with the best trained bodies of private academies. They belong to School No. 10, in Wooster-st., and form daily in the large covered area attached to the school, or in pleasant weather they repair to a neighboring park, and go through their manoeuvres, to the high satisfaction of the crowd which so novel a sight usually collects. These little fellows bear proudly aloft their rich silken banners, engraven with their title in letters of gold, "Robinson Zouaves," which is in honor of their instructor, who himself is a soldier of long practical experience, having shared the perils of glorious war during the entire Mexican campaign.

abstract: Editorial on British views of blockade
snippet: Editorial on British views of blockade
lead_paragraph: Mr. GREGORY, in his speech on the blockade, in Parliament, spoke affectionately of the "many humane, benevolent and far-sighted men in the Northern States, who were anxious for a peaceable separation," to whom he had been in hopes that "great moral weight" would be given by the recognition of the Southern Confederacy on the part of England and France; and the London Times, echoing the thought, says that "the best people in the States, and the wisest people here, all look to an amicable separation as the only possible solution of the difficulty, and the only way to heal the breach of feeling." As to who are the wisest people in England we, of course, would not pretend to dispute with the London Times; and if it says that those are the wisest people there who hold such notions, we must accept it as good authority. But we do not accept with equal submission its decision as to who are "the best people in the States." Indeed we are a little at a loss to identify the persons of whom the Times speaks, unless it means JEFF. DAVIS and his fellow traitors. They doubtless "look to a peaceable separation as the only possible solution of the difficulty," although we are inclined to think that Roanoke, and Donelson, and Pea Ridge, and Newborn, and Winchester may have thrown a haze over their bright visions, so that they do not look forward to it quite as confidently as they did. But even they do not look forward to any such thing as likely to "heal the breach of feeling," or at least none of them expresses any such thing. Undying hostility to the Yankees is their vow, whether successful or victorious.

abstract: Rev. Dr. BELLOWS lectured at Irving Hall last evening, on the "Field of Manassas," as viewed by himself at a visit on the 12th, 13th and 14th inst. The Doctor had quite a collection of trophies from the field, which, with the utmost nonchalance, he arranged on the stage in the presence of the audience, remarking that one of the lessons learned at Manassas was to wait upon one's self.
lead_paragraph: Rev. Dr. BELLOWS lectured at Irving Hall last evening, on the "Field of Manassas," as viewed by himself at a visit on the 12th, 13th and 14th inst. The Doctor had quite a collection of trophies from the field, which, with the utmost nonchalance, he arranged on the stage in the presence of the audience, remarking that one of the lessons learned at Manassas was to wait upon one's self. After a humorous reference to the correspondents and their remarkable stories, he said he would tell what he saw. The correspondents put what they saw and heard of in the same paragraph, without labelling each. [Laughter.] His narrative was compiled for the perusal of his family, and was read with but a slight company dress. He described the preparations for the journey, and his enjoyment in riding seventy-five miles on a McClellan saddle, the inspiriting appearance of the moving Union army. He did not see any of the log guns or "quaker guns." He hoped that those guns really had existed, for else there would be an enormous amount of lying for some one to answer for.

abstract: -- The letter of Secretary WELLES, written by direction of the President to Lieut. WORDEN, which we published yesterday, is a well-merited tribute to the gallantry displayed by that officer in the memorable conflict between the Merrimac and Monitor. But we think it due to his heroic services and his heroic suffering, that they should receive something more than mere barren gratitude. We learn, through a private source, that the injuries received by Lieut. WORDEN during the engagement, had well nigh terminated fatally, but the public will gladly hear that all such apprehensions are now relieved. Meantime there are, we believe, thousands who feel that such services and sufferings as his, impose a duty on them, and who would heartily express their sympathy in a practical form, should a fitting opening present itself.

Being aware that we cannot change the minds or alter the plans or our planting readers, we will state a few facts for their consideration.

abstract: Editorial on some railroads efforts to get roads built at US Government expense on pretext it is military necessity
snippet: Editorial on some railroads efforts to get roads built at US Government expense on pretext it is military necessity
lead_paragraph: There is a tremendous effort in progress at Washington, to saddle upon the Government the enormous cost of constructing useless and unprofitable railroads for the benefit of land and shareholders -- railroads which the sections interested do not build, simply because they are not wanted! The pretext is military necessity, and the test scheme is the Reading and Columbia road, to be built over the mountain-tops of Pennsylvania for the purpose of shortening the good inland route already built from New-York to Washington, twenty-five, or as is claimed, thirty miles. We fully exposed the character of this scheme, a day or two since. We stated that the road would cross mountain ridges, at grades of ninety feet to the mile, while the present road passes along the Lebanon valley; and that if one company owned both lines, they would work the long and level one, and abandon the steep one the Government is requested to build, on the score of economy of power and repairs. A correspondent denies these facts, and makes the following remarkable statement.
headline: {'main': 'The Railroad Job in Congress.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Railroad Job in Congress.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Editorial on progress and prospects of spring campaign
snippet: Editorial on progress and prospects of spring campaign
lead_paragraph: The Winter campaign closed with definite and brilliant military successes on the Southern seaboard and in the Southwestern States and the Spring campaign opened under the most favorable auspices, which have been fully justified by the remarkable events of the current month. But we believe that, great and valuable though the triumphs be that have been achieved in Arkansas, Tennessee, Virginia, North Carolina and Florida, and important though the operations be that are on the eve of consummation at the mouth of the Mississippi and on its upper waters, these are but the prelude to the decisive movements about to be begun upon the two main lines of military action.

abstract: Henry S. Scudder vs. R.B. Yond. This was an action to recover the sum of $259 for goods sold to one William J. Marshall, the payment of which, as alleged, was guaranteed by the defendant. The complaint alleged that the plaintiff trusted Marshall at the special request of the defendant, upon his guaranty that he would pay for the goods in the event of non-payment by Marshall.
lead_paragraph: Henry S. Scudder vs. R.B. Yond. -- This was an action to recover the sum of $259 for goods sold to one William J. Marshall, the payment of which, as alleged, was guaranteed by the defendant. The complaint alleged that the plaintiff trusted Marshall at the special request of the defendant, upon his guaranty that he would pay for the goods in the event of non-payment by Marshall. It is also alleged that plaintiff requested payment of Marshall, and that before the commencement of this action, notice was given of the failure on the part of Marshall to pay, and a demand of the defendant was made.

abstract: PHILADELPHIA, Saturday, March 29. JACKSON'S pyrotechnic factory, on Tenth and Reed streets, exploded early this morning. Four or  five persons were killed, including a son of Mr. JACKSON. The head of one of the victims was blown nearly two squares, and various fragments of humanity were scattered about the ruins, presenting a most shocking sight. Ten or twelve others, boys and girls, were seriously injured.

abstract: A MAN WITH TWO WIVES. Officer VAN ARSDALE, of the Third Precinct, brought before Justice STEERS, yesterday, a man named CHARLES II. FLEMING, upon the charge of bigamy. From the testimoney elicited upon the examination, it appears that the accused was married to a Miss BUTT, on the 21st of December last. His lawful wife, Mrs. ROWENA FLEMING was at that time living in this City.
lead_paragraph: A MAN WITH TWO WIVES. -- Officer VAN ARSDALE, of the Third Precinct, brought before Justice STEERS, yesterday, a man named CHARLES H. FLEMING, upon the charge of bigamy. From the testimony elicited upon the examination, it appears that the accused was married to a Miss BUTT, on the 21st of December last. His lawful wife, Mrs. ROWENA FLEMING, was at that time living in this City. Since his latter marriage he has lived with his new wife until a few days since, when she, by some means, became satisfied that hehad another wife living, whose rights were paramount to hers. She charged him with the crime, but he stoutly and persistently denied it. Her fears were [???] allayed to some extent, until the first wife was discovered, when measures were taken for his arrest. When brought before the Court and confronted by his two wives, he emphatically denied all knowledge of wife No. 1, but admitted that he was married to Miss BUTT last December, and insisted that the latter was his legal and only wife. The testimony of the clergyman who officiated at the marriage between him and wife No. 1, induced the Court to think otherwise. The clergyman who performed the ceremony at the second marriage, was also present, and testified that the prisoner was married by him to Miss BUTT, at the time above mentioned. FLEMING is said to be a man of means, and he insists that this prosecution is a conspiracy to defraud him of his money. The Justice held him in $2,000 bail, to answer the charge of bigamy.

abstract: I have but very few words to say in reply to the honorable gentleman from Clinton; but I should not feel that I had quite fulfilled my duty if I did not say something. I confess that I am to a certain degree disappointed in what I have just heard. I had missed my friend from his accustomed haunts for some days past, and my sympathies had been seriously excited, for I supposed that he was suffering from physical illness. I am pleased to find, however, that he has been laboring under nothing more than a superfluity of patriotism bile. I am very sorry to find that I have done anything to disturb his political digestion, -- but I congratulate him upon having obtained relief by the speech he has just made. I receive, with the utmost cheerfulness, whatever stings those remarks were intended to convey, believing that he may feel as much better as I shall feel worse, for his having made them. I had no intention, in my remarks a few days since, he say one word or one syllable which the greatest conceivable ingenuity, or the most morbid sensitiveness, could construct as unkind to the gentleman from Clinton. When I alluded to the locality he so [???] represents upon this floor, and spoke of the influence which the associations of that locality exerted upon him, in [???] his position and determining his action with reference to this bill. I had no more thought of reproducing him, than if I had spoken of his being an American as a reason for the position he holds. When I referred to the fact that his home was upon a soil consecrated by many victories, and specially pledged by its glorious history to the support of our country's cause. I spoke of this simply as a reason why he should be secured for being even excessively patriotic and [???] in relation to every measure relating to the nation's welfare. I repudiate, and with any apology that the facts as they have appeared may demand, any intention of conveying, by word or tone, anything that should be deemed a sarcasm. I had no such thought or purpose.

I am very sorry to find that I have done anything to disturb his political digestion, -- but I congratulate him upon having obtained relief by the speech he has just made. I receive, with the utmost cheerfulness, whatever stings those remarks were intended to convey, believing that he may feel as much better as I shall feel worse, for his having made them. I had no intention, in my remarks a few days since, he say one word or one syllable which the greatest conceivable ingenuity, or the most morbid sensitiveness, could construct as unkind to the gentleman from Clinton. When I alluded to the locality he so [???] represents upon this floor, and spoke of the influence which the associations of that locality exerted upon him, in [???] his position and determining his action with reference to this bill. I had no more thought of reproducing him, than if I had spoken of his being an American as a reason for the position he holds. When I referred to the fact that his home was upon a soil consecrated by many victories, and specially pledged by its glorious history to the support of our country's cause. I spoke of this simply as a reason why he should be secured for being even excessively patriotic and [???] in relation to every measure relating to the nation's welfare. I repudiate, and with any apology that the facts as they have appeared may demand, any intention of conveying, by word or tone, anything that should be deemed a sarcasm. I had no such thought or purpose.

abstract: While for many months the Red Slayer has been doing his dread work on the field of battle, and we have grown familiar with the black bulletins war, the country has been notably free from the great calamities incident to the ordinary operations of the complex machinery of modern civilization.
lead_paragraph: While for many months the Red Slayer has been doing his dread work on the field of battle, and we have grown familiar with the black bulletins war, the country has been notably free from the great calamities incident to the ordinary operations of the complex machinery of modern civilization. Comparatively few fatal accidents in the mine, in the factory, by shipwreck, by fire, by railroad mishap, have come to add their peculiar horrors to the death-harvest of battle. But the disaster in a sister city, whose details we are called on to record to-day, make a distressing exception to this happy immunity. A pyrotechnic factory in Philadelphia, which has lately been filling a Government contract for cartridges, and employed in the work fifty girls and twenty-four men, exploded early yesterday morning, killing five or more persons, (the full extent of the fatality is not yet known,) and wounding nearly fifty others -- men, girls and boys. As no cause is assigned for the explosion, we know not as yet upon whose head falls the fearful responsibility of the catastrophe whose sickening horrors the telegram recounts. If blame in any way attaches to the proprietor himself, he is already fearfully punished, a son of his being killed and a daughter seriously injured. We shall await with a painful interest the disclosure of the origin of this sad calamity, which carries mourning to many, many households, and must shroud our sister city with gloom.

abstract: JACKALOW, the Chinaman, who was arrested near Jersey City, in March, 1860, charged with having murdered Capt. LEETE and brother, of the sloop Spray, belong to Guilford, Conn., is finally about to expiate his crime upon the gallows. He was tried at Trenton, and convicted of robbery on the high sees. The case was appealed, on the ground that the crime was committed within the jurisdiction of the State of New-York. The case was argued at the Supreme Court of the United States, at Washington, about two weeks since. From the decision of the Court, which has just been rendered, it appears that Long Island Sound being a part of the "high seas," the State of New-York has no jurisdiction over its waters, and, therefore, all crimes committed on it comes within the jurisdiction of the United States Court. Accordingly, on Friday, JACKALOW was removed from the Mount Holy Jail, in Burlington County, to Tronton, for sentence. He appears in excellent spirits, and manifests no concern whatever in relation to his approaching fate. The bodies of the LEETES were never recovered, consequently JACKALOW could only be convicted of robbery, in stealing clothing, watch, and other articles belonging to the victims. He had also $700 in gold, undoubtedly the proceeds of the sloop load of produce brought to New-York.

abstract: A recent letter from Egypt to a Boston cotemporary gives an interesting account of an interview had by the writer with Mr. BUCKLE, the distinguished author of the History of Civilization in England, who is now temporarily sojourning for health in the mystic land of the Pyramids. From this source we learn that it is the intention of Mr. BUCKLE soon to pay a visit to the United States.
lead_paragraph: A recent letter from Egypt to a Boston cotemporary gives an interesting account of an interview had by the writer with Mr. BUCKLE, the distinguished author of the History of Civilization in England, who is now temporarily sojourning for health in the mystic land of the Pyramids. From this source we learn that it is the intention of Mr. BUCKLE soon to pay a visit to the United States. As the next (which will be the third) volume of his magnum opus is to be wholly occupied with a study of certain elements of civilization, as developed in Germany and the United States, he comes doubtless with the design of making a personal observation of American institutions, manners, and intellect.

abstract: -- When it became obvious to the rebel Chiefs that there was no hope of recognition from England or France, they suddenly developed an amazing affection for Spain, which they lovingly styled their "natural ally." About the same time, the occupation of the three Commissioners in London was cut off, by Earl RUSSELL's telling them he could have no further intercourse with them; so one of them, Judge ROST, immediately prepared to betake himself to the Spanish Court to convince that Government of the pacific, amicable and unambitious intentions of the Southern Confederacy. It appears, however, that he has been snubbed in advance. A dispatch dated Madrid, March 12, to the London Times, says the Government "has decided not to receive Mr. ROST, the Commissioner from the Confederate States of America." For a "natural ally," this is certainly not over friendly treatment. Where will the rebel Government apply next? We don't see any place this side of Dahomey. That is their only "natural ally," and the Richmond usurpers should hasten to send thither all the plenipotentiaries they can spare.
lead_paragraph: -- When it became obvious to the rebel Chiefs that there was no hope of recognition from England or France, they suddenly developed an amazing affection for Spain, which they lovingly styled their "natural ally." About the same time, the occupation of the three Commissioners in London was cut off, by Earl RUSSELL's telling them he could have no further intercourse with them; so one of them, Judge ROST, immediately prepared to betake himself to the Spanish Court to convince that Government of the pacific, amicable and unambitious intentions of the Southern Confederacy. It appears, however, that he has been snubbed in advance. A dispatch dated Madrid, March 12, to the London Times, says the Government "has decided not to receive Mr. ROST, the Commissioner from the Confederate States of America." For a "natural ally," this is certainly not over friendly treatment. Where will the rebel Government apply next? We don't see any place this side of Dahomey. That is their only "natural ally," and the Richmond usurpers should hasten to send thither all the plenipotentiaries they can spare.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a favorable report was made on the bill to amend the law relative to taking the testimony of witnesses out of the State; also on the bill to authorize clerks of Boards of  Excise to take affidavits in certain cases. A bill to encourage investments of small sums in the stocks of the State was introduced.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, a favorable report was made on the bill to amend the law relative to taking the testimony of witnesses out of the State; also on the bill to authorize clerks of Boards of Excise to take affidavits in certain cases. A bill to encourage investments of small sums in the stocks of the State was introduced. It provides that certificates may be in sums of $100, $500 or $1,000 each, as may be desired. The bill to enable the County of Westchester to acquire certain lands for the construction of the Harlem Bridge was passed. A concurrent resolution for the organization of a Commission of five persons to act as referees for the Court of Appeals was introduced, and laid over. The resolution approving the President's Message relative to emancipation, was made the special order for Wednesday evening.

abstract: It is reported from Washington that the prospects of getting a submarine inter-continental telegraph cable in operation before very long are encouraging. Mr. CYRUS FIELD, whose name is traditionally associated with this great project, went to England bearing a dispatch from Mr. SEWARD to Mr. ADAMS, to the effect that the United States Government is prepared to ask Congress to guarantee two per cent. upon...
lead_paragraph: It is reported from Washington that the prospects of getting a submarine inter-continental telegraph cable in operation before very long are encouraging. Mr. CYRUS FIELD, whose name is traditionally associated with this great project, went to England bearing a dispatch from Mr. SEWARD to Mr. ADAMS, to the effect that the United States Government is prepared to ask Congress to guarantee two per cent. upon a capital of three or three and a half million dollars for twenty or twenty-five years, if England will do the same. Mr. FIELD was to have had an interview with Lord PALMERSTON on the 21st instant; and was, we learn, hopeful that the interview would result favorably to his project. The experience during the Trent imbroglio will probably make the British Government all the more desirous of establishing communication between the two hemispheres. That little affair bled John Bull to the amount of a cool four millions sterling, besides indefinite private losses, all of which would have been avoided had the Atlantic Telegraph been in operation. It will be odd if we have hereafter to trace the realization of this great world-enterprise to the episode of MASON and SLIDELL.

abstract: The mild and beneficent oversight which John Bull maintains over American concerns must surely add strength to the ties which shall hereafter bind the entente cordiale. The truth is, our Government is too preoccupied at home to give that minute attention to the loose ends of international law, which disquiet the tranquil half of minkind.
lead_paragraph: The mild and beneficent oversight which John Bull maintains over American concerns must surely add strength to the ties which shall hereafter bind the entente cordiale. The truth is, our Government is too preoccupied at home to give that minute attention to the loose ends of international law, which disquiet the tranquil half of minkind. A little business in Morcoco is an example. Not long ago a British steamer, bound from Lisbon to Cadiz, called at Tangiers. Among its passengers were the purser of the rebel pirate, the Sumter, and the ex-Consul at Cadiz, a noted sympathiser with rebellion. These two gentlemen landed by way of stretching their legs and indulging an intelligent curiosity, but before they could reach the ship on their return, were arrested by the United States Consul, and thrown into prison. The arrest caused a serious commotion among the European residents. They held meetings and organized a plan for releasing the captives by force. At this moment the United States sloop Ino arrived in port. Our Consul determined to place his prisoners on board; the foreign population banded to prevent him by force and arms. Appealing to the faith of treaties, the Consul called upon the Moorish authorities to preserve public order, and protect him in the transfer; and after some hesitation, in the course of which the Consul threatened to haul down his flag and retire, if his demand were not complied with the military escort was afforded, and the captives embarked. The Ino sailed at once for the United States.
headline: {'main': 'A Trifling Matter at Tangiers.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'A Trifling Matter at Tangiers.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: FATAL ACCIDENT ON THE THIRD-AVENUE RAILROAD. A boy, names LOUIS LINDENBERGER, aged about four years, was run over by car No. 79 on the Thirdavenue Railroad, on Wednesday last, and injured so seriously that he died on Saturday. Coroner NAUMANN held an inquest upon the body yesterday.
lead_paragraph: FATAL ACCIDENT ON THE THIRD-AVENUE RAILROAD. -- A boy, names LOUIS LINDENBERGER, aged about four years, was run over by car No. 79 on the Third-avenue Railroad, on Wednesday last, and injured so seriously that he died on Saturday. Coroner NAUMANN held an inquest upon the body yesterday. The jury rendered the following verdict: "We find that the deceased came to his death from injuries from being run over by a Third-avenue Railroad car. The jury believe the accident to have been unavoidable, and exonerate the driver of the car from all blame."

abstract: Mr. GRAU'S short season of Italian Opera came to an end with the matinee on Saturday, when "Lucia di Lammermoor" was played to a good and fashionable house. This opera was substituted at the last moment for "Linda di Chamounix," which, much to the disappointment of the frequenters who desired to see Mme.
lead_paragraph: D'ANGBI in a goodcontralto role, could not be performed in consequence of the indisposition of Signor SUSINI. In common with other journals, we have remarked the waning powers of the basso, and whilst we sympathize with him in his affliction, rejoice that they can be traced to a merely accidental cause. Mme. D'ANGBI could not, of course, play the hurdy-gurdy in "Lucia," and was therefore compelled to sing between the acts, selecting for that purpose pieces that were dazzling in their brilliancy and perfect in their execution. The lady's reception was perfect. Of "Lucia," it is only necessary to say that the singers did all that could be expected under the circumstances. Signor BRIGNOLI, who, during the past week, has surprised all his old admirers by the good condition of his voice and will, sang admirably, especially in the elegiac closing of the opera. Miss KELLOGG and Signor MANCUSI were also in the cast.

abstract: ESCAPE OF A CONVICT. -- A convict, named JAS. GUTHRIE, who was serving a term in the State Prison, at Trenton, N.J., succeeded in making his escape on Saturday night. He is a Scotchman, 49 years of age, 5 feet 3 inches in height, brown hair, blue eyes, low forehead, dark complexion and slender-built. He has an anchor in blue India-ink on the back of his right hand, a figure of a ship on the right arm, below the elbow, and a scar inside of his arm. A reward of $75 has been offered for the arrest of GUTHRIE by Mr. HOAGLAND, keeper of the prison.

abstract: By the arrival at this port of the steamship New-York; we have advices from Europe three days later than by the China. She left Southampton on the 19th inst., and brings London journals of that date. The news is not specially important.
lead_paragraph: By the arrival at this port of the steamship New-York, we have advices from Europe three days later than by the China. She left Southampton on the 19th inst., and brings London journals of that date. The news is not specially important. A continuation of the debate on international maritime rights had taken place in the House of Commons, in which Mr. LINDSAY, Lord PALMERSTON, Mr. MASSEY, Mr. BRIGHT, and several other members took part. Mr. LAYARD had made a statement in the House of Commons, in reference to the recent arrest of rebels in Morocco, from which it appears that they were not released, as before reported, but were conveyed on board a United States vessel, and were supposed to be on their way to the United States. Mr. LAYARD expressed the hope that the President would order the release of the prisoners. No change of importance had taken place in financial or commercial matters.

abstract: editorial speculates on future uses for ship; Dispatches from Washington; editorial on new notes being readied for use; editorial on new notes of circulation being readied for use
snippet: editorial speculates on future uses for ship; Dispatches from Washington; editorial on new notes being readied for use; editorial on new notes of circulation being readied for use
lead_paragraph: The Bank Note Companies of this City are understood to have completed the engraved plates for the new Notes of the United States for Circulation as lawful money, under the act of 25th of February. The work of printing the Notes began at the close of last week, and will go on rapidly until the entire $150,000,000, authorized by the act, is prepared for circulation. Of this amount, $60,000,000 will be reserved to take the place of the existing issue of July 17 and Feb. 12, as the same is gradually withdrawn from circulation and the new issue substituted. The reason for this change is, that the present United States Notes are made receivable, on their face, for all public dues, including the customs from foreign merchandise now specifically pledged to the prompt payment of the public interest, and a yearly contribution to the sinking fund. As this interest is pledged to be paid exclusively in Gold, and will be so paid, at whatever cost to the Government, provision has been made that the customs duties shall also be paid in Gold. There would be an inconsistency, therefore, in continuing the circulation of the United States Notes of the old issue, to the prejudice of this provision, any longer than the substitution of the new Notes can be effected without inconvenience to the public or the Treasury Department. When the change is completed by the entire withdrawal of the existing issue, the National circulation of $150,000,000 will be uniform in all its offices, being lawful money in the payment of all debts, public and private, by and to all corporations and individuals throughout the country, the same as gold and silver coin is a uniform legal tender. It is also made lawful money in all payments, by and to the Government of the United States, other than the payment of interest on the public debt, by the United States, and in payment for customs to the United States -- the latter being specifically pledged for the former to be paid exclusively in gold coin.

abstract: Gen. SHERMAN visited Jacksonville, Florida, in person on Wednesday evening last, 19th inst. A committee of the loyal citizens immediately waited on him and represented the feelings of all who remained in the town to be strongly loyal. The next morning a Union meeting was held at the Court- house, where nearly every man left in Jacksonville was present, and the manifestation was of the most decidedly loyal character.

abstract: The early train from Baltimore, yesterday, brought to this city 91 contrabands from Eastern Virginia. The party was composed of both sexes and various ages, from early childhood to decrepid man and womanhood. They were taken in the cars to the foot of Washington-avenue, and they were there furnished with breakfast by [???] Volunteer Refreshment Committee. The arrival of this large number of contrabands soon drew a crowd to the refreshment saloon, among whom was a number of  colored persons. They conversed freely with the contrabands, and ascertaining their wishes and intentions, arrangements were soon made to provide temporary homes for them. One of the females, from her extreme age, attracted a good deal of notice. She was represented to be over 100 years old, and to have been the mother of 21 children. The health of nearly all of them appeared to be good. What these poor creatures are to do in a place like Philadelphia, already overcrowded with unemployed while labor, and where much suffering exists for want of employment, it is impossible to conjecture. A large number additional is expected to-day.

abstract: Editorial on various public orators on war and resulting riots
snippet: Editorial on various public orators on war and resulting riots
lead_paragraph: The bad habit of exaggeration into which telegraph has fallen, inclines the majority of readers to await, before opinions are made up upon current events, the less swift but more truthful story brought by the mails. The swifter witness reported, a day or two ago, a fearful riot, stopping very little short of homicide, as having occurred at Burlington, New Jersey. One SAMUEL AARON, endeavored, we were told, to lecture on the true interpretation of the Constitution, but was promptly interrupted by a portion of his audience, who, to vocal interpolations, presently added the less agreeable and decorous running gloss of addled eggs. From a repeated volley of these, the lecturer took flight. The mob at once pursued him, thirsting for his life; a thirst only not gratified because the friends of the victim adopted the most active measures for his protection. This was a very good story until another spoiled it. Mr. AARON, according to more trustworthy testimony, talked just as long as a lecturer, with any regard to decency and his audience, should talk. Now and again he was interrupted by expressions of dissent; and once, in the course of the prelection, an egg, otherwise than fresh, was misdirected toward him, and a similar missile, still more indifferently aimed, followed his peroration. Two or three lads, armed with such inodorous explosives, may easily throw the most peaceably disposed assemblage into confusion and retreat. But, in the present instance, the life of the speaker was not threatened; and beyond the noisy discussion of the rabble about the doors, there was no marked alarm or confusion. The audience had its teaching and went about its business.

abstract: Iu the Senate, Saturday, a favorable report was made on the bill to amend the law relative to taking the testimony of witnesses out of the State; also on the bill to authorize clerks of Boards of Excise to take affidavits in certain cases. A bill to encourage investments of small sums in the stocks of the State was introduced. It provides
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, Saturday, a favorable report was made on the bill to amend the law relative to taking the testimony of witnesses out of the State; also on the bill to authorize clerks of Boards of Excise to take affidavits in certain cases. A bill to encourage investments of small sums in the stocks of the State was introduced. It provides that certificates may be in sums of $100, $500 or $1,000 each, as may be desired. The bill to enable the County of Westchester to acquire certain lands for the construction of the Harlem Bridge was passed. A concurrent resolution for the organization of a Commission of five persons to act as referees for the Court of Appeals was introduced, and laid over. The resolution approving the President's Message relative to emancipation, was made the special order for Wednesday evening.

abstract: The Nashville having run the blockade of Beaufort, the question arises. Where will she go, and what will she do? She can go to no British port, the late order in Admiralty, which took effect more than a month ago, excluding the armed cruisers of both belligerents (that is, of both the United States and the "so-called Confederate Government") from entering any British harber.
lead_paragraph: The Nashville having run the blockade of Beaufort, the question arises, where will she go, and what will she do? She can go to no British port, the late order in Admiralty, which took effect more than a month ago, excluding the armed cruisers of both belligerents (that is, of both the United States and the "so-called Confederate Government") from entering any British harbor. We think we are able to divine the course she will take. She will abnegate her character as a public armed vessel of the Confederacy, and sail as a merchantman. Indeed, it is understood that the Nashville took out from Beaufort a heavy cargo of cotton; and, sailing in this character, she will of course be hospitably received at Liverpool, Southampton, or wherever she chooses to go. It must be confessed, the device is not wanting in shrewdness. In the first place, her arrival in an English port, after the notoriety she achieved at Southampton, will call attention to her, as giving a double and most flagrant proof of the laxity of the blockade; and Mr. WELLES may have the satisfaction to know that by letting her first go into Beaufort, and then come out, he has done the rebel cause in England more service than GREGORY and all his lists. In the next place, having disposed of her cargo of cotton, she will doubtless reassume her warlike character, and come home lighting up her pathway with a conflagration of other Harvey Birches. We do not think it will stand much against the conscience of her commander, PEGRAM, that this course will make him in form, as he was before in fact a pirate. If the Navy Department needed a lesson of how imbecility leads to countless confusions and disasters, we command it to follow the career of the Nashville.

abstract: ARRESTS FOR PASSING COUNTERFEIT HALF DOLLARS. New York and Brooklyn have recently been flooded with counterfeit half dollars, and all efforts of the Police to ferret out the parties engaged in issuing this bogus coin seemed unavailing, until Friday night last, two men notified the Deputy-Inspector of Police that they had received four counterfeit half dollars at a drinking-saloon kept by EDWARD MOCAETY, corner of Bridge Road and Navy-Street.
lead_paragraph: ARRESTS FOR PASSING COUNTERFEIT HALF DOLLARS. -- New York and Brooklyn have recently been flooded with counterfeit half dollars, and all efforts of the Police to ferret out the parties engaged in issuing this bogus coin seemed unavailing, until Friday night last, two men notified the Deputy-Inspector of Police that they had received four counterfeit half dollars at a drinking-saloon kept by EDWARD MCCARTY, corner of Bridge Road and Navy-Street. Detectives FROST and DENTON were detailed to work up the case, and taking with them Sergeant MONK, of the Second Cavalry, went to the place indicated. While the officers remained outside, MONK, went in, called for a drink, and received with his change a counterfeit half dollar, which evidently had never been passed before. Immediately thereafter McCARTY and an assistant in the place, named GARDINER, were arrested, and placed in custody of the United States Marshal.

abstract: The Times' City Article of Monday, March 17, says: French Rentes declined an eighth on Saturday evening. This adverse movement will excite surprise, if the figures of the monthly return of the Bank of France, showing an augmentation in the bullion of  2,440,000, are correct.

abstract: On Saturday New-York paid her share of tribute to the memory of the heroic officers of the Second Rhode Island Regiment who fell, fighting for the Union, at the battle of Bull Run. Throughout the greater part of the day, the rooms in the Astor House where the coffins containing the remains lay in state were visited by an immense number of people -- indeed, so great was the throng, that the large police force on duty could with difficulty keep the vestibules of the hotel leading to the rooms in a passable condition.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday New-York paid her share of tribute to the memory of the heroic officers of the Second Rhode Island Regiment who fell, fighting for the Union, at the battle of Bull Run. abstract: Unionism throughout the South are getting more and more numerous. A day or two since the Norfolk Day Book announced that seventy citizens of London County, Virginia.  had been thus seized, and a late letter to the Richmond Dispatch from High Point, North...
lead_paragraph: Unionism throughout the South are getting more and more numerous. A day or two since the Norfolk Day Book announced that seventy citizens of London County, Virginia, had been thus seized, and a late letter to the Richmond Dispatch from High Point, North Carolina, states that "a nest of traitors (loyalists,) has been discovered and broken up in Davidson, North Carolina, and that fifty of the number have been sent to Raleigh as prisoners." The Richmond usurpers will find it difficult to get jail accommodation if they go on at the present rate. How long will it be before the Southern people rise and reverse the process, casting the usurping chiefs into the prisons they are now filling with their victims?

abstract: The far-famed Parson BROWNLOW, as you are aware, has safely arrived in this city.
